headline: Knausgaard and Franzen Among Speakers at 92nd Street Y
abstract: Authors including Kate Atkinson, Lauren Groff and Jonathan Lethem will also give talks and read from their new works this fall.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 80 years, the 92nd Street Y has hosted literary titans for talks and readings. This upcoming season is no different: events will feature Karl Ove Knausgaard, Natasha Trethewey, Gary Shteyngart, Jonathan Franzen and Kate Atkinson.

headline: A Flurry of Activity as All of Baseball Chases the Red Sox
abstract: Boston is dominating, and even with Chris Sale headed to the disabled list, the gap is wide enough that the Red Sox mostly watched as other teams scrambled.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Dave Dombrowski had no trades to announce on Tuesday at Fenway Park, which made him the exception among top decision makers in baseball. Dombrowski, the president of baseball operations for the Red Sox, could hardly keep track of his peers’ deals on a frenetic non-waiver trading deadline.

headline: N.R.A. Joins Questioning of Florida Sheriff in ‘Stand Your Ground’ Case
abstract: The sheriff continues to defend his decision not to make an arrest in the fatal shooting of an unarmed black man.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — After a Florida sheriff  decided not to arrest a white man who the authorities say killed an unarmed black man in a confrontation over a handicapped parking spot, outrage came from expected places: the victim’s family, civil rights organizations and Democratic politicians eager to repeal Florida’s controversial self-defense law, known as Stand Your Ground.

headline: Justice Dept. Investigating Claims That Drug Companies Funded Terrorism in Iraq
abstract: In a filing, AstraZeneca said the case was related to a suit that accused five companies of giving the Iraqi health ministry drugs and devices that were then sold to fund attacks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department is investigating claims that major drug and medical device companies doing business in Iraq knew that the free medicines and supplies they gave the government to win business there would be used to underwrite terrorist attacks on American troops.

headline: Honors, at Last, for Ida B. Wells, ‘a Sword Among Lions’
abstract: Chicago commemorates a crusading hero who never got the recognition she deserved.
lead_paragraph: The Chicago City Council made a timely and historic decision last week when it renamed a prominent downtown street for the pioneering newspaper editor, anti-lynching campaigner and suffragist Ida B. Wells. Renaming Congress Parkway as Ida B. Wells Drive comes as Wells’s descendants are preparing to commemorate their forebear with a monument — also to be built in her adopted city, Chicago — and as the country gears up for the centennial of the 19th Amendment in 2020.

headline: Tuskegee Airman’s Remains Are Identified, Ending Daughter’s Quest for Answers
abstract: Lawrence E. Dickson was 24 when his fighter plane went down in December 1944. On Friday, officials confirmed that remains found last year were his.
lead_paragraph: Marla Lawrence Dickson Andrews never really got to know her father while he was alive.

headline: Yankees Quiet at Deadline but May Lose J.A. Happ Temporarily
abstract: The left-hander joined the Mets’ Noah Syndergaard in receiving a diagnosis of hand, foot and mouth disease, but Brian Cashman said no disabled list trip is imminent.
lead_paragraph: On a day when contending major league baseball teams traditionally add significant pieces to their rosters, the Yankees not only did not add anyone, but they may well have lost a player they were relying on to play an important role for them down the stretch.

headline: Chicago Chain Kept Hawaiian Restaurants From Using ‘Aloha Poke’ Name
abstract: The chain, Aloha Poke Co., which sent cease-and-desist letters to restaurants with similar names, has apologized after being accused of cultural appropriation.
lead_paragraph: Aloha Poke Co., a Chicago-based restaurant chain, has been fighting to protect its trademarked, Hawaiian name for more than a year. It was not until this week, however, that the backlash to its efforts drew a public apology from the company.

headline: Massachusetts Town Loses Its Entire Police Force as All 4 Members Quit
abstract: In a resignation letter, Blandford’s interim police chief and three part-time officers said their jobs had grown unsafe and untenable.
lead_paragraph: BLANDFORD, Mass. — The police cruiser sat at the edge of the parking lot in front of the town offices, angled toward the road as if an officer inside were waiting to catch speeders.

headline: Corrections: August 1, 2018
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Wednesday, August 1, 2018.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Review: In a Blissful Musical ‘Twelfth Night’ in Central Park, Song Is Empathy
abstract: This radiant Public Works production of Shakespeare’s comedy of identity asks us “to see through the eyes of another.”
lead_paragraph: Still looking for that ideal summer getaway? Have I got a paradise for you.

headline: Unable to See
abstract: Sande Milton and Jeff Chen make a puzzle together.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — A famous comedian once told a story of going away to a remote cabin with a small group of fellow comedians, one of whom was known for being incredibly self-referential. They took turns comparing their latest work, with that one comedian mainly telling stories about himself.

headline: At Florida Rally, Trump Boasts About the Economy and Takes Aim at Usual Targets
abstract: The president called himself “the most popular person in the history of the Republican Party” — a debunked claim — and took shots at his usual list of piñatas, boogeymen and political targets.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — President Trump brought a message of a booming economy with him to Central Florida on Tuesday evening. He boasted about his administration’s economic accomplishments at an event at a local high school, where a supporter cheerily praised him as “the best president.” And he signed a piece of work force legislation, holding up a scrawled piece of paper for all to see.

headline: Mets Endure Most Lopsided Defeat in Franchise History
abstract: An embarrassing loss to a division rival took a turn for the absurd in the eighth inning when Jose Reyes, a 16-year veteran infielder, came in to pitch.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On pace to lose more than 90 games, the Mets have endured a fair amount of misery, injuries and mistakes this season. Then came Tuesday night and a new nadir.

headline: Facebook, Greece, Extreme Heat: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Mueller Passes 3 Cases Focused on Illicit Foreign Lobbying to Prosecutors in New York
abstract: The special counsel has referred investigations into lobbying by Washington insiders to the federal prosecutors in New York handling the case against Michael Cohen, President Trump’s former lawyer.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel, has referred three investigations into possible illicit foreign lobbying by Washington insiders to federal prosecutors in New York who are already handling the case against President Trump’s former lawyer, according to multiple people familiar with the cases.

headline: Losing Earth: The Decade We Almost Stopped Climate Change
abstract: We knew everything we needed to know, and nothing stood in our way. Nothing, that is, except ourselves. A tragedy in two acts.
lead_paragraph: We knew everything we needed to know, and nothing stood in our way. Nothing, that is, except ourselves. A tragedy in two acts.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday: ‘The Sinner’ and ‘The Originals’
abstract: “The Sinner” returns, with Carrie Coon joining the cast. And “The Originals” comes to a close.
lead_paragraph: “The Sinner” returns, with Carrie Coon joining the cast. And “The Originals” comes to a close.

headline: News of Laos Dam Failure Didn’t Reach Them, but the Water Did
abstract: The flooding from a failed dam in Laos soon moved into neighboring Cambodia, upending life for impoverished farmers there with little hope of help.
lead_paragraph: SIEM PANG, Cambodia — Kang Ngan isn’t sure what a dam is. She doesn’t know how old she is, although she thinks “over 30” is a good guess. But she has lived long enough to know that something is terribly wrong along the Sekong River.

headline: A Push for 3-D Weapons by One of the World’s ‘Most Dangerous People’
abstract: Cody Wilson is engaged in a legal fight to distribute blueprints for printing 3-D weapons. He calls his efforts “a pretty mainline American idea.”
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — For Cody Wilson, this week had long been in the making. For more than five years, the professed gun-rights and free-speech advocate had sought to publish online his blueprints for a downloadable gun, but had repeatedly been blocked by the federal government.

headline: China’s Plan to Win Friends and Influence Includes Ski Slopes and Spas
abstract: The Belt and Road Initiative is widely seen as a push to develop geopolitical ties through infrastructure and ports. Companies are using it for more frivolous projects, too.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — In Thailand, a theater rigged with hydraulic seats will give moviegoers the sensation of flight. In Australia, an indoor ski slope is going up near the beaches of the Gold Coast. In the Czech Republic, a spa with Chinese medicine is under construction in the southern wine country.

headline: Celebrating Girlhood and Feminine Identity
abstract: Melissa Ann Pinney’s project exploring female identity spans three decades and presents women and girls as subjects in their own right, not as accessories in the lives of men.
lead_paragraph: Soccer moms couldn’t always drive their daughters to practice. It took Title IX, the 1972 federal law prohibiting gender-based discrimination in schools, to ensure that girls could play the same sports as boys. Yet even with that, after three waves of feminism — and arguably a fourth, with #MeToo — women are still battling to control their bodies and destinies.

headline: How Robert Indiana’s Caretaker Came to Control His Artistic Legacy
abstract: The late artist’s caretaker, whose loyalty has been questioned by some, will run a foundation that will shepherd Mr. Indiana’s art and create a new museum.
lead_paragraph: VINALHAVEN, Me. — Jamie L. Thomas has spent most of his 54 years on this remote island off the Maine coast, where he cobbled together a livelihood from an assortment of jobs.

headline: Colbert Jabs Trump for Saying, ‘Collusion Is Not a Crime’
abstract: Poking fun at President Trump for how often he repeats “No collusion,” Stephen Colbert said, “He uses it for every occasion — it’s like his ‘aloha.’”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: Take a Vacation From Exercise? Your Body May Not Thank You
abstract: Two new studies look at what happens when we do not exercise or move around much for a period of time.
lead_paragraph: At the height of summer, naps at the beach can be alluring, and many of us may find ourselves tempted to take prolonged vacations from exercise.

headline: Four Wineries Bringing New Energy and New Design to Napa Valley
abstract: These new wineries are shaking up the tourist scene in Napa Valley, with interesting spaces, intimate experiences, and an emphasis on dining and culture.
lead_paragraph: The winery visiting experience in California’s Napa Valley — an ever popular tourist draw — is getting a shake-up. A spate of new wineries in innovative spaces promise to offer guests a visit unlike the traditional group tour and tasting that's typical in the region.

headline: After Years of Quiet, Democratic Candidates Can’t Stop Talking About Health Care
abstract: A potent campaign theme emerges across the nation, with a particular emphasis on pre-existing conditions.
lead_paragraph: In June,  Senator Claire McCaskill of Missouri asked voters at a big political dinner to stand up if they had a pre-existing health condition.

headline: White House Weighs Another Reduction in Refugees Admitted to U.S.
abstract: Under one proposal, no more than 25,000 refugees could be resettled in the United States next year, a cut of more than 40 percent from this year’s limit.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House is considering a second sharp reduction in the number of refugees who can be resettled in the United States, picking up where President Trump left off in 2017 in scaling back a program intended to offer protection to the world’s most vulnerable people, according to two former government officials and another person familiar with the talks.

headline: Stumbles? What Stumbles? Big Tech Is as Strong as Ever
abstract: Facebook’s earnings report sent tech stocks cratering. But don’t let that fool you: Apple, Google, Facebook, Amazon and Microsoft are still on their way to dominating the future.
lead_paragraph: You may have heard that the tech giants are on their heels.

headline: Fed Holds Interest Rates Steady but, Defying Trump, Signals Increases to Come
abstract: Federal Reserve officials upgraded their already high marks for their economy, issuing a statement that keeps them on track to raise rates next month and in December.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve raised its already high marks for the state of the economy on Wednesday, refusing to bow to President Trump’s recent push for the central bank to pause its march toward higher interest rates.

headline: Why a Picture Book Now for Young Kids? Let’s Just Say He Could Feel It in His Bones
abstract: Jeff Smith, the creator of Bone, the graphic novel series, is going after younger readers.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Smith is the creator of Bone, the series often credited with kicking off the boom in graphic novels for children when it was published beginning in 2005. Now Smith has a picture book set in the world of Bone, “Smiley’s Dream Book,” aimed at kids ages 2 to 6 — who may be the series’ future readers. I talked to Smith about where the Bone characters came from, how Bone ended up as a series for children, and what the transition from comics to picture books was like for him. These are edited excerpts from our conversation.

headline: Anne Tyler’s Latest Heroine Quits Cushy Arizona for Quirky Baltimore
abstract: In her new novel, “Clock Dance,” a staid retiree plunges into the off-kilter lives of a single mother and her daughter.
lead_paragraph: CLOCK DANCE By Anne Tyler 292 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $26.95.

headline: Andrew Wheeler, New E.P.A. Chief, Details His Energy Lobbying Past
abstract: Mr. Wheeler, the agency’s acting administrator, has put forth the fullest explanation yet of his energy lobbying activities.
lead_paragraph: Want the latest climate news in your inbox? You can sign up here to receive Climate Fwd:, our email newsletter.

headline: 5 Shows to See in New York: ‘Pretty Woman,’ ‘Be More Chill’ and More
abstract: August turns out to be a month for musicals, with science fiction, a Hollywood rom-com and dueling garage bands on the agenda.
lead_paragraph: August in New York is traditionally a month without shrinks or new shows. Least of all musicals, which usually want to open when local crowds are available to get them off to a good start.

headline: Hotels Grapple With Racial Bias
abstract: Recent incidents around the country have raised questions about diversity training in the hotel industry.
lead_paragraph: Incidents of racial bias have hit major consumer brands, including Uber, Starbucks and Airbnb. Now they are cropping up at hotels, unsettling guests, spreading via social media with the hashtag #TravelingWhileBlack, and leading some in the travel industry to revisit diversity training and evaluate its effectiveness.

headline: Victories in the Bronx and Delusion in Queens
abstract: At the trade deadline, the Yankees figured out how to get better. The Mets focused more on convincing themselves that everything is fine.
lead_paragraph: Midafternoon Tuesday, as the clock ticked toward the 4 p.m. trade deadline, three Mets baseball executives breathed deeply, peered into each other’s eyes and rolled the dice.

headline: Green Party, Eyeing the 2020 Presidential Race, Prepares for the Midterms
abstract: The Democratic Party loomed large over the annual Green Party conference last month, but all eyes were on November, when Green leaders say they’ll field at least 224 candidates.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — The progressive activists who gathered in Utah two weeks ago to strategize for the midterm elections could each recall a moment when they realized the Democratic Party was their foe and decided to quit it.

headline: Living In ... Irvington, N.Y.
abstract: A small town with a progressive attitude, Irvington offers residents a sense of community and history — as well as proximity to the Hudson River.
lead_paragraph: A small town with a progressive attitude, Irvington offers residents a sense of community and history — as well as proximity to the Hudson River.

headline: Irvington, N.Y.: A Walkable Village With Striking Manhattan Views
abstract: A small town with a progressive attitude, Irvington offers residents a sense of community and history — as well as proximity to the Hudson River.
lead_paragraph: After spending 31 years raising their three sons in a four-bedroom, 19th-century Victorian near Main Street in Irvington, N.Y., Patricia and John Ryan decided to downsize. But when they sold their house in 2008, they knew they didn’t want to go far.

headline: Taiwan, ‘Still Fighting’ for Democracy, Gets Nod to Host Human Rights Event
abstract: For Taiwan, isolated by Chinese pressure, hosting the Oslo Freedom Forum is a kind of international validation — from dissidents, if not from governments.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Taiwan has had a rough time of it lately.

headline: Facebook, 3-D Guns, Apple: Your Wednesday Briefing

headline: Waiting for Caesar
abstract: Will the Trump White House start testing the limits of its power?
lead_paragraph: In the eight years of the Obama presidency, there were three cycles of policymaking. First came the attempt to pass an ambitious liberal agenda through a Democratic-controlled Congress, which ended with the Republican House takeover in 2010. Then came the attempt to strike bargains, grand and otherwise, with John Boehner and congressional Republicans, which petered out early in Barack Obama’s second term. And finally came the imperial phase, in which activists appealed to the president to claim powers that he had previously abjured, and override or sidestep congressional gridlock on immigration, climate policy and health care through the power of the presidential pen.

headline: Liberals, Don’t Lose Faith in the First Amendment
abstract: It gives people the tools to act, argues the national legal director of the A.C.L.U.
lead_paragraph: Have conservatives hijacked the First Amendment?

headline: The Fight Over 3-D-Printed Guns
abstract: Critics say that publishing blueprints for 3-D-printed weapons is a threat to public safety. Supporters say it’s a First Amendment right.

abstract: Wednesday: The wettest months of the year, and the greenest block in Brooklyn.

headline: Russia Attacks America’s Election System. Trump Shrugs.
abstract: The midterms are approaching, and the president has yet to get serious about protecting the nation’s electoral system from cyberinvasion.
lead_paragraph: With fewer than 100 days to go until the midterms, the evidence continues to pile up that America’s electoral system remains a hot target for hackers, most notably agents of the Russian government.

headline: Fighting for Judaism in the Jewish State
abstract: I am an Orthodox rabbi dedicating my life to breaking the ultra-Orthodox monopoly over Jewish life in Israel.
lead_paragraph: RA’ANANA, Israel —  I have not been detained by the Israeli police on my way to morning prayers, but I am preparing for that eventuality. That’s the new reality of life in the Jewish state for those of us who publicly oppose Jewish fundamentalism.

headline: Tommy Robinson, Anti-Muslim Activist, Is Freed on Bail in U.K.
abstract: The Court of Appeal ordered another hearing on a contempt of court charge against the far-right activist, who video recorded figures in a criminal trial, against a judge’s orders.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Tommy Robinson, the jailed British far-right activist backed by the former Trump aide Stephen K. Bannon but reviled by others who call him a violent purveyor of hate, was ordered to be freed on bail Wednesday, after challenging his conviction for contempt of court.

headline: DealBook Briefing: Facebook Is Acting Fast on Election Meddling This Year
abstract: In sharp contrast with its approach to interference in the 2016 presidential race, the social network is making security moves publicly ahead of the midterms.
lead_paragraph: Good Tuesday morning. Want this in your inbox every morning? Sign up here.

headline: Australian Senator Sarah Hanson-Young Sues Fellow Lawmaker After Sexist Remark
abstract: Sarah Hanson-Young says that during a debate on the floor of Australia’s Senate, a colleague told her to “stop shagging men.”
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — An Australian senator filed a defamation suit on Wednesday against a fellow lawmaker who she says made a sexist remark to her on the Senate floor during a debate about violence against women.

headline: ‘Short Term’ Health Insurance? Up to 3 Years Under New Trump Policy
abstract: Consumers may soon have access to less expensive health insurance providing fewer benefits under a Trump administration rule intended to skirt requirements of the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration issued a final rule on Wednesday that clears the way for the sale of many more health insurance policies that do not comply with the Affordable Care Act and do not have to cover prescription drugs, maternity care or people with pre-existing medical conditions.

headline: Australian Chain Reintroduces Free Plastic Bags, Bucking Global Trend
abstract: The decision by Coles, a large Australian supermarket chain, drew outrage on social media among people who warned of the environmental consequences.
lead_paragraph: Coles, a major Australian supermarket chain, on Wednesday reversed its decision to ban single-use plastic bags after its customers complained, a move that bucked a global trend to reduce plastic bag waste and prompted a social media backlash against the company.

headline: Data Breaches Keep Happening. So Why Don’t You Do Something?
abstract: News about leaks of personal information can lead consumers to believe that’s the new normal, but experts caution against such “breach fatigue.”
lead_paragraph: Last year was a banner year for the exposure of personal information, and so far this year there has been a steady drumbeat of data breaches, so many that experts worry that people are just throwing up their hands in defeat.

headline: Climate Change’s Raging Wildfires
abstract: Fast-moving blazes, broiling heat, droughts and bizarrely deadly twists — the new normal.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.

headline: A Rock Band Flirts With German Taboos, and Finds a Huge Following
abstract: Frei.Wild has become one of the most popular bands in Germany. But critics say the group fosters anti-immigrant sentiment and right-wing nationalism.
lead_paragraph: NATZ, Italy — By the time Frei.Wild took the stage at Alpen Flair, a three-day music festival in northern Italy, the sun had disappeared behind the forested peaks of the surrounding Alps. Most of the 20,000 audience members had traveled over 100 miles from Germany to see the band. The crowd was overwhelmingly white and largely male, and many fans shouted along as the band launched into one of its most controversial songs, “Südtirol.”

headline: Find Recently Lost Files on Your Mac
abstract: Can’t locate that file you were working in a few days ago and can’t remember what you called it? Here are some places to look.
lead_paragraph: Q. Windows 10 has that Timeline thing, but on a Mac, how can I find a file I know I worked on recently? Especially if I don’t remember what I called it or where I stored it?

headline: What You Get for $1.9 Million
abstract: A Spanish-style house in Los Angeles, a modernist home in Anchorage and a renovated 19th-century house in New Orleans.
lead_paragraph: A Spanish-style house in Los Angeles, a modernist home in Anchorage and a renovated 19th-century house in New Orleans.

headline: $1.9 Million Homes in California, Alaska and Louisiana
abstract: A Spanish-style house in Los Angeles, a modernist home in Anchorage and a renovated 19th-century house in New Orleans.
lead_paragraph: This one-story stucco house is one of 147 Spanish Revival homes — each one unique — constructed in West Los Angeles by Spiros G. Ponty, a prolific local builder. It sits in the historically protected South Carthay neighborhood, halfway between downtown Los Angeles and Santa Monica (about eight driving miles in each direction).

abstract: Wednesday: Fallout from the gynecologist scandal, a proposal for a citizenship question on the 2020 census, and a vest vending machine at SFO.

headline: A Pregnant Dolphin. A Fatal Gunshot. A Disturbing Trend.
abstract: The case is the latest example of violence against dolphins in the northern Gulf of Mexico, which experts say is becoming increasingly common.
lead_paragraph: This whodunit begins on a beach in Mississippi, where a bottlenose dolphin turned up dead one day this spring.

headline: A Palazzo on the Mediterranean
abstract: This five-bedroom house on Gozo, the westernmost island of Malta, is on the market for around $2.9 million.
lead_paragraph: This five-bedroom house on Gozo, the westernmost island of Malta, is on the market for around $2.9 million.

headline: House Hunting in … Malta
abstract: With multinational, financial services and internet gaming companies setting up offices in Malta, foreigners are moving in — and housing prices are going up.
lead_paragraph: This 18th-century limestone house is on Gozo, the rural, westernmost island of the three-island Republic of Malta, which is about 100 miles south of Sicily in the Mediterranean Sea. Despite an extensive renovation, this commanding structure retains a sense of history, on an island that was once home to the Knights of Saint John religious military order, said Svetlana Podgorska, an agent with Malta Sotheby’s International Realty, which has the listing.

headline: Taliban Surge Routs ISIS in Northern Afghanistan
abstract: More than 200 Islamic State militants and two top commanders surrendered to the Afghan government, after a decisive loss in a two-day battle with rival insurgents.
lead_paragraph: MAZAR-I-SHARIF, Afghanistan — More than 200 Islamic State fighters and their two top commanders surrendered to the Afghan government on Wednesday to avoid capture by Taliban insurgents, after a two-day battle that was a decisive victory for the Taliban, participants on all sides confirmed.

headline: Kate McKinnon and Mila Kunis: Just a Couple of ‘Bachelor’ Fans on the Run
abstract: The chance to work together intrigued the stars enough to sign on to “The Spy Who Dumped Me,” the rare female-led buddy action comedy. Bonus: They bonded over reality TV.
lead_paragraph: How did you spend your summer vacation? Were you fortunate enough to go sightseeing in Europe? Or were you on the run from a nefarious network of undercover evildoers who felt you were constantly getting in the way of their attempts to subvert the global order?

headline: On This Land: Dance Presenters Honor Manhattan’s First Inhabitants
abstract: Some performance spaces in New York are reminding viewers that the work they see is being performed on Indigenous land.
lead_paragraph: On an evening in early June, before the sun had gone down, a bonfire blazed outside Abrons Arts Center on the Lower East Side. Handmade quilts lined the steps of the outdoor amphitheater. Anyone walking down Grand Street could come in and take a seat.

headline: Now You Can Just Pay Celebrities to Say Stuff
abstract: Cameo is the “Being John Malkovich” of apps.
lead_paragraph: Remember Nikki Blonsky? She was the unknown Long Island teen plucked from a Cold Stone Creamery and cast as the star of the 2007 movie musical “Hairspray.” Now, a decade after that big splash, her acting career has slowed to a drip. Recently she lent her voice to “Pup Star,” a direct-to-digital entry in the “Air Bud” extended universe. Soon she’ll appear in a horror movie opposite Gary Busey’s son. But lately Ms. Blonsky has found a new performance platform: Cameo, a service that allows fans to pay low- to midrange celebrities to send them short, personalized video messages.

headline: Fields Medals Awarded to 4 Mathematicians
abstract: The prize, bestowed every four years to mathematicians 40 years or younger, is often described as the subject’s Nobel Prize.
lead_paragraph: Every four years, at an international gathering of mathematicians, the subject’s youngest and brightest are honored with the Fields Medal, often described as the Nobel Prize of mathematics.

headline: My Article Was Censored. I Found Out Why.
abstract: A reporter covering an art show didn’t expect to see her Times article blanked out in Qatar’s print edition.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.

headline: Trump Tells Sessions to ‘Stop This Rigged Witch Hunt Right Now’
abstract: The order to the attorney general on Twitter immediately raised questions from some lawyers about whether it was an attempt to obstruct justice in the special counsel’s Russia inquiry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump called on Attorney General Jeff Sessions on Wednesday to end the special counsel’s inquiry into Russia’s interference in the 2016 election, issuing an unambiguous directive on Twitter to shut down an investigation that even now is scrutinizing his tweets for evidence of obstruction.

headline: What to Cook Right Now
abstract: Make some Italian sausage sandwiches, or cook up a cowboy ragù inspired by a fire-loving oysterman on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. A gull cawed me awake the other morning, and I found myself grateful that it was nature and not the ping of a phone that had brought me to the surface. I thought of Jim Harrison, his poem “Age Sixty-nine”: “At dawn I have birds, clearly divine messengers that I don’t understand yet day by day feel the grace of their intentions.” The good mood lasted all day. I cooked outside at its end, Italian sausages, and I cooked a lot of them because that is what Melissa Clark taught me to do, so that on a Wednesday night afterward I could make her leftover Italian sausage sandwiches (above) for dinner, and easily, too.

headline: What to Know Before You Buy Short-Term Health Insurance
abstract: The plans cover less and follow fewer rules than most insurance that you can buy now. They are also less costly and will be marketed extensively.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration has just completed rules that will allow people to shop for a new kind of health insurance. So-called short-term plans will be offered for relatively long periods — just under a year at a time, with renewals for up to 36 months — and they will be marketed extensively in most states.

headline: The Particular Joy of Being a Grandparent
abstract: I have raised five children. But I have never felt this pure, unfettered happiness.
lead_paragraph: I never thought I could hold a baby for an hour — my head a few inches from hers, hanging on every sigh, waiting intently for the next scrunch of her lips or arch of her barely visible eyebrows — perfectly happy, an idiot entranced by a magic trick. But there I was on my granddaughter Avery’s first day of life, so happy I didn’t recognize myself.

headline: Crossing Cultures, and Genres, at the Glimmerglass Festival
abstract: Our critic takes stock of three shows at the festival: Bernstein’s “West Side Story,” Kevin Puts’s “Silent Night” and Janacek’s “The Cunning Little Vixen.”
lead_paragraph: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. — It’s a year of big birthdays at the Glimmerglass Festival, the annual series of operas performed here at the photogenic Otsego Lake.

headline: It’s No Summer Camp for Migrants
abstract: Recalling her childhood days at a Girl Scout camp, a reader is shocked that an immigration official would describe a detention center that way.

headline: Funeral Ads Tried to Get U.K. Talking. They May Have Worked Too Well.
abstract: A company says it wanted to start a national conversation about death. But regulators initially rejected its ads, saying they were likely to cause offense.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In one advertisement, a sun-kissed couple laugh and chase each other on a sandy beach. But the beachgoers are holding not surfboards, but wooden coffins.

headline: That’s Not Algae Swirling on the Beach. Those Are Green Worms.
abstract: Researchers demonstrated that plant-worms rotate in circular congregations along Atlantic beaches. But nobody is certain why.
lead_paragraph: Between April and September, just minutes after waves splash over beaches along the eastern Atlantic coast of England, Wales, France or the Channel Islands, tiny, green worms emerge from their sandy hide-outs. They gather in small pools, often near small boulders.

headline: Moving From Buyer to Seller, Major League Soccer Tests a New Revenue Stream
abstract: Bayern Munich forked over at least $13.5 million for Vancouver’s Alphonso Davies. M.L.S. hopes this is the start of a windfall.
lead_paragraph: You can learn a lot about a soccer league from its transfer spending.

headline: Campaigns Enter Texting Era With a Plea: Will U Vote 4 Me?
abstract: Welcome to the age of the political mass-text. Candidates in this year’s midterm elections are adding a new, hard-to-ignore tool to their arsenal.
lead_paragraph: Marla Hohner was at home in Dallas when a text message arrived from an unfamiliar number.

headline: At Least the Mets Didn’t Lose, 30-3. The Orioles Once Did.
abstract: Teams have lost by 20 runs many times in the major leagues.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday night’s 25-4 Mets debacle had fans scrambling for the record books. It was the biggest loss in franchise history, but hardly the biggest in baseball history.

headline: Worshiping the False Idols of Wellness
abstract: Charcoal, “toxins” and other forms of nonsense are the backbone of the wellness-industrial complex.
lead_paragraph: Before we go further, I’d like to clear something up: Wellness is not the same as medicine.

headline: Behind the Cover: Losing Earth
abstract: For this special issue, a look at the decade we almost stopped climate change.

headline: Alaska Airlines Apologizes to Gay Couple Asked to Move for Straight Couple
abstract: David Cooley, who owns a gay bar in West Hollywood, said his partner was given a choice: Move for the straight couple or get off the plane.
lead_paragraph: Alaska Airlines apologized this week after a flight attendant asked a gay man to give up his seat next to his partner so a straight couple could sit together, an exchange that put the airline on the defensive as it rebutted claims of discrimination.

headline: Belgium Has a New Fee for Journalists. The Media Is Not Amused.
abstract: Reporters living in the country who cover gatherings of the E.U.’s national leaders now have to pay more than $100 a year for background checks.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Journalists who cover the regular gatherings of the leaders of European Union countries got a rude surprise this week from the Belgian government: Most of them will have to pay for the right to do their jobs.

headline: Chinese Goods May Face 25% Tariffs, Not 10%, as Trump’s Anger Grows
abstract: The administration said it would consider raising proposed tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese products to 25 percent from 10 percent as China’s currency declines.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump escalated his trade war with China on Wednesday, ordering his administration to consider more than doubling proposed tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese goods to 25 percent from 10 percent, as talks between Washington and Beijing remain at a standstill.

headline: Who Wore It Better: Art or Commerce?
abstract: It’s a museum show. It’s a fashion show. It’s a critique. No, a boutique. Whatever you call the Whitney installation by the label Eckhaus Latta, you’re likely to leave with more questions (and clothes) than answers.
lead_paragraph: Labels. Can’t live with them, can’t live without them.

headline: Apple’s Stock Buybacks Continue to Break Records
abstract: The iPhone maker has repurchased almost $220 billion of its own stock since March 2012 — more than any other company.
lead_paragraph: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

headline: Review: ‘Random Acts of Flyness’ Is a Striking Dream Vision of Race
abstract: An uncategorizable new late-night series by the artist Terence Nance describes a reality that can only be captured through the surreal.
lead_paragraph: HBO’s “Random Acts of Flyness” is like almost nothing you’ve seen on TV before. But it begins with a kind of image you’ve seen much too often.

headline: Want Toilet Paper and Plastic Chairs? Check Out U.S. Embassy in London
abstract: Among the surplus items of little historical value are 1,200 rolls of toilet paper, Dyson vacuum cleaners and plastic chairs.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Are you in the market for 1,200 rolls of toilet paper? A broken Dyson vacuum cleaner? A Sony camera in unknown working condition — which doesn’t come with a charger?

headline: In Crown Jewels Heist in Sweden, 2 Thieves Escape by Speedboat
abstract: Two crowns and an orb made for the funerals of Charles IX and his wife in the 17th century were plundered from a cathedral near Stockholm at around midday.
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM, Sweden — Three national treasures of Sweden — two crowns and an orb made for the funerals of King Charles IX and his wife, Christina the Elder, in the 17th century — have been stolen in an audacious midday theft from a cathedral near Stockholm.

headline: The Woman Who Plans to Swim Around the World
abstract: This month, a New York woman will try to become the fastest person to complete six marathon swims on six continents. Then she has to get back to her day job.
lead_paragraph: The weather wasn’t cooperating with Jaimie Monahan on a recent weekend morning. It had rained heavily the night before, making the wind and waves too strong at sunrise for her to swim her planned 12-mile route, from the Brooklyn Bridge to Coney Island.

headline: Racism at American Pools Isn’t New: A Look at a Long History
abstract: Swimming pools, which exploded in popularity a century ago, are supposed to be places to relax, but black Americans have long faced harassment and violence there.
lead_paragraph: The poolside confrontations keep coming.

headline: English Freemasons Open the Door to Transgender Members
abstract: The all-male group in England and Wales says that male members who have transitioned to female can remain, and transgender men can join.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After centuries as an all-male institution, the Freemasons of England are adding a couple of provisos that long-ago members like the Duke of Wellington and Winston Churchill probably never considered.

headline: Finding Alarm and Consolation About the Apocalypse in Two New Books
abstract: Things are worse than ever, Roy Scranton insists in “We’re Doomed. Now What?” They always have been, Eugene Thacker says in “Infinite Resignation.”
lead_paragraph: In recent years, Steven Pinker, Gregg Easterbrook and other authors have tried to tell us that the state of the world is, as one of Easterbrook’s titles has it, “better than it looks.”

headline: The House of Artisanal Pain
abstract: At Behind the Circle in Bushwick, traditional Japanese-style hand-tattooing.
lead_paragraph: On a sweltering summer afternoon, Steven Millington, a 29-year-old mathematics student from Long Island, lay shirtless atop a raised wooden platform in the far corner of a dimly lit Brooklyn shop.

headline: Trade Secrets From the Wagner Festival Whisperer
abstract: An interview with Christian Thielemann, the music director of the Bayreuth Festival, whose political views get as much attention as his musicality.
lead_paragraph: BAYREUTH, Germany — The Bayreuth Festival Theater famously leaves audiences sweltering. When I arrived here last week, my Airbnb host warned, “If it’s hot outside, it will be even hotter inside.”

headline: Gaza and Google Translate: Covering the Conflict When You Don’t Speak the Language
abstract: David M. Halbfinger, The Times’s Jerusalem bureau chief, found Google Translate useful in Israeli and Palestinian territory, but Waze sometimes reaches a dead end.
lead_paragraph: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? David M. Halbfinger, bureau chief for The Times in Jerusalem, discussed the tech he’s using.

headline: Trump Tariffs Are Lifting Profits, Steel Giant ArcelorMittal Says
abstract: The company’s chairman and chief executive is a rare business leader who applauds President Trump’s protectionist approach to trade.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Lakshmi N. Mittal, the chairman and chief executive of ArcelorMittal, the world’s biggest steel maker, is the rare business leader who applauds President Trump’s protectionist approach to trade.

headline: Howard Felsher, Game Show Whiz Who Overcame Scandal, Dies at 90
abstract: After admitting to Congress that he had rigged a quiz show, he found redemption as a game show doctor, lifting ratings of daytime fare like “Family Feud.”
lead_paragraph: Howard Felsher, the television game show doctor who was fired because he went too far in fixing “Tic-Tac-Dough” in the 1950s by feeding contestants clues, but scored a comeback two decades later by helping to sustain “Family Feud” as a No. 1 hit, died on July 23 at his home in Tarzana, Calif. He was 90.

headline: Subway Ridership Dropped Again in New York as Passengers Flee to Uber
abstract: Joseph J. Lhota, the M.T.A. chairman, said the decline was caused by poor service, the rise of Uber and other ride-hailing services, and fare evasion.
lead_paragraph: In another alarming sign of the crisis plaguing New York City’s subway, ridership dropped for the second year in a row as passengers flee the system for Uber and other ride-hailing services, draining the transit system of badly needed revenue.

headline: YG and Buddy, Los Angeles Hip-Hop Two Ways
abstract: On the Compton MC’s third album and the up-and-comer’s debut, they showcase why their region is perhaps the most vibrant rap hub of this decade.
lead_paragraph: Though it gets far less credit than Atlanta, Los Angeles has become perhaps the most vibrant, diverse and consistently impressive hip-hop hub this decade. Atlanta — and its sonic offspring — may own the genre’s center, primary aesthetic approach and charts, but Los Angeles has nonetheless thrived by working two parallel tracks.

headline: College Students Want Children, but Don’t Know When Fertility Declines
abstract: Fewer than half of university students surveyed knew that female fertility declines after 35, and only one in five knew male fertility declines at 45.
lead_paragraph: Fewer than half of university students were able to correctly identify the age at which a woman’s fertility declines, according to a new study, and fewer than one in five knew when a man’s fertility declines.

headline: Google, Seeking a Return to China, Is Said to Be Building a Censored Search Engine
abstract: Google withdrew from China in 2010 to protest the country’s censorship. Now the internet giant is working on a search engine that complies with Chinese censorship rules.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Google withdrew from China eight years ago to protest the country’s censorship and online hacking. Now, the internet giant is working on a censored search engine for China that will filter websites and search terms that are blacklisted by the Chinese government, according to two people with knowledge of the plans.

headline: A Poem in The Nation Spurs a Backlash and an Apology
abstract: After a white poet’s use of African-American vernacular was criticized for being offensive, the magazine’s poetry editors apologized.
lead_paragraph: Since its founding in 1865, The Nation has published some of the most important voices in American poetry, including Hart Crane, Elizabeth Bishop, Amiri Baraka and Adrienne Rich.

headline: From 2018: Explaining QAnon, the Internet Conspiracy Theory That Showed Up at a Trump Rally
abstract: Do you remember Pizzagate? It’s a little like that: a web of baseless conspiracy theories. And its supporters were highly visible at an event for the president in Florida.
lead_paragraph: Those watching President Trump’s rally in Tampa on Tuesday couldn’t help but be exposed to a fringe movement that discusses several loosely connected and vaguely defined — and baseless — conspiracy theories.

headline: Don’t Get Shot in America. Live in Australia!
abstract: Not getting shot adds to the magic of visiting Australia.
lead_paragraph: Not getting shot adds to the magic of visiting Australia.

headline: Don’t Get Shot in America. Live in Australia!
abstract: Not being the target of snipers adds to the magic of visiting Down Under.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, a federal judge blocked attempts by a gun activist to post schematics for a gun that can be produced by a 3-D printer. If you feel America just dodged a giant bullet, you’re only partly right. There are still more than 393 million civilian-owned firearms in the United States, which means there are more guns than people.  If that makes you feel unsafe, visit Australia.

headline: Obama Endorses Dozens of Democrats, Rewarding Diversity and Loyalty
abstract: The former president, who has largely avoided campaign politics, endorsed 81 Democrats in the midterms, including officials who served in his administration.
lead_paragraph: Former President Barack Obama took a public step back into the electoral arena on Wednesday, issuing a slate of 81 endorsements for Democrats running in the 2018 elections and giving his stamp of approval to more than a dozen veterans of his administration and election campaigns who are seeking office in their own right.

headline: Autoplay Videos Are Not Going Away. Here’s How to Fight Them.
abstract: Videos that start without your consent are prominent across the web. Our tech columnist explains how the industry got here and what we can do.
lead_paragraph: The web is in a dark place, as I plan to examine in the next several columns. If you need proof, look no further than autoplay videos, the first example.

headline: Zimbabwe Protests Turn Violent as Some Call Election a Sham
abstract: Police officers fired live bullets to disperse protesters, who fought back with stones. At least three people were reported dead.
lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe — Protests in Zimbabwe’s capital turned violent on Wednesday as demonstrators called the country’s elections a sham and armed soldiers swept the streets. At least three people were reported dead.

headline: Prosecution Cites Lavish Spending by Paul Manafort in His Fraud Trial
abstract: The judge in the trial restricted prosecutors from displaying photos of Mr. Manafort’s expensive suits and from describing his pool house at his home in the Hamptons.
lead_paragraph: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — To the manager of Alan Couture, a high-end men’s wear boutique in Manhattan, Paul Manafort was one of his top five customers, spending more than $900,000, paid by wire transfer, over five years ending in 2014.

headline: Review: In ‘The Saintliness of Margery Kempe,’ a Comically Restless Mystic
abstract: A play based on a confessional, self-obsessed woman’s memoir — from the 15th century — is back, at the Duke.
lead_paragraph: To write a memoir, first you have to take yourself seriously — to consider your life worth scrutinizing, your thoughts worth passing along. That’s maybe not such a high bar to clear in this confessional, self-obsessed age, but for a woman in the 15th century? Rather unusual, especially if the writer in question didn’t know how to read.

headline: Anika Noni Rose Was Waiting for This Moment
abstract: It has taken a while, but playing the sultry title role in “Carmen Jones” fulfills a lifelong dream.
lead_paragraph: Way back in 2001, the York Theater Company staged a concert production of “Carmen Jones.” Anika Noni Rose, then 28, was cast as the angelic ingénue Cindy Lou, who sees the sensuous title character seduce her fiancé, Joe. At the time Ms. Rose had only one Broadway credit under her belt, hadn’t developed her voice enough to realize she was a soprano, and looked, she said, “like a 10-year-old.”

headline: Documents Shed Light on the Life and Death of Thurman Munson
abstract: The recently uncovered depositions stem from lawsuits filed after Munson, the Yankees’ catcher and captain, died at age 32 in a plane crash on Aug. 2, 1979.
lead_paragraph: The anguish still rises unmistakably from the pages of the deposition, which is now nearly 40 years old. In it, a witness named David Hall hesitates as he testifies, and a lawyer asks if he needs a short break. Hall declines and continues.

headline: Need a Politics Cleanse? Go Ahead and Treat Yourself.
abstract: Overwhelmed by current events? You can skip a few weeks without losing track of the plot.
lead_paragraph: Have you felt less popular lately than you once were? Are people avoiding you? Are your party invitations getting lost in the mail? Maybe it’s your breath.

headline: Who Desegregated America’s Schools? Black Women
abstract: “A Girl Stands at the Door,” by the Rutgers historian Rachel Devlin, shows how the work of desegregation was done disproportionately by a young population that felt called to action.
lead_paragraph: A GIRL STANDS AT THE DOOR The Generation of Young Women Who Desegregated America’s Schools By Rachel Devlin 342 pp. Basic Books. $32.

headline: Some Bach, and All of Robert Garland
abstract: Watch Crystal Serrano and Da’Von Doane in a portion of Mr. Garland’s “New Bach,” created for Dance Theater of Harlem in 2001.
lead_paragraph: #SpeakingInDance is a weekly visual exploration of dance on Instagram. Watch the video from our most recent post below, and follow us at @nytimes.

headline: Stop Uber From Flooding New York
abstract: A City Council bill to temporarily cap the number of for-hire vehicles is a good first step.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday evening, the New York City Council introduced a bill to place a temporary cap on the number of for-hire vehicles — the kind provided by services like Uber and Lyft — allowed on the city’s streets.

headline: Mars Close Up
abstract: Look skyward and dream.
lead_paragraph: Mars, the Red Planet named after the Roman god of war, is currently closer to the Earth than it’s been in 15 years, and the millions of people gazing at the bright red dot will once again be wondering, is there life out there?

headline: What’s Different About California’s Fires This Year?
abstract: In this week’s newsletter, we look at the links between sustained heat and destructive wildfires.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: Deadly Ebola Strikes Anew, a Week After Previous Outbreak Was Extinguished
abstract: At least 20 people have died as the Ebola virus struck the Democratic Republic of Congo again.
lead_paragraph: The Ebola virus has struck again in the Democratic Republic of Congo and has killed at least 20 people, the country’s Health Ministry reported Wednesday, just a week after officials announced the end of an Ebola outbreak 1,550 miles away.

headline: What You Need for a Mental Vacation
abstract: Five strategies for how to mellow out in August.
lead_paragraph: It can be really hard to concentrate in August when temperatures peak and September looms. The best way to make the most of the month — and beat the late-summer blues — is to clear some head space and find little ways to Zen out in your daily life. Here, some strategies to do just that.

headline: Facing Losses, Condé Nast Plans to Put 3 Magazines Up for Sale
abstract: Anna Wintour is staying, but the once-flush company behind Vogue and The New Yorker lost roughly $120 million last year.
lead_paragraph: Condé Nast, the company behind Vogue, Vanity Fair and The New Yorker, became one of the most successful magazine publishers by charming readers and advertisers alike with a formula built on old-world glamour and all-American pizazz. But now, even after having taken measures to cut spending and make itself more digitally savvy, the company is expected to adopt a more radical strategy to ensure that it does not fade away.

headline: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Turkish Officials Over Detained American Pastor
abstract: It was an unusual penalty against a government of a vital NATO ally, and is sure to inflame already simmering tensions between Turkey and the United States.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration  imposed sanctions on Wednesday against two top Turkish government officials over the detention of an American pastor being held on espionage charges, threatening to plunge already-fraught relations with a vital NATO ally into crisis.

headline: Netflix Won’t Offer Louis Farrakhan Documentary
abstract: The movie about the leader of the Nation of Islam who has a history of anti-Semitic views seemed to be set for streaming; Netflix cited a miscommunication.
lead_paragraph: Netflix will not release a documentary celebrating the musical career of Louis Farrakhan, the leader of the Nation of Islam who is notorious for his history of anti-Semitic comments.

headline: Stripes and Tangles of Neon, Under the Hamptons Sun
abstract: Neighboring shows offer new reflections on Keith Sonnier, whose assemblages include light, glass, found objects and the ambient sound of U2.
lead_paragraph: WATER MILL, N.Y. — Light is a thing of ungraspable nature, sometimes a particle, sometimes a wave. And for artists of the 1960s, light became a third thing: a material. Dan Flavin began making sculptures with commercial fluorescent bulbs in 1963, and spent three decades lighting galleries, warehouses, even a church. In ’60s West Germany, artists of the Zero group produced spotlit installations of spinning discs or suspended mirrors; in France, François Morellet and his colleagues at the Groupe de Recherche d’Art Visuel staged participatory events with neons or strobe lights; and in California, James Turrell, Robert Irwin and other artists loosely grouped into a Light and Space movement crafted immersive environments illuminated with soft, even pinks and blues.

headline: How to Read a Food Label
abstract: All the information stacked on food packaging can be confusing, but we’ll show you what you should focus on to really know what’s in your food.
lead_paragraph: All the information stacked on food packaging can be confusing, but we’ll show you what you should focus on to really know what’s in your food.

headline: Who Will Win in 2020: Trump or Warren?
abstract: Readers respond to columns by Bret Stephens and David Leonhardt imagining the outcome of the next presidential election.
lead_paragraph: Recently, two Opinion columnists imagined the outcome of the next presidential election and the circumstances which would lead us there. First, Bret Stephens presented a scenario in which President Trump and Vice President Mike Pence easily best their opponents, Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts and her running mate, Senator Sherrod Brown of Ohio, because the Democrats swing even further left and turn off their base. In response, David Leonhardt painted a picture that one reader described as “liberal erotica”: an unpopular incumbent who, without the help of a flawed rival and meddling Russians, loses “bigly” to Ms. Warren and former Attorney General Eric Holder and their campaign against a greedy, corrupt administration.

headline: Trade War, Jeff Sessions, Cody Wilson: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Facebook’s Security Chief to Depart for Stanford University
abstract: Alex Stamos, Facebook’s chief security officer, is joining Stanford to teach and to examine the role of security and technology in society.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Facebook revealed on Tuesday that it had identified a political influence campaign ahead of the November midterm elections, the company’s chief security officer, Alex Stamos, was front-and-center in speaking on the issue.

headline: Let’s Get Child Care Right
abstract: A reader compares the United States unfavorably with France.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Medical Liability Limits
abstract: The American College of Emergency Physicians writes that liability protections need to be in place for doctors who provide emergency services.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Right Time for the E.R.A.
abstract: An advocate says the #MeToo movement shows its necessity today.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The ‘Metsiest’ Mets Loss Ever
abstract: In a lost season, 25-4 is one for the Mets’ record book, unless this group figures out how to lose by 22.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — By sheer math, baseball is bound to produce unusual moments every so often. There are 30 major league teams and each of them plays 162 games, not including the playoffs.

headline: Trump, Fear and Power
abstract: A reader writes that the use of fear is a sign of cowardice, now power.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Modern Love: G.P.S. for My Lost Identity
abstract: This week on the podcast, Diane Guerrero tells a story of debit card fraud and self-knowledge.
lead_paragraph: This week on the podcast, Diane Guerrero tells a story of debit card fraud and self-knowledge.

headline: Diane Guerrero Reads ‘GPS for My Lost Identity’
abstract: On this week’s podcast, the “Orange Is the New Black” actress tells a story of debit card fraud and self-knowledge.
lead_paragraph: On this week’s podcast, Diane Guerrero reads “GPS for My Lost Identity,” a story of debit card fraud and self-knowledge.

headline: Trump’s Tweet Urging the End of the ‘Witch Hunt’
abstract: Readers react to the president’s call for Attorney General Jeff Sessions to stop the Mueller investigation. One calls it obstruction of justice.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Who Is Cody Wilson, the Man Behind 3-D Printed Guns?
abstract: Cody Wilson has pushed for the blueprints for 3-D printed guns to be widely available since he was a student at the University of Texas. Defense Distributed, the company he founded, is now at the center of a legal battle over this technology.
lead_paragraph: Cody Wilson has pushed for the blueprints for 3-D printed guns to be widely available since he was a student at the University of Texas. Defense Distributed, the company he founded, is now at the center of a legal battle over this technology.

headline: Weary California Firefighters Mourn a Fallen Colleague, ‘Our Brother’
abstract: In between exhausting shifts battling the raging Carr Fire, Redding firefighters took time to mourn.
lead_paragraph: REDDING, Calif. — They marched through a once-landscaped road reduced to ash. The temperatures had reached such intensity that there was no dirt left on the ground, just fused bedrock strewn with petrified trees. The heavy air was red and tinged with dirt, casting the scorched residential neighborhood in a sepia tone.

headline: 7 Musicians Reflect on Nico’s Enduring Influence
abstract: In honor of a new film about the musical icon, a handful of female recording artists reconsider her life — and her incomparable voice.
lead_paragraph: Best known as the Teutonic beauty who sang alongside Lou Reed on The Velvet Underground’s 1967 debut album, Nico — born Christa Päffgen — was a Zelig of contemporary culture. She worked as a fashion model in Berlin and Paris, played a bit part in Federico Fellini’s “La Dolce Vita,” embedded with Andy Warhol’s Factory and had an affair with the French film star Alain Delon (with whom she had a son). Music was her life’s connective tissue; she spent decades after her Velvet Underground moment as a solo performer, writing and performing in her bewitching contralto.

headline: Denmark’s Ban on Muslim Face Veil Is Met With Protest
abstract: A ban on face veils in public came into effect on Wednesday, setting off protests and criticism from human rights groups.
lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN — Denmark’s ban on face veils in public took effect on Wednesday, setting off protests and reigniting a debate over a law that rights groups say discriminates against Muslim women.

headline: Pennsylvania Diocese Orders Removal of Former Bishops’ Names From Church Buildings
abstract: The move by a Harrisburg bishop comes ahead of a grand jury report expected to expose decades of mishandled cases of child sexual abuse in the Catholic Church.
lead_paragraph: Anticipating the release of a Pennsylvania grand jury report exposing decades of mishandled sexual abuse cases in the Roman Catholic Church, the bishop of Harrisburg on Wednesday ordered that the names of former bishops dating to the 1940s be stripped from church buildings.

headline: ‘God, Come to Our Aid’: Survivors Describe Mexico Plane Crash
abstract: All 103 people aboard an Aeromexico flight survived a crash just after takeoff. Several were Mexican-Americans from the Chicago area.
lead_paragraph: DURANGO, Mexico — The Rev. Esequiel Sanchez felt apprehensive even before his flight took off from the city of Durango around 3:30 p.m. on Tuesday, en route to Mexico City. It began raining as the jetliner taxied down the runway. The downpour got stronger and stronger.

headline: Review: ‘The Spy Who Dumped Me’ Is a Buddy Comedy With a Body Count
abstract: Mila Kunis and Kate McKinnon are best friends who help each other through emotional and geopolitical chaos in this silly, bloody movie.
lead_paragraph: In its opening minutes, “The Spy Who Dumped Me” hops from a shootout in Vilnius, Lithuania, to a birthday celebration in Los Angeles. Audrey (Mila Kunis) is turning 30 in the wake of an abrupt breakup — via text — with one of the gunmen, a skinny dude named Drew (Justin Theroux) whose profession was a secret to Audrey. The title of this pleasantly silly, sometimes jarringly violent comedy, directed by Susanna Fogel (who wrote the script with David Iserson), isn’t terribly ambiguous, and I have now explained it fully.

headline: Tesla Reports Another Big Loss, but Sees Only Profit Ahead
abstract: Elon Musk, the chief executive, said the electric-car maker was about to turn a corner with output of its mass-market Model 3, buoying company shares.
lead_paragraph: Tesla recorded another huge loss last quarter and burned through hundreds of millions of dollars in cash as it ramped up production of its first mass-market model.

headline: Third-Party Line Will Feature Governor Cuomo, and a Slew of Republicans
abstract: Mr. Cuomo is likely to be sitting on the same ballot line — that of the Independence Party — with the very Republicans he has called traitors.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is the de facto leader of the New York State Democratic Party. His formal nomination for a third term came with splashy endorsements from party leaders like Hillary Clinton and Joe Biden. For months, he has rallied and railed against Republicans in Congress, calling them traitors and derelict in their duties.

headline: The Best TV Shows and Movies New to Netflix, Amazon and More in August
abstract: Every month, subscription streaming services add a ton of new movies and TV shows. Here are the ones we think are most interesting this month.
lead_paragraph: Every month, subscription streaming services add a new batch of movies and TV shows to their libraries. Here are the titles we think are most interesting for August, broken down by service and release date. Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice.

headline: Overlooked No More: Clara Lemlich Shavelson, Crusading Leader of Labor Rights
abstract: Shavelson ignited a huge strike by women garment workers that helped galvanize the labor movement. She went on to fight for suffrage and tenants’ rights.
lead_paragraph: Since 1851, obituaries in The New York Times have been dominated by white men. With Overlooked, we’re adding the stories of remarkable people whose deaths went unreported in The Times.

headline: ‘Castle Rock’ Season 1, Episode 4: Put on a Happy Face
abstract: Forget the supernatural. Most of the bad things happening here are done by bad people.
lead_paragraph: In my recap of Episodes 1-3, from last week, I mentioned that one of the best things “Castle Rock” has going for it is that its horrors are as existential as they are supernatural — which is exactly how it should be for a series based on the work of Stephen King. This week’s disturbing episode, “The Box,” carries that feeling even further, confirming that even if there weren’t ancient evils festering in this tiny Maine town, it would still be a pretty lousy place to live.

headline: Discussion Questions for ‘What it Means When a Man Falls From the Sky’
abstract: Lesley Nneka Arimah’s debut short story collection is our August pick for the PBS NewsHour-New York Times book club, “Now Read This.”
lead_paragraph: Our August pick for the PBS NewsHour-New York Times book club, “Now Read This,” is Lesley Nneka Arimah’s debut short story collection “What it Means When a Man Falls From the Sky.” Become a member of the book club by joining our Facebook group, or by signing up to our newsletter. Learn more about the book club here.

headline: On Broadway, Near La Salle
abstract: Doing their parts to retrieve a delivery man’s lost keys.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: With Lawsuits, New Jersey Signals Tougher Stance on the Environment
abstract: State officials announced lawsuits targeting a half-dozen sites around the state where communities are still feeling the effects of pollution.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — New Jersey officials announced on Wednesday that they were pursuing several lawsuits targeting former industrial sites around the state where communities are still grappling with the persisting effects of pollution that has seeped into soil, groundwater and nearby waterways.

headline: Parisian Woman Confronted Her Harasser, and Then He Hit Her, She Says
abstract: The woman, a 22-year-old engineering student, has created a website and Facebook page for other women to share stories of sexual harassment.
lead_paragraph: At first few people seemed to notice the encounter. The young Parisian woman in red and the man in the black shirt exchanged words as they passed each other in the street. They went their separate ways.

abstract: State Representative Nick Sauer, a Republican, said he would leave office hours after a report that he used an Instagram account with the photos to “catfish” men online.
lead_paragraph: An Illinois state representative resigned on Wednesday hours after a report about allegations that he posted nude photographs of his ex-girlfriend on Instagram without her consent in an effort to draw other men into “graphic” conversations.

headline: U.S. Prepares to Reduce Troops and Shed Missions in Africa
abstract: The plan by the head of Africa Command, which follows an ambush in Niger that killed four Americans, is a response to the Trump administration’s strategy to focus on threats from China and Russia.
lead_paragraph: STUTTGART, Germany — Hundreds of American troops in Africa would be reassigned and the number of Special Operations missions on the continent would be wound down under plans submitted by a top military commander, a response to the Trump administration’s strategy to increasingly focus on threats from China and Russia.

headline: Urban Meyer Placed on Paid Leave at Ohio State Following New Allegations
abstract: A report by an independent journalist included text message exchanges suggesting Meyer knew of Zach Smith’s abusive relationship with his wife. Meyer said last month he did not.
lead_paragraph: Ohio State announced Wednesday evening that Urban Meyer, the head coach of its storied football team, had been put on paid administrative leave while the university investigated allegations that Meyer knew a longtime former assistant coach had been accused of domestic abuse in 2015.

headline: Vladimir Voinovich, Dissident Russian Writer, Dies at 85
abstract: His satires were not well received by the Soviet authorities, and in 1980 he thought it best to live in the West until things thawed out.
lead_paragraph: Vladimir Voinovich, a Russian writer whose satirical novels vexed the Soviet authorities in the Leonid Brezhnev era, resulting in his banishment from the country for a decade, died on Friday in Moscow. He was 85.

headline: N.Y.U. Prevails in Case That Said It Let Retirement Plans Reap Excess Fees
abstract: A federal judge ruled against a group of New York University employees who claimed that faulty oversight had collectively cost workers millions of dollars.
lead_paragraph: New York University has prevailed in a lawsuit that accused it of failing to properly oversee employee retirement plans and causing thousands of workers to pay millions of dollars in excess fees.

headline: New York’s Economic Spending Shortchanges Nonwhite Communities, Report Says
abstract: A new report found that the $5 billion awarded through one of Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s signature development programs has gone to mostly white communities.
lead_paragraph: As New York has poured billions of dollars into economic development and trumpeted the rebirth of once-blighted regions of the state, the money awarded through one of the governor’s signature programs has flowed disproportionately to predominantly white communities, according to a new report.

headline: Faced With Crippling Sanctions, ZTE Loaded Up on Lobbyists
abstract: A Chinese company waged a furious — and ultimately successful — lobbying campaign to win a reprieve from penalties in Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Chinese telecommunications company ZTE was hit with crippling United States sanctions in April, it chose a very American solution: It loaded up on Washington lobbyists.

headline: Trump Finally Picks a Science Adviser. And Scientists? They Seem Relieved.
abstract: Kelvin Droegemeier, a well-regarded meteorologist, has a long research record. But his views on climate change are not well known.
lead_paragraph: President Trump will nominate Kelvin Droegemeier, a well-regarded meteorologist who studies severe storms, to be director of the federal Office of Science and Technology Policy.

headline: An Odd Day at Court: A Mayor on Jury Duty, a Councilman on Trial
abstract: A jury heard evidence that Councilman Jumaane Williams blocked an ambulance at a protest. Upstairs, Mayor Bill de Blasio chatted with fellow jurors.
lead_paragraph: No one is above the law — or jury duty for that matter.

headline: Afraid? Weak? Egotistical? Attack!
abstract: Trump doesn’t want a free press; he wants free propaganda.
lead_paragraph: It is simply not healthy for the country to have a president stuck perpetually in attack mode, fighting enemies real and imagined, pushing a toxic agenda that mixes the exaltation of grievance and the grinding of axes.

headline: Trump Says You Need an ID to Buy Groceries. Shoppers Say, ‘Huh?’
abstract: Two billionaire friends of President Trump say they cannot recall him ever doing his own grocery shopping, although he can handle a shopping cart.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just when it seemed like Tuesday’s “Make America Great Again” rally in Florida would end with the typical punch list — Democrats, journalists, immigrants — President Trump added new spice to his usual extemporaneous potpourri by asserting that supermarket shoppers need to show valid identification in the checkout aisle.

headline: Crowds, Stoked by Trump’s Rhetoric, Increase Their Ire Toward the Press
abstract: Menacing the media is a theme of President Trump’s rallies, but news organizations are anticipating an unnerving midterm election season, especially after a hostile crowd in Florida on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: The baby wearing a “CNN Sucks!” pin pretty much summed it up.

headline: Facebook Grapples With a Maturing Adversary in Election Meddling
abstract: The influence campaign revealed on Tuesday is adapting and evolving to better disguise itself, which limits the social network’s approach to stopping it.
lead_paragraph: They covered their tracks, using software to camouflage their internet traffic. They created Facebook pages for anti-Trump culture warriors, Hispanic activists and fans of alternative medicine. And they organized protests in coordination with real-world political groups.

headline: Can We Get a Little Joy Over Here?
abstract: This week’s Australia Letter aims to cheer you up, with a mix of the trivial and inspiring.
lead_paragraph: The Australia Letter is a weekly newsletter reflecting the experience (and quirks) of our Australia bureau chief. Sign up to get it by email. And here’s where to find all our Australia and New Zealand coverage.

headline: The Yankees Keep Chasing and the Red Sox Keep Winning. Now They Meet.
abstract: Anything the Yankees do, the Red Sox do a little better. As a result, the Yankees trail Boston by five and a half games as they begin a big series on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — When J.A. Happ made his debut for the Yankees on Sunday, the veteran left-handed pitcher provided his new team just what it had hoped for when it acquired him from the Toronto Blue Jays. Happ allowed one run (on a harmless solo homer) in six innings, the type of steady, workmanlike effort that has been a rarity from the Yankees’ starters in recent weeks.

headline: Charles Hamlen, Classical Music Manager With a Cause, Dies at 75
abstract: He co-founded one of the leading classical music management agencies, IMG Artists, and then left it behind to raise money to help people with AIDS.
lead_paragraph: Charles Hamlen, who co-founded one of classical music’s leading management agencies, helped build the careers of young stars, including the violinist Joshua Bell, and then left the business to raise money to help people with AIDS, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 75.

headline: Against Lowly Orioles, Sonny Gray Drags the Yankees Even Lower
abstract: Gray had his worst outing of the year at a poor time — just as the Yankees needed some momentum entering a series against the Boston Red Sox.
lead_paragraph: In a season of ups and mostly downs for Sonny Gray, this was undoubtedly the nadir: exiting the game to the sound of booing from the biggest Yankee Stadium crowd of the season, having just allowed seven earned runs in less than three innings to the worst team in baseball. And yet, as he walked off the mound, he was flashing a toothy grin.

headline: Whose Bones Has North Korea Returned? It May Take Years to Know.
abstract: Judging by past recoveries, the 55 caskets delivered on Wednesday to a government lab in Hawaii are likely to contain a jumble of bones and few reliable clues to their identity.
lead_paragraph: Two Air Force cargo planes left South Korea for Hickam Air Force Base in Hawaii on Wednesday carrying 55 flag-draped crates that are thought to contain the remains of American troops lost during the Korean War.

headline: Congress Strengthens Reviews of Chinese and Other Foreign Investments
abstract: The federal body known as Cfius will have expanded powers to decide whether proposed deals pose national security threats.
lead_paragraph: Chinese investment in the United States is about to get a bit harder.

headline: American Folk Art Museum Announces New Director
abstract: Jason T. Busch, who was most recently director of the Jason Jacques Gallery in Manhattan, will replace Anne-Imelda Radice.
lead_paragraph: The American Folk Art Museum announced Wednesday that Jason T. Busch will take over as its executive director in September, replacing Anne-Imelda Radice, who stepped down in March after nearly six years with the institution.

headline: Mueller’s Digging Exposes Culture of Foreign Lobbying and Its Big Paydays
abstract: Robert S. Mueller III’s investigations of foreign money flowing into Washington could be as much a part of his legacy as anything he unearths about Russian election interference.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The mandate given to Robert S. Mueller III and his team was broad: to investigate not just Russian election interference but also any related crimes they might unearth. So when this group of seasoned prosecutors began rooting around Washington, they pounced on a ripe target — lobbyists taking millions of dollars from foreign governments.

headline: ‘The Boys in the Band’ and a Generational Divide
abstract: Four gay men who recently attended the Broadway revival of this 50-year-old play — three seeing it for the first time — debate its significance and relevance.
lead_paragraph: Mart Crowley’s landmark play, “The Boys in the Band,” was first staged in 1968, in an Off Broadway production that ran for 1,001 performances, and in 1970 was turned into a movie directed by William Friedkin. But it has taken 50 years for it to make its Broadway debut — in a starry production directed by Joe Mantello and featuring, among others, Jim Parsons, Matt Bomer, Zachary Quinto and Andrew Rannells.

headline: Chinese Spiritual Leader Is Accused of Harassing Female Followers

headline: How Fake Influence Campaigns on Facebook Lured Real People
abstract: Activists became entangled with fake accounts and pages on Facebook, leading to significant consequences for them as the company tried to clamp down.

headline: 5 Simple Tips to Help Vegetarian or Vegan Travelers Eat Well, Anywhere
abstract: Traveling while vegetarian or vegan can be a challenge, but with a few tips and a little tech, you can roam freely, eat well and not have to worry about going hungry.
lead_paragraph: Traveling as a vegetarian or vegan has its obstacles. “In my experience on the road, there can be a lot of confusion about what being vegan or vegetarian means,” said Jamie Jones, a vegan and the chief operating officer of WhirlAway Travel, in West Chester, Pa. “And, the options for food aren’t always plentiful.”
