headline: In His Films, Brancusi Takes Flight
abstract: Sculptures by the Romanian master artist are on display at a ‘focused presentation’ at the Museum of Modern Art, along with his little-known and amazing films.
lead_paragraph: “Art is itself embodied in each curve! The sculptor chisels life down to its core.We know he’s found the germ, for we observeThat it is but an egg and nothing more.”

headline: The Radical Empathy of Dan Weiner
abstract: His photographs of mid-20th-century New Yorkers capture a moment in the city, but more than that, they preserve the people who lived those moments.
lead_paragraph: The New York that Dan Weiner photographed is gone. The Upper East Side, where he lived in the mid-20th century, went from gritty to glam. Hot spots like El Morocco vanished. Yet it would be a mistake to say his images are about nostalgia. If anything, they have a certain quiet urgency, drawn out through faces, lines and tones, that still offer lessons on how to see the world around us.

headline: Jacques Wirtz, Innovative Landscape Designer, Dies at 93
abstract: From Paris to Japan, he transformed gardens and grounds with the eye of a sculptor and the insight of a horticulturalist.
lead_paragraph: Jacques Wirtz, an acclaimed Belgian landscape architect whose innovative gardens blended sculptural treatment of boxwood and yew hedges with a deep knowledge of plants and flowers, died on July 21 at his home in Schoten, Belgium. He was 93.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Two true TV classics, one sweet, one swear-heavy. And a new Netflix movie starring Kristen Bell and Kelsey Grammer.
lead_paragraph: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every Friday for new suggestions on what to watch.

headline: Zimbabwe Elects Mnangagwa, the Man Who Ousted Mugabe
abstract: Emmerson Mnangagwa, who seized power last year, won a full term over his chief challenger, Nelson Chamisa.
lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe — Emmerson Mnangagwa, who seized power from President Robert Mugabe in a coup last year after serving as his enforcer for decades, was declared the winner early Friday of Zimbabwe’s disputed presidential election, continuing nearly four decades of rule by the nation’s dominant party.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘The Spy Who Dumped Me’
abstract: Susanna Fogel narrates a sequence from her film, featuring Mila Kunis and Kate McKinnon.
lead_paragraph: Susanna Fogel narrates a sequence from her film, featuring Mila Kunis and Kate McKinnon.

headline: Saudis Escalate Siege of Port in Yemen, Alarming Aid Groups
abstract: Airstrikes by the Saudi-led coalition on Al Hudaydah, occupied by Houthi rebels, killed at least 30 people, medical workers said.
lead_paragraph: AL HUDAYDAH, Yemen — Warplanes of the Saudi-led coalition fired more than two dozen missiles into this rebel-held Yemeni port city on Thursday, hitting the fish market, the entrance to the main hospital and a security compound in an attack that killed at least 30 people, medical workers said.

headline: How a Simple Moment in ‘The Spy Who Dumped Me’ Became an Elaborate Shoot
abstract: The director Susanna Fogel discusses the complexities of a comic car-theft sequence with Mila Kunis and Kate McKinnon.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies.  See new episodes in the series each Friday. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: The Next Wave
abstract: A poem about how the time of year affects one’s feeling about a 70-degree day.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: ‘Sweat’ to Start Free Election-Season Tour Across Midwest
abstract: Lynn Nottage’s Pulitzer Prize-winning play about working class anxieties will be performed in 18 counties in the lead-up to the election.
lead_paragraph: Lynn Nottage’s Pulitzer Prize-winning play “Sweat” will soon arrive in communities much like the one it depicts. The play, which explores the anxieties of the working class in Middle America, will embark on a free monthlong run through 18 cities this fall as part of the Public Theater’s Mobile Unit initiative.

headline: The Old Beer Hall in the Bronx
abstract: A wooden building in Eastchester, which was torn down in 1960, had a long history — possibly dating to the 17th century — as a watering hole.
lead_paragraph: Q. I remember an abandoned multi-story wood building at Boston Post Road (U.S. Rte. 1) and Dyre Avenue in the Bronx. I was told that it was a “beer garden.” What’s the story here?

headline: Russia, Pope Francis, Apple: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Judge Dismisses Two Lawsuits Against Fox News Over Retracted Seth Rich Story
abstract: Mr. Rich’s parents did not get the outcome they hoped for. But even in ruling against them, the judge noted that Fox had published a “sensational claim.”
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Manhattan dismissed a lawsuit Thursday that was brought against Fox News by the parents of Seth Rich, the young Democratic aide whose unsolved murder was turned into fodder for a lingering right-wing conspiracy theory.

headline: Michael Sheehan, Prescient Counterterrorism Expert, Dies at 63
abstract: Mr. Sheehan was said to have urged the Clinton White House in 1998 to focus on thwarting Osama bin Laden. His warning, an official said, went unheeded.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Michael A. Sheehan, a former top counterterrorism official for the State Department, the Pentagon and New York City, who sounded an early, and unheeded, warning about Osama bin Laden and the dangers of Al Qaeda before 9/11, died on Monday in Bethesda, Md. He was 63.

headline: Leslie Moonves Speaks on CBS Earnings Call but Not About Harassment Allegations
abstract: Mr. Moonves took questions from Wall Street analysts after second-quarter earnings were released, but did not address claims against him that are being investigated.
lead_paragraph: For Leslie Moonves, the chief executive of the CBS Corporation, it was back to business as usual.

headline: Trump and Italy’s Conte: Brothers in Nativism
abstract: President Trump and Giuseppe Conte, the new Italian prime minister, play to their publics by demonizing immigrants.
lead_paragraph: President Trump likes to claim that his meetings with foreign leaders are one huge victory after another in promoting his worldview. The reality is usually far different, but measured by this yardstick, his meeting with Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte of Italy was a smashing success. Standing alongside the president in the White House East Room, Mr. Conte sang praises to Mr. Trump for “positions and stances which are expressed with clarity,” and offered to be his “privileged interlocutor” in Europe.

headline: The Myth That a Cleaner Car Is Less Safe Than a Dirty One
abstract: The Trump administration is pushing a false narrative as a way to roll back mileage and emissions rules.
lead_paragraph: To justify rolling back auto gas mileage and emissions rules, the Trump administration has fabricated a false conflict between safety and improved fuel economy. The administration is wrong. Americans must have both, and can.

headline: Stop Calling Trump a Populist
abstract: From tax cuts to Kavanaugh, he’s been relentless about hurting working-class Americans.
lead_paragraph: Message to those in the news media who keep calling Donald Trump a “populist”: I do not think that word means what you think it means.

headline: Amazon Removes Products Featuring Nazi Symbols
abstract: The retailer said it would not let third-party merchants sell goods with Nazi and white nationalist symbols on its platform, amid pressure from nonprofits and lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Amazon said this week that it would not let third-party retailers sell products that feature Nazi and white nationalist symbolism on its platform, amid pressure from nonprofit groups and lawmakers.

headline: Top City Health Official, Who Faced Down Ebola and Zika, Will Resign
abstract: Dr. Mary Bassett, New York’s health commissioner, is leaving to take a position at Harvard University.
lead_paragraph: The New York City health commissioner, Mary T. Bassett, who coordinated the city’s response to a series of health crises involving Ebola, Legionnaires’ disease and the looming threat of the Zika virus, is leaving her job to take a top post at Harvard University, the city announced on Thursday.

headline: Young Rudy Giuliani Defends Himself
abstract: Newly discovered early glimmers of legal brilliance from “America’s lawyer.”
lead_paragraph: 1951. Seven-year-old Rudy Giuliani is caught by his mother with his hand in the cookie jar and crumbs around his mouth.

headline: Betty Miles, Whose Children’s Books Tackled Sexism, Dies at 90
abstract: As a woman of the 1950s, she said, she felt “presumptuous” about wanting a writing career, but overcame her qualms to carve out a successful one.
lead_paragraph: Betty Miles, a writer whose books for children and young adults addressed real-life issues like sexism, racism and censorship after she had thrown off the conventions of the 1950s to become a feminist, died on July 19 at her home in Shelburne, Vt. She was 90.

headline: The Latest Ebola Outbreak Is Centered in a War Zone
abstract: Unlike the earlier outbreaks, the epicenter this time is in a part of the Democratic Republic of Congo that is plagued by armed conflict.
lead_paragraph: A cluster of Ebola cases in the Democratic Republic of Congo — just one week after it declared an end to an outbreak on the other side of the country — is especially worrying because the new infections are in a war zone.

headline: CNN’s Jim Acosta Challenges Sarah Huckabee Sanders, Then Makes a Quick Exit
abstract: The White House briefing room became the latest venue for the fight over the president’s treatment of the news media.
lead_paragraph: Jim Acosta, the square-jawed CNN correspondent, has stood out among the White House press corps for his impassioned on-air monologues about the importance of the First Amendment.

headline: Trump Administration Moves Ahead With Tariffs on Canadian Newsprint
abstract: The tariffs are lower than what the Commerce Department initially imposed, but the decision is still a blow to the American newspaper industry, which is already struggling with declining revenue.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Commerce Department said on Thursday that it would proceed with tariffs on Canadian newsprint, a blow to an already-struggling American newspaper industry.

headline: Apple’s $1 Trillion Milestone Reflects Rise of Powerful Megacompanies
abstract: Apple is part of a group of giant companies that dominate the United States economy. That is good for financial markets, but not necessarily for everyone else.
lead_paragraph: U.S. Steel. General Motors. AT&T. Exxon Mobil.

headline: In Retrial of Norman Seabrook, All Eyes on an Imperfect Witness
abstract: The retrial of Norman Seabrook, the ex-president of the New York City correction officers’ union, began Thursday. His last trial ended in a mistrial.
lead_paragraph: For the second time in less than a year, Norman Seabrook, the former longtime president of New York City’s correction officers’ union, went on trial on federal corruption charges.

headline: Ian Poulter Leads Bridgestone Invitational. Let’s Talk About Tiger Woods.
abstract: Woods shot a four-under 66, four strokes off the lead. But he naturally commanded most of the attention at Firestone Country Club.
lead_paragraph: AKRON, Ohio — The Sky Sports reporter Nick Dougherty was about to address Kyle Stanley, who had carded a seven-under 63 for the early first-round lead Thursday at the Bridgestone Invitational. But then Dougherty’s attention drifted from Stanley to the television monitor in his peripheral vision, which showed Tiger Woods out on the Firestone Country Club course.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Beijing Buddhist Leader Accused of Harassment
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, August 3, 2018.
lead_paragraph: “There is a limit on how far and how high up public discussions can go before it gets on the leadership’s nerves.”

headline: No Credit, No Problem for Todd Howe, Who Is Freed on Bail
abstract: Mr. Howe, the disgraced government witness who helped federal prosecutors investigate major New York corruption cases, was released from jail.
lead_paragraph: The story of Todd R. Howe, the disgraced government witness who helped federal prosecutors investigate major New York State corruption cases, always seems to come down to credit cards and second chances — both of which seem to pose problems for Mr. Howe.

headline: Urban Meyer and the New Era of College Football: Winning Isn’t Everything
abstract: The remarkably successful Ohio State football coach is learning that tolerance for off-the-field problems is at an all-time low.
lead_paragraph: Until this week, Ohio State’s Urban Meyer was among the most valuable coaches in college football.

headline: How the U.S. Is Fighting Russian Election Interference
abstract: Russia is trying again to spread disinformation to exploit American division, using social media campaigns as well as more traditional tradecraft, officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senior Trump administration officials warned on Thursday that Russia is trying to interfere in November’s midterm elections and the 2020 presidential election and vowed to combat Moscow’s aggression.

headline: Tennessee Republicans Select Newcomer, Spurning Trump Loyalist in Governor’s Race
abstract: Diane Black lost despite showing fealty to the president. Marsha Blackburn and Phil Bredesen won the nominations for the open Senate seat.
lead_paragraph: Tennessee Republicans chose Bill Lee, a wealthy businessman who has never served in elected office, as their nominee for governor on Thursday, spurning a conservative candidate who eagerly sought — but only glancingly received — the support of President Trump’s White House.

headline: Prosecutors Document Paul Manafort’s Reversal of Fortune After 2014
abstract: In the third day of testimony in Paul Manafort’s tax and bank fraud trial, witnesses described how his finances deteriorated after losing his Ukrainian client.
lead_paragraph: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — A day after describing in detail how millions of dollars in payments from Ukrainian oligarchs enabled Paul Manafort to live in luxury through 2014, federal prosecutors outlined on Thursday how his financial fortunes reversed so sharply in subsequent years that he made his Manhattan condominium available on Airbnb.

headline: Yankees and Red Sox Face Off, Eager to Deploy New Weapons
abstract: This week’s series between the two teams is just an appetizer until the end of September, when they will play two more series with their new players fully integrated.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Alex Cora keeps track of the standings, always aware of just how close the Yankees are to his Red Sox. But Cora, the rookie Boston manager, knows that the landscape really only crystallizes in September, when teams at last get a clear sense of themselves.

headline: Corrections: August 3, 2018
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Friday, August 3, 2018.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Review: Mike Birbiglia Has a ‘New One.’ It’s Funny Until It Isn’t.
abstract: Mr. Birbiglia’s solo show about becoming a father is at first excruciatingly funny and then just kind of excruciating.
lead_paragraph: The comedian and storyteller Mike Birbiglia didn’t want to become a father. He had his reasons. Here’s the fifth one: He has a job. A baby, he says, would spit up all over that. “Kids hold us back.”

headline: Colorado Man Who Killed Naked Intruder Is Fatally Shot by the Police
abstract: The authorities say that Richard Black Jr. of Aurora may not have heard repeated orders to put down his gun.
lead_paragraph: A 73-year-old Aurora, Colo., man who fatally shot a naked intruder who broke into his home, only to be killed by one of the police officers who responded, may not have heard orders to put down his gun because of a hearing impairment, the police said Thursday.

headline: With One’s Glass Raised
abstract: Here’s to David Steinberg, who offers us a Scrabbly puzzle to start our solving weekend.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE —  This one made me smile, for two reasons: First, because the entries were entertaining, and second, because it’s an impressive fill for someone who was so young when he made it.

headline: Review: In ‘Christopher Robin,’ the Hundred Acre Wood Grows Up
abstract: Marc Forster’s film offers more or less what a Pooh reboot should: a lot of nostalgia, a bit of humor and tactile computer animation.
lead_paragraph: “Christopher Robin” answers a question that has weighed on the minds of all children and former children who bear some affection for Winnie the Pooh, Piglet and the rest of the Hundred Acre Wood. Namely, what if Christopher Robin grew up to become a giant stick in the mud?

headline: Top New Hampshire Democrat Arrested on Domestic Violence Charges
abstract: Colleagues on both sides of the aisle have called for Jeff Woodburn, the State Senate minority leader who is up for re-election, to resign.
lead_paragraph: A leading Democratic legislator in New Hampshire was arrested on Thursday on charges of domestic violence and assault.

headline: Myanmar Official Line: Rohingya Are Returning. But Cracks in That Story Abound.
abstract: On a government-led tour of repatriation centers and the surrounding countryside, the sanctioned narrative grew sticky with contradictions as witnesses spoke up.
lead_paragraph: MAUNGDAW, Myanmar — We waded through floodwaters, past soldiers hefting rifles, and climbed into a prefabricated hut.

headline: Red Sox Pummel Yankees, Leaving No Mistake Unpunished
abstract: The Red Sox jumped all over a woeful performance from the Yankees’ pitching staff, as well as some defensive miscues, for an emphatic victory to open the series.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — It is hard to pinpoint exactly where the Yankees lost it all against Boston on Thursday night — getting off the team bus, perhaps — but, sifting through the offensive avalanche led by Steve Pearce’s three home runs, the fourth inning would be a good place to start.

headline: U.S. Is Expanding Power to Block Chinese Firms. HNA Was Already No Match.
abstract: High-level meetings, powerful lobbying firms and a charm offensive were unable to get regulators to approve a deal with SkyBridge Capital, Anthony Scaramucci’s firm.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just over a year ago, two senior executives from the giant Chinese conglomerate HNA landed a meeting with Steven Mnuchin, the United States Treasury secretary, at his office. The executives, Adam Tan and Guang Yang, snapped a photo with Mr. Mnuchin, holding a model plane of the HNA-owned carrier, Hainan Airlines.

headline: Trump’s Inaccurate Claims About Highways, Immigration and Beyoncé From a Pennsylvania Rally
abstract: President Trump said his campaign rallies drew larger crowds than concerts for Beyoncé, Jay-Z and Bruce Springsteen. That was one of 15 inaccurate claims he made.
lead_paragraph: — President Trump, at a campaign rally on Thursday night in Wilkes-Barre, Pa.

headline: Trump Bashes ‘Fake News’: ‘They Can Make Anything Bad’
abstract: For much of a rally on Thursday night in Pennsylvania, President Trump focused on his multiple grievances with the Washington press corps.
lead_paragraph: WILKES-BARRE, Pa. — President Trump devoted the majority of his time at a rowdy rally here on Thursday targeting the news media, deriding the reporters present as “fake, fake disgusting news.”

headline: How I Lost the Fiancé but Won the Honeymoon
abstract: “Where is your husband?” people kept asking. “Why isn’t he here?”
lead_paragraph: My email junk folder is like a glimpse into a fantastical world where Ray-Bans are free and Michael Kors is always having a sale. Typically I don’t open any before clicking “delete all,” but that day one caught my eye: “Congratulations Nell Stevens! You have won a luxury honeymoon to India!”

headline: Red Sox’s Steve Pearce Proves He Fits With a Timely Outburst
abstract: Pearce, who was acquired by Boston about a month before the trade deadline, launched three homers and drove in six runs in the Red Sox’s win over the Yankees.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The phrasing is all so clinical, precise verbiage that all means the same thing: A ballplayer on the move. Steve Pearce experienced all of these designations in 2012 alone: released, signed as a free agent, purchased, selected off waivers. He bounced from the Minnesota Twins to the Yankees to the Baltimore Orioles to the Houston Astros, then back to the Yankees and the Orioles again. His Yankees career lasted just 12 games, and he hit .160.

headline: Pope Francis, Trade War, Apple: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Quantico’ and Lollapalooza
abstract: “Quantico” airs its series finale. And Post Malone and Tyler, the Creator perform live from Lollapalooza in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: “Quantico” shows its series finale. And Post Malone and Tyler, the Creator perform live from Lollapalooza.

headline: Australia’s Big Banks Have Stranglehold on Consumers, Government Says
abstract: The biggest banks used their position to exploit customers and block competition, a new government report says. In some cases, dead people were charged banking fees.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Australia’s four biggest banks have used their dominant position to exploit customers, deliver inferior products, charge exorbitant fees and block competition, according to a new government report calling for more competition and integrity in the industry.

headline: A Family’s 400-Year-Old Musical Secret Still Rings True
abstract: Created for the court for the Ottoman Empire, Zildjian cymbals are used by drummers worldwide.
lead_paragraph: The surest route to a drummer’s heart? Cymbals.

headline: Trevor Noah Shows How Apple Got Its Valuation to $1 Trillion
abstract: Hearing that Apple’s valuation had passed $1 trillion, he declared: “That’s it, folks. Apple has officially won capitalism. Wrap it up, it’s over.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: News Quiz: Test Your Knowledge of the Week’s Headlines
abstract: Did you stay up to date this week?
lead_paragraph: Did you stay up to date this week?

headline: For Many N.J. Transit Commuters, Last Year’s ‘Summer of Hell’ Is Now
abstract: A rash of train cancellations by New Jersey Transit, coupled with PATH delays, has added up to a season of aggravation for New Jersey commuters.
lead_paragraph: New Jersey’s new governor, Philip D. Murphy, a Democrat, has promised the state’s commuters that train service would improve after years of decline. What he did not warn them was that it would get so much worse before it got better.

headline: Murder, Politics and Architecture: The Making of Madison Square Park
abstract: From 19th-Century circuses and swanky hotels to an art and foodie destination today, this 6.2-acre green space continues to represent a city that is constantly reinventing itself.
lead_paragraph: From 19th-Century circuses and swanky hotels to an art and foodie destination today, this 6.2-acre green space continues to represent a city that is constantly reinventing itself.

headline: My Father Staged His Suicide to Look Like a Murder
abstract: Even with answers about his sensational death, I have unresolved questions about his complicated life.
lead_paragraph: I chose to sit in the overflow seating at my father’s funeral. Through a fuzzy speaker I listened as his new family eulogized a person who woke up every day with a smile on his face. His stepson wept as he declared that he considered my father, Alan Abrahamson, his real father.

headline: This Month’s Quiz: How Smart a Traveler Are You?
abstract: Here are a few questions, taken from recent articles in our Travel Tips collection, to test your travel savvy.
lead_paragraph: Here are a few questions, taken from recent articles in our Travel Tips collection, to test your travel savvy.

headline: Rumpelstiltskin Redux
abstract: In her brilliant new novel, “Spinning Silver,” Naomi Novik riffs on a number of fairy tales, including the straw-into-gold classic.
lead_paragraph: SPINNING SILVER By Naomi Novik 466 pp. Del Rey. $28.

headline: Workers Hardest Hit by Recession Are Joining in Recovery
abstract: Unemployment among those without a high school diploma has declined by two-thirds since the economy’s low point, the latest jobs report shows.
lead_paragraph: The least educated American workers, who took the hardest hit in the Great Recession, were also among the slowest to harvest the gains of the recovery. Now they are a striking symbol of a strong economy.

headline: Classical Myths Filtered Through a Modern Prism
abstract: In his new novel, “Metamorphica” — the title is a nod to Ovid’s epic poem — Zachary Mason reworks and respins ancient Greco-Roman myths.
lead_paragraph: METAMORPHICA By Zachary Mason 282 pp. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $26.

headline: How Alex Branson, Entrepreneur, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: The founder of Lavender Blues, which offers music classes for babies and toddlers in Brooklyn, likes to spend her day in the borough with her family.
lead_paragraph: Alex Branson decided to get serious about her idea for an inclusive music program for babies and toddlers “while under someone else’s parachute at someone else’s music class,” when she was working as a caregiver in London. Six years later, her company, Lavender Blues, is offering classes throughout six Brooklyn neighborhoods. A nanny for more than 14 years with a background in early childhood education, Ms. Branson, 38, prides herself on having cultivated a community of families (and bunnies, as she refers to the children). She lives with her wife, Toni, 36, the creator of Style Is Freedom, a genderless streetwear brand, and their cat, Betty, in Flatbush, Brooklyn.

headline: For Marilyn Stasio, Any Place Can Be the Scene of the Crime
abstract: This week’s mysteries move from a New Hampshire boarding school to a London rowhouse, with stops in New York City and a ramshackle shed in Oakland.
lead_paragraph: Who does what? Readers usually wonder about the mechanics of smoothly successful collaborations like that of Jonathan Kellerman and his son, Jesse. There are no psychologically wounded children in A MEASURE OF DARKNESS (Ballantine, $28.99), which would tip us to the hand of Kellerman père. But a loving exchange between a college student and his grandmother (a homemade coconut cake as a reward for a quick visit) suggests a more youthful sensibility. As for the keen sense of drama, it must be a genetic trait.

headline: ‘Beowulf’ Gets a 21st-Century Update
abstract: In “The Mere Wife,” by Maria Dahvana Headley, the epic poem is reimagined as an imaginative tale of class conflict.
lead_paragraph: THE MERE WIFEBy Maria Dahvana Headley308 pp. MCD/Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $27.

headline: Democrats See an Opening in Kansas if Trump Ally Wins Primary
abstract: Kris Kobach, a hard-line Trump supporter, could win the Republican nomination for governor, creating intraparty clashes over whether he’s too extreme.
lead_paragraph: TOPEKA, Kan. — The evolution of the Kansas Republican Party mirrors that of the national party, a rightward shift from the moderation of Dwight D. Eisenhower to the mainstream conservatism of Bob Dole to the small-government absolutism of former Gov. Sam Brownback and Wichita-based Koch Industries.

headline: Zephyr Teachout Is Running for Attorney General. But Her Real Target Is Trump.
abstract: The law professor and activist challenged Gov. Andrew Cuomo in the Democratic primary in 2014, and is a godmother to the current moment of upstart women candidates.
lead_paragraph: “Because of the internet, governments, corporations and citizens of other countries can now meaningfully participate in United States elections,” began the article in The Berkeley Journal of International Law. “They can, in short, influence who wins and who loses. Depending on your intuitions, this might seem like a very good thing, or the beginning of the end of democratic self-governance.”

headline: When a House Is So Much More
abstract: Why do some people get so emotional about real estate?
lead_paragraph: Buying a home is the biggest financial transaction most people will undertake in their lives. It can also be one of the most emotional.

headline: The Woman Who Created a Monster
abstract: For the 200th anniversary of “Frankenstein,” the poet Fiona Sampson has written a new biography of its author: “In Search of Mary Shelley.”
lead_paragraph: IN SEARCH OF MARY SHELLEY By Fiona Sampson 304 pp. Pegasus Books. $28.95.

headline: A Cheapskate’s Guide to Dublin, Rich in History and Beer
abstract: The beautiful capital city of Ireland has theater, literature and music emanating from its pores. But the city is also a victim of its own success.
lead_paragraph: My instructor, a woman named Áine, urged me on: “Do it for your country!” A group of us that had booked a traditional Irish games experience through Experience Gaelic Games (35 euros, about $42) stood out on a green field one hot afternoon in northern Dublin. Áine, having taught us the ways of hurling, a lacrosse-like game possibly as old as Ireland itself, was now instructing us in the ways of Gaelic football, which is played with a soccer ball-like orb. My immediate task: to juggle the ball off my foot while running toward a pair of goal posts, and then punt it through the uprights. My country, I thought, is about to be mighty disappointed.

headline: A Radar Blip, a Flash of Light: How U.F.O.s ‘Exploded’ Into Public View
abstract: Sightings of U.F.O.s in Washington in July 1952 garnered headlines around the world and caused so much concern that the government was forced to speak out.
lead_paragraph: In the early morning of July 20, 1952, Capt. S.C. “Casey” Pierman was ready for takeoff at Washington National Airport, when a bright light skimmed the horizon and disappeared. He did not think much of it until he was airborne, bound for Detroit, and an air traffic controller told him two or three unidentified flying objects were spotted on radar traveling at high speed.

headline: The Book Everyone in the Netherlands Is Talking About Is Finally Coming to the U.S.
abstract: Astrid Holleeder secretly recorded her brother and wrote a book about it. Now he’s on trial for murder, and she’s in hiding.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — Astrid Holleeder is a household name here in the Netherlands. If you’ve never heard of her, that’s about to change.

headline: See the Scars That Oil Exploration Cut Across Alaska’s Wilderness
abstract: A huge grid covers the landscape just outside the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, from seismic testing for oil and gas. Parts of the refuge itself could soon look the same way.
lead_paragraph: Matt Nolan, who runs a mapping business in Alaska using aerial photography, was flying a small plane to the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in the northeastern part of the state last month when he noticed a pattern on the tundra.

headline: Diana Taurasi and Brittney Griner Are the W.N.B.A.’s Iconic Duo. Don’t Wait.
abstract: They’re great apart but even better together. Taurasi and Griner have spent years tailoring their games to each other, and another championship for the Phoenix Mercury may be the reward.
lead_paragraph: For Diana Taurasi, the success she and Brittney Griner have found in the 2018 W.N.B.A season has done nothing less than change her perspective on the arc of her remarkable career.

headline: The Podcast Bros Want to Optimize Your Life
abstract: Don’t dismiss them as hucksters promoting self-help books and dubious mushroom coffee.
lead_paragraph: Do you want to optimize your life? Start your morning with a kale-garlic-ginger smoothie, or better yet, meditate and fast until noon. Next, hit the gym for your mixed martial arts workout and take a cold shower to activate your immune system. Then plan this summer’s vision quest: Maybe you’ll head to the jungles of Peru, where a shaman will brew you some mescaline-laced psychedelic tea — don’t worry; the intense nausea means you’re grasping new dimensions of reality.

headline: Pope’s Death Penalty Stance Won’t Stop Execution, Nebraska’s Catholic Governor Says
abstract: After years of battling over capital punishment, the state has scheduled what would be its first execution in 21 years for later this month.
lead_paragraph: LINCOLN, Neb. — When Nebraska lawmakers defied Gov. Pete Ricketts in 2015 by repealing the death penalty over his strong objections, the governor wouldn’t let the matter go. Mr. Ricketts, a Republican who is Roman Catholic, tapped his family fortune to help bankroll a referendum to reinstate capital punishment, a measure the state’s Catholic leadership vehemently opposed.

headline: What Causes Morning Sickness?
abstract: Millions of women suffer from the nausea and vomiting of pregnancy, but scientists are still exploring the underlying causes.
lead_paragraph: Q. Why don’t we know more about what causes morning sickness? With millions of data points annually, it seems like there should be good data!

headline: Weekly Health Quiz: Alan Alda, Fat Pets and Chinese Medicine
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Japanese Medical School Accused of Rigging Admissions to Keep Women Out
abstract: Tokyo Medical University was reported to have secretly skewed test scores out of the belief that women were more likely to drop out of the profession.
lead_paragraph: A Japanese medical school has been accused of manipulating the test scores of female applicants for years to artificially depress the number of women in the student body, a scandal that has triggered sharp criticism.

headline: Russia, Apple, Ernest Hemingway: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: How Paul Manafort’s Plans Backfired
abstract: The story of the former Trump campaign chairman and his ties to foreign governments begins long before the 2016 election.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: New York Today: A Picnic Packing List
abstract: Friday: Essentials for city picnics, and a fund for women in film, TV and theater.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this spotty Friday.

headline: Manufacturers Increase Efforts to Woo Workers to Rural Areas
abstract: Companies outside of urban centers don’t have enough high-skilled employees for an increasing numbers of jobs — and robots are not the answer.
lead_paragraph: They call it the “Not So Heavy Metal” tour. It’s a lighthearted effort by Minnesota-based Alexandria Industries to introduce middle and high school students — as well the general public — to manufacturing.

headline: The Great God of Depression
abstract: How mental illness stopped being “a terrible dark secret.”
lead_paragraph: Nearly 30 years ago, the author William Styron outed himself in these pages as mentally ill. “My days were pervaded by a gray drizzle of unrelenting horror,” he wrote in a New York Times Op-Ed article, describing the deep depression that had landed him in the psych ward. He compared the agony of mental illness to that of a heart attack. Pain is pain, whether it’s in the mind or the body. So why, he asked, were depressed people treated as pariahs?

headline: Follow the Money (Then Take a Picture)
abstract: With “Generation Wealth,” the filmmaker Lauren Greenfield looks back at 30 years of chronicling the rich — and predicting our cultural future.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps because she has spent her career watching the rich, the photographer and filmmaker Lauren Greenfield is herself rich to watch. At a party after the New York premiere of her new documentary — “Generation Wealth,” about the perils of capitalism — Ms. Greenfield was wired, welcoming and constantly working. She snapped pictures of the well-heeled crowd as she hugged her way around the room, occasionally misplacing a glass of white wine, in a churn of compliments and gossip.

headline: Summer Reading Contest, Week 8: What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
abstract: To participate, just post a comment here by Aug. 10 at 7 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on Aug. 21.
lead_paragraph: Update, Aug. 21: Winners have been announced!

headline: DealBook Briefing: The Trouble With a $1 Trillion Apple
abstract: Apple has become the first publicly traded American company to be worth $1,000,000,000,000. It’s not all good news.
lead_paragraph: Good Friday morning. Want this in your inbox every morning? Sign up here.

headline: A Museum Held a Show of Protest Art. Then the Artists Protested the Museum.
abstract: Dozens of works were removed from an exhibition at the Design Museum in London after their creators objected to the institution’s hosting an event for a defense firm.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Just after 11 a.m. on Thursday, a group of about 20 artists, many wearing black despite the searing sun, arrived at the Design Museum in London with an unusual aim: to remove their art from an exhibition.

headline: Pompeo Warns Turkey on Detained U.S. Pastor: The Clock Has ‘Run Out’
abstract: The imprisonment of Andrew Brunson prompted sanctions from the Trump administration. But the Turkish foreign minister said harsh tactics would not work.
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — Declaring that “the clock had run out,” Secretary of State Mike Pompeo urged Turkey on Friday to free an American pastor imprisoned on espionage charges, in a case that had spurred United States to impose sanctions against two top Turkish government officials.

headline: Attackers in Burqas Kill Dozens at Shiite Mosque in Afghanistan
abstract: Two bombers, wearing women’s clothes to hide explosive vests and automatic weapons, killed at least 29 worshipers during Friday Prayer.
lead_paragraph: KHOST, Afghanistan — At least 29 people were killed when suicide bombers disguised in women’s clothing stormed a Shiite mosque in eastern Afghanistan during Friday Prayer, officials said, the latest in a series of bloody attacks on the country’s Shiite minority.

headline: This Week in Arts: Shakira, Battery Dance Festival, ‘The Sinner’
abstract: The return of a titan of Latin pop, a dance festival with a view of the Statue of Liberty and a thriller from USA Network.
lead_paragraph: Aug. 10; ticketmaster.com.

headline: The ‘Abandon Whites’ Fantasy
abstract: Democrats don’t need to win the white working class. They need to do better with it.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.

headline: California Today: What Trump’s Auto Emissions Plan Means for California
abstract: Friday: State officials prepare a lawsuit against the proposal, Apple reaches a milestone, and an unlikely pair supports each other during the Carr Fire.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: The Week in Tech: SoftBank Strikes Again
abstract: Every SoftBank investment can make waves, just like the $240 million one in Brandless that it made this week.
lead_paragraph: Each week, technology reporters and columnists from The New York Times review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.

headline: The Basic Ingredients for Your Podcast Recipe
abstract: Making your own audio show can be fun and relatively inexpensive, but you should have a plan and get the right gear before you hit the Record button.
lead_paragraph: Q. I want to make podcasts. How do I do it?

headline: How Tech Billionaires Hack Their Taxes With a Philanthropic Loophole
abstract: A trendy maneuver allows wealthy donors to reap immediate tax benefits, while charities can wait for funds indefinitely — or even forever.
lead_paragraph: Late in 2014, Nicholas Woodman, the founder and chief executive of GoPro, announced what appeared to be an extraordinary act of generosity.

headline: China Threatens New Tariffs on $60 Billion of U.S. Goods
abstract: The new threat comes after President Trump asked his administration to consider more than doubling tariffs on $200 billion a year of Chinese goods.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China threatened on Friday to tax an additional $60 billion a year worth of imports from the United States if the Trump administration imposes its own new levies on Chinese goods.

headline: Wyatt Russell Taps Into His Hollywood DNA and Makes a Splash
abstract: Mr. Russell talks about his new leading role in AMC’s “Lodge 49,” why acting was never an inevitability and the role he’d grow out his beard for.
lead_paragraph: Blessed with royal Hollywood DNA — his parents are Kurt Russell and Goldie Hawn, after all — Wyatt Russell was well positioned for movie stardom. But after roles alongside his father in “Soldier” and “Escape From L.A.,” he wiped the stardust from his tender eyes and by 15 began mastering the skills to become a professional hockey player. Then injuries derailed his dreams, and he found himself back in front of the camera.

headline: Two Netflix Original Dads, Incarnated by TV Favorites
abstract: “Like Father,” “Father of the Year,” and “The Week Of”: Netflix comedies about families offer some pleasures amid the highly predictable stuff.
lead_paragraph: Two new Netflix Original comedy films offer family dysfunction enacted by veteran television performers. “Father of the Year,” starring David Spade, the “S.N.L.” and “Just Shoot Me” alum, had its premiere on July 20, while “Like Father,” which debuted Aug. 3, features Kristen Bell, once the well-loved teenage detective of “Veronica Mars,” as the estranged daughter of Kelsey Grammer, who should need no introduction.

headline: Village Townhouse Sale Breaks Record
abstract: A fully renovated Greenwich Village house closed last month at $37.2 million, a new high for downtown, while the producer Bob Weinstein sold his duplex.
lead_paragraph: The $37.2 million sale of an 1838 Greek Revival townhouse in Greenwich Village has set another record in New York City.

headline: The Cast of ‘The Bold Type’ on Staying Current
abstract: The show’s main trio of young stars discuss how the show explores race, queer identity and the #MeToo movement within the setting of a glitzy women’s magazine.
lead_paragraph: “The Bold Type,” which airs its Season 2 finale Tuesday on Freeform, is based on a familiar TV narrative: Smart young women living fun but complicated lives in New York City, where they pursue their dreams of career success and romance. For its sometimes realistic — and other times outrageous — portrayal of life as a young adult in New York, comparisons to shows like “Sex and the City” and “Girls” come easy.

headline: Learning Lines. And Crossing Them.
abstract: A brief (recent) history of plays, films and TV shows exploring the fraught, sometimes predatory relationship between directors and their charges.
lead_paragraph: “I want to deepen the work,” Evangeline says.

headline: Brazil’s Supreme Court Considers Decriminalizing Abortion
abstract: A rare two-day public hearing on abortion comes as legislators are trying to restrict the practice.
lead_paragraph: PETRÓPOLIS, Brazil — For three days after she had an illegal abortion, Ingriane Barbosa Carvalho hemorrhaged in silence. Even as she writhed in pain, and an infection caused by the botched procedure spread, Ms. Carvalho insisted to relatives she was just nursing a stomach bug.

headline: As Brexit Looms, Musicians Brace for the Worst
abstract: Britain’s classical music scene relies heavily on freedoms that come from European Union membership. How will it cope outside the bloc?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The composer Howard Goodall was passing through a London airport in March en route to a conducting gig in Houston. Idling at the currency exchange desk, he got into a conversation with an employee about whether Britain’s departure from the European Union, known as Brexit, would be good for his industry. When Mr. Goodall said no and suggested that the consequences would be “disastrous,” the clerk replied that everyone he asked that question “gives the same answer.”

headline: Five Weeknight Dishes
abstract: Don’t let those herbs wither in the fridge. Go wild with them! We’ll show you how.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Emily, in for Sam again, with five weeknight recipes for busy people who still want something good to eat. (If that’s you, would you consider signing up for my new weeknight newsletter, which starts in September?) Sam will be back with you on Sunday.

headline: Ebola Poses High Risk in Congo, W.H.O. Says
abstract: The latest outbreak of the virus is believed to have killed more than 20 people, but the danger of the disease spreading worldwide was said to be low.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — An outbreak of the Ebola virus in the Democratic Republic of Congo poses a high risk to the region, though the danger of the disease spreading worldwide was described as low, international health officials said on Friday.

headline: Olympian Erin Hamlin Marries a Childhood Playmate
abstract: Jonathan Hodge cheered for the world-class luger from afar. Then a chance meeting at a family gathering led to some competitive flirting. They both won.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Hodge has a reputation for pulling off small miracles on the basketball court. But the miracle he’s proudest of — sweeping four-time Olympian Erin Hamlin off her feet — lends itself less to repeat viewings by his core audience of hoops fanatics and goggle-eyed Minnesota schoolchildren.

headline: Deer Make the Worst Neighbors
abstract: Suburban homeowners are fascinated and irritated by these four-legged creatures.
lead_paragraph: Like many of us who choose to live in the suburbs, deer want a nice, safe neighborhood, with great food and plenty of privacy. For one particular doe and fawn, that neighborhood happens to be my backyard.

headline: Review: ‘Lodge 49,’ Where Beautiful Losers Join the Club
abstract: AMC’s oddball comic drama is blissfully low-stakes but high on character chemistry. (Or is it alchemy?)
lead_paragraph: It’s become a cliché to ask about a TV drama, “What are the stakes?” Often the question embodies an assumption: that a story can’t be worth your time unless it’s explosive and dire. Who gets killed? What’s everybody fighting over? How big are the dragons?

headline: India’s Higher Education Troubles
abstract: India’s public universities need better funding and greater autonomy.
lead_paragraph: When the Times Higher Education World University Rankings, which rates about 1,000 global institutions, was released in May, not even one Indian institute featured in the overall Top 100, though the Indian Institute of Science made it in the reputational rankings after seven years.

headline: Rome Wasn’t Sacked in a Day
abstract: Matthew Kneale’s “Rome: A History in Seven Sackings” narrates the city’s past through the marauders who have devastated it.
lead_paragraph: ROME A History in Seven Sackings By Matthew Kneale Illustrated. 417 pp. Simon & Schuster. $30.

headline: Trump’s Economic Claims Are Overblown
abstract: Yes, job numbers are strong, just as they have been for years before Trump took office.
lead_paragraph: For the second consecutive Friday, the Trump administration had an opportunity to point to fresh data that supposedly demonstrates the strong boost the president’s policies have given to the nation’s economy. Last week, news that the gross domestic product expanded at a 4.1 percent rate in the second quarter occasioned a presidential appearance on the south lawn of the White House. Friday’s announcement that 157,000 new jobs were added in July was marked more modestly, with a statement from the White House.

headline: From Rags to Ill-Gotten Riches in 1930s China
abstract: Paul French’s “City of Devils” is a narrative fiction of the “tawdry city” Shanghai before World War II.
lead_paragraph: CITY OF DEVILS The Two Men Who Ruled the Underworld of Old Shanghai By Paul French 299 pp. Picador. $28

headline: Do Cockroaches Carry Diseases?
abstract: A W.H.O. study said there was not enough evidence to conclude that the insects were vectors for human diseases.
lead_paragraph: A. The proven health risks of cockroach infestation seem to be predominantly those of filth, food contamination and allergic asthma rather than direct transmission of disease, according to an extensive review of public health risks from all kinds of pests conducted by the World Health Organization.

headline: How to Listen to the Book Review Podcast
abstract: Instructions to help you find and subscribe to the series.
lead_paragraph: Each week on The New York Times Book Review’s podcast, the Book Review’s editor, Pamela Paul, speaks with authors, critics and Times reporters about the latest releases and news in the literary world. Here’s how to listen:

headline: Personal Stories From the Refugee Experience
abstract: Three books relate the individual accounts of people caught up in events larger than themselves.
lead_paragraph: BUTTERFLY From Refugee to Olympian: My Story of Rescue, Hope, and Triumph By Yusra Mardini with Josie Le Blond 284 pp. St. Martin’s. $26.99.

headline: From ‘Mission: Impossible’ to ‘Godzilla’: Plane Jumps in the Movies
abstract: Tom Cruise, professional sky divers, even muscle cars: All have leapt from planes in recent films.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood loves to throw people out of planes. Several big-budget movies over the last four years have sent their characters hurtling from aircraft for various narrative purposes. And yet the main reason may just be because it’s cool.

headline: Watermill Center, All Star Code and Diana Rigg Held Parties
abstract: The summer charity circuit goes arty and techy in the Hamptons.
lead_paragraph: The summer charity circuit goes arty and techy in the Hamptons.

headline: Lemon Bars, With Blueberries in a Supporting Role
abstract: It’s a classic, arguably essential pairing, but striking the right balance can be tricky.
lead_paragraph: The best lemon bars strike a perfect balance: They’re both sweet and tangy, their sharp, creamy centers anchored by a crisp, buttery crust. My desert-island dessert, they’re the one confection I can imagine eating ad infinitum — or, at least until the rescue plane arrives.

headline: Magic Ripples Just Below the Surface in These Novels
abstract: In fantasies by K. Sello Duiker and Jaleigh Johnson, children use magic to navigate the streets of a South African township and a hostile world called Tallhaven.
lead_paragraph: Some books are like tour guides. Grinning, they whisk you through enchanted avenues, each carefree laugh rehearsed and calculated, each anecdote sliding a little too smoothly into place. All the while, your eye wanders down the crooked back streets, and you wonder what myth and magic really goes on down there, what true, dirty, uncomfortable histories have been covered over. Other books feel more like an old friend — they take you by the hand and lead you through their hometown, explaining what needs to be explained, trusting you’ll figure out the rest.

headline: The Literati: Henry James’s Final Curtain Call
abstract: Edward Sorel illustrates the great turn-of-the-century author’s fumbling foray into the theater.
lead_paragraph: Concerned about diminishing royalties from his novels, Henry James in his mid-40s began to write plays. Over five years of failure, few made it to the stage, but one, “Guy Domville,” succeeded in opening at London’s St. James’s Theater on Jan. 5, 1895. The highly respected George Alexander produced it and acted the title role.

headline: A Tornado Took On New York. The Tornado Didn’t Last Long.
abstract: A tornado touched down in Queens on Thursday, tearing down trees. There were no reported injuries. The warning, however, inspired jokes on social media.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers have become somewhat inured to the various reasons that their smartphones vibrate with alerts. And then there was Thursday night, when a tornado warning sent phones and their owners buzzing.

headline: Star Athlete Is Injured in Egg Attack, and Italy Debates ‘a Racism Emergency’
abstract: Daisy Osakue, whose eye was struck in an assault, has become the bandaged face of a question confronting Italy: Is it more racist under the anti-immigrant government?
lead_paragraph: MONCALIERI, Italy — Daisy Osakue grabbed her pink sneakers from the terrace and packed them in a suitcase embossed with the Italian flag. All around her family’s apartment, newspaper articles, old photos and posters hailed her success in track and field. Dozens of medals hung from pictures of her family celebrating in traditional Nigerian dress.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘An Odyssey,’ ‘Dunbar’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.

headline: Hats Are Big This Summer. Really Big.
abstract: La Bomba, the Palapa and the Spinner battle for beach space.
lead_paragraph: Fashion sometimes goes to gobsmacking, seemingly incomprehensible extremes. The gigantic straw sun hat of summer 2018 is one of those.

headline: A Revolution Within the Revolution: Cuba Opens to Same-Sex Marriages
abstract: A new constitution under discussion is a necessary reform that can set an example in L.G.B.T. rights.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — “I want to go there before things change” is a phrase I hear often from friends considering a trip to Cuba. But change has been underway for over a decade, from the day Raúl Castro became president after his brother Fidel fell ill in 2006. Since then, private property and self-employment have been legalized; tourism has boomed, benefiting thousands of Cubans who rent out rooms or serve meals in their apartments; and a lively art scene has sprouted in Havana, where artist-run spaces host exhibitions and lectures.

headline: Notes From the Book Review Archives
abstract: In which we consult the Book Review’s past to shed light on the books of the present. This week: Anne Tyler’s “The Accidental Tourist.”
lead_paragraph: Kate Tuttle reviews Anne Tyler’s most recent novel, “Clock Dance,” in this week’s issue. In 1985, Larry McMurtry expounded on Tyler’s skill and talent while writing about “The Accidental Tourist” for the Book Review. Read an excerpt below:

headline: Want to Be Part of a Story About Crossword Solving?
abstract: Who are the passionate puzzle solvers who show up every day to talk about The New York Times Crossword? The Times would like to meet you.
lead_paragraph: Who are the passionate puzzle solvers who show up every day to talk about The New York Times Crossword? The Times would like to meet you.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The New Season Ticket, Seat Optional
abstract: The Oakland A’s are planning to disrupt the traditional season-ticket model next season, allowing fans to buy access to all 81 home games without committing to a seat.
lead_paragraph: The phrase is part of the lexicon of sports, signifying a fan’s ultimate expression of devotion to a team: season tickets. For every game, the fan would be there in the same seat, never missing a moment of the action.

headline: Why ‘Can I Sue My Employer?’ Is Often the Wrong Question
abstract: A worker worries about being fired just because a new manager doesn’t like him and wonders if there is a way to fight back. Here’s why the law can’t help but other strategies might.
lead_paragraph: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: A Hiatus From Politics?
abstract: A reader suggests a conversational gambit.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: That Huge Surprise in His Own Family Genealogy? It’s Playing out in His Novels
abstract: Alan Gratz’s middle-grade novels — like the best-selling ‘Refugee’ — often deal with war, asylum seekers and Jewish history.
lead_paragraph: Middle-grade author Alan Gratz isn’t a genealogy buff, but his aunt is, and a few decades ago she traced the Gratz family line back to one Louis Alexander Gratz. “He was a penniless Prussian orphan who came to the United States in the 1860s, joined the Union Army and fought his way south with Sherman’s troops,” Gratz explains. “But the most surprising thing she discovered about old L.A. Gratz was that he had a secret: He was Jewish, but had abandoned his religion and heritage when he made his new start in America. Family lore has it that learning our ancestors were Jewish is what gave my anti-Semitic grandfather a fatal heart attack.”

headline: A Sunflower Farm Invited Tourists. It Ended Up Like a ‘Zombie Apocalypse.’
abstract: The owners of a Canadian seed farm were forced to close to visitors last weekend after selfie-taking tourists overwhelmed the farm and nearby roads with traffic.
lead_paragraph: This is a story about a good idea gone awry.

headline: John James, Black and Republican, Thinks He Can Crack the ‘Blue Wall’ in Michigan
abstract: Mr. James, 37, is a West Point graduate who spent eight years in the Army. He is the president of his family-run business. And he wants to become a senator.
lead_paragraph: • Update: John James won the Republican primary on Tuesday night.

headline: The National Comedy Center Opens, Jim Gaffigan Hologram and All
abstract: The Jamestown, N.Y., museum aims to draw in fans and historians alike, with artifacts like the Puffy Shirt from “Seinfeld.” There’s also a hologram theater.
lead_paragraph: Jamestown, N.Y., has long been known as the hometown of the “I Love Lucy” star Lucille Ball (and the site of a much-mocked, since-remade sculpture of her). Now, the city is hoping to expand its reputation for humor with the opening this week of the National Comedy Center, a museum devoted to, as its website says, “telling the vital story of comedy in America.”

headline: Buoyant Economy or a Blip? 4 Tips for Investing Before the Party Ends
abstract: The economy has been growing since March 2009, but some are skeptical that the expansion will continue. Experts offer advice for investing wisely in times of doubt.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to how the latest economic data could have an impact on investors, two opposite interpretations emerge.

headline: Amar’e Stoudemire Is on a Religious Quest
abstract: Accompanying the former N.B.A. star as he explores Jewish landmarks in New York.
lead_paragraph: The halls of the Jewish Museum in Manhattan were hushed and dim as Amar’e Stoudemire stepped inside. At nearly seven feet tall, the former New York Knicks star towered over the smattering of other visitors.

headline: Lincoln Center Still Has Mostly Mozart, but What Is It?
abstract: The center has overhauled its summer offerings. But its signature festival is now suffering from an identity crisis.
lead_paragraph: Where a concert takes place can be as crucial to its success as the quality of the performance itself. So a shift of locale for a Mostly Mozart Festival concert at Lincoln Center last month proved something of a revelation, especially at a time when the center is grappling with confusion over its summer offerings.

headline: The Trauma of Child Separation
abstract: A reader recalls her experience in post-World War II Germany.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Pompeo Says There’s ‘a Ways to Go’ Before North Korea Fulfills Nuclear Vows
abstract: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is urging Asian allies to keep pressuring North Korea with economic sanctions.
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo expressed growing exasperation with North Korea on Friday, accusing its government of refusing to respect a promise to President Trump to stop, or even slow, Pyongyang’s nuclear weapons program.

headline: Beth Macy Talks About ‘Dopesick’
abstract: “We're all connected, we’re all at risk of this,” Macy says about what she has learned reporting on the opioid crisis. “It’s everywhere.”
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

headline: 100 Goats, Chewing Everything, Invade Boise Neighborhood
abstract: “You would assume the homeowners were upset that their lawns were being destroyed, but everyone was enjoying it,” a local reporter said.
lead_paragraph: No blade of grass, no rose bush nor flower bed, was safe from the goats.

headline: Good Things Happen When Bread Meets Eggs
abstract: This dish — a pita, filled with an herb-packed omelet — is a mash-up worth replicating.
lead_paragraph: The original egg on a roll was not bought from a cart on the streets of Manhattan, I imagine, but it is now a cheap, fast, made-to-order breakfast for New Yorkers of all stripes in a hurry. Wrapped in paper, the sandwich is as unassuming as it is satisfying.

headline: A Cri de Coeur in a Pool of Milk: Decoding ‘Salome’ in Salzburg
abstract: The director Romeo Castellucci discusses a crucial moment in his enigmatic new production of Richard Strauss’s “Salome” for the Salzburg Festival.
lead_paragraph: SALZBURG, Austria — So much almost happens in Romeo Castellucci’s new production of Strauss’s “Salome,” playing at the Salzburg Festival through Aug. 27 and streaming online at medici.tv through Oct. 28.

headline: The Met Opera and Two Unions Reach a Deal, Very Quietly
abstract: Without the public rancor of their last negotiations, the Met and its orchestra and chorus reached a tentative labor deal. But its terms are secret for now.
lead_paragraph: This time, it was pianissimo. Without the noisy rallies or vituperative broadsides that marked its last round of labor negotiations, the Metropolitan Opera and two of its biggest unions reached a tentative labor agreement Friday morning, paving the way for its season to open next month.

headline: The Illness Is Bad Enough. The Hospital May Be Even Worse.
abstract: Older patients are particularly vulnerable to “post-hospital syndrome,” some experts believe, and that may be why so many patients return.
lead_paragraph: When she moved from Michigan to be near her daughter in Cary, N.C., Bernadine Lewandowski insisted on renting an apartment five minutes away.

headline: The Furor Over Sarah Jeong, a New York Times Tech Writer
abstract: A reader is shocked by the hiring of an editorial board member who has written tweets that he terms “racist, bigoted and disgusting.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Listen to ‘Dear Sugars’: Emotional Abuse
abstract: Invisible blows can still leave scars.
lead_paragraph: Invisible blows can still leave scars.

headline: Don’t Roll Back U.S. Fuel Standards
abstract: Readers urge the Trump administration not to enrich oil companies at the expense of the environment.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: An Ancient River in Syria Sections Off a Modern War
abstract: A trip along the Euphrates reveals damaged and depopulated towns, and an uneasy front held by a tenuous American presence.
lead_paragraph: ZOUR MAGHAR, Syria — On the eastern bank of the Euphrates River, Kurdish militiamen aligned with American troops burrow into sandbagged positions and eye their foes across the water.

headline: Chris Rock Will Star in ‘Fargo’ Season 4
abstract: The comedian will play the boss of a Kansas City crime family in 1950.
lead_paragraph: The comedian Chris Rock will star in Season 4 of “Fargo,” John Landgraf, the CEO of FX Networks, announced on Friday during the Television Critics Association press tour.

headline: Trump Will Have Blood on His Hands
abstract: His demonization of the news media won’t fall on deaf ears.
lead_paragraph: The voice, if I had to guess, belongs to that of a white American male in late middle age. The accent is faintly Southern, the manner taunting but relaxed. It’s also familiar: I’m pretty sure he’s left a message on my office number before. But the last voice mail left almost no impression. Not this time.

headline: Art Lee, Fly-Fishing Virtuoso and Writer, Dies at 76
abstract: Mr. Lee was a Catskills fixture whose reputation as an angler spread far and wide. He once took Jimmy Carter fishing and wrote a whole book on a knot.
lead_paragraph: Art Lee, a writer and guide who described the sylvan joys — and the slyest tricks — of fly-fishing to generations of trout and salmon anglers, died on July 25 at a hospital in Middletown, N.Y. He was 76.

headline: Deep Dives Into Justice From Shakespeare, Wilde and Atticus Finch
abstract: With “The Tempest,” “An Ideal Husband” and “To Kill a Mockingbird,” the Stratford Festival carries on a conversation about purity and forgiveness.
lead_paragraph: STRATFORD, Ontario — Weird things happen when you take a theatrical deep dive; you may even get a case of the bends.

headline: A Pregnant Woman Ordered a Latte at McDonald’s. She Received a Cup of Cleaning Fluid.
abstract: “It just felt like my mouth was burning,” she said. The fast-food chain said the same thing has happened before.
lead_paragraph: A McDonald’s franchise in Canada has apologized after serving a pregnant woman a cup of cleaning fluid instead of coffee, a mistake the company said has occurred in the past with other customers.

headline: Rick Genest, Tattooed ‘Zombie Boy’ in Lady Gaga Video, Dies at 32
abstract: Mr. Genest, whose tattoos covered his entire body, participated in the 2011 Lady Gaga music video “Born This Way.”
lead_paragraph: Rick Genest, a model who was known for his head-to-toe tattoos and for appearing in the music video for Lady Gaga’s 2011 song “Born This Way,” has died in Montreal. He was 32.

headline: 2 Workers at Arizona Migrant Children Centers Are Charged With Sexual Abuse
abstract: The authorities recently detailed the charges against the men, Fernando Magaz Negrete and Levian D. Pacheco, who worked at centers operated by Southwest Key Programs.
lead_paragraph: Two youth care workers at Arizona shelters for migrant children have been charged with sexually assaulting immigrant teenagers, according to court records. They are the latest claims of abuse at government-contracted shelters that have a key role in the Trump administration’s hard-line immigration crackdown.

headline: Christopher Gibbs, Avatar of ‘Swinging London,’ Dies at 80
abstract: An antiques dealer and arbiter of eclectic taste, he popularized the 1960s Peacock Revolution in fashion and “distressed bohemian” in interior design.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Gibbs, an erudite London antiques dealer and dandy who introduced the raffish “distressed bohemian” style to interior design and helped start the Peacock Revolution in men’s wear, died early Sunday at his home in Tangier, Morocco. Only minutes earlier, at midnight, he had turned 80.

headline: Beyoncé and Jay-Z Squeeze Triumph From Reconciliation
abstract: For their On the Run II tour, pop’s most powerful couple perform the third act of their high-stakes play about faithfulness and disappointment.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Before Beyoncé and Jay-Z even made it to the MetLife Stadium stage here on Thursday night, the rain arrived for a baptism. Everyone in the audience was ordered to leave their seats and take shelter, and the beginning of the show was delayed more than an hour. As the skies opened, the stadium floor was empty and still, anticipating renewal.

headline: Feminists in Line for Free Lipstick
abstract: Nothing says “I’m a woman” like a red lip. But a red lip costs $18.50 plus tax.
lead_paragraph: We were in a line that wrapped halfway around a city block, and we were talking about color: red versus pink, shimmery versus matte. One woman liked that peach gloss Michelle Obama goes for; another thought Meghan Markle had a nice defined nude thing going.

headline: ‘Better Call Saul’ Starts Its Fourth Season, Still Waiting for Saul
abstract: AMC’s ‘Breaking Bad’ prequel continues to find ways to spin out the adventures of Jimmy McGill, the shyster lawyer who will someday become Saul Goodman.
lead_paragraph: For three seasons, “Better Call Saul” has been an exercise in narrative delayed gratification: saving itself, postponing consummation, keeping its two story lines — fated to someday converge — apart for as long as possible.

headline: Why a Trade Truce Could Add Almost $2 Trillion to the Stock Market
abstract: A closer look at the S.&P. 500 suggests that trade tensions are holding investors back.
lead_paragraph: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

headline: Read These 3 Books About Global Warming
abstract: Predictions and solutions in these books drawing on scientific research and social policy.
lead_paragraph: This year has seen record-high temperatures around the world, including in Japan, where triple-digit temperatures killed at least 86 people since May and hospitalized more than 20,000 over one week in July. According to scientists, this is an upward trend, and 2018 may be one of the hottest years on record. Here are three books that predict how global warming may affect humanity and what we can still do.

headline: Weinstein Releases Emails Suggesting Long Relationship With Accuser
abstract: The producer said in court papers a grand jury never saw emails showing a consensual relationship with one accuser, lasting years after an alleged attack.
lead_paragraph: The attorney for Harvey Weinstein accused the Manhattan district attorney’s office on Friday of withholding hundreds of emails from the grand jury that suggest the producer’s relationship with a woman accusing him of rape was consensual and lasted for years after the alleged attack.

headline: The Real Cost of Keeping Les Moonves
abstract: CBS should realize that workplace harassers can lead to high turnover, poor productivity and a poisoned workplace culture.
lead_paragraph: Leslie Moonves is a rainmaker and a kingmaker. As the chief executive of CBS, he transformed the television network from last place to most watched. He’s made careers, and he has made a fortune, for himself and for his employer. And that’s probably why the CBS board decided to let him keep his job despite allegations in a recent exposé in The New Yorker that he sexually harassed women and helped foster a climate of harassment throughout the company.

headline: Beachfront Soundtrack: The Week in Classical Music
abstract: A 17-year-old violinist and a Mozart string quintet were among the highlights.
lead_paragraph: [Read all of our classical coverage here.]

headline: Peloton’s New Infusion Made It a $4 Billion Company in 6 Years
abstract: The fitness company selling stationary bikes and subscriptions to live classes once confused investors. Now, after new financing of $550 million, it’s the toast of Silicon Valley.
lead_paragraph: For Peloton’s first two years in business, venture capital investors didn’t get it. The company’s founders struggled to convince them that blending stationary bikes and streaming live video classes would work. It had to cobble together money from a network of more than 200 angel investors to get off the ground.

headline: Mary Carlisle, Depression-Era Movie Ingénue, Is Dead at 104
abstract: Discovered at 14 in a Hollywood commissary, she went on to appear in 50 movies, including three with Bing Crosby, and was a darling of the press.
lead_paragraph: Mary Carlisle, an angel-faced blond actress who often played spunky but innocent ingénues in scores of Depression-era films, died on Wednesday in the Woodland Hills section of Los Angeles. She was 104.

headline: Zimbabwe’s Opposition Calls Vote Results ‘Fraudulent’ in Tense Aftermath
abstract: Street violence subsided but political clashes continued. President Emmerson Mnangagwa’s victory became official, but his opponent, Nelson Chamisa, still insists he won.
lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe — Presidential election results showing that the man who ousted Robert Mugabe in a coup last year in Zimbabwe had won his own term in office were “fraudulent and illegitimate,” the main opposition candidate said on Friday as he vowed to challenge them in the courts.

headline: This Week’s Wedding Announcements
abstract: All of the weddings right here on one handy page for you.
lead_paragraph: Jeanie Walls Knigin and William Gary Knisely met in 2016, after a woman whom Ms. Knigin knew referred Mr. Knisely to her as a potential date. It turned out that he had been out with several other women in Ms. Knigin’s sphere, but none had been quite right, and each had suggested that he might contact another acquaintance.

headline: NASA Names Astronauts for Boeing and SpaceX Flights to International Space Station
abstract: Their voyages are scheduled for next year, and they would be the first American astronauts to launch from American soil since 2011.
lead_paragraph: NASA has named the astronauts chosen to fly on commercial spacecraft made by Boeing and SpaceX to and from the International Space Station, the research laboratory that orbits around Earth.

headline: ‘Better Call Saul’: What to Remember Before Watching Season 4
abstract: Jimmy was left with a lot to reckon with, some of which he didn’t yet know. But we know. Here’s help sifting through the ashes of Season 3.
lead_paragraph: Just how bad will Jimmy McGill break this season? That’s the big question for viewers as “Better Call Saul” returns to AMC for Season 4 on Monday, Aug. 6. Created by Vince Gilligan and Peter Gould as a prequel to “Breaking Bad,” “Saul” stars Bob Odenkirk as its title character … sort of.

abstract: A man’s decision to cooperate with prosecutors in a case that has already resulted in the arrests of 16 people could be a turning point for corruption investigations in Argentina.
