lead_paragraph: LONDON — The police in London on Wednesday identified a Sudanese-born Briton from Birmingham as the driver who had plowed a car into three people and crashed outside Parliament, leaving the authorities trying to pry a motive from a suspect they said was uncooperative.

headline: Qatar Comes to Aid of Turkey, Offering $15 Billion Lifeline
abstract: The sum is a small fraction of what Turkey needs to shore up its faltering economy, but it was a symbolically important sign of international support.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkey won a measure of international support in its increasingly tense standoff with the United States on Wednesday when Qatar offered a relatively small but symbolically important financial lifeline.

headline: The Story of ‘the Most Underrated Composer in History’
abstract: Rimsky-Korsakov, his style and career guided by an inferiority complex, is the subject of this year’s Bard Music Festival.
lead_paragraph: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — If your reaction to hearing the name Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov is a shrug, even a smirk, you’re not alone.

headline: The Shape of Things to Come
abstract: Voluminous proportions for fall, layered for maximal impact.
lead_paragraph: Voluminous proportions for fall, layered for maximal impact.

headline: Fall Fashion: The Shape of Things to Come, Starring the Season’s Freshest Faces
abstract: For T’s latest cover story, the models of the moment try on a mix of supersize streetwear and pumped-up couture details.
lead_paragraph: For our latest cover story, Willy Vanderperre captured fall’s voluminous proportions as styled by Alastair McKimm: layer upon layer of jackets, sweaters and dresses — and a single Balenciaga coat meant to look like it’s six or seven separate and stacked pieces — punctuated by platform Comme des Garçons Nikes and Prada bucket hats. This new silhouette was worn by the models of the moment — Adesuwa Aighewi, Anok Yai, Alyssa Traoré and Sora Choi. “When I’m at the shows, I’m watching the faces as much as the outfits, and as soon as I saw our cover model, Adesuwa Aighewi, I knew I wanted her for this magazine,” writes Hanya Yanagihara in her letter from the editor. “The Nigerian-Chinese-Thai-American daughter of scientists, she is clearly black and clearly Asian, clearly beautiful and clearly and inimitably herself.” See more from T’s Aug. 19 Women’s Fashion issue.

headline: T’s Fall Women’s Fashion Issue: An Education
abstract: A successful magazine is a collection of disparate personalities with disparate interests who are all trying to tell stories using the language in which they are most fluent.
lead_paragraph: When I came aboard as the editor of T a little over a year ago, I promised myself that I would never pretend I knew what I didn’t. Unfortunately, there was a great deal I didn’t know — more, even, than I’d realized. But one of the things I love most about working at a magazine is that they’re constructed so that your colleagues will all be expert in a subject or a field in which you’re ignorant. Mine collectively know more about, variously, art, literary theory, theater, music, design, architecture, gardening, film and food than I ever will, and their knowledge is my delight. A successful magazine is a collection of disparate personalities with disparate interests who are all trying to tell stories using the language in which they are most fluent. Sometimes that language is literally language. But sometimes that language is a vernacular not of words, but of images: It is photography, or illustration, or graphic design, or typography.

headline: A Long History of Attacking Women, Yet He Was Free to Kill Again
abstract: Could the police have saved Kimberly Dobbie? When the crime is domestic violence, or something like it, the answer is complicated.
lead_paragraph: LEWISTON, Me. — The killing of Kimberly Dobbie happened in broad daylight, on the sidewalk near a laundromat. That was rare.

headline: The Conflict of Interest That Is Killing Recycling
abstract: Some of the biggest recycling operations are owned by landfill companies whose profits improve when recycling doesn’t work well.
lead_paragraph: In the past few years, one of the core pillars of the environmental movement — recycling — has fallen on hard times. News dispatches reveal hundreds of cities and counties scaling back their recycling programs because of the high costs associated with processing recyclables and the lack of demand for the materials. A new conventional wisdom is gaining ground suggesting that recycling may not be worth the effort.

headline: Israeli Military Clears Itself of Wrongdoing in 2014 Gaza War’s ‘Black Friday’
abstract: The military said its inquiry into one of the war’s bloodiest episodes found no criminal wrongdoing by Israeli forces.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Known as “Black Friday,” Israel’s assault on Rafah in the southern Gaza Strip on Aug. 1, 2014, was one of the deadliest and most scrutinized episodes in the 50-day war that summer.

headline: Behind the Cover: Under Their Thumb
abstract: For this issue, a look at the unlikely activists who took on Google and Facebook as they made billions mining personal data.

headline: Moshe Mizrahi, 86, Who Won an Oscar for ‘Madame Rosa,’ Is Dead
abstract: Born to a Jewish family in Egypt, Mr. Mizrahi was the first Israeli filmmaker to win an Academy Award and is still the only one.
lead_paragraph: Moshe Mizrahi, an Israeli director whose “Madame Rosa,” one of several movies he made in France, won the Academy Award for best foreign-language film in 1978, died on Aug. 3 at a hospital in Tel Aviv. He was 86.

headline: Trump Administration Sanctions Companies Helping North Korea
abstract: The sanctions were ordered against three organizations and an individual accused of facilitating illicit shipments to North Korea.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration announced new sanctions on Wednesday against three organizations and an individual accused of facilitating illicit shipments to North Korea, keeping pressure on the government of Kim Jong-un amid ongoing negotiations over the dismantling of his nuclear program.

headline: Tencent, the Chinese Internet Giant, Stumbles. Beijing Gets the Blame
abstract: Bureaucratic reshuffling made it difficult for the company, an emblem of Chinese innovation, to get approvals to make money off new games, hurting earnings.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Its chat app has inspired Silicon Valley. It owns some of the biggest video game franchises in the world. And after years of growth it has become one of the largest internet companies in the world.

headline: In the Berkshires, a Powerful Play and a Classic Musical About Prejudice
abstract: Jen Silverman’s harrowing “Dangerous House” and a revival of “West Side Story” join a conversation about racial and sexual violence.
lead_paragraph: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass. — Theater seasons rarely have a theme; they come together too haphazardly for that. But there’s something in the Berkshires air right now, even aside from humidity. Last weekend, I saw three productions that all dealt, at least in part, with the life-destroying effects of prejudice. Together, they seemed to be engaged in an accidental conversation with our own time and world.

headline: Fox Business Took a Shot at Denmark. Denmark Fired Back.
abstract: An anchor, Trish Regan, called the country a warning about socialism, mentioning it alongside Venezuela. The Danish finance minister led an angry response.
lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN — Danes are used to hearing their country mentioned in international comparisons. On measures like maternal health, public trust and happiness, they are accustomed to appearing near the head of global league tables.

headline: In the Studio With a Pair of Ethical Taxidermists
abstract: Outside of Amsterdam, Jaap Sinke and Ferry van Tongeren make magic in their mad-scientist lab.
lead_paragraph: In the Dutch city of Haarlem, in a cavernous former horse butchery filled with Victorian antiques, crocodile skins, anatomical models, glass eyes and animals in various states of mummification, a pair of whiskery former admen are creating some of the most exquisite ethical taxidermy in the world. Founded in 2012, Darwin, Sinke and van Tongeren is named for its two owners, Jaap Sinke and Ferry van Tongeren and, as they put it, their “sleeping” partner, Charles Darwin.

headline: Primary Wins Bring a Night of ‘Firsts’
abstract: Diverse candidates in Connecticut, Minnesota and Vermont advanced to the general election, potentially setting them up for historic wins in November.
lead_paragraph: Diverse candidates in Connecticut, Minnesota and Vermont advanced to the general election, potentially setting them up for historic wins in November.

headline: Genoa Bridge Collapse: Rescuers Use Drones to Survey Damage
abstract: Emergency workers in Italy continue to dig through the bridge’s rubble, as focus turns to the structure’s troubled past.
lead_paragraph: Emergency workers in Italy continue to dig through the bridge’s rubble, as focus turns to the structure’s troubled past.

headline: Think You Know What Your ETF Costs? Take a Closer Look
abstract: Investors tend to evaluate the cost of an ETF based on the expense ratio. But ETFs also come with other hidden costs that can eat into returns over time. Are you ready to become a cost hunter?
lead_paragraph: Investors tend to evaluate the cost of an ETF based on the expense ratio. But ETFs also come with other hidden costs that can eat into returns over time. Are you ready to become a cost hunter?

headline: ETF Costs Can Be Tricky
abstract: Investors tend to evaluate the cost of an ETF based on the expense ratio. But ETFs also come with other hidden costs that can eat into returns over time. Are you ready to become a cost hunter?
lead_paragraph: Investors tend to evaluate the cost of an ETF based on the expense ratio. But ETFs also come with other hidden costs that can eat into returns over time. Are you ready to become a cost hunter?

headline: Memphis Milano Returns, and Takes Over Fashion
abstract: The case for the loud colors and clashing patterns of the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: Memphis Milano, the Italian-born design movement of the 1980s, was the antithesis of minimalism. It was an orgy of loud colors, clashing patterns and big shapes, with little to tie it together. It’s an aesthetic that’s as confusing as it is unabashed, and perhaps that’s why it’s striking such a chord in these confusing times.

headline: From Masthead to Maître D’: Gabé Doppelt at Tower Bar
abstract: “Believe it, darling!”: A longtime magazine editor enters the hospitality industry.
lead_paragraph: The amber votive candles flickered with their usual sexy sophistication. As ever, the pillows on the beige suede banquettes had been perfectly plumped. A peek inside the reservation ledger revealed that nothing had changed about the clientele: studio moguls, fashion designers, literary agents, A-list movie stars.

headline: Transgender Girl, 12, Is Violently Threatened After Facebook Post by Classmate’s Parent
abstract: After becoming the target of a hateful online campaign, Maddie, a seventh grader in a small Oklahoma town, said, “I’m going to keep my head held up high.”
lead_paragraph: A 12-year-old transgender student in a small Oklahoma town near the Texas border was targeted in an inflammatory social media post by the parents of a classmate, leading to violent threats and driving officials to close the school for two days.

headline: Tesla Is Said to Be Subpoenaed by S.E.C. Over Elon Musk Tweet
abstract: The government is investigating Tesla after Mr. Musk said he had secured funding to take the electric-car company private, causing its shares to soar.
lead_paragraph: Federal securities regulators have served Tesla with a subpoena, according to a person familiar with the investigation, increasing pressure on the electric car company as it deals with the fallout from several recent actions by its chief executive, Elon Musk.

headline: Is Trump a Regular Guy? Yes, an Ex-Aide Says, Sometimes He Drives His Rolls-Royce
abstract: Corey Lewandowski, the president’s former campaign manager, told stories about a Rolls-Royce and a platinum American Express card in explaining how the president understands regular people.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Being a billionaire president sometimes means confronting doubts that you understand the lives of regular people. That’s especially true for President Trump, who has built a political reputation for caring about working-class people despite decades of gold-plated living arrangements.

headline: Evidence Against Manafort Is ‘Overwhelming,’ Prosecutors Say
abstract: In closing arguments, the special counsel’s office described Paul Manafort, the former Trump campaign chairman, as well versed in financial matters and motivated to commit fraud.
lead_paragraph: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — The evidence against Paul Manafort is “overwhelming,” a prosecutor told jurors during closing arguments in his fraud trial on Thursday, saying that he hid more than $16 million in income and fraudulently obtained $20 million in bank loans even though, as a trained lawyer, “Mr. Manafort knew the law.”

headline: ‘Castle Rock’ Season 1, Episode 6: Sound and Vision
abstract: This week, Henry Deaver’s combination of confusion and passivity leads him into one seriously freaky situation.
lead_paragraph: In a “Castle Rock” cast that includes the charismatic old pros Scott Glenn and Sissy Spacek and the quirky scene-stealer Melanie Lynskey, it’s easy to overlook how quietly excellent André Holland has been as Henry Deaver.

headline: Trump Revokes Ex-C.I.A. Director John Brennan’s Security Clearance
abstract: The White House cited “erratic” behavior by Mr. Brennan, who has frequently been a fierce critic of the president.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump revoked the security clearance of John O. Brennan, the former C.I.A. director under President Barack Obama, on Wednesday in a striking act of retaliation against an outspoken critic. The president threatened to do the same to other former national security officials who have antagonized him.

headline: What Must Survive a Corrupt Catholic Church
abstract: By making monasteries, of a sort, of our homes and hearts, we may develop the spiritual disciplines necessary to endure this seemingly endless trial.
lead_paragraph: I have a Catholic friend who lives in an exceptionally bad diocese and who for years has been heaving rocks up mountains to keep his faith strong and his family in church. His resilience has amazed me. Yesterday, after a grand jury report revealed that bishops and other leaders of the Roman Catholic Church in Pennsylvania covered up child sexual abuse by more than 300 priests over a period of 70 years, my friend, a tough-guy lawyer, wrote to tell me that he wept in his office. He said, “I am at the end.”

headline: Expressing Complicated Love for Lauryn Hill as an Iconic Album Turns 20
abstract: In “She Begat This: 20 Years of ‘The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill,’” Joan Morgan makes a case for Hill’s artistic and historical importance while also paying attention to the stickier parts of the star’s career.
lead_paragraph: A lot of people have a lot of thoughts (not to mention feelings) about the elusive hip-hop star Lauryn Hill, but only the journalist Joan Morgan could have written a slender book as capacious as this one. When Hill released her first and only full-length solo studio album in 1998, the ensuing critical and commercial success was so extraordinary that it fueled two decades’ worth of speculation about future projects and opinions about existing ones. With “She Begat This: 20 Years of ‘The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill,’” Morgan takes an album that was a cultural touchstone — the kind of work that elicits ardent devotion and ardent backlash — and holds it up to the light, showcasing its brilliance and its shadows.

headline: Does Your Identity Help Make Your Point?
abstract: Readers wrote about harnessing the power of their identities when offering an opinion, but without relying on it to do the work for them.
lead_paragraph: In the recent op-ed “Go Ahead, Speak for Yourself,” Kwame Anthony Appiah, a philosophy and law professor at New York University, asked, “What does it signify when people use this now ubiquitous formula (‘As a such-and-such, I …’) to affix an identity to an observation?”

headline: School Administrator ‘Stunned’ After Being Suspended Because She’s Married to a Woman
abstract: Shelly Fitzgerald, who works at a Catholic School in Indianapolis, was put on paid leave after school leaders got a copy of her marriage certificate.
lead_paragraph: For 15 years, Shelly Fitzgerald has worked as a guidance counselor and administrator at Roncalli High School, a Catholic school in Indianapolis.

headline: Uber’s Losses Continue in Its March Toward an I.P.O.
abstract: Uber’s latest quarterly results indicate little change to its financial trajectory under Dara Khosrowshahi, who took over a year ago.
lead_paragraph: Just over a year after Travis Kalanick was ousted as chief executive of Uber, the ride-hailing company released new financial results that showed continued growth and narrowing losses as it advances toward an initial public offering.

headline: Israel Is Proud of Who We Are
abstract: Some critics believe that a law defining Israel as the nation-state of the Jewish people is a threat to the Jewish people. This is audacious and preposterous.
lead_paragraph: Israel is no stranger to criticism. Both within our country and outside of it, there is no shortage of opportunity to debate and disagree. Recently, even many outsiders who claim to love Israel have taken to criticizing it. In these very pages, Ronald Lauder, the president of the World Jewish Congress, wrote recently about his concerns about what is happening to Israel, apparently reflecting the worries of others in the Jewish diaspora when he suggests that Israel is somehow too Jewish or that its democracy is under threat.

headline: The Street Where ‘They Do Strange Things’
abstract: Alice Sparberg Alexiou’s history of the Bowery, “Devil’s Mile,” is a narrative not only of the famous street but also of New York City.
lead_paragraph: DEVIL’S MILE The Rich, Gritty History of the Bowery By Alice Sparberg Alexiou Illustrated. 290 pp. St. Martin’s Press. $28.99.

headline: Keri Russell and Adam Driver Are Headed to Broadway Together
abstract: The pair will co-star in a revival of “Burn This” by Lanford Wilson, which comes to Broadway in March.
lead_paragraph: Two stars of the screen, Keri Russell and Adam Driver, are heading to Broadway. The pair has been cast in a revival of Lanford Wilson’s “Burn This,” which will open in March.

headline: Wigstock Returns From the Dead
abstract: The outdoor drag festival will feature Lady Bunny and Neil Patrick Harris on Sept. 1 at Pier 17 in Lower Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Sometime around 1984, a group of inebriated drag queens left the Pyramid Club in the East Village in Manhattan and wound up at Tompkins Square Park, where a spontaneous performance before a bunch of homeless people turned into a festival called Wigstock.

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
abstract: Paintings by Bruce Kurland and new photographs by his daughter Justine Kurland; Jonas Mekas’s experimental work; and Kiki Smith’s art at the Museum at Eldridge Street.
lead_paragraph: Through Aug. 31. Higher Pictures, 980 Madison Avenue, Manhattan; 212-249-6100, higherpictures.com.

headline: Palestinian Mail Reaches the West Bank, 8 Years Late
abstract: Ten tons of letters and packages, which Israel had prevented from entering the Palestinian territory of the West Bank, have finally been released.
lead_paragraph: Ten tons of letters and packages, which Israel had long prevented from reaching Palestinians in the occupied West Bank, have finally been delivered. Some of the pieces are eight years old.

headline: Trump’s Insults Across Racial Lines
abstract: Was the president’s tweet calling a black former aide “that dog” racist? A reader cites his harsh words about white critics as well.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: Ethan Hawke Is Just Right as a ’90s Indie-Rocker in ‘Juliet, Naked’
abstract: Rose Byrne and Chris O’Dowd also star in this adaptation of Nick Hornby’s novel.
lead_paragraph: “Juliet, Naked” — in which, just so you know, there is no nudity and nobody named Juliet — marks a milestone in the interminable Generation-X midlife crisis. Ethan Hawke becomes a grandpa. Is that a spoiler? A shocker? An occasion for tears? For schadenfreude?

headline: A Consequence of Ukraine’s War: Less Hunting, More Wolf Attacks
abstract: With hunting banned as far as 40 miles from the front line, pheasants and hares proliferate, drawing foxes and wolves into closer contact with people and pets.
lead_paragraph: USPENIVKA, Ukraine — Aleksandr Podlesnyi saw the lunge before he recognized the shape as a wolf.

headline: This Is Not the Way to Stop Homes From Flooding
abstract: The federal government is considering a plan that could cost taxpayers more money and encourage land speculation without addressing the problem.
lead_paragraph: A year ago this month, Hurricane Harvey lumbered ashore along the Texas Gulf Coast, stalling there for four days and dumping more than 60 inches of rain that would cause catastrophic flooding. It was the second-most costly hurricane in American history. Southeastern Texas has been digging out ever since.

headline: Norman Seabrook Guilty of Bribery in Trial That Cast Shadow Over De Blasio
abstract: A jury found the once-powerful leader of the correction officers’ union guilty of accepting a kickback to steer union funds to a hedge fund.
lead_paragraph: Norman Seabrook, the once-powerful former leader of the New York City correction officers’ union, was found guilty of bribery and conspiracy on Wednesday in a case that cast a shadow over Mayor Bill de Blasio’s fund-raising efforts and touched on corruption in the New York Police Department.

headline: Christine Hallquist on Her Primary Victory: ‘It Gives the Transgender Community Hope’
abstract: Ms. Hallquist, a Vermont Democrat, made history Tuesday night by becoming the first transgender nominee for governor from either major party. She spoke to The Times the next morning.
lead_paragraph: Christine Hallquist, the former chief executive of an electric utility company, made history on Tuesday when she beat three other candidates in Vermont’s Democratic primary to become the first transgender person to be nominated for a governorship by a major party.

headline: Why Turkey’s Crisis Feels Familiar for Emerging Markets: It’s the Debt
abstract: The country has unique challenges, but other emerging markets where big borrowing fueled rapid growth and strong returns could feel the pinch of a stronger dollar.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 10 years now, the flood of cash from global central banks has financed shopping malls in Istanbul, booming cities in China and 100-year bonds in Argentina. Today, many of the malls are empty, property developers in China are riddled with debt, and Argentina has just submitted to a bailout from the International Monetary Fund.

headline: A Free Press Needs You
abstract: Don’t just take it from us. Scores of publications from around the country are raising their voices.
lead_paragraph: Don’t just take it from us. Scores of publications from around the country are raising their voices.

headline: Cuomo Says America ‘Was Never That Great’ in Jab at Trump Slogan
abstract: Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s remark drew immediate criticism from his Republican opponent, Marcus Molinaro, who said the governor owed the nation an apology.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo mocked President Trump’s ubiquitous “Make America Great Again” campaign slogan on Wednesday, quickly drawing the ire of Republicans from New York to the White House for saying that America “was never that great.”

headline: A Question for Tesla’s Board: What Was Elon Musk’s Mental State?
abstract: The same traits that have made Mr. Musk a great entrepreneur also make him a potentially troublesome chief executive. Tesla’s board should act as a filter.
lead_paragraph: There’s no question that Elon Musk is one of the great entrepreneurs of this era. He may even be in “a class of one,” as he recently described Tesla, the revolutionary electric car company he founded.

headline: South Korea, John Brennan, Genoa: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Four Girls Fight Off Would-Be Kidnapper at Summer Festival
abstract: The girls kicked their attacker, scratched at his clothes and “threw iced coffee at him until he finally let go.”
lead_paragraph: The girls protected themselves the only way they knew how — kicking and scratching their attempted kidnapper and throwing a cup of iced coffee in his face.

headline: For 9 Hours, Cubans Got Internet in an Unusual Place: Everywhere
abstract: In order to post a picture to Facebook or send an email, Cubans must buy an access card and find a public hot spot. But a recent test hinted that this may soon change.
lead_paragraph: If you walk through Havana, you’ll usually see groups of people huddled around certain plazas, parks and side streets with their cellphones held up to their faces. These people are online.

headline: Awkwafina Reads ‘Single Woman Seeking Manwich’
abstract: The actor and rapper, now in “Crazy Rich Asians,” tells a story about the often dismal online dating scene.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever been rejected by … a sandwich? This week on Modern Love: the Podcast, the actor and rapper Awkwafina reads “Single Woman Seeking Manwich,” an essay about the often dismal online dating scene and the strange war stories it produces.

headline: ‘The Biggest Climate Story No One Is Talking About’
abstract: This week: Germany’s moment of reckoning, a new way to forecast future temperatures and the last of the fin whale hunters.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: An Epic Heroine in New York
abstract: The Bharatanatyam dancer Neha Mondal Chakravarty didn’t mind performing on a rainy city sidewalk: “Sometimes it’s about the bliss that you get in just exploring.”
lead_paragraph: #SpeakingInDance is a weekly visual exploration of dance on Instagram. Watch the video from our most recent post below, and follow us at @nytimes.

headline: Herbert Sperling, Drug Kingpin Tied to French Connection Case, Dies at 79
abstract: He was serving a life sentence for his role in importing heroin and was accused of plotting to murder the mastermind of the theft of drugs from the police.
lead_paragraph: Herbert Sperling, a convicted drug dealer from Hell’s Kitchen who was accused of ordering the execution of Vincent C. Papa, the fellow mobster who masterminded the brazen theft of 400 pounds of French Connection heroin and cocaine from a police vault, died on July 3 at a hospital near Ayer, Mass. He was 79.

headline: Overlooked No More: Sissieretta Jones, a Soprano Who Shattered Racial Barriers
abstract: She was the first African-American woman to headline a concert at Carnegie Hall, but she didn’t care for her stage name, “the Black Patti,” which compared her to a white diva.
lead_paragraph: Since 1851, obituaries in The New York Times have been dominated by white men. With Overlooked, we’re adding the stories of remarkable people whose deaths went unreported in The Times.

headline: John Smyth, Christian Camp Leader Accused of Beatings, Dies at 77
abstract: He left Britain after an inquiry found he had brutally beaten young men at elite camps. But he was never prosecuted and went on to open similar camps in Africa.
lead_paragraph: John Smyth, an evangelical Christian leader and anti-gay campaigner who was dogged by allegations that he physically abused boys at elite Christian summer camps but was never formally charged, died on Saturday at his home in Bergvliet, South Africa, near Cape Town. He was 77.

headline: Any Weight Loss Can Be Healthful, but More Can Be Much Better
abstract: Overweight people who lost 5 to 10 percent of their weight lowered their risk for metabolic syndrome by 22 percent. Those who lost 20 percent cut their risk by over 50 percent.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to losing weight, more can be better. A lot better, according to a new study.

headline: E.U. Sees Real Brexit Talks at Last — and Real Dangers
abstract: With the British government so fragile, the European Union is discussing how to finesse the real state of the talks to protect Prime Minister Theresa May and avoid a cliff edge.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — From the start of the torturous negotiations over Brexit, as Britain’s exit from the European Union is known, the talks have followed an all too familiar dynamic.

headline: 5:47 Train? Grab a Bottle of Pinot (and a Few Plastic Cups)
abstract: Blink and you could miss it: Between Tracks 16 and 17 on the lower level is Penn Station’s only liquor store. Customers, understandably, are devoted.
lead_paragraph: During evening rush hour, the ebb and flow of commuters who visit Pennsylvania Station’s only liquor store resembles a wave crashing into, and then retreating, from the shore.

headline: Anomaly or Omen? A House Republican Tells Voters He ‘Stood Up’ to Trump
abstract: With many Republicans courting the president and others afraid to criticize him, an Ohio congressman has gingerly created a small crack in the wall, risking Trumpian wrath.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A low-profile Republican congressman from northeast Ohio has gone where few in his party have dared this campaign season: He has bragged to his constituents that he has stood up to President Trump.

headline: Ignore, Condescend, Dismiss: Debate Playbook for Men Facing Women
abstract: An offer to Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez highlights how male candidates often use debates to diminish female opponents, perhaps increasingly at their peril.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Ben Shapiro, the right-wing pundit, elicited outrage on his behalf from conservatives when he asked the Democratic congressional candidate Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez to debate him and she said that she did not owe a response “to unsolicited requests from men with bad intentions.”

headline: Protesters in Russia Accuse Government of Entrapping Young Critics
abstract: As the number of Russian teenagers arrested on extremism charges rises significantly, parents and others accuse the government of silencing dissent.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Hundreds of demonstrators walked through downtown Moscow on Wednesday to protest against a growing number of arrests of young Russians on extremism charges for material shared or stored on social media sites.

headline: Report Finds Traces of a Controversial Herbicide in Cheerios and Quaker Oats
abstract: The herbicide glyphosate is the world’s most popular weedkiller. There is widespread disagreement among lawyers, researchers and regulators over any potential links to cancer.
lead_paragraph: An environmental research and advocacy group has found traces of a controversial herbicide in Cheerios, Quaker Oats and other breakfast foods that it says could increase cancer risk for children.

headline: Are Targeted Ads Stalking You? Here’s How to Make Them Stop
abstract: Ever been haunted by an online ad for an item you researched or bought? Targeted ads were designed to follow you around everywhere. Here’s how to banish them.
lead_paragraph: Online ads have always been annoying, but now they’re worse than ever.

headline: After Taliban Siege of Ghazni, Afghans Tell of Fear and Deprivation
abstract: The siege was the latest example of ordinary Afghans caught between Taliban violence and a government that leaves them vulnerable.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Some of the earliest aid that arrived in Ghazni, a strategic city under siege by the Taliban for days, included body bags and medical supplies, food and water for thousands of residents, and coffins for 250.

headline: Jahana Hayes Was Told She ‘Had No Chance.’ She, and Voters, Beg to Differ.
abstract: Overcoming a life of early poverty and homelessness, Ms. Hayes is now poised to become the first black Democrat to represent Connecticut in Congress.
lead_paragraph: It was about a minute into Jahana Hayes’s victory speech, which, to that point, consisted of two words — “Wow,” she said twice, gathering her composure — when she recalled the launch of her unlikely campaign for Congress just 102 days earlier, “with no money, no network, no people.”

headline: 44 Small Graves Stir Questions About U.S. Policy in Yemen
abstract: An airstrike by a Saudi-led coalition on a bus carrying Yemeni children casts new light on the United States’ role in the war there.
lead_paragraph: DAHYAN, Yemen — The boys crammed into the bus, their thin bodies packed three to a seat, with latecomers jammed in the aisle. They fidgeted with excitement about the day’s field trip, talking so loudly that a tall boy struggling to get their attention put his hands over his ears and yelled.

headline: Was the U.S. Actually ‘Built on Tariffs,’ as Trump Says?
abstract: We took a look at the evidence for President Trump’s claim, which appeared to refer to a period starting in the late 19th century.
lead_paragraph: What He Said

headline: Gunshots Fired on Set of 50 Cent and 6ix9ine Music Video
abstract: No one was reported hurt after multiple gunshots were fired Tuesday in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, where the rappers were filming.
lead_paragraph: Shots were fired along the Brooklyn waterfront on Tuesday night during the filming of a music video by the New York rappers 50 Cent and 6ix9ine, the police said. No one was reported hurt.

headline: Paul Manafort, Trump, Opioids: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Jack Dempsey’s Place
abstract: Hoping for an autograph from the Manassa Mauler.
lead_paragraph: After this week, individual Metropolitan Diary items will no longer be posted online. Starting Monday, Aug. 27, the full column will appear weekly online as it does in print.

headline: ‘We Are Tired of Crying for the Dead’: A Stunned Genoa Mourns
abstract: At a morgue in Italy, people looking for the missing after a bridge collapse dreaded what they might find. Residents wondered how they would get across the city.
lead_paragraph: GENOA, Italy — All day Wednesday outside the austere building that houses Genoa’s morgue, parents, children, friends and colleagues of possible victims of a collapsed bridge entered, dreading what they might find.

headline: ‘It’s Really Hard to Be a Catholic’: The Pain of Reading the Sex Abuse Report
abstract: Catholics around the country said they felt frustrated with the church’s leadership.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — John Cabon stood quietly and crossed himself before a statue of the Virgin Mary outside St. Paul’s, the mother church of the Pittsburgh Diocese.

headline: Hold the Phone! My Unsettling Discoveries About How Our Gestures Online Are Tracked
abstract: As I learned about companies that track “behavioral biometric” data, I developed a jarring mental image of computers silently recording my clicks, pauses, mouse swoops and typos.
lead_paragraph: I was nearing the end of a five-hour marathon of meetings about Mastercard’s cybersecurity efforts when an executive made a passing comment that snapped me out of my mild stupor.

headline: The Virtues of Catholic Anger
abstract: In the face of the Pennsylvania abuse scandal, Christians should use their rage to combat evil within the church.
lead_paragraph: Every American Catholic I know is angry — with good reason. The recent release of a grand jury investigation into 70 years of sexual abuse by priests in Pennsylvania is appalling in its breadth and detail.

headline: Would My Family Pass an ‘Australian Values Test’?
abstract: The government focuses on “integration” and insists on the strength of Australian multiculturalism, but seems to worry that it is vulnerable. My parents tell another story.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — When I was growing up, there were times when my corner of Sydney did not feel all that Australian.

headline: Morgana King, Jazz Singer and ‘Godfather’ Actor, Is Dead at 87
abstract: A well-regarded singing career brought her some fame, but probably not as much as her small part as Vito Corleone’s wife.
lead_paragraph: Before March 1972, Morgana King was known as a jazz singer with an impressive vocal range and an ability to put a distinctive spin on an eclectic selection of songs. But by late that month, although she remained an accomplished singer, millions of moviegoers thought of her as Vito Corleone’s wife.

headline: Lyric McHenry, Reality TV Star, Is Dead After Being Found Unconscious in Bronx
abstract: Ms. McHenry, 26, the daughter of a Hollywood producer, was discovered lying on a sidewalk near a highway. Her body showed no signs of trauma, the police said.
lead_paragraph: Lyric McHenry, the reality television star and daughter of a Hollywood producer, was found unconscious on an overpass in the Bronx on Tuesday morning, the authorities said. Ms. McHenry, who was 26, was later pronounced dead at Bronx-Lebanon Hospital, the police said.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Speakers, Students, Activists, Survivors
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, August 16, 2018.
lead_paragraph: “Let us have a childhood. This is not something we should have to worry about.”

headline: Bannon’s New Group Issues a Midterm Plea: Save Trump
abstract: The group is Stephen K. Bannon’s new vehicle since he was pushed out of the White House last year. Trump advisers say Mr. Bannon is just promoting himself.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Stephen K. Bannon, the former White House chief strategist, is forming a group to try to sell voters on a midterm message that they should support Republicans to defend the Trump agenda and save the president from impeachment.

headline: Why the Explosive Report on Catholic Church Abuse Is Unlikely to Yield Criminal Charges
abstract: Legal barriers, political opposition and fierce lobbying efforts by the Catholic Church have kept Pennsylvania’s courthouse doors closed to childhood victims who came forward later in life.
lead_paragraph: The searing grand jury report issued Tuesday in Pennsylvania that accuses bishops and other Roman Catholic Church leaders in that state of covering up child sexual abuse by more than 300 priests has prompted growing calls for justice, while leaving Americans wondering about the broader impact of the revelations on the church and other institutions.

headline: New Haven Overdoses Tied to Laced K2
abstract: More than 70 people were taken to a hospital after overdosing on a batch of synthetic marijuana that the police believe was laced with an opioid.
lead_paragraph: A park in the shadow of Yale’s Old Campus became the scene of a mass overdose on Wednesday as ambulance crews rushed from person to person, desperately treating dozens of semiconscious and disoriented drug users in New Haven.

headline: Think There Are Too Many Bars in Your Neighborhood? You’re Not Alone
abstract: The number of establishments licensed to sell liquor in New York City is going up. Now a coalition of community groups is trying to tap the brakes.
lead_paragraph: A resident of Inwood testified to trash-strewn streets and violence in her corner of Manhattan, while a woman from the Upper West Side lamented the departure of a shoemaker and barbershop. A man from Williamsburg, Brooklyn, complained that his community was “overrun.”

headline: Trump and the Politics of Arf
abstract: The president: still neurotically insecure after all these years …
lead_paragraph: I am beginning to worry that when I die, the highlight of my obituary will be that I was once called “a dog” by Donald Trump.

headline: Adam Jones’s Bond With Baltimore Means More Than a Ring
abstract: Jones vetoed a trade to a contending team so he could spend the rest of the season with the Orioles in a city he has grown to love and defend.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — With Baltimore’s baseball team careening through a dismal season, on pace to lose more than 110 games for the first time since they became the Orioles in 1954, its front office decided to dismantle the roster to build for the future.

headline: Editors’ Note: August 16, 2018
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Thursday, August 16, 2018.
lead_paragraph: OBITUARIES

headline: Little-Known Justice Dept. Official Makes Trump’s Security Clearance List
abstract: Critics said the inclusion of Bruce Ohr on the list of those whose clearances were revoked or under review was an abuse of presidential power and an intrusion on the independence of law enforcement.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the White House announced on Wednesday that President Trump was revoking or reviewing the security clearances of former officials who have emerged as some of his chief political antagonists, the list also included a little-known career Justice Department official, Bruce Ohr.

headline: Readers Respond to the 8.5.18 Issue
abstract: Here’s what they had to say about the decade we almost stopped climate change.
lead_paragraph: RE: LOSING EARTH

headline: You Talkin’ to Me?
abstract: Alan Arbesfeld wishes someone a happy birthday.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — We have a tribute puzzle from Alan Arbesfeld today, and it serves as both a fan letter and a birthday card. Let’s help Mr. Arbesfeld celebrate.

headline: Ronald Acuña Jr. Hit With First Pitch, Prompting Calls for Pitcher’s Suspension
abstract: The Atlanta Braves phenom was hit with the first pitch he saw from Miami’s Jose Ureña in what may have been an attempt to slow down the streaking slugger.
lead_paragraph: Ronald Acuña Jr. of the Atlanta Braves appeared to be a victim of one of baseball’s many unwritten rules on Wednesday, but thanks to one of the written rules his record-tying home run streak will remain intact whenever he is able to play again.

headline: In a Proxy Fight for the Party’s Future, a New Face Presses Her Democratic Opponent
abstract: In their final debate in a Massachusetts congressional race, Ayanna Pressley challenges Michael Capuano over abortion funding, Trump’s wall and gun control.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — In one of the last Democratic congressional primaries where a woman of color is hoping to unseat a white male incumbent, the challenger used their final debate on Wednesday to aggressively question her opponent’s commitment to party principles.

headline: ISIS Member Arrested in Sacramento, U.S. Says
abstract: Omar Ameen, 45, who is also a longtime member of Al Qaeda, lied to obtain refugee status in 2014, prosecutors say.
lead_paragraph: Federal authorities said Wednesday they had arrested an Iraqi citizen and longtime member of Al Qaeda and the Islamic State who fled after killing an Iraqi police officer in 2014, eventually settling in Sacramento as a purported refugee.

headline: Luis Cessa Wilts in Replacement Start as Yankees Fall to Rays
abstract: Cessa, called up from Class AAA to fill in for the injured C.C. Sabathia, was knocked around by the Rays.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees were low on options for a replacement starter on Wednesday after placing C.C. Sabathia on the 10-day disabled list two days before he was scheduled to start.

headline: 60 Times Madonna Changed Our Culture
abstract: Power. Innovation. Identity. Madonna has blended all of these and much more into a singular career in music, fashion, movies and beyond. For her 60th birthday, we assessed her broad and deep influence.
lead_paragraph: Power. Innovation. Identity. Madonna has blended all of these and much more into a singular career in music, fashion, movies and beyond. For her 60th birthday, we assessed her broad and deep influence.

headline: Pro-Trump Fan of Social Distortion Says Lead Singer Punched Him at Concert
abstract: Tim Hildebrand, a Republican, said he was beaten by Mike Ness after he held up his middle finger at the stage in protest of an anti-Trump diatribe by Mr. Ness.
lead_paragraph: The police in Sacramento are investigating an allegation that the lead singer of the pop-punk band Social Distortion punched a fan who protested his diatribe against President Trump during a concert last month.

headline: Genoa, Turkey, Elon Musk: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Qatar’s BeIN Sports Says It Has Proof of Saudi Role in Piracy Dispute
abstract: As European soccer’s top leagues begin another season, the world’s biggest pirate TV network, beoutQ, is back on the airwaves too.
lead_paragraph: As European soccer’s top leagues begin another season, the world’s biggest pirate television network is back on the airwaves too.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘Snowfall’ and ‘The Great Food Truck Race’
abstract: A new episode of “Snowfall” debuts and “The Great Food Truck Race” competitors head to Yuma, Ariz.
lead_paragraph: A new episode of “Snowfall” debuts and “The Great Food Truck Race” competitors head to Yuma, Ariz.

headline: Get to Know Besha Rodell. And Maureen Dowd Is on Her Way to Sydney.
abstract: This week’s Australia Letter gives you a chance to connect with two of our terrific journalists.
lead_paragraph: The Australia Letter is a weekly newsletter reflecting the experience (and quirks) of our Australia bureau chief. Sign up to get it by email. Here’s where to find all our Australia and New Zealand coverage.

headline: For Some Viewers, ‘Crazy Rich Asians’ Is Not Asian Enough
abstract: In Singapore, where the film was largely shot, detractors say the cast is unrepresentative of diversity in the city-state.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — “Crazy Rich Asians,” a romantic comedy that opened in the United States on Wednesday, is a rare commodity: a Hollywood film with a majority Asian cast. For many Asian-American viewers, that is a positive, if sorely belated, development.

headline: Shahidul Alam: A Singular Voice in Photography for Dignity and Human Rights
abstract: Over three decades, the photographer has covered major events, natural disasters and the struggle against governmental abuses. Now he is in jail in Bangladesh.
lead_paragraph: Shahidul Alam grimaced as he staggered on his way into a Dhaka courthouse on Aug. 6. Handcuffed and surrounded by the police, he loudly proclaimed he had been tortured after more than 30 plainclothes officers snatched him from his home the night before.

headline: 11-Year-Old Bride of Malaysian Man Is Returned to Thailand
abstract: The girl’s marriage to a man 30 years her senior highlighted the prevalence of child brides in Malaysia, which belies the country’s modern outlook.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — An 11-year-old bride to a Malaysian man 30 years her senior has returned to her native Thailand, where she is under the care of the local social welfare department.

headline: Our Hubris Will Be Our End
abstract: Then we’ll adapt and start telling ourselves new stories, just as humans have always done.
lead_paragraph: You can walk to the beach from where we are staying. It’s a long peel of dun-colored sand bordered by tidy rainbow summer houses, monotonous black and white condos and monstrous blue McMansions that blister the length of the Delmarva Peninsula. On the other side of the sand lies the heaving, implacable mass of unfathomable gray-green water that covers nearly three-quarters of the globe, once a boundary between the known and unknown, a limit-space of mystery and terror, now tamed, or so we think, to a vacation fun zone. There are lifeguards, though, lean summer kids with lazy tans, and to the north, rising from the low trees, towers built to defend the American coastline from Nazi subs.

headline: Poem: Bamboo, the Dance
abstract: Selected by Rita Dove.
lead_paragraph: Paul Celan’s harrowing Holocaust incantation, “Death Fugue,” is the apparent inspiration for this poem by Marilyn Chin, a withering takedown of our so-called global diplomacy. The immigrant’s dream of a better life, “free and lush,” deteriorates as she is swept up into a vicious cycle of ethnic and gender bias. Storybook rhymes turn sinister, and ancient totems are buried under the unrelenting cadence of a New World tarantella — xenophobia and nationalism exacting their murderous toll while “the bamboo grows and grows.” Selected by Rita Dove

headline: A 28-Year-Old Novice, She Took on the Machine and Won
abstract: Much like Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, Julia Fahl, a first-time candidate in New Jersey, took advantage of an energized Democratic base to defeat a mayor who started serving the year she was born.
lead_paragraph: LAMBERTVILLE, N.J. — The welcome mat at the entryway to the home of this town’s likely next mayor reads, “The Patriarchy.”

headline: Democrats Calling for New Leadership
abstract: Here are the candidates who are calling for new leadership if Democrats win back the House.
lead_paragraph: Here are the candidates who are calling for new leadership if Democrats win back the House.

headline: How Your Brain Morphs Stressful Family Vacations Into Pleasant Memories
abstract: There may be a lot of bickering, but your memory creates a nostalgia-inducing highlight reel that makes you want to plan the next trip.
lead_paragraph: In 2015, my husband and I traveled to Washington, D.C., for our annual family vacation with our energetic son, who was then 8. There were no mishaps or disasters, but my husband and I spent most of our time bickering and stressed out.

headline: How Karate Helped an Aging Expert Age Better
abstract: The ancient Greek karate style known as pankration offers time-tested lessons on aging well.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Kirk Daffner, 61, paused briefly to center himself before he began the first of more than 108 carefully orchestrated maneuvers. He lunged, rolled, did one-armed push-ups and slapped the mat with his open hand. He jumped in the air spread-eagled, touching his feet, then grunted as he kicked at an unseen foe, his hands balled into fists or fingers extended, chopping the empty air.

headline: How to Enjoy a Ski Destination When It’s Not Ski Season
abstract: Just because the slopes are bare doesn’t mean you shouldn’t visit a ski resort. From wildlife tours to stargazing, many have more to offer in the warm months than you may think.
lead_paragraph: Vail, Colo., Jackson Hole, Wyo., and Park City, Utah, may all be mainstay skiing destinations, but trips to their resorts — or those in any other ski spot in the United States for that matter — shouldn’t be confined to ski season. Pamela Lenci, general manager of Caldera House, a new hotel in Jackson Hole, said that top ski locales offer plenty of diversions in the summer and fall, too.

headline: A Critic Who Worships Literature, and Defends His Faith Accordingly
abstract: In his passionate new essay collection, “American Audacity,” William Giraldi fiercely emphasizes the cultural importance of high literary standards.
lead_paragraph: AMERICAN AUDACITY In Defense of Literary Daring By William Giraldi 462 pp. Liveright. $30.

headline: Rebecca Solnit: By the Book
abstract: The author, most recently, of the essay collection “Call Them by Their True Names: American Crises” keeps an eye on the “daily eruptions of the internet”: “Like a lot of us, I’m hypervigilant about the crazy stuff going on.”
lead_paragraph: The author, most recently, of the essay collection “Call Them by Their True Names: American Crises” keeps an eye on the “daily eruptions of the internet”: “Like a lot of us, I’m hypervigilant about the crazy stuff going on.”

headline: Keanu Reeves Is Doing a New Thing: Publishing Books
abstract: The actor and his business partner, the visual artist Alexandra Grant, have created X Artists’ Books, an imprint full of esoteric titles.
lead_paragraph: IN THE MODERN pastime of thinking about Keanu Reeves, a few images endure: the monastic undercover F.B.I. agent in “Point Break,” the monastic prophesied savior of an oppressed future in “The Matrix,” the monastic emissary from an alien planet in “The Day the Earth Stood Still.” Of these, “monastic art-book publisher” is perhaps less immediate, though, as of last year, it’s no less accurate. Since the summer, X Artists’ Books, a small press that Reeves launched in Los Angeles with the visual artist Alexandra Grant, has been producing aggressively esoteric titles of the kind that wouldn’t fly at larger imprints.

headline: More Strikeouts Than Hits? Welcome to Baseball’s Latest Crisis
abstract: This could be the first season in major league history to feature more strikeouts than hits, a slowdown that worries many league officials.
lead_paragraph: One thing you learn from studying baseball history is that people have always predicted the sport’s demise. Over and over, the game weathers every perceived crisis and continues to thrive. More than 70 million fans will attend major league games this season; another 40 million or so will go to minor league games. Countless more watch the sport on television and online.

headline: In Kentucky House Race, a Battle of Ideology vs. Résumé
abstract: A year ago, Representative Andy Barr was thought to hold a safe House Republican seat in Kentucky. Then came the candidacy of the Democrat Amy McGrath.
lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, Ky. — One morning last week, Representative Andy Barr stood on a podium to celebrate the renaming of Veterans Affairs facilities here for two local World War II heroes, the result of legislation the congressman had sponsored.

headline: 36 Hours in Istria
abstract: Truffle aficionados aren’t the only ones who will appreciate this food lover’s paradise in northern Croatia. Ancient hill towns, craggy shorelines and a rich history are only a few of the peninsula’s other attractions.
lead_paragraph: Spend enough time on this verdant peninsula and someone will tell you: “I have a friend here who has lived in four different countries and never moved.” A 100-year-old Istrian, for example, would be able to say that she was born in Austro-Hungary (which ended in 1918), came of age when Istria was part of Italy (until 1947), spent most of her adult years as a Yugoslavian, and, finally, starting in 1991, became Croatian.

headline: Reeling From the ‘Year Without a Sam’s Club,’ Alaskans Wonder: What’s Next?
abstract: A primary election Tuesday is expected to set up a tense, three-way race for governor as Alaska reaches a crossroads. Will outside forces set the state’s fate?
lead_paragraph: FAIRBANKS, Alaska — Monica Laakso, a bar manager married to a utility lineman, saw her monthly food bill jump by $200. The Fairbanks Senior Center had to eliminate cookie treats from its Meals on Wheels program. And Benny Lin, owner of the Pagoda Restaurant, got a shock when the price of salt tripled just about overnight.

headline: The Paul Manafort Trial: What the Jurors Will Consider
abstract: In weighing whether to find Paul Manafort guilty or not of financial fraud charges, jurors will have to take into account evidence, witness credibility and other factors.
lead_paragraph: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — Jury deliberations began on Wednesday in the trial of Paul Manafort, President Trump’s former campaign chairman, who is charged with 18 counts of bank and tax fraud. The prosecution called 27 witnesses and presented 388 documents, including Mr. Manafort’s financial records and emails. The defense rested without calling any witnesses, which is not uncommon.

headline: Pelosi, Under Threat in Her Own Party, Says She Is Building Bridge to New Leaders
abstract: Nancy Pelosi, the House Democratic leader, is confronting threats from different corners of her party, and attacks from Republicans, in a test of her grip on her caucus.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Pelosi is girding for a mortal challenge to her leadership of the Democratic Party after the November elections or even sooner, and in a signal of reassurance to anxious lawmakers says that she is deliberately building a “bridge” to a new generation of party leaders.

headline: California Fires: What Travelers Need to Know
abstract: Wildfires have limited access to areas in several major parks in recent days, including Yosemite. Here is where things stand now.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a record-setting year for wildfires in California, especially Northern California. Among three major blazes, one threatened Yosemite National Park and another became the largest in state history.

headline: Where ‘Block Party’ Has a Score of Meanings
abstract: In Brooklyn, young artists reconsider a summer ritual, that is part celebration, part town-hall meeting.
lead_paragraph: Crushed cans, old playing cards, burned out cigarette butts, a lone, fading and bright red bow — the beauty and detritus of urban life — were culled from the streets by Kahlil Robert Irving, a 26-year-old artist who has mixed found objects into a collagraphic print hanging in a turn-of-the-century Brooklyn limestone that houses the Jenkins Johnson Projects.

headline: Trevor Noah Assails White House for Dodging N-Word Question
abstract: “I feel like this should be the easiest question ever,” Noah said about whether President Trump had used a racist slur.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: Our Blind Spots Often Hide the Truth About America
abstract: Responding to readers, the author of a recent Op-Ed about “Trump Country” says that we must remain vigilant against easy, reductive frameworks and labels.
lead_paragraph: Editor’s note: An Op-Ed by Sarah Smarsh, “Liberal Blind Spots Are Hiding the Truth About ‘Trump Country,’” received more than 1,500 comments from readers. Here are a selection of the comments, which raised questions that we put to the author.

headline: This Is Your Brain on Omarosa
abstract: We are determined not to be distracted from the important news of the week.
lead_paragraph: There will be no mention of Omarosa in today’s column. None. There are things that matter — the parlous military situation in Afghanistan, for example — and Omarosa and her explosive new tell-all, “Unhinged: An Insider’s Account of the Trump White House,” which is published by Gallery Books, a division of Simon & Schuster, just isn’t one of them.

headline: A Gay Wedding Is a Wedding. Just a Wedding.
abstract: There are some things you shouldn’t say or do, and some you should, when attending the wedding of a same-sex couple.
lead_paragraph: When Jove Meyer, a wedding and event planner in Brooklyn, is working with a same-sex couple, he sometimes finds himself cringing when he hears a guest use the term “gay wedding.”

headline: A Paid Family Leave Plan That Congress Might Actually Pass
abstract: Marco Rubio’s proposal is pragmatic, flexible and doesn’t raise taxes. It’s Americans’ best shot at getting paid family leave.
lead_paragraph: Early this month, Senator Marco Rubio introduced the Economic Security for New Parents Act, a proposal for paid family leave that is modeled after one that I developed. The idea is to offer new parents the option of collecting Social Security benefits for at least two months in return for deferring their retirement age for the period of time necessary to offset the cost.

headline: New York Today: A Playlist for Commutes
abstract: Thursday: Tunes for your trip to and from work, and Grand Central Reads to whet your literary appetite.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this feverish Thursday.

headline: La Liga Will Bring Regular-Season Matches to America
abstract: Spain’s top soccer league, looking to increase its audience and the value of its media rights, will venture where other leagues have been loath to go.
lead_paragraph: American professional sports leagues have long played regular-season games abroad to expand their international fan bases: Major League Baseball games in Tokyo, N.B.A. games in London, and N.F.L. games in Toronto and Mexico City.

headline: Are We Now Electing Supreme Court Justices?
abstract: Sure seems like it, from watching the TV ads for and against Brett Kavanaugh.
lead_paragraph: Unless you’ve been hiding under a rock — an ever more appealing prospect this summer — you have no doubt noticed the televised election campaign being waged for Judge Brett Kavanaugh’s elevation to the Supreme Court.

headline: John Brennan: President Trump’s Claims of No Collusion Are Hogwash
abstract: That’s why the president revoked my security clearance: to try to silence anyone who would dare challenge him.
lead_paragraph: When Alexander Bortnikov, the head of Russia’s internal security service, told me during an early August 2016 phone call that Russia wasn’t interfering in our presidential election, I knew he was lying. Over the previous several years I had grown weary of Mr. Bortnikov’s denials of Russia’s perfidy — about its mistreatment of American diplomats and citizens in Moscow, its repeated failure to adhere to cease-fire agreements in Syria and its paramilitary intervention in eastern Ukraine, to name just a few issues.

headline: A Culture of Secrecy That Perpetuated Abuse
abstract: A sweeping report issued by a grand jury in Pennsylvania sheds new light on the systemic nature of sexual abuse in the Catholic Church.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Aretha Franklin, Paul Manafort, ‘Crazy Rich Asians’: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Keïta Gets 2nd Term as Mali President With Runoff Victory
abstract: President Ibrahim Boubacar Keïta was declared the victor after a second round of voting and despite his opponents’ claims of electoral fraud.
lead_paragraph: BAMAKO, Mali — President Ibrahim Boubacar Keïta of Mali claimed an overwhelming victory on Thursday in a runoff vote after a controversial first round of voting last month that was marred by insecurity and allegations of electoral fraud.

headline: How to Spruce Up for Asian Games? Cover a Polluted River
abstract: The so-called Black River has been hidden by a nylon net with lights atop it so athletes don’t see one of Jakarta’s more embarrassing eyesores.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — With thousands of Asia’s top athletes preparing to descend on the Indonesian capital for the start of the 2018 Asian Games this weekend, city officials were in crisis mode about a heavily polluted river behind the athletes’ village.

headline: DealBook Briefing: Tencent, and the Markets, Are Hurting. Blame Beijing.
abstract: A crackdown on gaming weighed heavily on the fortunes of the Chinese internet giant. Investors worldwide worry that the pain could spread.
lead_paragraph: Good Thursday morning. (Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.)

headline: Review: In ‘Memoir of War,’ a Writer Awaits Her Husband’s Return
abstract: Mélanie Thierry is an enigmatic Marguerite Duras in this film based on Duras’s semi-autobiographical novel.
lead_paragraph: Marguerite Duras (who died in 1996 at 81 and was well known for the novel “The Lover”) was an unconventional writer, and by all accounts she lived life unconventionally as well. “Memoir of War,” adapted from her 1985 book that was in part derived from her diaries of occupied France in World War II, depicts the writer as a young woman (Mélanie Thierry) emotionally rived by loss. But she is determined to hold on to her identity as she awaits a reunion with a husband who might not be coming home.

headline: Review: In ‘Notes on an Appearance,’ the Hipster Vanishes
abstract: Watching Ricky D’Ambrose’s experimental mystery film requires learning how to watch it.
lead_paragraph: In “Notes on an Appearance,” a controversial political theorist who haunts the action has written a book called “Everything Is Permitted.” That phrase might well have been the guiding philosophy of this experimental mystery film. The writer and director, Ricky D’Ambrose, has called it a “scrapbook movie.” Watching it requires learning how to watch it. Static shots are edited in a deliberately primitive style, eliding crucial bits of narrative. The camera often fixates on ostensible clues: a postcard, books, mysterious home movies in which no one is seen.

headline: Review: ‘Do You Trust This Computer?’ The Quick Answer: Nope
abstract: The documentary looks at artificial intelligence and warns of a very dangerous world that’s soon to come.
lead_paragraph: “We’ve opened Pandora’s box: We’ve unleashed forces that we can’t control, and we can’t stop. We’re in the midst of essentially creating a new life form on Earth.”

headline: Review: In ‘We the Animals,’ Three Brothers Rush Toward Maturity
abstract: Jeremiah Zagar’s elemental coming-of-age tale follows mixed-race siblings in upstate New York.
lead_paragraph: A tiny, uncut gem of a movie, “We the Animals” is the first narrative feature from the nonfiction filmmaker Jeremiah Zagar and, as such, its subordination of plot to character and observation makes perfect sense. Most of that observation is through the eyes of Jonah (Evan Rosado), the film’s occasional narrator and the youngest of three preteen brothers in a mixed-race, blue-collar family in upstate New York. On one level, then, “We the Animals” is a classic coming-of age tale; on another, it’s a near perfect depiction of the emotional damage that can result from economic insecurity.

headline: Review: ‘A Whale of a Tale’ Fights Back Against ‘The Cove’
abstract: Megumi Sasaki’s disgruntled documentary attempts to balance Louie Psihoyos’s 2009 film about dolphin capture and slaughter.
lead_paragraph: Presented as a counterweight to “The Cove” — Louie Psihoyos’s Oscar-winning 2009 documentary about dolphin capture and slaughter in Taiji, Japan — Megumi Sasaki’s “A Whale of a Tale” is a rambling blend of complaint, tourism and straw-men arguments. What it’s not is persuasive.

headline: Review: ‘Puppet Master: The Littlest Reich’ Releases Murderous Nazi Dolls
abstract: This prurient reboot of the “Puppet Master” has unsuspecting conventioneers under attack by dolls.
lead_paragraph: An operatic aria of sleaze and slaughter, “Puppet Master: The Littlest Reich” reboots the deadly-doll franchise that began in 1989 with the campy “Puppet Master.” But while you don’t require familiarity with the dozen or so earlier titles to enjoy this one, you do require a sense of humor that’s easily triggered and a gag reflex that isn’t.

headline: Review: Ghosts and Goofiness Haunt ‘Down a Dark Hall’
abstract: In Rodrigo Cortés’s teen horror movie, a boarding school has haunts along its hallways.
lead_paragraph: Kit (AnnaSophia Robb) is a typical movie teenager — complete with psychiatric prescriptions, visions of her dead father and accusations of being an unhinged pyromaniac. Her mother’s last hope is to send Kit to Blackwood Boarding School, a dusty academy which promises to unveil the potential of five specially selected students.

headline: As Carson Wentz Recovers, Nick Foles Waits in the Wings. Again.
abstract: Three weeks until the Eagles’ season opener, Wentz, the star quarterback who had knee surgery in December, is not sure whether he will play that night.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Carson Wentz stood at the line of scrimmage Tuesday morning, his arms outstretched, and waited for his cue. Dropping back, Wentz spun right and rolled left, and there, as he prepared to throw toward a receiver stationed along the sideline, he confronted a pass-rusher — a Philadelphia Eagles staffer swatting a vinyl shield.

headline: Review: ‘The Wife’ Looks Behind the Closed Doors of a Literary Marriage
abstract: Jonathan Pryce, Glenn Close and Christian Slater dig into meaty roles in this adaptation of Meg Wolitzer’s 2003 novel.
lead_paragraph: “The Wife” pulls off the not inconsiderable feat of spinning a fundamentally literary premise into an intelligent screen drama that unfolds with real juice and suspense. Adapted from Meg Wolitzer’s 2003 novel, the film pivots on the marriage between a celebrated author, Joe Castleman (Jonathan Pryce), and his wife, Joan (Glenn Close), whose symbiotic relationship has had profound implications for his success.

headline: Review: ‘Alpha’ Explains How Man’s Best Friend Got That Way
abstract: A soulful boy bonds with a soulful beast, 20,000 years ago, in this solo feature debut by the director Albert Hughes.
lead_paragraph: Literature and cinema have served up dozens, if not hundreds, of “boy and his dog” stories over the years, but “Alpha” may be a genre first: an origin tale.

headline: In Edinburgh, the Plays Are Short (and Some Are Sweet)
abstract: There are hundreds of shows to see in the Edinburgh International Festival and its ancillary Fringe event. But finding the good ones can be hard work.
lead_paragraph: EDINBURGH — If you’re looking for a single show at this year’s Edinburgh International Festival to introduce you to the Scottish capital, where better to start than with David Greig’s “Midsummer”?

headline: Millions of Frequent Flier Miles Are Donated to Reunite Families Separated at Border
abstract: Facebook, Twitter and Reddit helped bring together strangers who wanted to help reunite families. Then one tweet from a professor led to a flood of donations.
lead_paragraph: On the morning of Aug. 6, a law professor at the University of Michigan wrote a tweet about a family that had been separated by immigration authorities after crossing into the United States.

headline: Walmart Is Finding Success in the Grocery Aisle
abstract: The retailer’s push into food, with initiatives to encourage people to buy food online, helped propel a crucial measure of sales to its largest increase in a decade.
lead_paragraph: Walmart’s many efforts to bolster its food shopping services — including letting customers order online and pick up in person, expanding its home delivery of groceries, even experimenting with robots — appear to be paying off, the company said on Thursday.

headline: In China, Salmon is Salmon, Even if It’s Trout
abstract: New rules help sustain a longstanding industry practice but anger consumers frustrated with the country’s persistent problems with food labeling.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — For years, fish sellers in China have labeled something other than salmon as salmon, according to a local media report that outraged sushi lovers across the country.

headline: The Real Risk of the John Brennan Episode
abstract: It may strike fear into the many civil servants and government contractors who need security clearances for their jobs.
lead_paragraph: Toying with access to classified information has become the White House’s go-to method for drawing attention away from screw-ups and scandals. On July 23, the White House faced a grim news cycle in response to President Trump’s disastrous Helsinki summit with Russian President Vladimir Putin. Then the White House press secretary, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, announced that Mr. Trump was “looking to take away” the security clearances of a number of former top officials who had criticized him, among them the former C.I.A. director John Brennan.

headline: California Today: Yosemite National Park Reopens to Visitors
abstract: Thursday: Tourists and wildlife return, Tesla is subpoenaed, and Portuguese-Americans keep tradition alive in the Central Valley.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Create Your Own Emoji Characters, One Way or Another
abstract: Your mobile device and computer already have thousands of those colorful pictographs available. But if you can’t find the exact one to communicate your mood, make your own.
lead_paragraph: Q. Can I make my own emoji if I don’t see a character on my phone that fits my needs? Where do the ones on the phone keyboard come from?

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties are in Hell’s Kitchen, Manhattan Valley, and Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are in Hell’s Kitchen, Manhattan Valley, and Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s properties include a three-bedroom in Tarrytown, N.Y., and four-bedroom in Weston, Conn.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a three-bedroom in Tarrytown, N.Y., and four-bedroom in Weston, Conn.

abstract: This week’s properties are in Hell’s Kitchen, Manhattan Valley, and Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn.

abstract: This week’s properties include a three-bedroom in Tarrytown, N.Y. and a four-bedroom in Weston, Conn.

headline: Atal Bihari Vajpayee, Former Prime Minister of India, Dies at 93
abstract: As India’s leader from 1998 to 2004, Mr. Vajpayee ended a long moratorium on nuclear tests but also eased tensions with Pakistan and built closer ties with United States.
lead_paragraph: Atal Bihari Vajpayee, who as India’s prime minister from 1998 to 2004 stunned the world by ending a decades-old moratorium on nuclear weapons tests but nevertheless managed to ease tensions with Pakistan and build closer ties to the United States, died on Thursday in New Delhi. He was 93.

headline: What Corona Owner’s $4 Billion Bet on a Marijuana Firm Says About Pot’s Future
abstract: Constellation’s investment in Canopy shows just how far traditional alcoholic beverage companies are willing to go to find growth.
lead_paragraph: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

headline: Counting Cranes
abstract: Construction cranes are the most visible sign of where new homes are being built.
lead_paragraph: You know there is major construction underway when cranes tower above. And wherever they cluster, it is a good bet that there are new homes being built.

headline: It Took a Village to Make Their Perfect Home
abstract: After years in a quiet walk-up, a couple discovers a “huge life upgrade” in the abundant conveniences of a bustling co-op community.
lead_paragraph: Meghan Gerard and Ellis Rosen shared a fourth-floor walk-up in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. It had a narrow railroad layout, with balky heat and finicky windows. Ms. Gerard had a 50-minute subway trip, with a bad transfer, to her job in Manhattan as a hospital administrator at N.Y.U. Langone Health. Mr. Rosen, a cartoonist and illustrator, works from home.

headline: Melania Trump’s Parents Ignite Debate Over ‘Chain Migration’
abstract: Readers debate who deserves to get a family visa to immigrate to the U.S., citing as examples their own families’ stories and the stories of families they know.
lead_paragraph: The naturalization of Melania Trump’s parents last week in a private ceremony in Manhattan led many of our readers to question President Trump’s opposition to family-based immigration.

headline: Have a Question About Fitness? The Times Has the Answer.
abstract: A new online service called Ask helps Times readers ask questions about a variety of topics and get reliable answers.
lead_paragraph: If you could sit down with a New York Times journalist or an expert source and ask them a question, what would it be?

headline: Fall for Dance Celebrates 15 Years With 6 Premieres
abstract: The beloved annual festival will return to New York City Center in October, with appearances by ballet stars and international dance companies.
lead_paragraph: Fall for Dance, New York City Center’s beloved annual festival, celebrates its 15th anniversary in October with six world premieres and appearances by ballet stars including Sara Mearns, Justin Peck and Herman Cornejo.

headline: Review: ‘Minding the Gap’ Is an Astonishing Film About American Life
abstract: A young director records himself and two skateboarding pals through hard times and painful revelations.
lead_paragraph: They grew up together in Rockford, Ill., three boys united by their love of skateboarding. At a certain point — around middle school, it seems — one of them, Bing Liu, began videotaping their exploits.

headline: How the Blaze’s Emotional Dance Music Brings Listeners to Tears
abstract: The French duo’s heartfelt songs are accompanied by visuals that have caught the attention of the “Moonlight” director Barry Jenkins.
lead_paragraph: PALM SPRINGS, Calif. — In April, the afternoon after Beyoncé headlined the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival’s opening weekend with an ambitious performance of history and imagination, the pair of cousins who make up the French electronic music duo the Blaze were still reeling, sharing their impressions in English salted with heavy accents and equally heavy romantic sentiments.

headline: Davis Cup Overhaul Wins Approval From Tennis Officials
abstract: The International Tennis Federation’s bid to radically revamp the annual men’s team competition was ratified on Thursday morning.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — The International Tennis Federation’s bid to radically revamp the Davis Cup competition was ratified on Thursday morning after months of debate and division over the proposal.

headline: Remembering Aretha Franklin
abstract: In a musical career of more than five decades, Aretha Franklin had more than 100 singles on the Billboard charts. But more important, says Jon Pareles, chief popular music critic for The New York Times, she freed other singers to let their voices fly.
lead_paragraph: In a musical career of more than five decades, Aretha Franklin had more than 100 singles on the Billboard charts. But more important, says Jon Pareles, chief popular music critic for The New York Times, she freed other singers to let their voices fly.

headline: Aretha Franklin, Indomitable ‘Queen of Soul,’ Dies at 76
abstract: With hits like “Respect” and “Chain of Fools,” she defined a female archetype: sensual and strong, long-suffering but ultimately indomitable.
lead_paragraph: Aretha Franklin, universally acclaimed as the “Queen of Soul” and one of America’s greatest singers in any style, died on Thursday at her home in Detroit. She was 76.

headline: Aretha Franklin’s 20 Essential Songs
abstract: The singer, songwriter and pianist’s catalog showcased the range and power of one of the greatest vocalists of all time.
lead_paragraph: Soul found its apotheosis in Aretha Franklin. Ever since she was crowned “The Queen of Soul” in 1967 by DJ Pervis Spann in a mock ceremony at the Regal Theater in Chicago, no one has come close to contesting the title. Ms. Franklin — who died Thursday at 76 — sang in a voice that struck an ideal balance of strength and sensitivity, of roiling emotion and refined skill. Even when she hit a note with terrific force, her tone never lost its beauty. And each note brought with it a huge context. “American history wells up when Aretha sings,” President Obama wrote in an email to The New Yorker’s David Remnick for a 2016 profile of the star. “Nobody embodies more fully the connection between the African-American spiritual, the blues, R&B, rock ’n’ roll — the way that hardship and sorrow were transformed into something full of beauty and vitality and hope.”
