headline: Aretha Franklin’s Music ‘Enabled Me to Literally Get Up in the Morning’
abstract: The “Queen of Soul” left an enduring mark on the civil rights and women’s rights movements. We want you to tell us how her songs made you feel.
lead_paragraph: When the news of Aretha Franklin’s death broke Thursday, we asked our readers how her music influenced them. More than 250 responded, talking about her influence on their self-esteem and confidence, their connection to African-American culture and more. We published a few of these stories below. They have been condensed and lightly edited.

headline: Do Penguins Mate for Life? Not According to These Paternity Tests
abstract: New research challenges assumptions that some penguins mate for life, and suggests DNA testing is needed to avoid inbred captive populations.
lead_paragraph: Roto and Copper, two Gentoo penguins at Loveland Living Planet Aquarium in Utah, cared for three children together, taking turns feeding them. They’re a social pair, just like Coco and Gossamer, a neighboring penguin couple that raised their own chicks.

headline: Trump Says Newspapers Are ‘in Collusion’ on Championing a Free Press
abstract: The president lashed out after more than 200 newspapers, including The New York Times, published editorials about the dangers of the Trump administration’s repeated attacks on the news media.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Thursday assailed the media for editorials in newspapers across the country that championed the freedom of the press, a unified response in the face of the president’s relentless attacks.

headline: Thought the Preschool Interview Was Hard? Try the One for Doggy Day Care
abstract: Dog owners planning an end-of-summer trip sans pet had better prep their pooches (and themselves) for a long trial “play date” and lots of paperwork.
lead_paragraph: Poe seemed anxious. He was acting antsy and clingy. And though the adults tried talking to him in the hope of helping him get acclimated, Poe wasn’t having any of it.

headline: Weird Subway Quirks, Addressed
abstract: Why is it so difficult to switch from express to local at Penn Station? Why can’t you change directions at 86th St. and Lexington Ave.?
lead_paragraph: Q. Why are both subway stops at Penn Station set up so that the uptown and downtown express trains come in on the same platform, while the locals come in on side platforms? It makes it difficult to switch from express to local (or vice versa).

headline: Aretha Franklin Reigned as Queen, in Voice and in Image
abstract: Yoking her formidable vocal powers to a brilliant sense of self-presentation, Ms. Franklin made herself a model of empowerment and pride.
lead_paragraph: There are so many refractory facets to consider in the life of the vocal genius Marianne Faithfull once characterized as “the voice of God” that talking about Aretha Franklin’s fashion sense feels a bit like speaking of Benjamin Franklin’s knack for flying a kite.

headline: Witchcraft in the #MeToo Era
abstract: In pop culture, witchcraft has emerged as a free-spirited expression of feminism and self-affirmation. But it’s also a religion to dozens of covens around New York.
lead_paragraph: In a secluded nook of Central Park, 13 witches stood in a circle on a cloudless Saturday, eyes closed, chanting. A makeshift altar on the forest floor bore a lantern, a silver chalice, a bowl of water, a jar of salt, a sunflower and a wand.

headline: Grandeur in a Modest Setting
abstract: Among the deep pleasures at Nepali Bhanchha Ghar in Jackson Heights, Queens: doughnuts, skinny and rough, and succulent meat that presses teeth into service.
lead_paragraph: Among the deep pleasures at Nepali Bhanchha Ghar in Jackson Heights, Queens: doughnuts, skinny and rough, and succulent meat that presses teeth into service.

headline: At Nepali Bhanchha Ghar, Splendor Comes Served on a Plate
abstract: At this Jackson Heights, Queens, restaurant, the specialties include sel roti, doughnuts of crushed rice and sugar, and jhol momo, dumplings in a chutney.
lead_paragraph: The doughnuts are skinny and rough, a stack of crooked halos. Called sel roti, they’re made at Nepali Bhanchha Ghar in Jackson Heights, Queens, with a batter of crushed rice, sugar and ghee (clarified butter), scooped with a sawed-off soda bottle and poured in the shape of a ring, into a pan of spitting oil.

headline: In the ‘Roma’ Trailer, Cinematography Takes Center Stage
abstract: Alfonso Cuarón’s semi-autobiographical tale is set in Mexico City in the 1970s. The last time he made a film set there was his breakout, “Y Tu Mamá También.”
lead_paragraph: You may not recognize any of the actors in the just-released trailer for “Roma,” but the film’s real star is the director Alfonso Cuarón. In his first film since winning an Oscar for the 2013 astronaut drama “Gravity,” Mr. Cuarón tells the semi-autobiographical story of a turbulent year in the life of a Mexico City family led by a maid (Yalitza Aparicio) during the early 1970s. The title refers to a neighborhood where protesters clashed with federally supported militias.

headline: Calls for Punishing Abusive Priests
abstract: Readers are shocked by the news of over 1,000 victims of child sexual abuse and urge the Catholic Church to “address its demons.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Contemplative State
abstract: Beaded pantsuits, high collars and other looks to fit a woman deep in thought.
lead_paragraph: Beaded pantsuits, high collars and other looks to fit a woman deep in thought.

headline: Fall Fashion: The New Take on Dressing Smart
abstract: Lace-embellished separates, oversize knits and tweed suiting combine to create looks for the woman deep in thought.
lead_paragraph: This season, designers came up with plenty of ideas for the cerebral woman. The photographer Harley Weir turned her lens on a set of looks styled by Suzanne Koller, among them tweed suiting, lace-embellished separates, oversize knits and a shearling-trimmed jacquard dress with a built-in bra — on the outside. See more from T’s Aug. 19 Women’s Fashion issue.

headline: Elon Musk Is the Id of Tech
abstract: Let me answer the question many are thinking: Is he crazy?
lead_paragraph: A lot of people have been asking me for my take on what’s going on with Elon Musk these days. But what they’re really asking is obvious: Is he crazy?

headline: Melting Ice Uncovers 1946 Wreckage of U.S. Plane in Swiss Glacier
abstract: Parts of the aircraft, which made a crash landing more than 70 years ago, recall the death-defying rescue of the 12 Americans onboard.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After an emergency landing on a Swiss glacier, the group of 12 Americans drank melted snow and survived on rations of one chocolate bar a person until daring pilots shuttled them to safety after five days marooned on the ice.

headline: Things to Do in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Nine scoops of ice cream in one day? Why not? Also, free jazz and a visit to Manhattan’s oldest house.
lead_paragraph: Hold onto your helmets. This week we’re doing a serious ice cream crawl all over greater New York City. If that’s not enough fun, we’re also heading to a jazz weekend that unwraps layers of history in Harlem.

headline: British Museum Kept a Statue for 150 Years. Now, Easter Island Wants It Back.
abstract: The government of Chile said it would ask for the return of the statue, which was taken by British sailors in 1868, on behalf of the island’s indigenous people.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “Hoa Hakananai’a” — “Lost or Stolen Friend” in English — is one of the British Museum’s most popular exhibits. Standing 7 feet, 9 inches tall, the statue’s prominent brow and deep-set eyes are the backdrop for thousands of tourist selfies every year.

headline: Wait, What Did You Just Say About Jews?
abstract: A bank teller’s derogatory remark leaves a reader wondering whether to speak up or wait for it to happen to someone else.
lead_paragraph: I went to my local bank to cash a check. The teller was new and seemed like a nice lady. She asked for my ID. (It’s bank policy.) I gave it to her gladly, and we exchanged small talk over customers who get angry about the ID requirement. Then she leaned toward me and said in a quiet voice, “It’s mostly the Jews who get mad.” I am Jewish but don’t have a so-called Jewish sounding name. I didn’t say anything, but this has really stuck with me. Should I go to her boss, or hope she says something similar to someone who will speak up?

headline: Half of Yeshivas Under Investigation Denied Entry to Education Officials, City Says
abstract: An inquiry that began three years ago to determine whether 39 yeshivas were sufficiently teaching subjects, like math, science, and English, has little to show.
lead_paragraph: Three years after the city launched an investigation into whether certain ultra-Orthodox Jewish schools were providing an adequate education in secular subjects, it revealed on Thursday that it had made little progress. In a letter to the state’s Education Department seeking guidance, Richard A. Carranza, New York City schools chancellor, acknowledged that investigators had managed to visit only half the schools involved.

headline: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Big lives cast long shadows on this week’s list of recommended books. In “Famous Father Girl,” Leonard Bernstein’s elder daughter, Jamie, describes what it was like having the renowned conductor/composer for a dad. “Empress” explains how Nur Jahan came to amass power and influence in a patriarchal dynasty that ruled much of what is now India, Pakistan, Afghanistan and Bangladesh. And Claire Tomalin, whose acclaimed biographies have told the stories of Jane Austen, Charles Dickens and other literary giants, gets around to sharing her own accomplished and incident-filled life in a new memoir. It’s not all biography this week: Other subjects include evolution, financial crises and satires of millennial culture.

headline: Taking Back My Eyebrows
abstract: They were the topic of many conversations about my heritage — and the bane of my existence. But when I decided to embrace my brows, they became my secret weapon.
lead_paragraph: For the past 10 years, almost every new interaction I’ve had with a person — romantic, platonic, professional — has followed the same script.

headline: Revoking Brennan’s Clearance: An Abuse of Presidential Power
abstract: A civil rights lawyer says the right to criticize public officials is “a cornerstone of a constitutional democracy.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Colorado Baker Sues Governor Over Cake Dispute With Transgender Woman
abstract: Masterpiece Cakeshop is at the center of another battle over whether claims of religious freedoms can be used to refuse services to gay and transgender people.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — The baker who won a United States Supreme Court case this year after refusing to make a cake for a same-sex wedding has sued the governor of Colorado, alleging the state discriminated against him when he declined to make a blue and pink cake for a transgender woman.

headline: Ex-C.I.A. Director John Brennan Strikes Back After Trump Revokes His Security Clearance
abstract: The White House cited “erratic” behavior by Mr. Brennan, who has frequently been a fierce critic of the president.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — John O. Brennan, the C.I.A. director under President Barack Obama, struck back at President Trump on Thursday for revoking his security clearance, calling the president’s claims of “no collusion” with Russia to influence the 2016 election “hogwash” and arguing that the commander in chief was trying to silence anyone who would dare challenge him.

headline: Muslim Job Applicant Who Refused Handshake Wins Discrimination Case in Sweden
abstract: Farah Alhajeh placed her hand on her heart when greeting a prospective colleague, explaining that she avoided physical contact with men because of her religion.
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM — A Muslim woman in Sweden who said she was discriminated against in a job interview for refusing to shake hands on religious grounds has been awarded financial compensation by a labor court.

headline: We Got Goop’d
abstract: This week, our friend and colleague, Taffy Brodesser-Akner, chats with us about her viral article, “How Goop’s Haters Made Gwyneth Paltrow’s Company Worth $250 Million.”
lead_paragraph: This week, our friend and colleague, Taffy Brodesser-Akner, chats with us about her viral article, “How Goop’s Haters Made Gwyneth Paltrow’s Company Worth $250 Million.” We trace some similarities and differences between Gwyneth and fellow mogul, Oprah, and ask why the wellness industry, ironically, can make us feel bad. Taffy helps us understand how oftentimes, when our current healthcare systems fail to take the pain and suffering of women and gender nonconforming people seriously, Goop can offer a seductive alternative — that comes at a price.

headline: Google Employees Protest Secret Work on Censored Search Engine for China
abstract: About 1,400 of the internet company’s employees have signed a letter demanding transparency, saying censored search results raise “urgent moral and ethical issues.”
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of Google employees, upset at the company’s decision to secretly build a censored version of its search engine for  China, have signed a letter demanding more transparency to understand the ethical consequences of their work.

headline: After a Director Dies, Friends Finish His Life’s Work: A Zombie Musical
abstract: Ryan McHenry left detailed instructions for “Anna and the Apocalypse,” based on his feeling that “High School Musical” would be “better if Zac Efron were eaten by zombies.”
lead_paragraph: “Anna and the Apocalypse” is a zombie movie. But it’s also a ghost story.

headline: Is a Rail Yard in Queens the Site of New York’s Next Mega-Development?
abstract: A massive, multi-billion-dollar project is being considered for an industrial site in Sunnyside. It could change the city. One problem: Locals don’t love it.
lead_paragraph: On a summer afternoon, Deputy Mayor Alicia Glen took a stroll on a graffiti-tagged concrete-and-metal bridge overlooking the Sunnyside rail yard, a place where people don’t usually stroll. One of the only pedestrians in sight, she peered through the curved chain-link fence at the sheds and tracks below, a blue and gray Long Island Railroad train whizzing by in the distance.

headline: Trapped in 99-Million-Year-Old Amber, a Beetle With Pilfered Pollen
abstract: The discovery is among the strongest evidence in the fossil record that the insects pollinated prehistoric cycads, a plant that preceded flowering plants.
lead_paragraph: Bees and butterflies are praised for their pollination prowess. But millions of years before they ever flirted with a flower, beetles were one of the world’s pre-eminent pollinators.

headline: When Aretha Franklin Brought Down the House at the Kennedy Center
abstract: Her rendition of “Natural Woman” in December 2015 was unforgettable. Performers, guests and others who were there talk about the soaring performance.
lead_paragraph: In her final decade, Aretha Franklin’s two best-loved performances both took place in Washington. In 2009, she graced Barack Obama’s inauguration with a gorgeous “My Country, ’Tis of Thee” while wearing a hat so remarkable it ended up on display in the Smithsonian. And on Dec. 6, 2015, she sang an unforgettable rendition of her own anthem of rebirth, “(You Make Me Feel Like) A Natural Woman,” in tribute to the song’s co-writer, Carole King, who was receiving the Kennedy Center Honors for lifetime achievement alongside Rita Moreno, Cicely Tyson and other luminaries.

headline: Northern Rivers Is a Breezy, Ex-Hippie Wonderland for Australian Chefs
abstract: The appealing landscape and beaches have attracted young, talented restaurateurs and the ‘boho-chic’ set.
lead_paragraph: Astrid McCormack tells a story about one of the first meals she served at her restaurant Fleet in Brunswick Heads, New South Wales: It was 2015, and Ms. McCormack and her partner, the chef Josh Lewis, had just opened on a quiet stretch of the town’s small business district. At the end of service, a local customer said to Ms. McCormack, “Thank you, everything about this was so wonderful. There goes Brunswick Heads.”

headline: Review: In ‘Mile 22,’ Mark Wahlberg, Patriotism and Paranoia
abstract: The plot involves a team of covert agents devoted to a level of violence we’re told most people find unpalatable. Peter Berg directs.
lead_paragraph: A testosterone cocktail of reactionary sound bites and incoherent action that even Michael Bay might have rejected as too amped, Peter Berg’s “Mile 22” makes for an appalling referendum on the state of commercial cinema in 2018.

headline: In Italy Bridge Collapse, Both Design and Upkeep Are Under Suspicion
abstract: The engineering and maintenance of Riccardo Morandi’s 1967 cable-stayed bridge are under scrutiny, days after it collapsed in Genoa.
lead_paragraph: When bridges collapse suddenly, flaws in design or construction, or inadequate inspection and maintenance, are usually to blame. In the case of the Morandi Bridge in Genoa, Italy, which stood for half a century before falling apart Tuesday in a tangled heap of concrete and steel, both design and maintenance may be at fault, experts said.

headline: Investigators Seize Fake Luxury Goods Worth Half a Billion Dollars
abstract: The counterfeit goods were knockoffs from designers like Gucci, Hermes and Tory Burch, and filled 22 shipping containers brought in from China.
lead_paragraph: The federal government said it had seized enough counterfeit Gucci bags, Hermes belts and Tory Burch purses to fill 22 shipping containers, in a six-year investigation into the importation and sale of fake luxury goods that ended on Thursday with charges filed against 33 people. The individuals were charged with conspiracy, trafficking in counterfeit goods and trademark counterfeiting.

headline: Review: The Spinning Mathematicians of Kathak Dance
abstract: At Battery Dance Festival, a program devoted to the northern Indian form kathak, whose solo practitioners are expert calculators of numbers and time.
lead_paragraph: One of the strongest attractions of the free Battery Dance Festival is its setting at the bottom tip of Manhattan, with a glorious sunset backdrop of water, sky and the Statue of Liberty. But the sun and moon switching places aren’t the only moving objects in the vista at Robert F. Wagner Park. When a tall-masted schooner looms in nearly close enough to board or a Jet Ski races full speed as if to ram the audience, it can be hard for a dancer to command complete attention.

headline: Using the Hashtag #ShareYourRejection, Writers Are Tweeting about Their Rocky Paths to Publication
abstract: It’s not all glamour and prizes.
lead_paragraph: The water cooler that is Twitter has been awash in discussion of rejection. The writer Saeed Jones began the conversation by mentioning that Breadloaf, the storied writer’s conference held annually at Middlebury College, had repeatedly turned down his application.

headline: Review: Matt Groening Enters the Netflix Age With ‘Disenchantment’
abstract: With the medieval-fantasy satire, the creator of “The Simpsons” and “Futurama” throws in a story along with jokes.
lead_paragraph: First he came for the family sitcom. Then he came for the science-fiction adventure. Now he’s back for the medieval fantasy, and he’s grabbing the Disney princess movie while he’s at it.

headline: Aretha Franklin on Heaven and Earth
abstract: No one blended the sacred and the sexual quite as she did. It made her the forebear of the likes of Madonna and Beyoncé and Adele.
lead_paragraph: Part of the story of Aretha Franklin, a musical prodigy raised in church who turned to secular music, is not unlike that of other American artists. But she revolutionized American music. Ms. Franklin, who died on Thursday at the age of 76, sang for kings and presidents and luminaries. And she met them as an equal.

headline: Simone Biles Didn’t Compete for Two Years. She’s Still Dominant.
abstract: Will the reigning Olympic champion gymnast become a five-time all-around national champion? Signs point to yes.
lead_paragraph: Simone Biles, the most decorated American gymnast ever, competed last month for the first time in 712 days. Despite a fall, she won the meet with an all-around score of 58.700, the highest logged by any woman in the world since, unsurprisingly, Biles at the 2016 Rio Olympics.

headline: Surprise Gift: Free Tuition for All N.Y.U. Medical Students
abstract: A plan will cover the $55,000 annual tuition for every current and future New York University School of Medicine student, regardless of financial need.
lead_paragraph: The New York University School of Medicine announced on Thursday that it would cover the tuition of all its students, regardless of merit or need, citing concerns about the “overwhelming financial debt” facing graduates.

headline: Settling Arguments About Hydrogen With 168 Giant Lasers
abstract: Scientists at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory said they were “converging on the truth” in an experiment to understand hydrogen in its liquid metallic state.
lead_paragraph: With gentle pulses from gigantic lasers, scientists at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California transformed hydrogen into droplets of shiny liquid metal.

headline: How Ants Avoid Traffic Jams
abstract: Ants have a lesson for humans on how to be more productive: Less is more. Here’s the ingenious trick the insects deploy for maximizing efficiency.
lead_paragraph: Ants have a lesson for humans on how to be more productive: Less is more. Here’s the ingenious trick the insects deploy for maximizing efficiency.

headline: The Secret to Ant Efficiency Is Idleness
abstract: To dig a nest tunnel quickly and get the most out of their efforts, 30 percent of fire ants do 70 percent of the work.
lead_paragraph: Ants are renowned for their industriousness. Ask the grasshopper in the story by Aesop. He had to come begging the hard-working ant for food when winter came because he had frittered away his summer.

headline: A Revamped Fringe Festival Returns to New York
abstract: The New York International Fringe Festival will be split into two, with one slate in Manhattan and a “bring your own venue” slate in the other boroughs.
lead_paragraph: The New York International Fringe Festival will return on Oct. 1 after a one-year hiatus with a new structure and the New York debut of a play about James Franco that had faced a legal hurdle.

headline: In Praise of Karel Capek
abstract: “This is the power of ‘War With the Newts’: It leaves us staring with bewilderment at the ways that we — with our tiny acts of greed and insensitivity and willful blindness — did all this.”
lead_paragraph: Two things keep Karel Capek’s “War With the Newts” from getting the recognition it deserves: its cover and its title. The best translation’s cover design, black text on teal, has all the panache of a dishwasher manual. And the title evokes spacesuit-clad heroes racing around cheap sets, firing laser guns at unscary animatronic lizards.

headline: A New U.S. Post to Pressure Iran, and a Stark Challenge Ahead
abstract: The job of special envoy will be filled by Brian Hook, who said withdrawing from the 2015 nuclear accord has opened new avenues of diplomacy despite strained relations with Europe.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration is creating a special envoy post to coordinate the United States’ economic pressure campaign against Iran, the latest in a series of moves to cut off Tehran’s revenue and force it into a new nuclear agreement.

headline: Netflix and Kenya Barris, Creator of ‘Black-ish,’ Reach a Deal
abstract: The production deal, which had been expected, came after Mr. Barris’s relationship with ABC soured, leading him to negotiate an early exit from his contract there.
lead_paragraph: Netflix formally announced Thursday that it had struck a production deal with Kenya Barris, the creator of the acclaimed ABC comedy “black-ish.”

headline: An American in Japan, Leading a Zen Koan of a Life
abstract: Tracy Franz’s “My Year of Dirt and Water” considers the paradoxical experience of being married to a Buddhist monk, cloistered in a Japanese temple.
lead_paragraph: MY YEAR OF DIRT AND WATER Journal of a Zen Monk’s Wife in Japan By Tracy Franz 307 pp. Stone Bridge Press. Paper, $16.95.

headline: The Media’s Joint Response to Trump’s Attacks
abstract: Readers discuss editorials from newspapers across the country defending a free press.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How Dangerous Are Italy’s Bridges? Even After Genoa, No One Knows
abstract: No central authority tracks or enforces maintenance of Italy’s aging transportation network — and that is a big problem, experts say.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Amid predictions that the death toll may rise in the bridge collapse in Genoa, experts warned on Thursday that other potentially deadly threats lurked in the country’s aging infrastructure, but so little information is available that no one can reliably estimate the scale of the problem.

headline: He Begged on TV for His Family’s Return. Then He Was Accused of Killing Them.
abstract: Chris Watts was arrested Wednesday in Frederick, Colo., on suspicion of killing his pregnant wife and two young daughters.
lead_paragraph: Chris Watts stood on his porch in Frederick, Colo., on Tuesday, and pleaded in an interview with a television reporter for his missing wife and two young children to come home.

headline: Gay Afghan Teenager Denied Asylum in Austria Because He Didn’t Fit Stereotype, Rights Group Says
abstract: The 18-year-old was told in a document that his walk, behavior and clothing did not “give the slightest indication” he could be gay, an L.G.B.T. rights group said.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A gay Afghan 18-year-old who was seeking asylum in Austria because he feared persecution in his country had his application denied because the authorities said he did not act like a stereotypical gay man, citing his walk, behavior and clothing, according to a Vienna-based organization that helps refugees.

headline: Aretha Franklin, Free Press, Google: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Church of Aretha Franklin
abstract: How the Queen of Soul preached to us all.
lead_paragraph: In 2015, Aretha Franklin invited me and a few others to join her in Philadelphia as she sang for Pope Francis. I was certainly thrilled to see the pontiff up close. But, I must confess, after many years of friendship, I was still more excited to watch the Queen of Soul. Even at 73, Franklin could trap lightning in her mouth at a moment’s notice and shout down fire to earth.

headline: Aretha Franklin Had Power. Did We Truly Respect It?
abstract: The Queen of Soul sang the most empowering popular song ever. But even though she was brimming with it, we don’t think of her as an artist with swagger.
lead_paragraph: Officially, “Respect” is a relationship song. That’s how Otis Redding wrote it. But love wasn’t what Aretha Franklin was interested in. The opening line is “What you want, baby, I got it.” But her “what” is a punch in the face. So Ms. Franklin’s rearrangement was about power. She had the right to be respected — by some dude, perhaps by her country. Just a little bit. What did love have to do with that?

headline: An Overdose Left Him With Brain Damage. Now What?
abstract: “People think that if you overdose on drugs, you either die or you’re O.K., but that’s not true.”
lead_paragraph: NORTH ANDOVER, Mass. — It was a Sunday afternoon, and in the cozy house at the end of the street, Andrew Foote sat in his usual chair while a movie played on the television.

headline: Woman vs. Woman: Another Record Is Set for Midterm Elections
abstract: A surge of women running this year has created more Senate races with two female nominees.
lead_paragraph: A surge of women running this year has created more Senate races with two female nominees.

headline: ‘Weaponized Ad Technology’: Facebook’s Moneymaker Gets a Critical Eye
abstract: Facebook gives political campaigns the ability to tailor ads to as few as 20 people. Critics say the technique can polarize and manipulate voters.
lead_paragraph: Facebook has made a mint by enabling advertisers to identify and reach the very people most likely to react to their messages. Ad buyers can select audiences based on details like a user’s location, political leanings and interests as specific as the Museum of the Confederacy or online gambling. And they can aim their ads at as few as 20 of the 1.5 billion daily users of the social network.

headline: U.S. and China to Rekindle Trade Talks as More Tariffs Loom
abstract: The meeting, to be held in Washington this month between midlevel officials, comes as the Trump administration is preparing more tariffs on Chinese goods.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and China will return to the negotiating table late this month in an attempt to ease months of tensions that have been building since trade talks broke down this year and both countries began imposing escalating rounds of tariffs on each other.

headline: 6 Plays and Musicals to Go to in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Previews, openings and some last-chance picks.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages and a few last-chance picks of shows that are about to close. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.

headline: 6 Comedy Shows to Catch in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

headline: 4 Film Series to Catch in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to film series and special screenings.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to film series and special screenings happening this weekend and in the week ahead. All our movie reviews are at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.

headline: 12 Pop, Rock and Jazz Concerts to Check Out in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

headline: 7 Things to Do With Your Kids in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for children and teenagers happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for children and teenagers happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

headline: 4 Classical Music Concerts to See in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to the city’s best classical music and opera happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to the city’s best classical music and opera happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

headline: 31 Art Exhibitions to View in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to new art shows and some that will be closing soon.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to new art shows and some that will be closing soon.

headline: 6 Dance Performances to See in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to dance performances happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to dance performances happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

headline: How Has This Heated Political Moment Affected Your Relationships?
abstract: We want to hear how these politically polarized times are creating rifts in your friendships or marriage.
lead_paragraph: We want to hear how these politically polarized times are creating rifts in your friendships or marriage.

headline: Archaeologists Find 3,200-Year-Old Cheese in an Egyptian Tomb
abstract: The cheese was found in a tomb that had been thought lost to shifting sands until it was rediscovered in 2010.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, a team of archaeologists cleaning sand from an ancient Egyptian tomb discovered a group of broken jars, one of them containing a mysterious white substance.

headline: Vatican Calls Abuses by Pennsylvania Priests ‘Criminal and Morally Reprehensible’
abstract: “Victims should know that the pope is on their side,” the Vatican said in response to a grand jury report on clergy sex abuse.
lead_paragraph: The Vatican responded on Thursday to the horrors of a Pennsylvania grand jury report on clergy sex abuse, saying it felt shame and sorrow over the findings that more than 1,000 children had been abused by hundreds of priests over decades while bishops covered up their crimes.

headline: When the Resistance Meets the Polls: A Historic Week for Women Politicians
abstract: In an election year already dominated by a surge of women, and L.G.B.T. candidates, this week’s Democratic primary signaled that zeal is translating into votes.
lead_paragraph: Gender Letter is a weekly take on news and culture. Tell me what you think at dearmaya@nytimes.com.

headline: What Three Days With the Parkland Student Activists Taught Me
abstract: They survived a school shooting and are now doing extraordinary work. As I learned shadowing them on a national voter-registration tour, they’re also still kids.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.

headline: Photographing a Fast-Moving New York, Slowly
abstract: Lugging her cumbersome camera around mid-20th century New York, Evelyn Hofer captured a rapidly changing city, slowly, sensitively and methodically.
lead_paragraph: It’s no secret that most New Yorkers have always moved at breakneck speed. But in mid-20th-century New York, Evelyn Hofer — often toting a cumbersome 4x5 Linhof Technika view camera — found momentary pauses. Her saintlike patience and technical expertise, as well as a penchant for capturing people’s emotional intensity, imbue her images with a pulsing, urban kineticism.

headline: As Cars Collect More Data, Companies Try to Move It All Faster
abstract: It’s been three decades since cars’ internal networks got an update. With autonomous vehicles on the horizon, quick decisions will rely on a faster network.
lead_paragraph: Cars need to get faster — not on the road, but on the inside.

headline: Cuomo vs. Nixon? He’d Rather Campaign Against Trump
abstract: Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s motivation behind his recent attacks on the president has more to do with his re-election this year than any ambitions in 2020.
lead_paragraph: There was a time when Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo used to shy away from criticizing President Trump. No more.

headline: F.D.A. Approves Generic EpiPen That May Be Cheaper
abstract: Teva Pharmaceuticals will sell a generic copy of Mylan’s EpiPen, which became the target of public outrage over its price.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved the first generic version of EpiPen, providing new competition that could help drive down the cost of a lifesaving product that had become a notorious symbol of high drug prices.

headline: Trump’s Military Parade Could Be Postponed Until 2019, Official Says
abstract: The decision came as Defense Department officials said that the event could cost more than $90 million.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A military parade ordered up by President Trump and planned for Veterans Day this year could be postponed until 2019, the Pentagon said Thursday.

headline: Inside the Fitzpatrick-Leland House With the Clothing Brand Co
abstract: Instead of opening a storefront on Melrose Place, founders Stephanie Danan and Justin Kern decided to lease a Rudolph M. Schindler home.
lead_paragraph: Instead of opening a storefront on Melrose Place, founders Stephanie Danan and Justin Kern decided to lease a Rudolph M. Schindler home.

headline: A Midcentury Modern House Where You Can Browse Clothes and Linger by the Pool
abstract: The women’s wear line Co has taken up in the Fitzpatrick-Leland house, designed by Rudolph M. Schindler, in Laurel Canyon.
lead_paragraph: The Fitzpatrick-Leland house — a multitiered L-shaped structure just off Mulholland Drive in L.A.’s Laurel Canyon neighborhood — has had many lives. Frank Lloyd Wright protégé Rudolph M. Schindler designed it in 1936 as a spec for a real estate developer looking to lure Hollywood into the hills, and it’s since seen everyone from artists to architecturally minded Airbnbers. Now, it will be the showroom and by-appointment shop of the contemporary women’s clothing brand Co. “We didn’t want to be another storefront on Melrose Place,” says co-founder Stephanie Danan. “This felt truer to what we believe in, and to the line."

headline: Venezuela Cuts to Fight Inflation (Zeroes From Its Currency, That Is)
abstract: President Nicolás Maduro is rolling out measures to stabilize the economy and increase revenue, but economists — and the population — remain skeptical.
lead_paragraph: MEDELLÍN, Colombia — Faced with nearly incomprehensible inflation — 32,714 percent as of Wednesday — Venezuelan officials thought they had a solution: They changed the color of the bank notes and increased their denomination. Then they said they would lop off three zeros. And when that didn’t seem enough, they announced they would cut off two more.

headline: Goodnight Moon
abstract: Knocking on a neighbor’s door.
lead_paragraph: After this week, individual Metropolitan Diary items will no longer be posted online. Starting Monday, Aug. 27, the full column will appear weekly online as it does in print.

headline: Aretha Franklin, Trump, N.Y.U.: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: A Promise of a Cleaner South Africa
abstract: With the departure of a compromised top prosecutor, the country’s new president can now take on endemic corruption in government and the ruling African National Congress.
lead_paragraph: The ouster of South Africa’s chief prosecutor by the country’s highest court on Monday demonstrates both the hurdles and the promise of the battle against deeply ingrained corruption, which he pledged after the resignation under duress of the perfidious Jacob Zuma as president six months ago.

headline: Meet the Special Counsel Team: So Careful They Won’t Even Disclose Their Shake Shack Orders
abstract: The trial of Paul Manafort, President Trump’s former campaign chairman, has provided the public with its first extended glimpse of Robert S. Mueller III’s investigators.
lead_paragraph: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — Greg D. Andres looked like any ordinary guest at the Westin hotel here, standing near the valet in flip-flops and a white Notre Dame boxing T-shirt, waiting for a Postmates delivery from Shake Shack.

headline: Something Not Rotten in Denmark
abstract: If this be socialism, make the most of it.
lead_paragraph: To be or not to be a socialist hellhole, that is the question. Sorry, I couldn’t help myself.

headline: Read These 3 Books About Gun Violence in Chicago
abstract: Two books explain the contributing factors, while a young adult novel shows the toll it takes on a teenager.
lead_paragraph: The devastating gun violence in Chicago once again garnered national attention after 66 were shot, 12 fatally, during a particularly violent weekend earlier this month. Two of these books explain some of the factors that have bred this violence, while a young adult novel gets inside the mind of a teenager caught in its cross hairs.

headline: 3 Knockout Art Shows to See in Los Angeles Right Now
abstract: At the Hammer, one of the strongest biennials; at the Fowler, the most beautiful sculpture show in recent memory; and at LACMA, Iranian superheroes.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — If I were a young artist choosing a big coastal city to land in, I’d opt for Los Angeles. No contest. Sure, there are problems, starting with traffic, sprawl and gentrification. Housing is hard to find here. It is in New York too, but here the weather’s kinder.

headline: ‘Dr. Bumbum,’ Brazilian Plastic Surgeon, Is Charged in Patient’s Death
abstract: The celebrity surgeon, known as Dr. Bumbum, performed a buttock lift. The case has stirred concerns in a country seen as hooked on beauty.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — A celebrity plastic surgeon has been charged in the death of a patient, in a case that has drawn attention to the dangers posed by risky elective cosmetic procedures in a country that is generally seen as being obsessed with beauty.

headline: Omarosa Manigault Newman Releases Tape of Lara Trump’s $15,000-a-Month Job Offer
abstract: The audio is the latest in the trickle of recordings that Ms. Manigault Newman has made public to bolster the credibility of her book, “Unhinged.”
lead_paragraph: Omarosa Manigault Newman released a secret recording on Thursday that she said backed her claim that President Trump’s daughter-in-law had offered her a $15,000-a-month contract in exchange for her silence about her time as a White House adviser.

headline: Education Department Opens Civil Rights Inquiry Into Abuse at Ohio State
abstract: The inquiry keeps a harsh spotlight on the university, drawing additional scrutiny to how officials handled claims of sexual misconduct by a team doctor.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Education Department has opened a civil rights investigation into how Ohio State University officials handled reports of sexual misconduct by a former team doctor, the university announced on Thursday.

headline: Please Let Me Join Your Heist
abstract: I’ll cut straight to the chase: I want in.
lead_paragraph: You’re organizing a heist, and I want in. Here’s what I bring to the table:

headline: Who Tracks Migrant Children Who Enter the U.S. Alone? Don’t Ask Us, 4 Agencies Say.
abstract: Officials from four federal agencies denied responsibility for children who have crossed the border alone once they are released from government custody.
lead_paragraph: Trump administration officials acknowledged Thursday that they have no system for tracking the tens of thousands of migrant children who are released from federal custody each year after traveling to the United States alone.

headline: John Elway’s Comments on Colin Kaepernick Could Complicate N.F.L. Collusion Case
abstract: A claim that Denver had given Kaepernick a fair offer only to be snubbed raises some issues once the timing of the offer, and the team’s other behavior, is examined.
lead_paragraph: The collusion case against the N.F.L. brought by the former San Francisco 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick has been shrouded in mystery. Dozens of league executives and owners have been questioned, but their depositions remain confidential.

headline: Dream of a Better Life in Afghanistan Ends in a Hilltop Grave for Students
abstract: The students left villages for the capital city to pursue an education and lift themselves and their families out of poverty. A suicide bombing ended all that.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The teenage students were lowered into a mass grave one after another, shoulder to shoulder — just as they had sat at their lecture hall the day before.

headline: For News Media, a Day of Solidarity in a Summer of Unease
abstract: Job losses, insults from Mr. Trump and threats have made this a difficult time for many journalists. On Thursday, more than 300 publications responded.
lead_paragraph: For the nation’s journalists, this has been a summer of unease and unrest.

headline: Cut in Two, Genoa Finds Its Political Paralysis Now Eclipsed by Shock
abstract: The collapsed bridge illuminates the larger issue of Italy’s difficulty in making strategic decisions, which leads to immobility.
lead_paragraph: GENOA, Italy — When Deborah Ilardi woke up on Tuesday, her first thought was about celebrating her 29th birthday. She couldn’t have imagined that she’d end the day worrying about where she was going to live.

headline: Cuomo’s New Opponent: Trump
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is facing activist and actress Cynthia Nixon in New York’s Democratic primary next month. But in public appearances the governor is focusing on a different rival: President Trump.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is facing activist and actress Cynthia Nixon in New York’s Democratic primary next month. But in public appearances the governor is focusing on a different rival: President Trump.

headline: Revoking Clearance, Trump Aims Presidential Power at Russia Inquiry
abstract: The move to revoke John Brennan’s security clearance may be the latest sign that the president is determined to punish anyone connected to the Russia investigation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For more than a year, law enforcement officials have repeatedly rebuffed President Trump’s efforts to use the power of his office to derail the Russia investigation. Stymied, Mr. Trump is lashing out in other ways against an investigation that he clearly hates or fears.

headline: Democrats Question Kavanaugh’s Testimony About Bush Nominee
abstract: Democrats say that files from the Bush White House show that President Trump’s Supreme Court nominee played a significant role in a nomination he distanced himself from.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As a White House lawyer working for President George W. Bush, Brett M. Kavanaugh helped the administration’s effort to win Senate confirmation for one of Mr. Bush’s most disputed judicial nominees, a Mississippi district court judge who was seeking an appeals court seat, internal White House emails show.

headline: Donald Trump, the Payback President
abstract: What fun is it being president if you can’t use the tools of government to punish your critics?
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s decision to strip the security clearance of John Brennan, a former director of the C.I.A., qualifies as one of the least surprising moves from the White House this year. Mr. Brennan has been an outspoken critic of Mr. Trump, and the president’s skin is as thin as his regard for democratic norms. And despite the laughable rationalizations now being peddled by administration apologists, Mr. Brennan’s spanking is just the latest display of what has become standard operating procedure for this president: using the official levers of government to punish critics and to encourage other detractors to sit down and shut up.

headline: New York’s Push to End Inequality Extends to Garbage
abstract: Poor neighborhoods that receive a large share of the city’s trash will get relief in a law that caps the amount of garbage sent to transfer stations.
lead_paragraph: For years, residents in less prosperous parts of North Brooklyn, Southeast Queens and the South Bronx have held their noses and complained about the huge amount of trash trucked in and out of garbage transfer stations that sprang up by their homes. Together these areas see nearly three-quarters of the city’s trash move along their streets.

headline: In Japan, 100 Years of Glory Days for High School Baseball
abstract: The national tournament draws 50,000 people to games in Koshien, is televised everywhere and turns teenagers into household names.
lead_paragraph: World Cup soccer banners adorned the lockers throughout the Yankees’ clubhouse for the early weeks of summer, but when Komazawa University Tomakomai High School was whipped, 15-2, in the final of the Hokkaido South regional baseball tournament shortly after, no one knew enough to console or even rib Masahiro Tanaka, an alumnus.

headline: Manafort Jurors Ask for Definition of Reasonable Doubt
abstract: The jury deciding the fate of President Trump’s ex-campaign chairman ended its first day of deliberations with four written questions to the judge. The answers might have been less than satisfying.
lead_paragraph: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — Jurors deciding the fate of Paul Manafort ended their first day of deliberations on Thursday with four written questions to the judge, including, “Can you please redefine reasonable doubt?”

headline: Once Dry Discussions, Cabinet Meetings Are Now Part of the Trump Show
abstract: The president alternates between gentle and pointed quizzing of his cabinet secretaries in a ritual with a story line that has become almost comically consistent.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s cabinet meeting on Thursday began with him calling the vaunted Queen of Soul a former employee. It ended with him musing that things were looking up for American farmers who have been stung by the effects of his trade war.

headline: Yankees’ Depleted Offense Barely Registers Against the Rays
abstract: With the bases loaded and no one out in the ninth inning, poised for a dramatic walk-off victory, the home team falls short.
lead_paragraph: Getting through the Yankees’ lineup used to be about as easy as navigating a minefield.

headline: Second Man Is Convicted in 1983 Racially Motivated Killing in Georgia
abstract: Bill Moore, 59, pleaded guilty to voluntary manslaughter in the death of Timothy Coggins, who was stabbed more than 30 times and dragged behind a truck.
lead_paragraph: In October 1983, the body of Timothy Coggins, a 23-year-old black man, was found on a grassy roadside in a small Georgia city about 40 miles south of Atlanta. He had been stabbed more than 30 times, and been dragged behind a truck. X marks had been cut into his body.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Revoking Clearance, Trump Aims Presidential Power at Russia Inquiry
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, August 17, 2018.
lead_paragraph: “The message he’s sending is: Don’t cross me.”

headline: Turkish Airstrike in Iraqi Territory Kills a Kurdish Militant Leader
abstract: The attack killed Zaki Shingali, a leader of a group that Turkey calls a terrorist organization, but he was considered a hero to the Yazidi minority in Iraq for his efforts to help them.
lead_paragraph: A Turkish airstrike this week killed a senior leader of an organization banned in Turkey as his convoy was leaving a village in northern Iraq, officials said.

headline: Review: Chasing Shopworn Dreams in ‘Pretty Woman: The Musical’
abstract: This wan resuscitation of the 1990 movie about a Cinderella prostitute is likely to make you nostalgic for Julia Roberts’s original performance.
lead_paragraph: No one should have had to step into that red dress again. I’m talking about the long, strapless number that Julia Roberts wore in the 1990 film “Pretty Woman,” in a moment of pure, movie-magic apotheosis.

headline: Ronald Acuna Jr. Returns but Sees Home Run Streak End
abstract: The young outfielder appeared no worse for wear a day after he was intentionally hit by Miami’s Jose Urena, who was suspended for six games.
lead_paragraph: A day after he was forced to a leave a game after being intentionally hit with the first pitch of the game, Ronald Acuna Jr. of the Atlanta Braves stepped up to lead off the bottom of the first inning of his team’s game against the Colorado Rockies and lined a single to left center, extending his hitting streak to nine games.

headline: Big Cheese Wheels
abstract: Jeff Chen offers us a puzzle with a lot of personality.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — If you have been reading Wordplay for a while, you know that I do not believe that crossword puzzles are merely two-dimensional blocks meant to test your knowledge. That would be demeaning not only to this puzzle solving pastime of ours, but also to the people who make them.

headline: In Shadow of Mt. Etna, Europe Makes a Last Stand for Solar
abstract: Europe was an early backer of solar power technology. But its panel manufacturing has fallen off, and China has emerged as the dominant force.
lead_paragraph: CATANIA, Italy — The enormous glass building on the outskirts of this Sicilian city had been intended for making silicon wafers for flash memory chips. That plan got crushed by the global financial crisis.

headline: Corrections: August 17, 2018
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on August 17, 2018.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Elon Musk Details ‘Excruciating’ Personal Toll of Tesla Turmoil
abstract: After setting off a furor that unsettled the markets and his own board, the Tesla chief talks about the pressure he is under and his struggle to cope.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk was at home in Los Angeles, struggling to maintain his composure. “This past year has been the most difficult and painful year of my career,” he said. “It was excruciating.”

headline: For 13 Days, I Believed Him
abstract: Can a relationship built on lies ultimately be good for you?
lead_paragraph: James was all over my dog, Cindy, photographing her and posting her to his Facebook. He would roughhouse and then curl around her, pinning Cindy down and forcing her to look him in the eyes: a deep, locked gaze that said they were connected, that said he belonged in this apartment with this dog.

headline: Aretha Franklin, Genoa, Trump: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘To All the Boys I’ve Loved Before’ and ‘The Great British Baking Show’
abstract: A new romantic comedy, “To All the Boys I’ve Loved Before,” is on Netflix, and the Season 5 finale of “The Great British Baking Show” is airing.
lead_paragraph: A romantic comedy, “To All the Boys I’ve Loved Before,” on Netflix and the Season 5 finale of “The Great British Baking Show.”

headline: North Korea Presses Demand for End of War Amid Talk of Pompeo Visit
abstract: South Korea’s leader indicated that Secretary of State Mike Pompeo was preparing for his fourth visit to the North.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea pressed its demand on Friday that the United States agree to declare an end to the 1950-53 Korean War, as South Korea’s leader indicated that the American secretary of state, Mike Pompeo, was preparing for his fourth visit to the North.

headline: Talking About Failure Is Crucial for Growth. Here's How to Do It Right.
abstract: Research shows that talking about failure makes for happier, more productive workers.
lead_paragraph: We’ve all flopped on a big presentation.

headline: The N.Y.C. Parks Commissioner on ‘the Experience of Place’
abstract: Mitchell J. Silver on his lifelong love of New York City parks — along with global inspirations for ones yet to come.
lead_paragraph: Mitchell J. Silver, the New York City parks commissioner, manages over 1,950 parks and recreational areas, from off-the-beaten-path Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx to the vibrant Rockaway Beach and Boardwalk in Queens. With growing numbers of visitors to the city’s recreational spaces, he has focused on what he calls “the experience of place.”

headline: As Stock Markets Brush Off Trade Tensions, a Warning of Trouble Ahead
abstract: Copper’s broad use in cyclical industries means if demand for the metal starts to fall off, then industrial economies may start to slow.
lead_paragraph: Among the world’s investment nerds, copper has a special title: They call it “Dr. Copper” because of its reputed ability to predict the direction of the global economy as well as any Ph.D.-holding economist might.

headline: What’s in a List? Two Critics on Theater’s Special Relationship
abstract: Ben Brantley and his London counterpart Michael Billington find much that’s enthralling about the state of playwriting in their countries.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — One very sticky afternoon last month — amid a surprisingly crowded summer theater season — Michael Billington came calling on me in the un-air-conditioned Marylebone flat where I was staying for a few weeks. Mr. Billington has been the drama critic for The Guardian since 1971 and is probably the most revered member of his profession in this country.

headline: Amid an Anti-Muslim Mood, a Museum Appeals for Understanding
abstract: An exhibition at the Uffizi gallery in Florence shows how the city benefited from dialogue with the Muslim world.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, Italy — They were made in Syria six centuries ago, and stand elegantly in a row of vitrines at the Uffizi Gallery here: five ceramic jars that once contained treatments, ointments and scents from the faraway Orient. These “Albarelli” jars are decorated with an interlacing pattern of flower stems and foliage. And at the center of each one is a lily — the historical emblem of Florence.

headline: News Quiz: Test Your Knowledge of the Week’s Headlines
abstract: Did you stay up to date this week?
lead_paragraph: Did you stay up to date this week?

headline: Colbert Razzes Cuomo for Saying America Was ‘Never That Great’
abstract: Stephen Colbert gave a blunt assessment of Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s statement. “That is the dumbest thing you can say as a politician,” Colbert said.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Unbearable’ Noise and Dust: Kushner Companies Accused of Driving Out Tenants in Brooklyn Building
abstract: At the waterfront building, only 71 rent-stabilized tenants are left. When the Kushner Companies bought it, there were 316.
lead_paragraph: When the Kushner Companies bought the building at 184 Kent Avenue in Brooklyn in 2015, there were 316 rent-stabilized tenants, seemingly protected from eviction and large rent increases.

headline: How Do You Die From Leukemia?
abstract: Though survival rates have improved markedly, a variety of problems can cause death.
lead_paragraph: Q. How does one typically die from cancer of the bone marrow, such as leukemia or multiple myeloma?

headline: What Is Billy Bob Thornton Doing These Days?
abstract: Just another semi-rock-star dad, bowling with his bandmates in between acting gigs.
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — Billy Bob Thornton stood at the foot of a lane inside the Bowlmor bowling alley and arcade here and squinted at a rack of pins. He paused a moment, his right arm poised at a 90-degree angle, his right hand gently cradling the ball. He reached back, aimed and, with a quick two-step, lobbed the ball down the middle of the lane.

headline: Searching for Language to Capture How Climate Change Has Altered Our World
abstract: In “Rising,” Elizabeth Rush surveys the new contours of an America already changed by rising waters.
lead_paragraph: RISING Dispatches from the New American Shore By Elizabeth Rush Illustrated. 299 pp. Milkweed Editions. $26.

headline: The Costs of Motherhood Are Rising, and Catching Women Off Guard
abstract: College-educated women in particular underestimate the demands of parenthood and the difficulties of combining working and parenting, new research shows.
lead_paragraph: An economic mystery of the last few decades has been why more women aren’t working. A new paper offers one answer: Most plan to, but are increasingly caught off guard by the time and effort it takes to raise children.

headline: A Puppy as a Starter Kid
abstract: Our parenting style created an entitled, unsociable and disobedient individual. Whatever we had done with our dog, we had to do the exact opposite with our twins.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, my husband, Dave, and I got a fawn-colored French bulldog puppy. When we introduced Chucho to our friends, a trend developed. Many of them assumed the acquisition of a canine symbolized our first step toward having a baby. One person, Justin, went so far as to say, “Starter kid, huh?”

headline: From a Marsh to a Mountain, Crime Fiction Heads Outdoors
abstract: Marilyn Stasio’s selections take readers to a North Carolina swamp, a peak in Minnesota and a jungle in Laos, with a pit stop at a California beach.
lead_paragraph: The wildlife scientist Delia Owens has found her voice in WHERE THE CRAWDADS SING (Putnam, $26), a painfully beautiful first novel that is at once a murder mystery, a coming-of-age narrative and a celebration of nature. The author, with her husband, Mark, of three books about southern Africa, Owens here surveys the desolate marshlands of the North Carolina coast through the eyes of an abandoned child. And in her isolation that child makes us open our own eyes to the secret wonders — and dangers — of her private world.

headline: Stepsisters, Lovers and Gender-Bending Artists, Now Celebrated in a Novel
abstract: In “Never Anyone but You,” Rupert Thomson reimagines the lives of the Surrealist icons Claude Cahun and Marcel Moore.
lead_paragraph: NEVER ANYONE BUT YOU By Rupert Thomson 350 pp. Other Press. $25.95

headline: What Role Do Teachers Play in Education?
abstract: Andrea Gabor’s “After the Education Wars” looks at efforts to reform the classroom through technology and standardized testing.
lead_paragraph: AFTER THE EDUCATION WARSHow Smart Schools Upend the Business of Reform By Andrea Gabor 373 pp. The New Press. $27.99.

headline: Weekly Health Quiz: Lyme Disease, Swimmers and Female Doctors
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Is ‘The Bassarids’ an Operatic Masterpiece, or ‘Strauss Turned Sour’?
abstract: Hans Werner Henze’s opera, based on Euripides’s “The Bacchae,” returns this month to the Salzburg Festival, the site of its premiere in 1966.
lead_paragraph: It’s a strange, seductive story. A young man becomes king. The king becomes a bit overconfident, deciding to test his power against a charismatic stranger’s worshipers. This stranger — it turns out he’s the god of wine and dance — responds by ensorcelling members of the royal family. Eventually, the king loses his head: to his own mother, a follower of the new cult.

headline: A Writer’s Trip Into the Amazon Reveals Brazil and Himself
abstract: Chris Feliciano Arnold’s “The Third Bank of the River” is a reported and personal look at the problems plaguing the Amazon and its people.
lead_paragraph: THE THIRD BANK OF THE RIVER Power and Survival in the Twenty-First Century Amazon By Chris Feliciano Arnold 336 pp. Picador. $28.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘Democracy in Chains,’ ‘Black Mad Wheel’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.

headline: In a Divided Era, One Thing Seems to Unite: Political Anger
abstract: Disputes over politics have divided Americans’ homes, strained marriages, ruined friendships and invaded the workplace.
lead_paragraph: Ken Storey was in a pique, the kind that often seizes and overwhelms the better judgment of people who follow politics closely these days.

headline: Alexa vs. Siri vs. Google: Which Can Carry on a Conversation Best?
abstract: Digital assistants from Amazon, Apple and Google can only have meager back-and-forth exchanges with us. Listen to how that tells us something about where they’re going in the future.
lead_paragraph: Digital assistants from Amazon, Apple and Google can only have meager back-and-forth exchanges with us. Listen to how that tells us something about where they’re going in the future.

headline: Giving Others a Voice in Congress, One Hand-Delivered Letter at a Time
abstract: Since President Trump’s inauguration, a group of Washington-based volunteers have spent their lunch breaks and after-work hours delivering over 12,000 letters to Capitol Hill.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After President Trump’s inauguration, Debbie Matties felt helpless.

headline: A New Film Compares Democrats to Nazis and Trump to Lincoln. At This Screening, It Was a Hit.
abstract: Attendees at a viewing party in Ohio said the film, from the conservative provocateur Dinesh D’Souza, was a confirmation of a worldview they feel is often ridiculed.
lead_paragraph: MEDINA, Ohio — There were two marquee events scheduled on a recent Wednesday evening in northern Ohio’s Medina County.

headline: The Legacy De Gaulle Left in London
abstract: In exile during the Nazi occupation of France, the great general spent three years in the British capital, a period that defined his sense of destiny.
lead_paragraph: With its bland architecture and gray concrete pavement, little distinguishes Curzon Square from its surroundings in the heart of London’s Mayfair district. But it was here that Charles de Gaulle wrote a speech that would change his country’s fate and, he believed, fulfill his destiny.

headline: A Retirement Community Turned Away These Married Women
abstract: According to the facility’s “cohabitation policy,” marriage is between one man and one woman, “as it is understood in the Bible.”
lead_paragraph: Mary Walsh and Beverly Nance did considerable research in 2016 before deciding to move into a continuing care retirement community outside St. Louis.

headline: Some States Sitting on Piles of Cash, and Cities Want a Cut
abstract: States like Ohio are placing their surpluses in rainy-day funds, but cities that have suffered because of cuts since the recession say it is time to loosen up.
lead_paragraph: LORAIN, Ohio — Welcome to Lorain, where the mayor, Chase Ritenauer, would like to show you around.

headline: The Scalding, Hands-On Art of Amezaiku
abstract: Watch the Japanese candy artist Shinri Tezuka create a lifelike goldfish out of blistering hot sugar syrup in his Tokyo studio.
lead_paragraph: Watch the Japanese candy artist Shinri Tezuka create a lifelike goldfish out of blistering hot sugar syrup in his Tokyo studio.

headline: Hundreds of Reindeer Died by Lightning. Their Carcasses Became a Laboratory.
abstract: “From death comes life,” said researchers who studied how decomposing bodies, with the help of scavengers, might alter plant diversity across a broad landscape.
lead_paragraph: On a chilly day in August 2016, more than 300 reindeer, huddled for warmth, dropped dead on a mountain plateau in Norway. They died by lightning, which coursed through the wet ground, climbed up their legs and fatally jolted their hearts.

headline: How Edward Tricomi, Master Stylist, Spends His Sundays
abstract: The co-owner of the salon chain Warren Tricomi cooks in and hikes around his second home, a 60-acre former Russian Orthodox convent in Accord, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Edward Tricomi, 66, has styled the tresses of Saudi Arabian royals, Mick Jagger and Scarlett Johansson. The co-owner of Warren Tricomi, a small chain of salons, Mr. Tricomi lives in Midtown West with his wife, Deborah Tricomi, 63, an assistant principal at a public school in the South Bronx, their son Luke, 27, who works in branding and marketing, their Italian greyhound, Edie, and their cockatiel, Peeky. On the weekends, they all escape to their second home: a 60-acre former Russian Orthodox convent, renovated by Mr. Tricomi himself 20 years ago, in Accord, N.Y.

headline: Reviving a Centuries-Old Japanese Confectionery Art
abstract: Amezaiku, a candy-making technique that calls for sculpting molten sugar syrup, nearly went extinct. Now, it’s seeing new life among a dedicated group of Tokyo craftsmen.
lead_paragraph: FIRST THE FINGERS BURN. Any apprentice in the centuries-old Japanese confectionery art of amezaiku must accept this as the price of beauty. Molten syrup, heated to a scalding 176 degrees Fahrenheit, is scooped up with bare hands. There’s no time to cry out; from the moment it touches the skin, you have about five minutes to pull and squeeze the hot ball, impale it on a stick and sculpt it — into a panda, a crane, a rhinoceros beetle — with nothing but singed fingers and tiny scissors for making swift cuts as the syrup congeals.

headline: ‘I’ve Seen Too Many Accidents’: The Perils of Deliverymen
abstract: “Delivereros,” many undocumented, put themselves in danger every day, for little reward. After the death of a 14-year-old last November, others in the field take stock.
lead_paragraph: It would be difficult to find a bicycle deliveryman in New York who doesn’t know the story of Edwin Vicente Ajacalon. He was a 14-year-old boy who lived in the city for about a year, having come to the United States illegally and unaccompanied from rural Guatemala, where he’d finished sixth grade and helped his parents work the fields.

headline: Melania Trump, a Mysterious First Lady, Weathers a Chaotic White House
abstract: On many matters, Mrs. Trump has directed her East Wing to operate independently of the West Wing, and she is still keeping Washington at a distance.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hours after Melania Trump moved into the White House in June of last year, she peered out a window and took in a stunning view of the Washington Monument: “Looking forward to the memories we’ll make in our new home!” the first lady cheerily wrote on Twitter in a snapshot of the tableau.

headline: Life in Turkey Now: Tough Talk, but Fears of Drug Shortages
abstract: The lira’s plunge, exacerbated by a dispute with the U.S. over a detained pastor, has exposed growing economic pressures that some economists say could be near a breaking point.
lead_paragraph: Turkish banks are pulling back on credit to consumers and businesses. Power plants have shut down because of the soaring cost of imported fuel. Building projects in Istanbul stand half finished after their backers ran out of money.

headline: Embracing the Basement
abstract: Some of the best deals in New York City are on apartments with below-grade space, where buyers can still get a surprising amount of light and air.
lead_paragraph: Some of the best deals in New York City are on apartments with below-grade space, where buyers can still get a surprising amount of light and air.

headline: The Underground Apartment Market
abstract: Buyers and developers preoccupied with sky-high homes are reconsidering the lowly basement, as nest seekers look earthbound for deals.
lead_paragraph: Life in New York has driven Elizabeth Yanev into the ground — and she is delighted.

headline: As Austerity Helps Bankrupt an English County, Even Conservatives Mutiny
abstract: The local government in an affluent part of England is out of cash, and others may follow. Its former leader blames funding cuts from London.
lead_paragraph: NORTHAMPTON, England — It was a seething, stomping protest in this ordinarily genteel medieval town: Throngs of residents, whistling and booing, swarmed the county hall. “Criminals!” they shouted. They held up banners that read: “Tory councilors wanted for crimes against people in Northamptonshire.”

headline: Can a Music Festival Make Kosovo Cool?
abstract: The father of the pop star Dua Lipa has started a festival that he hopes will change the way people think about his country.
lead_paragraph: PRISTINA, Kosovo — Last Friday afternoon, Dukagjin Lipa, 49, sat backstage at Kosovo’s first major music festival, bleary-eyed and trying to ignore the two cellphones ringing on the table in front of him.

headline: Elon Musk, Aretha Franklin, ‘Disenchantment’: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Nancy Pelosi’s Dilemma
abstract: Under fire from both parties, the longtime House Democratic leader faces an uncertain political future.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: How to Make a Crossword Puzzle
abstract: In the final part of this series, the New York Times crossword editors reveal their process for evaluating and editing a puzzle submission.
lead_paragraph: DEB AMLEN: The hardest part of submitting your finished crossword puzzle to an editor is the waiting. Once you’ve kissed your work goodbye, time seems to tick by really slowly until you get that email. A rejection can be disappointing and is a sign to try again, but a “Yes!” is exhilarating.

headline: For Catholics, Gradual Reform Is No Longer an Option
abstract: Yes, there is still holiness in the church. But the sin is so pervasive and corrosive that it is irresponsible to talk about anything else.
lead_paragraph: I often use a handy metaphor to explain to my students how feminists have historically differed among themselves in their approaches to bringing about change in patriarchal institutions. Some feminists seek a place at the table; others want to reset the table. The former hope to promote gradual progress from within an existing framework of norms and organizational structures; the latter demand nothing less than radical, wholesale reform.

headline: Can Imran Khan Save Pakistan?
abstract: If the incoming prime minister can persuade the military to enable him to improve relations with the United States, Afghanistan and India, he will pull off a feat none of his predecessors has managed.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — When Imran Khan is sworn in as the prime minister of Pakistan on Saturday, he will be confronted by daunting challenges.

headline: New York Today: Aretha Franklin’s New York
abstract: Friday: Aretha Franklin’s performances in the city and readers’ memories of the “Queen of Soul.”
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this still-sultry Friday.

headline: A Ballet Crowd, Bustin’ Out All Over ‘Carousel’
abstract: Amar Ramasar, Brittany Pollack and Craig Salstein get a chance to stretch on Broadway. With Justin Peck, they talk about the challenges and rewards.
lead_paragraph: Since March, three ballet dancers — Brittany Pollack, Amar Ramasar and Craig Salstein — have been living in a different world, where daily class happens not in a pristine studio with barres and mirrors, but on the carpeted floor of a theater mezzanine. And instead of being thrown onstage in a debut because another dancer is injured, or performing in three ballets in one night (sometimes four), they dance the same thing every night.

headline: The Beast in Me
abstract: We tend to forget we are animals, until we become prey.
lead_paragraph: MISSOULA, Mont. — In the summer of 2012, the same year that scientists fully decoded the genome of the bonobo, the last great ape, my partner and I were stalked by a female grizzly bear. We first saw her high above us in a field of huckleberry bushes as we hiked along Grinnell Lake on the east side of Glacier National Park in Montana.

headline: The Coming Green Wave
abstract: This silent majority will no longer stand by as the Trump administration tries to destroy a century of bipartisan love of the land.
lead_paragraph: If emotions were water, and you took all the heartbreak felt by the millions who followed the plight of a starving orca whale grieving over her dead calf, you’d have a river the size of the mighty Columbia.

headline: How to Get the Most Out of College
abstract: They’re privileged, pivotal years. Navigate them with as much care as you did the path that got you there.
lead_paragraph: We overwhelm teenagers with advice about choosing a college. Go big. Go small. Put prestige above cost. Do the opposite.

headline: 5 Takeaways From Elon Musk’s Interview With The Times About Tesla
abstract: The Tesla chief executive addressed a wide range of issues, including the search for a chief operating officer and his tweet that sent the company’s shares soaring.
lead_paragraph: Tesla is not considering hiring a second in command, the electric carmaker’s founder and chief executive, Elon Musk, said in wide-ranging comments to The New York Times.

headline: The Debt-Shaming of Stacey Abrams
abstract: Our pernicious double standard on politicians who owe money.
lead_paragraph: The campaign for governor of Georgia is a supersaturated microcosm of American politics right now, offering the starkest possible choice between irreconcilable visions of the country’s future. The Democrat, Stacey Abrams, former minority leader of the Georgia House, aims to become the first African-American woman governor in American history. She seeks to harness her Southern state’s changing demographics, assembling a coalition of minority voters and white urban and suburban liberals. Her opponent, Secretary of State Brian Kemp, is a Trump manqué skilled in voter suppression. He boasted in a campaign ad, “I’ve got a big truck, just in case I need to round up criminal illegals and take them home myself.”

headline: DealBook Briefing: The Agony of Elon Musk
abstract: The Tesla chief told The New York Times that working nonstop to turn the company around is taking its toll on him. His directors agree.
lead_paragraph: Good Friday morning. (Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.) Today, we’re paying our respects to Aretha Franklin, the Queen of Soul.

headline: Summer Reading Contest, Week 10: What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
abstract: Our final week begins! To participate, just post a comment here by Aug. 24 at 7 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on Sept. 4.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Week Ten — the final week of our Ninth Annual Summer Reading Contest.

headline: ‘Crazy Rich Asians’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: Jon M. Chu narrates a sequence from his film.
lead_paragraph: Jon M. Chu narrates a sequence from his film.

headline: In ‘Crazy Rich Asians,’ How Word Travels Fast
abstract: The director Jon M. Chu explains his visual choices for a scene in which rumors about a couple (Henry Golding and Constance Wu) are spread through social media.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series each Friday. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: Kerala Flooding: Hundreds Killed in Indian State’s Worst Rains Since 1920s
abstract: The floods have left at least 324 people dead, and hundreds of thousands more have been made homeless.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The idyllic tourist destination of Kerala, India, is experiencing some of its worst floods in nearly a century, with torrential rains in recent days killing at least 324 people, state officials said, and shuttering the state’s major infrastructure.

headline: This Week in Arts: Dancing on the Beach, Afropunk and Regina Hall
abstract: Beach Sessions Dance Series heads to Rockaway; Afropunk continues its inclusive tradition; and another film from the star of “Girls Trip” lands in theaters.
lead_paragraph: Aug. 25-26, beachsessionsdanceseries.com

headline: What to Care About When Everything Is Terrible
abstract: In the Trump presidency, everything is a distraction from everything else, because it all matters.
lead_paragraph: As of Thursday, 565 migrant children — 24 of them under the age of five — remained separated from their parents after the Trump administration tore families apart at the United States-Mexico border. Though the administration backed away from its “zero tolerance” immigration enforcement policy after prolonged outcry, this level of casual cruelty is not so easily cleaned up: It lingers both in the children who have yet to see their parents again and in the lasting trauma done to even reunified families.
