lead_paragraph: Katharine Elizabeth Glueck and Maor Yaakov Cohen were married Aug. 18 at the Renaissance Arlington Capital View Hotel in Arlington, Va. Rabbi Aaron Miller officiated.

headline: Ellen Toobin, Eric Dodd
abstract: The couple met at Macalester College in St. Paul, from which they both graduated.
lead_paragraph: Ellen Frances Toobin and Eric Jamison Dodd were married Aug. 18 in New Fairfield, Conn. Allen W. Bernard, the life partner of the bride’s late grandfather, Robert McIntosh, and who became a Universal Life minister for this event, officiated at Great Hollow Nature Preserve and Ecological Research Center.

headline: Anna Grummon, Hunt Allcott
abstract: The couple met in 2013 at a track workout of the San Francisco Road Runners Club.
lead_paragraph: Anna Haight Grummon and Hunt Volney Allcott were married Aug. 18 at Pinecrest Chalet, a resort in Pinecrest, Calif. Elizabeth Allcott St. Clair, the groom’s sister, officiated, having become a Universal Life minister for the occasion.

headline: Harlan Trevithick, Michael Simpson
abstract: The couple met in Washington in 2011 at a bar where the groom then worked.
lead_paragraph: Harlan Isabel Byers Trevithick and Michael Zachary Simpson were married Aug. 18 at the Red Lion Inn in Cohasset, Mass. Reid Whitten, a friend of the couple who obtained a one-day solemnization certificate from the State of Massachusetts, officiated.

headline: Jessica Assaf, Alex Regenstreich
abstract: The couple met in 2017 at Burning Man, in a camp called “Infinite Love” where both stayed during the festival.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Sara Assaf and Alex Bradley Regenstreich were married Aug. 18 at a private residence in Malibu, Calif. Rabbi Lori Shapiro officiated.

headline: Mia Solkin, David Ban
abstract: The couple met in 2013 after the bride spotted the groom at a restaurant where both were dining, and enlisted a friend to deliver her card to him.
lead_paragraph: Mia Adrienne Solkin and David Ian Ban were married Aug. 18. Dr. Richard J. Kolker, an uncle of the bride who received permission from Massachusetts to solemnize the marriage, officiated at a rented private residence in Sheffield, Mass.

headline: Morgan Spicer, Zachary Brown
abstract: The couple met at Syracuse, from which both graduated.
lead_paragraph: Morgan Sarah Spicer and Zachary Evan Brown were married Aug. 18 at the Estate at Farrington Lake in East Brunswick, N.J. Michael A. Smith, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Petia Popova, Redmond Manierre Jr.
abstract: The couple met as undergraduates at the University of Mary Washington. She is an admissions adviser at Georgetown, he is a financial planner at UBS.
lead_paragraph: Petia Petrova Popova was married Aug. 17 to Redmond Livingston Manierre Jr. in Madison, Va. The groom’s father, who was appointed a civil celebrant by the Fauquier County Court of Virginia, officiated at Early Mountain Vineyards.

headline: William Clayman, Joshua Handell
abstract: The couple met while attending law school at Yale, from which each received a law degree.
lead_paragraph: William Gilbert Clayman and Joshua Keith Handell were married Aug. 18 at the Yale Club of New York City. Kyle Roche, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated. Judge Diane S. Sykes, of the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, led the couple in an exchange of vows.

headline: Jenette Lotze, Brian Stauber
abstract: The couple were married in a self-uniting ceremony at the First Unitarian Church of Pittsburgh.
lead_paragraph: Jenette Irene Lotze and Brian Todd Stauber were married Aug. 18 in a self-uniting ceremony led by Jennifer B. Halperin, a religious educator at the First Unitarian Church of Pittsburgh, where the ceremony took place.

headline: Sneha Kondragunta, Vijay Ramanavarapu
abstract: The couple initially met in 2009, but didn’t have a first date until the groom’s mother intervened to set the two up, in 2016.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Sneha Kondragunta and Vijay Ramanavarapu were married Aug. 18 in Washington. Pandit Venkatachari Samudrala, a Hindu priest, officiated at the Ronald Reagan Building and International Trade Center.

headline: Kelley McKenna, Bradford Atwood
abstract: The couple met in 2013 at a pizza party for the track team, of which her daughters and his son were members.
lead_paragraph: Kelley Anne McKenna and Bradford Tyler Atwood are to be married Aug. 19 in Providence, R.I. The Rev. Dr. Claudia P. Demick is to perform the ceremony at the Central Congregational Church, where she is an associate minister.

headline: Abigail Fisch, Benjamin Cotton
abstract: The couple met at The Columbia Daily Spectator, where the groom served as editor in chief, and began dating four years later.
lead_paragraph: Abigail Davidson Fisch and Benjamin Ronald Cotton are to be married Aug. 19 at B'nai Jeshurun synagogue in Manhattan. Rabbi Mark Wildes is to officiate.

headline: Puja Parikh, Saad Rizwan
abstract: The couple met at Cornell during law school. She is now a clerk for a federal judge in Louisville, Ky. He is a litigation associate in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Puja Virendra Parikh was married Aug. 18 to Saad Ullah Rizwan in Manhattan. Pandit Prabhakar Sharma, a Hindu priest, officiated at the Mandarin Oriental hotel.

headline: Sarah Goulet, Daniel Riley
abstract: The couple met in 2015 at the Corner Bistro in New York.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Germaine Goulet and Daniel Vroman Riley were married Aug. 18 at Pilot Hill Farm on Martha’s Vineyard in Massachusetts. Daniel Goldstein, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Megan Byrne, Kevin Jason
abstract: The bride and groom met at Stanford, from which each received a law degree.
lead_paragraph: Megan Dorathea Byrne and Kevin Eli Jason were married Aug. 18 in Brooklyn. The Rev. William G. Smith, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Charles Borromeo Church.

headline: Margaret Hsu, Stuart Wagner
abstract: The bride works for a digital asset trading platform, the groom is a software engineer at Microsoft. They were married at the Four Seasons in Seattle.
lead_paragraph: Margaret Kathryn Hsu and Stuart Blair Wagner were married Aug. 18 at the Four Seasons Hotel in Seattle. Meghan Desai, a friend of the couple who was ordained a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Emilie Aries, Brad Bolte
abstract: The couple met in 2012 during a game of sand volleyball in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Emilie Eve Aries and Brad William Bolte were married Aug. 18 at the home of the groom’s parents in North Branch, N.Y. Christopher J. Johnstone, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Jamey Lundblad, William Melamed Jr.
abstract: The couple met at a holiday party in Chicago in 2008, and for their first date, watched the inaugural concert for Barack Obama on television.
lead_paragraph: Jamey Ralph Lundblad and William Lee Melamed Jr. were married Aug. 18. Maureen Mizwicki, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the R. W. Glasner Studio, a museum in Chicago.

headline: Erin Jones, James Geter II
abstract: The bride graduated from Spelman College in Atlanta and the groom graduated from Morehouse College in Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: Erin Ann Jones and James Nelson Geter II were married Aug. 18 at the Old Whaling Church, Edgartown Liturgical Arts Center on Martha’s Vineyard in Massachusetts. Stacey Thomas, a minister ordained by Open Ministry, officiated.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘The Affair’ and ‘Dying to Belong’
abstract: The season finale of “The Affair” airs and a new show, “Dying to Belong,” debuts.
lead_paragraph: The season finale of “The Affair” airs and a new show, “Dying to Belong,” debuts.

headline: Back From the Dead, Parma Embraces a Soccer Renaissance
abstract: Three years ago, Parma’s soccer team had gone bankrupt and ceased to exist. On Sunday it makes its triumphant return to Italy’s Serie A.
lead_paragraph: PARMA, Italy — Eight trophies are lined up along the back wall of the museum at Parma’s Stadio Ennio Tardini. Each one is polished to perfection, placed on a plinth and bathed in a soft spotlight, picking out the glint of silver and the gleam of gold. The effect is one of deep reverence, an almost holy glow.

headline: Before You Flush Your Contact Lenses, You Might Want to Know This
abstract: Flushing disposable contacts down the toilet or washing them down the drain may contribute to the problem of microplastic pollution, researchers said.
lead_paragraph: If you throw out your contact lenses every day or so, you’re not alone — more than 45 million people in the United States wear contacts, and many of them use disposable versions of the little plastic hemispheres.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $1,000,000
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: Throngs Enticed by ‘Game of Thrones’ Threaten a Magical City
abstract: Dubrovnik, Croatia, known to “Game of Thrones” fans as King’s Landing, is a fantasy made real. As crowds of “set-jetters” threaten to spoil the port’s sublime majesty, officials are fighting back.
lead_paragraph: DUBROVNIK, Croatia — Winter is coming.

headline: Trump Won Pennsylvania. Democrats Want the State (and His Voters) Back.
abstract: With its redrawn congressional map and working class union towns, the state has found itself at the center of Democrats’ plans to win control of the House of Representatives.
lead_paragraph: CONWAY, Pa. — The rules are workable enough in the right hands, in the right corner of a right-leaning region of a state like this one.

headline: Security Clearances, Elon Musk, Aretha Franklin: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Here are the week’s top stories, and a look ahead.

headline: As Taliban Start Charm Offensive, Afghan President Calls for Cease-Fire
abstract: The Taliban have been courting civilians for weeks and promising not to harm soldiers who surrender, raising hopes of a cease-fire in Afghanistan. On Sunday, the government made the first move.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Even as insurgents in Afghanistan have escalated their attacks against government forces across the country, they have also been staging a simultaneous charm offensive of sorts in advance of Eid al-Adha, the Islamic Feast of Sacrifice, which starts this week.

headline: How the Senate Got Its Groove Back With the Power of the Purse
abstract: While the Senate may be at odds over the Supreme Court vacancy, it is trying, for the first time in years, to advance funding bills the old-fashioned way.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Against the backdrop of rising partisan rancor over the Supreme Court vacancy, an unlikely bipartisan breakthrough is quietly taking place in the Senate, where the annual spending bills are advancing in a way that hasn’t been seen in years.

headline: Lincoln’s Stovepipe Hat and Letters Could Be Sold to Ease Nonprofit’s Debt
abstract: The bloodstained gloves from the night of his assassination are also part of a collection that may be auctioned to erase a debt of more than $9 million.
lead_paragraph: An Illinois nonprofit bearing Abraham Lincoln’s name is so deep in debt that it is considering selling some of the 16th president’s possessions, including one of his iconic stovepipe hats and bloodstained gloves from the night of his assassination.

headline: Pregnant Minister Cycles to Hospital to Give Birth
abstract: Julie Anne Genter, New Zealand’s minister for women’s affairs, posted photographs on social media of her “mostly downhill” trip to a hospital, where she was due to have labor induced.
lead_paragraph: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — Since taking office, New Zealand’s prime minister has broken boundaries and made headlines by becoming only the second sitting world leader to give birth, taking six weeks of parental leave and returning to her leadership role with a baby in tow and nary a fuss.

headline: For Some Girls, Empowerment Comes With Two Wheels and a Helmet
abstract: Two years ago, a college student started a bicycling group in Newark designed to address the gender gap in cycling by reaching a new generation of young female riders.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — The training wheels were off. The young woman with a bright smile and golden sunglasses told Kaneisha Marable she didn’t need them. The little girl believed her.

headline: 5 Pearls of Wisdom About College for Students Starting Their First Year
abstract: Readers who are college graduates offer advice to incoming freshmen who wonder if degrees are worth the hype.
lead_paragraph: Fall may not be quite in the air yet, but the school year is already beginning on many campuses. And so college freshmen, who just a few months ago tossed their high school graduation caps into the air and heard “Oh, the Places You’ll Go!,” begin a new season of angst.

headline: ICE Detained Man Who Was Driving His Pregnant Wife to a Hospital
abstract: Joel Arrona-Lara was driving his wife to a scheduled cesarean section when he was arrested. The agency said he was wanted for homicide in Mexico.
lead_paragraph: A man was driving his pregnant wife to a scheduled cesarean section on Wednesday when immigration officials arrested him — leaving her to drive herself to a hospital and have the baby on her own, according to the woman and the family’s legal representative.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Fill the last days of the season with jam, pickles and pies. Or, relax and still eat well.
lead_paragraph: Sam is still away, eating raw mussels off the rocks or whatever he does for food up in the Gulf of Maine. I’m here to usher the rest of us into the lull before Labor Day.

headline: If Only Her Voice Could Change the Way the Mets Play
abstract: Marysol Castro is the first female public-address announcer for the Mets. In a bizarre season, she considers herself a voice of hope. Or maybe of reason.
lead_paragraph: The Mets are deep in a season that defies adjectives. Puzzling? Disappointing? Maddening? Bizarre? All apply, which is why Marysol Castro considers herself a voice of hope. Or maybe a voice of reason.

headline: Trump Attacks New York Times Report on Don McGahn’s Cooperation With Mueller
abstract: President Trump said that The Times had falsely implied that the White House counsel “turned” on him. The newspaper said it stood by its report.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY HEIGHTS, N.J. — President Trump attacked The New York Times on Sunday in a series of tweets in which he denounced a report describing the extensive cooperation between the White House counsel, Donald F. McGahn II, and the special counsel’s investigators.

headline: ‘All of Africa Is Here’: Where Europe’s Southern Border Is Just a Fence
abstract: Ceuta, a Spanish enclave on Morocco’s coast, is surrounded by a double 20-foot fence topped with barbed wire, the latest flash point for Europe-bound migrants.
lead_paragraph: CEUTA, Spain — For most migrants from Africa, the last stage of their trip to Europe involves some sort of perilous sea crossing. At the border in Ceuta, there is just a fence.

headline: As Trump Dismantles Clean Air Rules, an Industry Lawyer Delivers for Ex-Clients
abstract: The top air pollution official in the Trump administration had been a lawyer for polluting industries. They are now benefiting from his new role.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As a corporate lawyer, William L. Wehrum worked for the better part of a decade to weaken air pollution rules by fighting the Environmental Protection Agency in court on behalf of chemical manufacturers, refineries, oil drillers and coal-burning power plants.

headline: Rita Borsellino, 73, Dies; a Murder Made Her an Anti-Mafia Crusader
abstract: After her brother, a prosecutor, was killed in a bombing, she campaigned against Cosa Nostra influence in Sicily.
lead_paragraph: In July 1992, the Sicilian Mafia sent a loud and gruesome message to those who would challenge it when it killed a prosecutor named Paolo Borsellino with a car bomb in Palermo. He was the second prosecutor to meet that fate in two months; in May, another bomb had killed Giovanni Falcone.

headline: There Is More to Stacey Abrams Than Meets Partisan Eyes
abstract: As minority leader in the Georgia State House, Ms. Abrams, the Democratic nominee for governor, showed both a penchant for standing on liberal principle and a willingness to negotiate with Republicans.
lead_paragraph: CHATSWORTH, Ga. — Stacey Abrams’s Republican opponent in the Georgia governor’s race is fond of calling her an “out-of-touch radical liberal.”

headline: Taiwan President Stops in U.S. as Relations Warm, Angering China
abstract: President Tsai Ing-wen, over Chinese objections, made two brief stopovers in the last week, meeting with members of Congress who favor closer ties.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan visited Houston over the weekend, her second brief stop in the United States in one week, a sign of efforts to deepen relations between Washington and Taipei despite vehement opposition from China.

headline: ‘This Story Transcends Race’: Kevin Kwan on the Appeal of ‘Crazy Rich Asians’
abstract: The author of the novel, from which the movie was adapted, talks about how the film is opening new doors for its cast and why it’s making white men cry.
lead_paragraph: With its lavish banquets, helicopter escapes and sweeping descriptions of Singapore’s lush coast, Kevin Kwan’s novel “Crazy Rich Asians” practically begs to be turned into a film. But when Mr. Kwan wrote the book, which was published in 2013, he never thought his set pieces would spring to life. “I told a story that I think was very cinematic. Did I ever dare to dream it would ever happen? Absolutely not,” he said in a phone interview with The New York Times on Friday. “I didn’t think I would even get it published to begin with.”

headline: Review: In ‘Mystery Road,’ Judy Davis Goes West
abstract: In a six-episode Australian series, an Indigenous detective and an outback sergeant team up in classic western fashion.
lead_paragraph: Aaron Pedersen, an Aboriginal actor who’s a major star in Australia, first played the Indigenous detective Jay Swan in the 2013 film “Mystery Road” (available on Amazon Prime). Swan is a classic type, the cop caught between his belief in the system and his loyalty to his own people, who automatically see him as a sellout. As embodied by the imposing Mr. Pedersen, he’s also a classic western hero: white hat, casual swagger, stony, squinting stare.

headline: ‘Crazy Rich Asians’ Tops Box Office, Proving Power of Diversity (Again)
abstract: With $25 million in weekend ticket sales, “Crazy Rich Asians” gave Hollywood its best-selling comedy since “Girls Trip,” another unusually inclusive film.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “Crazy Rich Asians,” powered by jubilant reviews and pent-up demand for a major Hollywood film led by Asian stars, took in a strong $25.2 million at North American theaters over the weekend, easily enough for No. 1.

headline: Trucking Wages and Safety
abstract: The head of the American Trucking Associations and two truck-safety advocates discuss an editorial on “the plight of long-distance truck drivers.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Swaying Americans’ View of the Economy
abstract: Readers discuss how and if perceptions change based on political party and which president is in power.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Ignoring Global Warming at Our Peril
abstract: A reader wonders how many more dire effects we must see “before Americans show some bipartisanship in standing up to our president’s folly.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Charter Schools and Racial Justice
abstract: School choice is an answer, not the enemy, an advocate says.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Emaciated by Cancer and Mistaken as a Drug Addict, Filipino Dies in Detention
abstract: When police in the Philippines arrested Allan Rafael, he explained he looked sick because of chemotherapy not narcotics. His death in custody has outraged a loyal constituency of President Duterte.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — In an impoverished area near Manila, the Philippine capital, the body of Allan Rafael lay in a white coffin as distraught relatives reminisced about the cancer-stricken man who died in detention after being arrested in President Rodrigo Duterte’s brutal drug war.

headline: China Trade Talks Resume, and the Fed Chairman Will Speak
abstract: Reports will show whether the housing market continued to slow in July, and Greece officially ends its reliance on financial bailouts.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what to expect in the week ahead:

headline: Interviewing Elon Musk
abstract: For our Corner Office columnist, an hour with a deeply emotional Mr. Musk was not just another C.E.O. interview.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.

headline: Sanitizing Hong Kong of Free Speech
abstract: Pro-China politics once again tries to snuff out any talk of independence.
lead_paragraph: Authorities in Hong Kong want to ban the pro-independence Hong Kong National Party under a law that prohibits groups thought to endanger national security, public safety and public order.

headline: A New, Flourishing Literary Scene in the Real Shangri-La
abstract: The Kingdom of Bhutan, tucked away in the Himalayas, just got TV. Now it’s home to ambitious young authors who are telling their country’s stories for the first time, usually in English.
lead_paragraph: THIMPHU, Bhutan — Not long ago, when Bhutan’s government tried to enroll children in school, parents hid them in the attic and bribed government agents with butter and cheese to go away. Families needed their children as field hands. The last thing they cared about were books.

headline: John Calder, British Publisher Who Fought Censorship, Dies at 91
abstract: His authors included Samuel Beckett and Henry Miller, and he fought in court to publish “Last Exit to Brooklyn,” which had been ruled obscene.
lead_paragraph: John Calder, an independent British publisher who built a prestigious list of authors like Samuel Beckett and Heinrich Böll and spiritedly defended writers like Henry Miller against censorship, died on Aug. 13 in Edinburgh. He was 91.

headline: Donald McGahn, Indonesia, Pakistan: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: To Reach Men, Advertisers Dial In to Sports Radio
abstract: Sports is a niche area in radio over all, but it is increasingly attractive to marketers who want to reach an engaged audience that is primarily male.
lead_paragraph: Sports programming isn’t the most popular stop on the radio dial in Portland, Ore.

headline: Review: Marcelo Gomes Returns to Honor Frederick Ashton
abstract: At the Joyce Theater on Saturday, the Sarasota Ballet presented a program on the 30th anniversary of Ashton’s death, with Mr. Gomes as one of the cast.
lead_paragraph: Saturday was a red-letter day twice over for New York dance-goers: the 30th anniversary of the choreographer Frederick Ashton’s death and the return to the American stage of the dancer Marcelo Gomes. Ashton, though British, always felt his work was better appreciated in New York over more than 50 years of his lifetime; Mr. Gomes — who made an immediate resignation from American Ballet Theater in December after an allegation of sexual misconduct — has been among the city’s most missed dancers.

headline: Gov. Murphy Vowed to Fix N.J. Transit. Now It’s His Problem.
abstract: Gov. Philip D. Murphy promised to reverse New Jersey Transit’s dismal performance. Seven months later, commuters hold him responsible for disruptions.
lead_paragraph: Just seven months into his first term, New Jersey Gov. Philip D. Murphy is already resorting to emergency measures to try to fix New Jersey Transit, the state agency that has been failing to keep its trains running on time — or at all.

headline: Boy’s Lemonade Stand, Shut Down for Lack of Permit, Reopens With Fanfare
abstract: A state health inspector told Brendan Mulvaney he needed a permit to sell lemonade. A national uproar followed. Now he’s back in business.
lead_paragraph: BALLSTON SPA, N.Y. — When a 7-year-old boy’s lemonade stand was shut down by a health inspector here last month, it became the talk of the town. Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo weighed in. A New York State senator introduced legislation in the boy’s name, and the roadside drink entrepreneur’s photo was splashed across newspapers around the country.

headline: Harlem’s Trash Bins Were Overflowing. So the City Took 223 Away.
abstract: New York’s Sanitation Department removes litter baskets if they are used for household or commercial trash. Residents say it’s left sidewalks a mess.
lead_paragraph: The green litter basket had stood on a street corner in Harlem for as long as anyone could remember, collecting unwanted plastic bottles, candy wrappers and crumpled bags and papers.

headline: Trump Lawyers’ Sudden Realization: They Don’t Know What Don McGahn Told Mueller’s Team
abstract: The lapse has contributed to a growing recognition that an early strategy of full cooperation with the inquiry was a potentially damaging mistake.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s lawyers do not know just how much the White House counsel, Donald F. McGahn II, told the special counsel’s investigators during months of interviews, a lapse that has contributed to a growing recognition that an early strategy of full cooperation with the inquiry was a potentially damaging mistake.

headline: Uber’s Vision of Self-Driving Cars Begins to Blur
abstract: Since a self-driving Uber killed a pedestrian in March, the company’s executives have been divided over the future of its autonomous vehicle efforts.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — After Dara Khosrowshahi took over as Uber’s chief executive last August, he considered shutting the company’s money-losing autonomous vehicle division. A visit to Pittsburgh this spring changed that.

headline: Giuliani Says ‘Truth Isn’t Truth’ in Defense of Trump’s Legal Strategy
abstract: President Trump’s personal lawyer, Rudolph Giuliani, made the comment on “Meet the Press” on Sunday in response to a question about a potential interview by the special counsel.
lead_paragraph: First, the facts were alternative, Kellyanne Conway, a counselor to President Trump, suggested last year.

headline: Five Minor Leaguers Who Could Make a Splash in September
abstract: Vladimir Guerrero Jr. is hardly the only top prospect ready to deliver on his minor-league promise should he get a call-up when big-league rosters expand.
lead_paragraph: It has been an incredible year for rookies in Major League Baseball, with Juan Soto of the Washington Nationals, Ronald Acuna Jr. of the Atlanta Braves and Miguel Andujar of the Yankees all looking like seasoned veterans.

headline: Residents of Brazil Border Town Attack Camps for Venezuelan Migrants
abstract: As Brazilians in the northern town of Pacaraima set fire to their tents, hundreds of Venezuelans ran back across the border.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Residents of a border town in northern Brazil that has become a main entry point for Venezuelans seeking refuge destroyed migrant camps over the weekend in one of the most dramatic instances of a backlash to the Venezuelans’ growing presence there.

headline: Apartment Hunting in Astoria
abstract: The listing made the place sound like a good fit.
lead_paragraph: After this, individual Metropolitan Diary items will no longer be posted online. Starting Monday, Aug. 27, the full column will appear weekly online as it does in print.

headline: Meat Entree
abstract: Peter Gordon feeds us well.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Who’s hungry? Peter Gordon is cooking up a storm today, so I hope you brought an appetite.

headline: Trump’s Silly War With Harley-Davidson
abstract: The president’s tariffs led the company to move jobs to Europe. He responded by trying to incite a Harley boycott.
lead_paragraph: Not content to undermine a NATO ally and wipe hundreds of billions of dollars in value from global stock and currency markets, President Trump followed up last week by punching a revered American company in the gut. The motorcycle manufacturer Harley-Davidson, celebrating its 115th year in business, offended the president by having the temerity to move jobs to Europe. The company did so because tariffs that Mr. Trump imposed on imported steel and aluminum, combined with countervailing tariffs from the European Union, raised Harley’s export costs by some $2,200 per bike. Unable to pass that on to European consumers, Harley acted in the face of mounting losses. “Many @harleydavidson owners plan to boycott the company if manufacturing moves overseas,” Mr. Trump tweeted. “Great!”

headline: The New York Times Endorses Zephyr Teachout for Attorney General in Thursday’s Primary
abstract: The office is a potential firewall against an out-of-control president and a historically corrupt New York State government.
lead_paragraph: The most important choice facing New York voters this fall is whom they will pick as their next state attorney general. The office could be the last line of defense against an antidemocratic president, a federal government indifferent to environmental and consumer protection and a state government in which ethics can seem a mere inconvenience.

headline: Greece’s Bailout Is Ending. The Pain Is Far From Over.
abstract: As a new era of financial independence beckons, more than a third of the population is in poverty, unemployment remains high and wages have tumbled.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — When Dimitris Zafiriou landed a coveted full-time job two months ago, the salary was only half what he earned before Greece’s debt crisis. Yet after years of struggling, it was a step up.

headline: Michael Cohen, Trump’s Ex-Lawyer, Investigated for Bank Fraud Over $20 Million
abstract: The inquiry, which could deal a significant blow to President Trump, is entering the final stages. Charges against Mr. Cohen could come in August.
lead_paragraph: Federal authorities investigating whether President Trump’s former personal lawyer and fixer, Michael D. Cohen, committed bank and tax fraud have zeroed in on well over $20 million in loans obtained by taxi businesses that he and his family own, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: Nixon, Clinton and Trump
abstract: The more Trump is cornered, the more he mirrors Richard Nixon.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago last Friday, President Bill Clinton testified before the independent counsel, Kenneth Starr, and a grand jury about his sexual relationship with the White House intern Monica Lewinsky.

headline: Steve Bannon Has Found His Next Trump
abstract: The American president’s former Svengali is palling around the Continent with a far-right Hungarian prime minister. How does this end?
lead_paragraph: “If there’s an explosion or fire somewhere, Steve is probably nearby with some matches,” one of Steve Bannon’s former Breitbart News employees once said (admiringly). So it shouldn’t be surprising that Mr. Bannon, who was Donald Trump’s chief strategist, has arrived in Europe.

headline: Israel’s Latest Culture War Plays Out Under the Wedding Canopy
abstract: Rejecting the strictly Orthodox monopoly over marriage and divorce, Israeli Jews increasingly opt for alternative weddings.
lead_paragraph: KIBBUTZ HULDA, Israel — There was nothing subversive about it at first glance: The bride wore white; the groom broke a glass under the wedding canopy to a hearty “Mazel Tov!”

headline: How Sexism Follows Women From the Cradle to the Workplace
abstract: New economic research suggests that the attitudes toward a woman when she is born have a lasting impact on how much she works, and earns, as an adult.
lead_paragraph: White women born in parts of the United States where sexist attitudes are more prevalent grow up to earn less and to work less than women born elsewhere, relative to men born in those same states, new economic research shows.

headline: They’ll Check on You After Surgery: Meet the Times’s Crossword Puzzlers
abstract: Internet commentary can often be vicious, but fans of The Times’s crossword puzzle have forged a tight-knit and caring community.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.

headline: Staten Island Little League Team Is One Win Away From U.S. Finals
abstract: ‘Mid-Island Mania’ is sweeping the borough as the team beat a Houston team, 2-1. The team has dedicated its dream season to a player’s father who died.
lead_paragraph: The Mets are slogging through another bad season, and the Yankees are far behind the rival Red Sox, but one New York baseball team is playing like a champion: the Mid-Island Little League squad.

headline: ‘We Are Entitled to a Righteous Anger’: Catholics Return to Mass After Sex Abuse Report
abstract: Some area priests, in homilies, confronted last week’s grand jury report detailing the abuse of more than 1,000 children by priests.
lead_paragraph: Some Catholic priests offered fiery homilies, telling parishioners their anger at the sex abuse detailed in last week’s grand jury report was justified, even necessary. Others asked the faithful to pray for the abusers. And some said nothing about the scandal on the first Sunday since the release of the report that detailed 70 years of child sex abuse by hundreds of priests in Pennsylvania.

headline: Yankees Keep Winning Games and Losing Players
abstract: Didi Gregorius was the latest Yankees star to sustain an injury that could keep him from helping in the team’s pursuit of Boston.
lead_paragraph: It seems these days that nothing can be completely favorable for the Yankees. On Saturday, they easily beat the Toronto Blue Jays, 11-6, but their catcher, Austin Romine, took a baseball off his chin, shaking him to the point that he had to be held up by the home plate umpire.

headline: Tesla Slashes Spending, and May Add to Its Troubles
abstract: The electric-car maker’s cash position was closely watched even before its chief executive, Elon Musk, floated the idea of taking the company private.
lead_paragraph: As questions swirl about whether Tesla will go private — and the well-being of its chief executive, Elon Musk — one crucial factor looms large over the fate of the electric car company: Tesla’s own financial health.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Trump Lawyers’ Sudden Realization: They Don’t Know What Don McGahn Told Mueller’s Team
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 20, 2018.
lead_paragraph: “Truth isn’t truth.”

headline: The Mozart of Fly Casting
abstract: Maxine McCormick began fly casting when she was 9 years old. At 14, she has back-to-back world titles.
lead_paragraph: As the competitors in the 2016 Flycasting World Championships arrived at their hotel in Nelijarve, Estonia, some noticed a 12-year-old girl jumping on the hotel’s trampoline.

headline: No Corrections: August 20, 2018
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, August 20, 2018.
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, August 20, 2018.

headline: Asia Argento, a #MeToo Leader, Made a Deal With Her Own Accuser
abstract: The actress and director Asia Argento, among the first women to publicly accuse Harvey Weinstein, arranged to pay an actor after he said she sexually assaulted him when he was 17, documents show.
lead_paragraph: The Italian actress and director Asia Argento was among the first women in the movie business to publicly accuse the producer Harvey Weinstein of sexual assault. She became a leading figure in the #MeToo movement. Her boyfriend, the culinary television star Anthony Bourdain, eagerly joined the fight.

headline: ‘The Affair’ Season 4 Finale Recap: The Gift
abstract: The maddening messiness of adult life is the unifying thread of this week’s season finale.
lead_paragraph: “Everybody’s so crazy,” says Helen Solloway in the final minutes of the final episode of the extraordinary fourth season of “The Affair.” O.K., she employs an uncouth adjective unfit for this publication when she says it, but you get the idea.

headline: ‘Sharp Objects’ Episode 7: Welcome to the Dollhouse
abstract: This week Camille comes to two alarming conclusions.
lead_paragraph: Most episodes of “Sharp Objects” open with Camille awakening from a dream. These feverish montages serve multiple purposes: They mark the beginning of a new day; they conjure a surreal atmosphere that seeps into the characters’ waking lives; and many of them provide a brief, impressionistic recap of the previous episode’s most haunting moments.

headline: Your Indoor Cycling Questions, Answered
abstract: Stacey Griffith is a founding senior master instructor at SoulCycle and author of “Two Turns From Zero.” She teamed up with our editors to answer your questions about all things indoor cycling.
lead_paragraph: Stacey Griffith is a founding senior master instructor at SoulCycle and author of “Two Turns From Zero.” She teamed up with our editors to answer your questions about all things indoor cycling.

headline: Sacha Baron Cohen Pranked Me, Can I Sue? Yes. Win? Not So Much.
abstract: Mr. Cohen has been sued many times. There’s a reason he rarely loses: His unsuspecting subjects don’t read the fine print.
lead_paragraph: Sacha Baron Cohen, disguised as an antiterrorism expert, coaxed Daniel Roberts, an ardent gun rights activist, into biting on a sex toy, and other embarrassing acts, while being filmed. Mr. Roberts thought he was part of a training video. Instead, he was being played for laughs, as part of an episode of Mr. Cohen’s Showtime series, “Who Is America?”

headline: Novak Djokovic Breaks New Ground, Completing Set of 9 Masters Titles
abstract: With a win over Roger Federer in Cincinnati, Djokovic became the first man to triumph in singles at all nine Masters events on the ATP Tour.
lead_paragraph: MASON, Ohio — In an era largely dominated by Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal, it hasn’t been easy to carve out new entries in the record books of men’s tennis.

headline: ‘Insecure’ Season 3, Episode 2: The Bad Decision Index
abstract: Issa gets a much-needed wake up call and Daniel deals with some internal conflict. Who best handled their problems this week?
lead_paragraph: During the Season 3 premiere of “Insecure,” I was shocked by Issa’s baby steps toward successful adulting: She actually made more good decisions than bad ones, unlike what we were used to seeing in the previous seasons. But how did she do this week? And how about Daniel, last week’s Worst Decision Maker?

headline: Baseball Reaches Out to the Next Generation on Their Own Turf
abstract: The second annual Little League Classic featured the Mets and Phillies, though the Little Leaguers will probably remember the players in the crowd as much as the game on the field.
lead_paragraph: WILLIAMSPORT, Pa. — In Section I of BB&T Ballpark here on Sunday night, Logan Castellano had the rare opportunity to sit next to a major league pitcher. So he took advantage and asked Steven Matz, a Mets starting pitcher, for tips on throwing a changeup.

headline: Simone Biles Cruises to All-Around Title at U.S. Championships
abstract: It was mostly a competition for second place as Biles, in her path to the 2020 Olympics, continued to dominate with ease.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Simone Biles had nothing to prove at the United States gymnastics championships this weekend, the second stop on her comeback tour. But she had one person to please: Herself.

headline: Let Kids Play
abstract: Doctors should prescribe playtime for young children, the American Academy of Pediatrics says.
lead_paragraph: The most famous painting of children at play is “Children’s Games,” the 1560 work by Pieter Bruegel the Elder of a town square in which children from toddlers to adolescents (scholars have counted 246) are playing a range of timeless games. There are dolls and marbles and tiddlywinks, ball games and climbing games and riding games (scholars have counted 90 or so). The children are the only ones in town, and their activities offer a kind of taxonomy of play.

headline: Greece, Donald McGahn, Uber: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘MTV Video Music Awards’ and ‘Minding the Gap’
abstract: Watch the 35th annual MTV Video Music Awards. Or stream a touching documentary on Hulu.
lead_paragraph: Watch the 35th annual MTV Video Music Awards. Or stream a touching documentary on Hulu.

headline: How to Ask for Help and Actually Get It
abstract: People want to help you. You just have to ask.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Smarter Living newsletter. Editor Tim Herrera emails readers with tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: Australian Prime Minister Abandons Climate Targets, Bowing to Party Pressure
abstract: On Monday, Malcolm Turnbull announced he would delay a climate and energy policy that divided senior figures in the Australian government.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull of Australia abandoned plans for emission targets Monday, bowing to pressure from conservatives who considered toppling Mr. Turnbull’s government over an energy policy that aimed to reduce prices and bring the country into line with international climate change commitments.

headline: A Visual Record of the Joys, Fears and Hopes of Older Transgender People
abstract: Transgender and gender variant issues have more recently become part of the public consciousness, but many narratives leave out those who are older.
lead_paragraph: In “To Survive on This Shore,” the photographer Jess T. Dugan and the professor Vanessa Fabbre have created a road map, archive and remarkably moving body of work about a group almost entirely left out of many narratives: older transgender and gender variant people.

headline: Two More Earthquakes Hit Indonesian Island, Killing More Than a Dozen
abstract: The earthquakes come as the region was still recovering from an Aug. 5 quake that killed 460 people and wiped out whole villages.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Indonesian island of Lombok was reeling on Monday from two earthquakes that killed at least 14 people a day earlier, just two weeks after a separate earthquake devastated the island and killed at least 460 people.

headline: What Twins Can Teach Us About Nature vs. Nurture
abstract: The relative importance of nature and nurture has been debated for centuries, and has had strong — and sometimes misguided — influences on public policy.
lead_paragraph: The day my identical twin boys were delivered by an emergency cesarean, I noticed a behavioral difference. Twin A, who had been pushed against an unyielding pelvis for several hours, spent most of his first day alert and looking around, while Twin B, who had been spared this pre-birth stress, slept calmly like a typical newborn.

headline: This Drug Is Safe and Effective. Wait. Compared With What?
abstract: Comparative effectiveness research may be the best way to answer questions that patients and physicians face every day.
lead_paragraph: We spend many billions of dollars each year on the discovery and development of new drugs, but almost none of it addresses two crucial questions: How do these new therapies compare with already known ones? What are the relative benefits and harms in a particular situation, for a person like you?

headline: 1918: Germans No Longer Believe in Victory
abstract: A German soldier who had wandered into enemy lines told Americans that his compatriots had given up expectation of victory but would continue to fight.
lead_paragraph: (Special telegram to The Herald.)

headline: Overnight Getaways Before (or After) the Kids Go Back to School
abstract: From Mexico City to Key West, there’s still time for one more quick trip before school starts.
lead_paragraph: A frantic fall schedule may be just around the corner, but hotels in Kansas City, Mo., Mexico City, Miami Beach and Key West, Fla., are offering attractive deals for one last getaway before the end of summer. Whether you want to take the family, or are looking for a getaway once the kids are back in class, these four vacation packages are worth a look.

headline: After the Bitcoin Boom: Hard Lessons for Cryptocurrency Investors
abstract: The number of people who bought virtual currencies more than doubled last winter. For people who got in late, the bust has been disastrous.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Pete Roberts of Nottingham, England, was one of the many risk-takers who threw their savings into cryptocurrencies when prices were going through the roof last winter.

headline: Behind Most Wildfires, a Person and a Spark: ‘We Bring Fire With Us’
abstract: Climate change may be making California’s wildfires more extreme, but they are almost all ignited by human activity, not natural causes.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In the summer of 1965, Johnny Cash was living in the wilderness of Southern California when — possibly high on drugs — he sparked a wildfire with his overheated truck that blazed through more than 500 acres and threatened the lives of endangered condors.

headline: Meet the ‘Change Agents’ Who Are Enabling Inequality
abstract: In “Winners Take All,” Anand Giridharadas explores a global elite that bemoans the state of the world while refusing to seek real, structural change.
lead_paragraph: WINNERS TAKE ALL The Elite Charade of Changing the World By Anand Giridharadas 288 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $26.95.

headline: The Secret to Keeping Black Men Healthy? Maybe Black Doctors
abstract: In an intriguing study, black patients were far more likely to agree to certain health tests if they discussed them with a black male doctor.
lead_paragraph: Black men have the lowest life expectancy of any ethnic group in the United States. Much of the gap is explained by greater rates of chronic illnesses such as diabetes and heart disease, which afflict poor and poorly educated black men in particular.

headline: Marie Kondo, in Reverse: How to Fill a Space
abstract: When her roommate moved out and took all the furniture, a Brooklynite had to furnish an entire apartment. She decided to do it slowly and deliberately.
lead_paragraph: When Jessica Lauretti moved into her two-bedroom in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, five and a half years ago, it marked the end of nearly a decade of kinetic, and at times chaotic, living.

headline: Two U.S. Agents Fired Into Mexico, Killing Teenagers. Only One Faces a Lawsuit.
abstract: The Supreme Court has been asked to decide whether American officials may be sued for cross-border shootings after lower courts reached opposite conclusions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Constitution should mean the same thing in Arizona as it does in Texas. But federal appeals courts have issued starkly different rulings about whether border guards in those states can be held to account for shootings across the Mexican border that took the lives of two teenagers.

headline: My Armenia
abstract: A poet returns to his ancestral country where, after the recent “velvet revolution,” the sense of a new era is palpable.
lead_paragraph: Each time I’ve come to Yerevan in the past decade the city has surprised me with its evolving elegance and cultural richness. The downtown has an energy that is a long way from the sleepy Soviet city I first visited in the 1980s. Walking the shady avenues off Republic Square on a recent visit, I found the city has become a hip place, with wine bars, microbreweries, cafes, art galleries, boutiques selling crafts and carpets, an ever-new array of restaurants, as well as upscale hotels and clothing stores.

headline: Here Are the Lobbying Emails Cuomo Fought Hard to Keep Secret
abstract: New York spent more than $200,000 in legal fees to try to keep nearly 350 pages of the emails secret.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — In January 2016, as Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo was preparing his annual State of the State address, some high-placed state officials knew they had a problem.

headline: Kim Jong-un Focuses on Economy as Nuclear Talks With U.S. Stall
abstract: North Korea’s leader is lashing out against economic missteps as he turns his attention to building prosperity. But he needs American cooperation.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — When North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, visited a hydroelectric dam under construction last month, he reportedly “flew into a rage” after learning why the dam was still unfinished after 17 years of work.

headline: Donald Trump, Asia Argento, Simone Biles: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Why Even a Blue Wave Could Have Limited Gains
abstract: The divergent geography of 2018 means we will really have two midterm elections, and one favors Republicans.
lead_paragraph: The proper way to view the 2018 midterms might not be as one event, but as two very different elections playing out at once. It’s almost Mars vs. Venus: The Senate hinges on red, rural states where Democrats are on defense. But the House will be decided by swing, suburban seats where Republicans are highly vulnerable.

headline: What Does It Mean to Be Human? Don’t Ask
abstract: We don’t see the problem with our self-importance because our narcissism is so complete.
lead_paragraph: Over time, the idea of “being human” has surely meant — and will continue to mean — many things. There is and has never been just one answer. But surely one thing it ought to involve today is the ability to recognize that the question itself is a problem.

headline: Motherhood and the Back-to-College Blues
abstract: Summer is ending, and all my baby birds are leaving the nest.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — It is dusk in August, and the voices of the robins fill the air. All spring I watched these birds building their nests and raising their nestlings, those sharp-eyed babies making harsh, monosyllabic demands. All summer I watched the robins teaching their fledglings to flutter up from the ground and into the tree limbs, or at least the inner branches of a dense shrub, as quickly as they could. Now the young birds have grown past the one-note call of desperation they made under their parents’ care. All the robins, young and old, are singing the same song now. At twilight it is a mournful sound — something less than heartbreaking, something more than melancholy.

headline: Robert Mueller’s Unlikely Witness
abstract: Concerned that he was being set up to take the blame for possible acts of obstruction, the White House counsel started talking to investigators.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Who Is Afraid of Shahidul Alam?
abstract: The imprisonment of Bangladesh’s most respected photojournalist illustrates the country’s drift toward autocracy.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 5, Shahidul Alam, the acclaimed Bangladeshi photojournalist, was dragged from his home by around 30 plainclothes policemen and taken into custody. The policemen forced their way into Mr. Alam’s apartment building at 10:30 p.m., snatched the cellphones of the building’s security guards and destroyed its video surveillance cameras.

headline: New York Today: Congestion for New Jersey Commuters
abstract: Monday: Route 495 repairs and a summer of magic.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this somewhat sunny Monday.

headline: Kofi Annan’s Tragic Idealism
abstract: He believed in the vision of the United Nations but understood that it might never achieve it.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2004, I traveled to Sudan with Kofi Annan, the secretary general of the United Nations. Mr. Annan, who died Saturday at age 80, was hoping to put an end to the genocidal violence that the Sudanese president, Omar Bashir, had launched against the people of Darfur. I watched Mr. Annan sit quietly in a blazing hot shed while a local government official blamed the violence on the Darfuris themselves, handing the secretary general a list of alleged rebel atrocities and complaining bitterly about the role of the United Nations in taking their side. Only when he had finished did Mr. Annan gently ask, “What about the Janjaweed?” — the camel-borne thugs whom he pointed out  the government had unleashed on peaceful villagers. That, another official explained, was rebel propaganda. Then the verbal assault resumed.

headline: Who Made My Puzzle?
abstract: This month’s spotlight shines on constructor Robyn Weintraub.
lead_paragraph: Where do you currently reside?

headline: DealBook Briefing: Who Isn’t Worried About Elon Musk?
abstract: Tesla shares dropped after the company founder’s emotional interview with The New York Times. Investors, and Arianna Huffington, are concerned.
lead_paragraph: Good Monday morning. (Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.) The bull market could become the longest ever on Wednesday.

headline: Your Spit Might Help You Learn to Eat Your Greens
abstract: When people were repeatedly exposed to bitter compounds in a study, their saliva changed to produce proteins that rendered those flavors more palatable.
lead_paragraph: It is not uncommon for children to despise kale, broccoli or the bitter taste of brussels sprouts. By the time we become adults, many of us have learned to eat our greens. But it wasn’t just willpower that helped you develop a taste for foods that once made you grimace. New research shows that proteins in our saliva may adapt and bind to bitter compounds, making them more palatable.

headline: Netflix Tests Promotional Videos but Users See ‘Commercials’
abstract: An experiment by Netflix to highlight some of its shows with promotional videos was met with resistance from viewers who disliked the interruptions.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy for a Netflix subscriber to watch one episode after another of a favorite show: A viewer makes a selection and lets them keep on coming.

headline: For Glenn Close, the Seventh Nomination Just May Be the Charm
abstract: Ms. Close talks about her critically acclaimed role as a long-suffering spouse in “The Wife” and speculation that she may finally land that elusive Oscar.
lead_paragraph: Early in “The Wife,” Joan Castleman listens in as her celebrated husband, Joe, receives the call that writers dream of: He has been awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature. As the speaker extols him for reinventing the very nature of storytelling, the camera zooms in on Joan, portrayed by Glenn Close, her eyes registering a rapid succession of barely perceptible emotions: victory, awe, disbelief, pride, bitterness, even rage. Leaving us to wonder what on earth she could possibly be thinking.

headline: At 59, a Gutsy Chef Makes Her Restaurant Debut
abstract: You won’t necessarily find kebabs at Sofreh, Nasim Alikhani’s new restaurant in Brooklyn, but a bold, modern take on Persian cuisine.
lead_paragraph: In Persian cooking, herbs are measured in epic terms — by the quart, not the tablespoon.

headline: The Russia Fun-House Mirror
abstract: This week I’ll try to make some arguments you might not have heard before.
lead_paragraph: John Brennan, a former C.I.A. director and a self-declared supporter of the Communist Party candidate for president in 1976, claims that he knows that the Trump campaign colluded with the Russians. To my mind, in making this claim, he provided ample evidence of why he should not possess a security clearance. Because if he does actually know this — and if his knowledge is based on information gained through the use of his clearance — then he is guilty of a grave security breach. If not, well, then he’s just a windbag. But one who is coddled and promoted, if not taken totally seriously, by Trump haters. Which makes me wonder when the progressive left got comfortable with the national security state and its spies. It’s just such contortions — on the left and on the right — that have me thinking differently about politics.

headline: ‘We Abandoned Them’: Pope Francis Condemns Sex Abuse and Cover-Up
abstract: “We showed no care for the little ones,” the pope wrote in a letter urging all 1.2 billion Catholics to fight the culture that had enabled abuse.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Pope Francis, whose pace of action on clerical sexual abuse has threatened lasting damage to his papacy, on Monday did what no pope had done before, issuing a letter to all Catholics condemning the “atrocities.” But he offered no specific remedies.

headline: Going Vertical for Instagram’s New Video App
abstract: IGTV, the company’s new venture, allows longer videos, but your clips need to meet a few requirements.
lead_paragraph: Q. What is the difference between posting a video to Instagram and to IGTV?

headline: California Today: At an Oakland Hospital, a New Way to Treat Opioid Addiction
abstract: Monday: Highland Hospital offers treatment on demand, Nia Wilson’s family moves to sue BART, and a collector sells his Disneyland memorabilia.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: After 60 Years, a Bank Robber Returns to the Crime Scene. This Time, Just for a Drink.
abstract: Boyne Lester Johnston stole 260,000 Canadian dollars from a bank in Ottawa in 1958. This month, he sipped Champagne at the bank, now a hip restaurant.
lead_paragraph: When a dapper young bank teller in Ottawa made off with hundreds of thousands of Canadian dollars and slipped across the border in 1958, he instigated an international manhunt.

headline: Korean Families, Separated for 6 Decades, Are Briefly Reunited
abstract: Relatives who live on opposite sides of the inter-Korean border were able to meet for the first time since fighting ended in 1953, in a new round of reunions intended to be a show of good will.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — For two hours on Monday, a 92-year-old woman held her son’s hand and looked him in the eyes for the first time in more than 65 years, as family members from North and South Korea were permitted a rare chance to see one another after war divided their country and separated relatives.

headline: PepsiCo to Buy SodaStream for $3.2 Billion, in Push for Healthier Options
abstract: The deal for the maker of home-carbonation machines is a late effort by PepsiCo’s departing chief executive to firmly steer the company away from sugary sodas.
lead_paragraph: PepsiCo announced on Monday that it planned to buy SodaStream, the popular maker of home-carbonation machines, for $3.2 billion, as the beverage giant extends its bet on products that are not sugary sodas.

headline: What to Cook Right Now
abstract: Make a take on Iranian ghalieh mahi from Nasim Alikhani of Sofreh in Brooklyn, or BLT tacos, or David Tanis’s recipe for nectarine and raspberry cobbler.
lead_paragraph: Morning! This is Tejal, filling in for Sam, and I’m pleased to report that Melissa Clark has not one but two new recipes for us this week. The first is a take on Iranian ghalieh mahi, made by caramelizing onions with herbs and tamarind until it turns into a dark, sweet, tangy mash, and serving it with a crisp-edged piece of cod.

headline: Pope Francis Could Save the Church. Will He?
abstract: The current crisis could be a chance for him to advance his radical vision and turn a crisis into an opportunity for renewal.
lead_paragraph: The Roman Catholic Church’s clergy sex abuse crisis has come roaring back to life as if it were the worst days of 2002, when the scandal tsunami out of Boston seemed to inundate the entire church.

headline: Poor Countries Have an Unlikely Ally Close to the White House
abstract: How China’s growing influence opened the door for a new United States development finance agency
lead_paragraph: In 1971, Richard Nixon was president, the war in Vietnam was dragging on and the People’s Republic of China was trying to assume its place on the United Nations Security Council — one of many instances in which poor countries and former colonies began asserting themselves on the world stage.

headline: I’m a Doctor and Even I Can’t Afford My Student Loans
abstract: When the highest earners struggle with the cost of education, the nation needs to get serious about the problem.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the New York University School of Medicine became the second medical school in the nation to become fully tuition-free. Dr. Robert Grossman, dean of the medical school, cited young physicians’ “crushing debt” as an impetus for the move. One may think that doctors, with their gigantic salaries, are immune to student debt worries, but Dr. Grossman’s announcement made official what many medical school students have long known: The crisis of paying for education has finally caught up with the one percent.

headline: In Alabama, Challenging Hidden Racial Discrimination
abstract: A federal appeals court has allowed fast-food workers to contest a state law blocking the city of Birmingham from raising its minimum wage.
lead_paragraph: STANFORD, Calif. — The city of Birmingham, Ala., where some of the civil rights movement’s most consequential struggles took place 50 years ago, is now ground zero in a new 21st-century fight against economic inequality and racial oppression, with implications for communities of color across the country.

headline: What the Heck Is That?
abstract: A look at one of the entries from last week’s puzzles that stumped our solvers.
lead_paragraph: The United States Military Academy, established in 1802 by President Thomas Jefferson as part of the Military Peace Establishment Act, has appeared in The New York Times Crossword a total of 82 times in its abbreviated form, U.S.M.A.

headline: How to Do a Makeup Look in 5 Minutes. Tops.
abstract: Our columnist books a session with a makeup artist.
lead_paragraph: Lately everyone seems to be a makeup artist. On Instagram there are countless people showing off their skills at contouring their cheekbones and seamlessly blending four colors of eye shadow on their lids. Men do it. Children do it. Rihanna does it.

headline: FIFA Ousts Top Lawyer, Last Senior Link to Blatter Era
abstract: The departure of the Swiss lawyer, Marco Villiger, came as FIFA President Gianni Infantino tries to impose his authority on world soccer’s governing body, and it may not be the last.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — FIFA parted ways with its top lawyer on Monday, removing the last senior official remaining from the Sepp Blatter era, when a corruption scandal devastated the organization’s top leadership and its reputation.

headline: With a Little Wine (and a Lot of Herbs), Clams Turn On the Charm
abstract: Best of the bivalves? Alison Roman says yes, and steams them in a pool of toasted garlic oil with dry white wine.
lead_paragraph: I have more than a few unpopular opinions about food (sandwiches are just O.K.), but I think one that really gets people going is this: Clams are the best bivalves. There, I said it. Raw, they are milder, brinier and cleaner than an oyster. Steamed, they are juicier, meatier and less fishy than a mussel. They are perfect in every way.

headline: Is This the Most Powerful Sculpture at the Met?
abstract: In a corner of the Met Museum, a hand looms out of the darkness. Holland Cotter shows us why one small statue has captured his heart.
lead_paragraph: In a corner of the Met Museum, a hand looms out of the darkness. Holland Cotter shows us why one small statue has captured his heart.

headline: Why You Cried at the End of ‘Coco’
abstract: When the song “Remember Me” plays at the end of “Coco,” everyone cries. Aisha Harris explains why the moment is so powerful.
lead_paragraph: When the song “Remember Me” plays at the end of “Coco,” everyone cries. Aisha Harris explains why the moment is so powerful.

headline: How Robin Williams Made a Joke Both Funny and Sad
abstract: In a 1986 comedy special, Robin Williams performed a routine about his relationship with his 3-year-old son. Dave Itzkoff explains why it's so extraordinary — and revealing.
lead_paragraph: In a 1986 comedy special, Robin Williams performed a routine about his relationship with his 3-year-old son. Dave Itzkoff explains why it's so extraordinary — and revealing.

headline: Who Wants to Be a Gold Medalist?
abstract: The Olympics have reality show auditions now, and they seem to be working.
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — Olympic canoe and kayak coaches were intrigued by Athlete No. 214. After seeing his performance in speed, agility and endurance tests, they asked him to get on a specialized rowing machine and try to maneuver a high-tech kayak in the Olympic training pool.

headline: As Trump Goes on a Twitter Rampage, Melania Trump Announces a Solo Trip to Africa
abstract: Another day of dissonant messaging unfolded from the Trump White House.
lead_paragraph: ROCKVILLE, Md. — Under the banner of her “Be Best” campaign, Melania Trump, the first lady, told a group of cyberbullying prevention experts on Monday that social media “can be destructive and harmful when used incorrectly.”

headline: A James Baldwin Book, Forgotten and Overlooked for Four Decades, Gets Another Life
abstract: The novelist’s only children’s book is coming back into print, and it couldn’t be more timely.
lead_paragraph: “I never had a childhood,” the writer James Baldwin once said. “I was born dead.”

headline: Ann Dowd on ‘The Handmaid’s Tale,’ Aunt Lydia and the Miracle of Forgiveness
abstract: Ms. Dowd, who was nominated for another Emmy for “The Handmaid’s Tale,” discusses what drives Aunt Lydia and Season 2’s controversial ending.
lead_paragraph: This interview includes spoilers for the first two seasons of “The Handmaid’s Tale.”

headline: Three Things to Watch This Week
abstract: Are you in the mood for something silly, emotional or inspiring?
lead_paragraph: What’s your mood? What’s your taste? Do you like “It’s Always Sunny in Philadelphia” or “Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt”? The Times TV critic Margaret Lyons has recommendations below on what you should tune into this week.

headline: Lost Subway Goats Find a New Home, With Help From Jon Stewart
abstract: The comedian picked up the goats that had trotted into the N train line tracks with plans to relocate them to a farm in Watkins Glen, N.Y., a spokeswoman said.
lead_paragraph: The call from the train operator came in just before 11 a.m. on Monday to the New York City subway’s command center, an alert unusual even for a system accustomed to morning commutes with delays: There was a breaking situation unfolding on the tracks.

headline: India Moves to Take Custody of Accused Jeweler Who Fled to Britain
abstract: Indian authorities are seeking the extradition of Nirav Modi, whose designs have been worn by Kate Winslet and Naomi Watts. He is accused of defrauding banks of $2 billion.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Nirav Modi, the jeweler whose designs adorned Hollywood stars but who fled India this year amid accusations that he defrauded banks of $2 billion, has been found in Britain and is the subject of an extradition request, officials said on Monday.

headline: Minnesota Democrats Targeted in Ads Citing Allegations Against Keith Ellison
abstract: An ad campaign launched on Monday by a conservative super PAC used abuse allegations against Rep. Keith Ellison to attack the credibility of four Minnesota Democrats.
lead_paragraph: A conservative super PAC launched an ad campaign on Monday that uses domestic abuse allegations against Representative Keith Ellison, the Democratic nominee for attorney general in Minnesota, to attack other members of his party running for office in the state.

headline: Brett Kavanaugh Urged Graphic Questions in Clinton Inquiry
abstract: A newly released memo shows that Mr. Kavanaugh, President Trump’s Supreme Court pick, took a relentlessly tough stance as a young lawyer investigating Bill Clinton’s affair with Monica Lewinsky.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Brett M. Kavanaugh, President Trump’s Supreme Court nominee, urged prosecutors investigating President Bill Clinton to question him in graphic detail about his sexual relationship with Monica Lewinsky, a White House intern, according to a memorandum released on Monday by the National Archives.

headline: Britain Takes Over a Private Prison Steeped in Filth and Violence
abstract: Staff with the security firm G4S locked themselves in offices for their own safety while blood, vomit and rat droppings littered the hallways, the government says.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British government seized control of a major prison from the private firm G4S on Monday after inspectors reported that the facility had fallen into “a state of crisis,” with prisoners using drugs and administering jailhouse justice with near impunity.

headline: Police Are Attacked in Chechnya; ISIS Claims Responsibility
abstract: Ramzan A. Kadyrov, the Chechen strongman appointed by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, said the attacks had aimed to create “an illusion” of disorder.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — At least four police officers were injured on Monday in a series of attacks in the mountain republic of Chechnya, Russian law enforcement authorities said, raising fears of renewed violence in the restive region.

headline: Review: ‘R.R.R.E.D’ Is a Bad Hair Day
abstract: A future-shock musical comedy about redhead rights could use a makeover.
lead_paragraph: You may have heard that the recessive gene for red hair will be gone by the end of the century. Not true: The rumor appeared to originate with a company testing for genetic ancestry, followed up by research from a certain Oxford Hair Foundation, which turned out to be backed by Procter & Gamble, a manufacturer of hair products.

headline: Bill Cunningham, Style Maven, Leaves Behind a Memoir and It’s ‘a Real Dilly’
abstract: In his posthumous book, “Fashion Climbing,” the Times’s onetime fashion and society photographer recalls his younger days as a hat maker and man about town.
lead_paragraph: Like a pair of pearl earrings from Tiffany’s, Bill Cunningham’s posthumous memoir arrives as if in a small blue box. It’s an unexpected gift. Cunningham, for many years the fashion and society photographer for The New York Times, left it behind when he died in 2016. Apparently no one knew he’d written it.

headline: Pentagon Says an American Is Killed in a Helicopter Crash in Iraq
abstract: Several other troops were injured in the crash that followed a joint counterterrorism operation in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An American service member died in Iraq on Sunday in a helicopter crash following a joint counterterrorism operation, military officials said.

headline: Trump Says Hispanic-American Border Patrol Agent ‘Speaks Perfect English’
abstract: President Trump’s remark about Adrian Anzaldua, who arrested a smuggler in Texas, was the latest example of the president making a racially tinged remark in public.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was supposed to be a White House salute to the heroism of immigration agents who put their lives on the line to protect Americans. But on Monday, President Trump appeared to have something else on his mind: the ethnicity of one of the men he was honoring.

headline: Farfetch, Online Retailer, Plans to Go Public as Luxury E-Commerce Grows
abstract: The London-based online luxury marketplace, which has more than a billion active consumers, has turned to Wall Street to fuel its growth.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Farfetch offers the latest Gucci items delivered to your door in 90 minutes, has distribution deals with brands like Nike and TAG Heuer, and recently started an Arabic-language site to cater to the tastes of wealthy Middle Eastern shoppers.

headline: The End of the Greek Bailout
abstract: This may hurt a bit.

headline: Nicki Minaj Cries Foul, but Travis Scott Is No. 1
abstract: “Astroworld” holds atop the Billboard 200, fending off “Queen” in its debut week. Ms. Minaj complained that industry maneuvering cost her the top spot.
lead_paragraph: In some ways, this week’s Billboard album chart was just a classic contest between two stars: Nicki Minaj, with her first LP in four years, was challenging Travis Scott, the incumbent, for the top spot.

headline: Aasif Mandvi’s One-Man Show Will Return to New York
abstract: “Sakina’s Restaurant,” which originally ran in 1998, will play at the Minetta Lane Theater in October. A Patti Smith show is also in the new lineup.
lead_paragraph: Aasif Mandvi’s “Sakina’s Restaurant” is returning to New York this fall. The actor and writer will perform his one-man show about an Indian immigrant’s experiences working in the food-service industry for four weeks at the Minetta Lane Theater beginning Oct. 5.

headline: Trump and Giuliani Taunt Brennan About Filing a Lawsuit
abstract: Two tweets amounted to an odd “bring it on” challenge to John O. Brennan, the former C.I.A. director, who had mused about suing in response to losing his security clearance.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump and Rudolph W. Giuliani, his personal lawyer, both taunted John O. Brennan, the former C.I.A. director, on Monday, apparently hoping that they could goad Mr. Brennan into filing a lawsuit against the president for revoking his security clearance.

headline: Turkey Drops Travel Ban for German Journalist
abstract: A Turkish court has ruled that Mesale Tolu is free to leave the country while she awaits trial on terrorism-related charges.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A Turkish court has ruled that a German journalist facing trial on terrorism-related charges is free to leave the country, a move that could help improve relations between two countries with deep ties.

headline: A Chinese Pharmacist Found Out He Had Cancer. Then He Vanished.
abstract: Rather than burden his parents with the expense of his treatment, Tang Gongwei chose to disappear.
lead_paragraph: ZHANGJIAJIE, China — Tang Chunwu set off from his room in a ramshackle inn just after sunrise, the beginning of Day 92 in his search for his son.

headline: ‘We Cannot Afford This’: Malaysia Pushes Back Against China’s Vision
abstract: A country that once courted Chinese investment now fears becoming overly indebted for big projects that are neither viable nor necessary — except to China.
lead_paragraph: KUANTAN, Malaysia — In the world’s most vital maritime chokepoint, through which much of Asian trade passes, a Chinese power company is investing in a deepwater port large enough to host an aircraft carrier. Another state-owned Chinese company is revamping a harbor along the fiercely contested South China Sea.

headline: Venezuela Agrees to Pay $2 Billion Over Seizure of Oil Projects
abstract: The state oil company was under pressure after ConocoPhillips, which had won an arbitration ruling in a decade-long fight, seized cargoes and terminals to force compliance.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — More than a decade ago, Venezuela seized several oil projects from the American oil company ConocoPhillips without compensation. Now, under pressure after ConocoPhillips carried out its own seizures, the Venezuelans are going to make amends.

headline: The Police Aren’t the Solution to Chicago’s Violence
abstract: We need more jobs, thriving schools and better access to food.
lead_paragraph: My office is a little different from most people’s. It is under a tent on a street corner in Chicago, a street that straddles Englewood and Auburn Gresham — neighborhoods notorious for violence and poverty. Every day in the summer, volunteers in my organization, Mothers/Men Against Senseless Killings, come from all over the city to help feed and play with the neighborhood children.

headline: Summer 2018 News Quiz | June 1-Aug. 31

headline: 8 Fast-Food Chains Will End ‘No-Poach’ Policies
abstract: The restaurants have pledged to end a practice that prohibited workers from switching jobs within the individual chains.
lead_paragraph: Eight more restaurant chains have agreed to end a policy that blocks workers from switching jobs within the individual brands, becoming the latest companies to curtail a once-prevalent hiring practice that critics say depressed wages for some of America’s lowest-paid employees.

headline: What’s New, and What’s Free, at the 2018 U.S. Open
abstract: A Louis Armstrong Stadium with a roof, a serve clock, Hawk-Eye on every court and a plethora of free events are among the features as the tournament celebrates its 50th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Anderson could hear the clang of fans thumping their sneakers into the metal bleachers during his fourth-round win over Paolo Lorenzi at the temporary Louis Armstrong Stadium during last year’s United States Open. The noise sounded like a toddler brandishing a wooden spoon against the side of an oversized pot.

headline: Trump Complains About Fed Chairman’s Raising of Interest Rates

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump complained to wealthy donors at a fund-raiser in the Hamptons last week that the man he chose as chairman of the Federal Reserve, Jerome H. Powell, has disappointed him by raising interest rates, according to people who attended the event.

lead_paragraph: Roughly 5,300 years ago, a group of ancient sheep herders in East Africa began an extraordinary effort to care for their dead.

lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Uri Avnery, a firebrand Israeli journalist, politician and peace activist who riled the establishment by exposing national scandals and conferring with Yasir Arafat, the father of the Palestinian cause, long before that was legal or fashionable for Israelis, died on Monday in Tel Aviv. He was 94.

headline: Company Is Offering ‘Fur-ternity Leave’ for New Pet Owners

It gave workers a larger commuter stipend, as well as a reason to avoid the office altogether: “fur-ternity leave,” or the ability to work from home for a week to welcome new dogs or cats.

headline: Measles in Europe, Recently at Record Low, Jumps to Highest Level Since ’90s
abstract: A combination of complacency, instability and opposition to vaccination contributes to lagging immunization rates in many countries.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Cases of measles, which appeared headed toward elimination in Europe, have soared this year, reaching their highest level in two decades across the Continent as vaccination rates fall short, the World Health Organization reported on Monday.
