lead_paragraph: News broke Tuesday afternoon that a jury in Alexandria, Va., had found Paul Manafort, President Trump’s former campaign manager, guilty on eight counts: five counts of tax fraud, two counts of bank fraud and one count of failure to disclose a foreign bank account. Minutes before that, in New York, Trump’s former lawyer, Michael Cohen, pleaded guilty to violating campaign finance law and other charges, implicating the president in his statement.

headline: Jeter and Rodriguez Together Again, but Not on the Field
abstract: The two are in Miami because Jeter’s Marlins are playing the Yankees, for whom Rodriguez is a special adviser. Jeter was in shirt and pants; Rodriguez in pinstripes.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — For close to a decade, Alex Rodriguez and Derek Jeter shared the left side of the infield, offering a contrast of what it meant to be a Yankee. Jeter was the shortstop and captain, always playing with poise. Rodriguez was the third baseman and the expert at creating distractions, intended or not. They were side by side far less often after Jeter’s fractured ankle in the 2012 postseason, followed by Rodriguez’s season-long drug suspension two years later. And by the end of the 2016 season, both were retired.

headline: Review: ‘Crime+Punishment’ Is a Tough Documentary About Police Abuses
abstract: A filmmaker follows two cases that expose deep-seated problems in the New York Police Department.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year — not long after Stephen Maing’s documentary “Crime+Punishment” won a special jury award for “social impact” at the Sundance Film Festival — the New York Police Department instituted mandatory “no quota” training for all its officers. The background and meaning of that policy is laid out in Mr. Maing’s meticulous and dismaying film, which also illuminates some of the deep, perhaps intractable problems of policing in New York City and beyond.

headline: Corrections: August 23, 2018
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Thursday, August 23, 2018.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: Anatomy of a Crime: Sex, Hush Money and a Trump Fixer’s Guilty Plea
abstract: Coordinating with Michael Cohen, a tabloid giant turned its tip line into a trip wire for negative stories that could hurt the Trump campaign, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: The federal campaign finance and tax evasion case that is embroiling the White House began in the unlikeliest of places: the world of supermarket tabloids.

headline: We’ve Been Fooled!
abstract: Kyle Dolan demonstrates a farming technique.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — There are many deep and meaningful lessons to be learned from cultivating the earth, and chief among them — despite what the “experts” may tell you — is that Mother Nature adores a good practical joke.

headline: Two Goals, Two Reds and One Tie for Red Bulls and N.Y.C.F.C.
abstract: The two teams played to a draw despite N.Y.C.F.C. ending the game with just nine players because of two ejections.
lead_paragraph: In the four years of the Hudson River Derby, the often-chippy Major League Soccer rivalry between the Red Bulls and New York City F.C., a few themes have emerged.

headline: Education Secretary Considers Using Federal Funds to Arm Schools
abstract: The Education Department may let school districts use money meant for academic enrichment to buy guns, officials with knowledge of the plan say.
lead_paragraph: Updated Aug. 23, 2018: The education community has responded to Secretary DeVos’s policy proposal. Read the latest here.

headline: Rivals Challenge Malcolm Turnbull, Australia’s Leader, as Party Support Fades
abstract: The prime minister’s chances for political survival dimmed on Thursday as at least two cabinet ministers sought to replace him.
lead_paragraph: CANBERRA, Australia — Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull lost the support of key members of his party on Thursday and rivals emerged to challenge his leadership, grinding the House of Representatives to a halt, throwing the government into chaos and giving the revolving door of Australian politics another push.

headline: Quotation of the Day: How a Tabloid and Trump’s Team Kept Scandals Off the Front Page
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, August 23, 2018.
lead_paragraph: “You might say nobody reads the tabloids, but actually most of us do — through inadvertent exposure.”

headline: Verizon Throttled California Firefighters’ Internet Speeds Amid Blaze (They Were Out of Data)
abstract: The allegations were made in court documents filed as part of a net neutrality lawsuit. Verizon says it “made a mistake” and should have removed the restrictions during an emergency.
lead_paragraph: As the largest fire on record in California continued to carve its destructive path through the northern part of the state, firefighters sent a mobile command center to the scene. With thousands of personnel, multiple aircraft and hundreds of fire engines battling the blaze, officials needed the “incident support unit” to help them track and organize all those resources.

headline: Asked to Shoulder the Load for Yankees, Lance Lynn Falters
abstract: With the bullpen depleted, the Yankees left Lynn in the game despite an escalating pitch count. The decision came back to cost them dearly.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Lance Lynn may be built like a plow horse, a barrel-chested pitcher with a constitution built to carry his team deep into games. But the Yankees, with their deep, dominating bullpen, are built to make a man of Lynn’s talents gratuitous.

headline: Donald Trump, Pollution, Facebook: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: It’s Not Easy to Hear
abstract: A reader finds that it’s easy to connect with people who are different. We just have to listen to each other.
lead_paragraph: Australia Diary collects reader stories reflecting Australia’s unique character. Want to share your story, photo, poem or video? Email nytaustralia@nytimes.com.

headline: ‘They Treated Our Men Like Goats’: Guards in Afghan Blast Sue Employers and Canada
abstract: Badly hurt in a suicide attack, Nepali contractors hired to protect Canadian diplomats found they had much less medical coverage than they’d thought.
lead_paragraph: LALITPUR, Nepal — Man Bahadur Thapa cannot sleep. At home in Lalitpur, a Nepali city of ancient temples, the pricking pain from the shrapnel lodged in his body keeps him awake.

headline: As Trade War Intensifies, China Moves to Bolster Its Economy
abstract: Weak growth puts Beijing at a disadvantage in dealing with the White House. But more spending and lending could worsen the country’s addiction to debt.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — As China’s economy slows and the trade war with the United States intensifies, Beijing’s economic bosses are swinging into action.

headline: To Get All the World’s Muslims to Hajj, It Would Take at Least 581 Years
abstract: Because of yearly caps, it would be impossible for Islam’s 1.8 billion worshipers to all make the pilgrimage to Mecca, a once-in-a-lifetime obligation.
lead_paragraph: Because of yearly caps, it would be impossible for Islam’s 1.8 billion worshipers to all make the pilgrimage to Mecca, a once-in-a-lifetime obligation.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘Follow This’ on Netflix and the Season Finale of ‘American Woman’
abstract: Watch a documentary series about Buzzfeed journalism on Netflix and catch the season finale of “American Woman.”
lead_paragraph: Watch a documentary series about Buzzfeed journalism on Netflix and catch the season finale of “American Woman.”

headline: Todd Frazier Powers Mets Past the Giants
abstract: Frazier delivered his third multi-R.B.I. game of the month as the Mets won for the 12th time in the last 19 games.
lead_paragraph: Todd Frazier delivered an R.B.I. double to cap a three-run second inning and added a solo homer in the seventh as the Mets beat the San Francisco Giants, 5-3, Wednesday at Citi Field.

headline: China Forces Out Buzzfeed Journalist
abstract: Megha Rajagopalan, who had written extensively about a crackdown on Muslim minority groups, said the Chinese authorities did not explain their decision.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — An American reporter for Buzzfeed News has become the latest foreign journalist to be forced from China, which has a history of retaliating against news organizations and individual journalists for critical coverage.

headline: Australia Bars China’s Huawei From Building 5G Wireless Network
abstract: American officials have long worried that Chinese tech firms such as Huawei and ZTE could be involved in espionage. Those jitters are now going global.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The fog of cyberespionage concerns surrounding Huawei has for years kept the Chinese technology giant largely out of the United States. Now it has cost the company potentially lucrative business in another country: Australia.

headline: Why You Should Take Time to Mourn During Career Transitions
abstract: Grief is common when you leave a job you love.
lead_paragraph: On my last day in the newsroom at a North Carolina alt-weekly, I found myself choking back tears. For the first time in almost a decade, my desk was completely clean. All of my old reporter notebooks, past newspaper editions and sticky notes with scribbled writing on them were in the trash.

headline: 5 More Cheap(ish) Things That Could Disproportionately Improve Your Life
abstract: Small things can have huge ramifications.
lead_paragraph: For years I was against the idea of paper planners. I thought they were cumbersome, wasteful and, in the age of Google Calendar, simply unnecessary. The pinnacle of redundancy.

headline: ‘My Moms Never Tried to Hide the Fact That We Were a Family’
abstract: Katie Swanger set out to celebrate her family by photographing her two mothers and the men who have become her brothers.
lead_paragraph: Katie Swanger once proudly told her friends on the school bus that she had two moms who loved each other just like their moms and dads did. That was after she eagerly told her nursery school classmates that you do not need both a man and a woman to make a baby.

headline: Playing for Lenny: Musicians Recall the ‘Magical’ Bernstein
abstract: He could be flamboyant or restrained. Furious or loving. Players from several orchestras recall what it was like to be conducted by Leonard Bernstein.
lead_paragraph: Leonard Bernstein’s centenary, like the man it honors, can feel over the top, with more than 2,500 events on six continents over two years. (What, they don’t like “West Side Story” in Antarctica?)

headline: Brash, Confident and Democratic: How Leonard Bernstein Symbolized America
abstract: Five writers on what made the protean Bernstein, born 100 years ago, one of the most indelible figures in the history of the arts.
lead_paragraph: A man, a country and an era came together in Leonard Bernstein, the musician of the American century.

headline: Pope Will Visit a Changed Ireland. How Much Difference Can He Make?
abstract: Once the bedrock of European Catholicism, Ireland has legalized gay marriage, elected a gay prime minister and voted to strip a ban on abortion this year.
lead_paragraph: MURRISK, Ireland — On the sacred mountain where St. Patrick is said to have fasted before banishing Ireland’s snakes into the sea, Geraldine Reilly walked past grazing sheep, a statue of the nation’s patron saint and a sign informing pilgrims how to gain indulgences through praying “for the intentions of our Holy Father the Pope.”

headline: In Praise of Bernstein as Conductor: Movement That Mesmerized
abstract: To his fans, especially the baby boomers who were the target audience for his Young People’s Concerts, his theatrical podium persona was thrilling.
lead_paragraph: Whenever Leonard Bernstein had to list his profession on a form, he always wrote “musician.” He liked the comprehensiveness of the word, which encompassed composing, performing, teaching, advocating on behalf of living composers. Still, as he ruefully acknowledged, Bernstein will probably always be best known for a particular part of his musicianship: as a conductor, certainly the most influential American maestro of the 20th century.

headline: What Leonard Bernstein Should You Listen To?
abstract: We provide suggestions about recordings and upcoming live performances focused on the conductor and composer whose 100th birthday is Aug. 25.
lead_paragraph: So you want to explore more Leonard Bernstein at his centenary? An easy entry into his discography — really, into classical music — is his 1959 recording of Gershwin’s “Rhapsody in Blue” (with Bernstein as the piano soloist with the Columbia Symphony Orchestra) and “An American in Paris” (with the New York Philharmonic). That same year, his first Broadway musical, “On the Town,” received a stellar studio recording, with the show’s lyricists, Betty Comden and Adolph Green, in the cast.

headline: Turkey’s Colorful Carpet Fields Bask in Summer Sun
abstract: Tens of thousands of rugs are laid out every year to soften their colors for a market that prefers pastel tones.
lead_paragraph: From above, they may look like Dutch tulip fields. But these are Turkish carpets, laid out to bask in the summer sun.

headline: When Your Heart Fails You
abstract: We control my heart from a laptop. So why do I feel so helpless?
lead_paragraph: My heart is broken. But not the way you think I mean. It’s actually broken. Doctors call it heart failure, but since I’m not the type of person who likes to fail at anything, I’ll just say that it is broken. It’s permanent, though, and that’s the hardest thing for me to accept. My heart can no longer do the things it was born to do, and it never will again.

headline: Hold your breath: a song of climate change
abstract: Selected by Rita Dove.
lead_paragraph: Hold your breath and sing at the same time? Impossible. Yet the excuses for inaction in Bob Hicok’s parable of environmental greed rapidly rise to a rousing chorus of denial. W.H. Auden’s “The Age of Anxiety” has devolved into an age of outrage whose citizenry has grown adept at justifying procrastination to the point of changing course to suit its comfort. Hicok’s exhortation to accept responsibility for our future falls on conveniently stoppered ears: The final line, with its rhyming monosyllables, lands like a judge’s gavel. Selected by Rita Dove

headline: There’s Less to Portraits Than Meets the Eye, and More
abstract: Photographing faces has become a means of surveillance, but a carefully made portrait can still, like nothing else, remind us of a common humanity.
lead_paragraph: Portraiture existed long before photography was invented. And for more than a dozen years after photography’s invention, it was practically impossible to make a photographic portrait: the required exposure times were too long. But the two eventually came together, and now their pairing seems so natural that it’s as though photography was invented for making portraits.

headline: Readers Respond to the 8.12.18 Issue
abstract: Here’s what they had to say about the Pentagon’s failed campaigns in Iraq and Afghanistan and Paul Ryan’s retirement.
lead_paragraph: Readers respond to the 8.12.18 issue.

headline: Naomi Osaka’s Breakthrough Game
abstract: The 20-year-old is poised to burst into the top tier of women’s tennis. Can she also burst Japan’s expectations of what it means to be Japanese?
lead_paragraph: The temperature in Boca Raton had soared above 90 degrees, but on a side court at the Evert Tennis Academy, Naomi Osaka was just digging into one of her last training sessions before the summer hardcourt season. Wearing leggings and a tank top — her magnificent mane of frizzy blond-tinted hair emerging from the back of her Adidas cap — the 20-year-old smacked crisp topspin groundstrokes with her coach, Sascha Bajin, a German of Serb descent best known for working as Serena Williams’s hitting partner for eight years. On the sideline, Osaka’s Japanese mother, Tamaki, sat in the shade in a denim jumpsuit and sunglasses, her daughter’s miniature Australian shepherd sitting by her feet. Pacing on the grass alongside the court was her Haitian-born father, Leonard Francois, a taciturn man in a baseball cap who trained her from age 3 and still tracks nearly every shot she hits.

headline: Talking Sex With Dad (in the Ford Taurus)
abstract: You know that scene in “Lady Bird” when Saoirse Ronan throws herself out of a moving vehicle to avoid talking to her mother for another second? That was me, at 14, in the car with my father.
lead_paragraph: Before his fingers had reached the volume knob to turn off Steely Dan, I already knew: My bookish and tightly wound father was about to tell me something I did not want to hear.

headline: Dev Hynes: ‘Untitled Improvisation #1’
abstract: Watch the polymath musician behind Blood Orange build a song on drum machine, keyboard, guitar, voice and cello.
lead_paragraph: Watch the polymath musician behind Blood Orange build a song on drum machine, keyboard, guitar, voice and cello.

headline: The Question We Must Keep Asking
abstract: We can only define ourselves by continually re-evaluating our humanness.
lead_paragraph: Many of the problems in the world today, when one reflects upon them, call for an answer to an ancient question: What is it to be human?

headline: Five Tips to Give Kids Some Culture and a Vacation at the Same Time
abstract: Traveling with the whole family is a great way to open your children's eyes to a world beyond their front door — but that doesn’t mean you can’t have fun, too. Here’s how.
lead_paragraph: “Of course you want your children to have fun on your family vacation, but why not give them a flavor of the local culture while they’re doing so?,” said Niamh O’Connell, vice president of guest experience at Rosewood Hotel Group. “When kids have some understanding of the destination they’re in, their trip becomes more memorable and enriching,” she said. “It goes beyond the usual fun in the sun escape.”

headline: The Best Players Never to Win the U.S. Open
abstract: From Bjorn Borg and Vitas Gerulaitis to Evonne Goolagong Cawley and Amélie Mauresmo, these players came close but were never able to win in New York.
lead_paragraph: Bjorn Borg did not like the United States Open. He didn’t like the rambunctious New Yorkers, the nighttime lights — all the stuff his archrivals Jimmy Connors and John McEnroe reveled in.

headline: By the Book: George Pelecanos
abstract: The crime novelist and screenwriter George Pelecanos, whose new book is “The Man Who Came Uptown,” would want Gladys Knight to write his life story: “Music heads will get that one.”
lead_paragraph: The crime novelist and screenwriter George Pelecanos, whose new book is “The Man Who Came Uptown,” would want Gladys Knight to write his life story: “Music heads will get that one.”

headline: The Stories That Would Have Been: The 1978 U.S. Open
abstract: A strike shut down New York City’s three daily newspapers about two weeks before the Open. A longtime reporter wrote fresh accounts of the matches we missed.
lead_paragraph: About two weeks before the 1978 United States Open, a strike shut down New York City’s three daily newspapers, putting a crimp into the print coverage of the tournament’s shift to the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows, Queens, from its 54-year home at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills.

headline: How FireEye Helped Facebook Spot a Disinformation Campaign
abstract: The cybersecurity company has shifted its attention to detecting disinformation and uncovering social media campaigns intended to influence politics.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — FireEye, a cybersecurity company that has been involved in a number of prominent investigations, including the 2016 attack on the Democratic National Committee, alerted Facebook in July that it had a problem.

headline: On Multiple Screens, John Akomfrah Deftly Weaves Tales of the African Diaspora
abstract: At the New Museum, a survey of John Akomfrah’s ambitious videos shows the artist reflecting on politics, nature, postcolonial history, migration and race.
lead_paragraph: John Akomfrah’s extraordinary survey at the New Museum, “Signs of Empire,” should be required viewing for those who consider themselves activists, artists, critics or leaders — or people who simply want to expand their worldview.

headline: How Dev Hynes, English Misfit, Became Blood Orange, R.&B. Miracle Worker
abstract: The polymath musician is a whole new model of artist, daubing his signature sensibility over music, film, dance and everything else he touches.
lead_paragraph: On a sticky late-spring Saturday in New York, Devonté Hynes was on the set of the video for the song “Jewelry,” one of his newest solo recordings under the name Blood Orange — a typically restless, jazzy slow jam that starts as a spoken-word poem and ends as a kind of languid rap. The “set,” in this case, meant the sidewalk on a slip of street running west to east between Sixth Avenue and Washington Square Park. As with most of the videos the 32-year-old Hynes has created since he began making music professionally, back in his late teens, he was directing this one himself.

headline: 36 Hours in Thessaloniki
abstract: Greece’s second city is filled with remnants of its multilayered past, but sprinkled among the monuments are plenty of modern diversions.
lead_paragraph: Frequently outshone by the idyllic Aegean Islands, and overshadowed by the ancient glories of Athens, Greece’s second-largest city is hardly a household name. But the buzzing metropolis in the country’s northern mainland doesn’t need to trade on its looks or fame to earn respect. The once-powerful port is still filled with the Unesco-listed remains of the three empires that ruled it — the Romans, the Byzantines and the Ottomans — as well as many traces of its multireligious past, which saw Muslims, Christians and Jews living side by side. (Two world wars, a Turkish-Greek population exchange in the 1920s and the deportation of the Jews in the 1940s effectively ended the “Jerusalem of the Balkans.”)

headline: A Rebirth for Alabama Democrats? Not So Fast
abstract: Democrats were euphoric after Doug Jones’s Senate victory, but even he says “you’re not going to see a giant blue wave” in one of America’s reddest states.
lead_paragraph: MONTGOMERY, Ala. — When Doug Jones won a Senate seat in Alabama last December, many Democrats celebrated the outcome as a watershed, while Republicans saw it as a blip.

headline: The Courts of New York City
abstract: In the city that hosts the U.S. Open, playing tennis on a regular basis can feel like an administrative and logistical boondoggle for New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: In the city that hosts the United States Open, playing the sport on a regular basis can feel like an administrative and logistical boondoggle for tennis-loving New Yorkers like myself. To paraphrase one of John McEnroe’s most famous outbursts, for recreational tennis players New York City can be the “absolute pits of the world.”

headline: Giraffe Parts Sales Are Booming in the U.S., and It’s Legal
abstract: An investigation showed imports made into pillows, boots and other items have become increasingly popular, at a time when the animal’s global population is dwindling.
lead_paragraph: At a time when the giraffe population is plummeting in the wild, the sale of products made with giraffe skin and bone is booming.

headline: Back-to-School Blues
abstract: Just in time for the new semester, the graphic novelist Victoria Jamieson draws a reflection on the trials of junior high.

headline: When the Best Move Is Staying Put
abstract: They scoured both sides of the Hudson River for the perfect rental. What they found was a new sense of purpose.
lead_paragraph: Corey Nolan arrived in New York four years ago from his hometown, Atlanta, moving in with a friend who owned a large two-bedroom in a West Village co-op — “a dream situation,” he said.

headline: Paul Manafort, Hawaii, Urban Meyer: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Breaking Norms Will Renew Democracy, Not Ruin It
abstract: Most of President Trump’s alleged transgressions offend against the etiquette of modern liberal governance, not the Constitution.
lead_paragraph: Hardly a day goes by without President Trump being accused of breaking a presidential norm or two, doing something that no president has ever done — nor, it’s implied, ever ought to do.

headline: The Man Who Wrote Mueller’s Rules
abstract: The regulations for investigating a president were devised with checks and balances in mind. That’s why Congress may have the final say.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: New York Today: A Beach in Manhattan
abstract: Thursday: Readers weigh in on a proposed beach and river swimming rules.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this dazzling Thursday.

headline: Man on Terror Watch List Kills Relatives Near Paris, Officials Say
abstract: The assailant, who was killed by the police, was on a terrorism watch list. But the French interior minister described him as having “important psychiatric problems.”
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A man on a terrorism watch list fatally stabbed his mother and sister, and seriously wounded another person, in a Paris suburb on Thursday, before the police shot him to death, the authorities said.

headline: Search Your Souls (What’s Left of Them), Republicans
abstract: Senators and representatives, now is the time to stand on the right side of history.
lead_paragraph: How many people from Donald Trump’s campaign and inner circle have to confess to crimes or be convicted of them before it is clear to everyone — Republicans especially — that the campaign was guided by criminals, if not was a criminal enterprise itself?

headline: Trump Cites False Claims of Widespread Attacks on White Farmers in South Africa
abstract: Citing “large scale killing of farmers” and land seizures, President Trump tweeted that he had asked Secretary of State Mike Pompeo to investigate.
lead_paragraph: CAPE TOWN, South Africa — President Trump waded into South Africa’s proposal to seize land from white farmers, saying in a post on Twitter late Wednesday that he had asked Secretary of State Mike Pompeo to “closely study” the “the large scale killing of farmers” — a claim disputed by official figures and the country’s biggest farmer’s group.

headline: DealBook Briefing: The Biggest Ever I.P.O. Is on Hold
abstract: Saudi Aramco says its landmark public debut isn’t canceled, but there’s no timeline for getting it back on track.
lead_paragraph: Good Thursday. Want this in your inbox every morning? Sign up here.

headline: An Eclectic Lineup at a Festival Dogged by Scandal
abstract: The Ruhrtrienniale festival in Germany presents unpredictable works in postindustrial settings. But this year controversy has overshadowed the event.
lead_paragraph: ESSEN, Germany — The Ruhrtriennale, an international arts festival that reanimates the disused factories of Germany’s rust belt every summer, has acquired a reputation for being ambitious, eclectic and unpredictable.

headline: Review: ‘Blue Iguana’ Takes Two Goofballs, Adds a Caper and Comes Up Empty
abstract: Sam Rockwell and Ben Schwartz star in this heist film written and directed by Hadi Hajaig.
lead_paragraph: In a change of pace for the distinguished character actor Sam Rockwell, his new role in the action comedy “Blue Iguana,” is Eddie, a muscled meathead whose brutish charm is only appreciable in contrast to the oafishness of Paul (an amiable Ben Schwartz), Eddie’s partner in crime.

headline: Review: In ‘What Keeps You Alive,’ a Couple, a Cabin and a Crisis
abstract: A couple’s blissful vacation turns dark in Colin Minihan’s film.
lead_paragraph: The opening shot of “What Keeps You Alive” is a mouse’s eye view of tall ominous trees. The second is of a car turning down a darkly lit street, which veers toward a home perched on a hill.

headline: Review: In ‘Searching,’ a Clever Conceit and John Cho as Leading Man
abstract: The entirety of the action in Aneesh Chaganty’s psychological thriller unfolds on screens, apps and online.
lead_paragraph: At its core, “Searching” is like any number of thrillers about tracking down a missing person: John Cho plays David Kim, a single father whose teenage daughter Margot (Michelle La) doesn’t come home one night or make it to school the following morning. Distraught, David combs through the trail of her online presence and passes along findings to Rosemary Vick (Debra Messing), the lead detective on the case. Days go by and the clues don’t turn up Margot, but they are revealing: David learns he does not know as much about her as he once thought. He takes things into his own hands, suspicious of those around him and increasingly unsatisfied with Vick’s investigation.

headline: Review: ‘An L.A. Minute’ Isn’t Worth the Time
abstract: The film, starring Gabriel Byrne, is meant to skewer the mores of Tinseltown.
lead_paragraph: In this miserable misbegotten picture, Gabriel Byrne plays Ted Gould, a best-selling author living in Hollywood, where his books are regularly adapted into films. His latest, “Kinky Cadavers,” is about a homeless serial killer, and as a publicity stunt some associates of his have arranged a photo shoot of a buffet for some genuine unfortunates. These folks are a little unruly; they make for the food as if they’re really hungry, because they are. Ted’s agent gets a bowl of pasta upended on his head. How’s that for épater-ing le bourgeois?

headline: Review: In ‘The Bookshop,’ Seeking Calm, Finding Conflict
abstract: Emily Mortimer and Bill Nighy form a tender connection in this film adaptation of Penelope Fitzgerald’s 1978 novel.
lead_paragraph: The Spanish director Isabel Coixet might have been the best thing to happen to “The Bookshop,” a gently disruptive adaptation of the 1978 novel by the English writer Penelope Fitzgerald. A more conventional filmmaker might have nudged this scathing attack on class entitlement in the romantic-comedy direction that early scenes seem to tease. Instead, Ms. Coixet highlights the undertow of subtle savagery in her genteel material, giving its picturesque setting — an English coastal village in 1959 — a more sinister, cynical cast.

headline: Review: ‘Maison du Bonheur,’ a Beguiling Portrait of a Woman in Paris
abstract: Sofia Bohdanowicz’s documentary captures a way of life through the observations of a delightful woman who has occupied the same apartment for 50 years.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2015, the Canadian documentary filmmaker Sofia Bohdanowicz undertook an experiment. She traveled to France, where she had spent an early and apparently unhappy part of her life, and moved in with Juliane Sellam, the 77-year-old widowed mother of a colleague in Quebec. Her intent, as Ms. Bohdanowicz puts it in voice-over in “Maison du Bonheur,” was to film Ms. Sellam in an attempt to understand and possibly capture a “way of life.”

headline: Review: Economic Anxiety Leads to Violence in ‘Arizona’
abstract: Rosemarie DeWitt and Danny McBride star in this grisly dark comedy set during the housing meltdown of 2009.
lead_paragraph: The wonderful actor Rosemarie DeWitt, undervalued by mainstream Hollywood, gets a showcase of sorts in “Arizona,” a grisly dark comedy set in the title state during the 2009 housing market meltdown.

headline: Review: In ‘Makala,’ the Difficulties of Selling Charcoal in Congo
abstract: The director, Emmanuel Gras, closely follows a man as he tries to improve his life.
lead_paragraph: Reviewers have cheered “Makala” since it won the top prize last year at Cannes in Critics’ Week, a parallel festival devoted to first- and second-time feature directors. The case for it has some appeal: Rooting for its principal subject is irresistible, and — while pushing at the edges of what constitutes a documentary — it captures a type of work that movies seldom show.

headline: Trump Denounces Justice Dept. as Investigations Swirl Around Him
abstract: The president chiefly blamed Attorney General Jeff Sessions, complaining that he never “took control” of the Justice Department.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump blamed the Justice Department on Thursday for the investigations surrounding him, criticized the deal struck with his former lawyer Michael D. Cohen and lashed out at Attorney General Jeff Sessions, who countered with a rare public rebuke of the president.

headline: In Serial Rape Case That Stumped Police, Genealogy Database Leads to Arrest
abstract: The police in Fayetteville, N.C., used DNA records to track down a suspect in six rape investigations tied to the Ramsey Street Rapist.
lead_paragraph: About a decade ago, Fayetteville, N.C., was terrorized by a series of rapes committed on and around a major thoroughfare on the northern side of the city.

headline: Review: In ‘Hot to Trot,’ a Look at Same-Sex Ballroom Dancing
abstract: The documentary follows the format that was so successful for the spelling-bee film “Spellbound,” but it doesn’t have the same results.
lead_paragraph: Follow contestants as they prepare for forthcoming competitions; film them as they compete. This template for documentaries, perhaps popularized by the spelling-bee movie “Spellbound,” is getting to be too easy. Not only does it provide nonfiction filmmakers with a clear narrative arc, but it also tips them off about when it’s safe to stop shooting. A contest, won or lost, is over when it’s over.

headline: Why Are We Talking About Impeachment?
abstract: If campaign finance violations qualify as high crimes and misdemeanors, elections won’t be able to settle anything.
lead_paragraph: My inbox was full on Wednesday. Michael Cohen. Paul Manafort. Collusion! Corruption! Grifter! Crook! These were the words that kept popping up in emails from people who see Cohen’s plea deal as a vindication of their deeply held opinions of the president. Trump supporters who emailed me had a different set of themes: Mueller, Clinton, Obama, double standards, conspiracy — all the way up to ruling-class privilege.

headline: Alibaba Had a Bright Quarter, Despite Clouds Over China’s Economy
abstract: Chinese stocks are slumping. The currency is down. But serving the country’s middle-class shoppers still seems to be rollicking good business.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The escalating trade fight between China and the United States is making this an uneasy time for the world’s second-largest economy. Chinese stocks have slumped. The currency has gone for a ride.

headline: Amazon Tribe Never Seen by Outsiders Is Spotted by Drone
abstract: A Brazilian expedition captured images of the indigenous peoples and their tools, along with an aerial photo of a thatched hut.
lead_paragraph: New video footage from a drone shows the first images of members of an isolated Amazon tribe that had no known contact with the outside world, the Brazilian government said this week.

headline: Spanish Soccer Players Threaten to Block Match in U.S.
abstract: The league is hoping to increase revenue by raising its profile overseas, but players are concerned that the demands placed on them are excessive.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — When representatives of Spain’s top soccer league announced last week that they planned to stage a series of regular-season games in the United States, part of an effort to increase television and international sponsorship revenue, they apparently failed to consult a group essential to making the match happen: the players.

headline: U.K. Outlines Plan to Avert Chaos of a No-Deal ‘Brexit’
abstract: Britain hopes that preparing to leave the European Union without an agreement will strengthen its negotiating hand. But its findings show millions of Britons would suffer.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British government issued its first contingency plans on Thursday for leaving the European Union without an agreement, seeking to prepare the public for possible disruptions without spreading alarm that could undermine support for the entire undertaking.

headline: Make Several Gmail Addresses Out of One
abstract: Thanks to the way Google processes your mail, you can modify part of your address for different situations and still get all your messages.
lead_paragraph: Q. Do periods matter in Gmail addresses? I get messages addressed to my account at firstnamelastname@gmail.com but also to firstname.lastname@gmail.com, and none of these seem to be meant for other people.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s properties include a three-bedroom in Millstone, N.J., and a five-bedroom in Great Neck, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a three-bedroom in Millstone, N.J., and a five-bedroom in Great Neck, N.Y.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties are in Turtle Bay, Kips Bay and Crown Heights, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are in Turtle Bay, Kips Bay and Crown Heights, Brooklyn.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
abstract: This week’s properties include a three-bedroom in Millstone, N.J., and a five-bedroom in Great Neck, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
abstract: This week’s properties are in Turtle Bay, Kips Bay and Crown Heights, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: California Today: The Human Element in California’s Wildfires
abstract: Thursday: How people start or exacerbate blazes, a sudden opportunity for Duncan Hunter’s challenger, and a teetotaler’s guide to Sonoma County.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Attempted Hacking of Voter Database Was a False Alarm, Democratic Party Says
abstract: The Democratic National Committee says suspicious activity was merely a test by the Michigan Democratic Party, which did not inform the national committee.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The suspected hacking attempt of the Democratic National Committee’s voter database this week was a false alarm, and the unusual activity that raised concern was merely a test, party officials said on Thursday.

headline: Home Building, By the Numbers
abstract: Planning to build a house? Here is where your money will go.
lead_paragraph: Finding a house that perfectly fits your needs can be challenging, to say the least. Chances are, you’ll have to compromise.

headline: Cynthia Nixon Says She Can Win. But Who Are Her Voters?
abstract: Polls show Ms. Nixon trailing far behind Gov. Andrew Cuomo. But her campaign insists she’s reaching a new electorate not captured by the old metrics.
lead_paragraph: Bonsu Thompson was, by his own admission, an unlikely host for a fund-raiser for Cynthia Nixon’s campaign.

headline: In ‘Small Fry,’ Steve Jobs Comes Across as a Jerk. His Daughter Forgives Him. Should We?
abstract: Lisa Brennan-Jobs has written a memoir about her famous father. The details are damning, but she doesn’t want them to be.
lead_paragraph: When Steve Jobs told his daughter Lisa Brennan-Jobs that the Apple Lisa computer was not named after her, it was not a cruel lie to a little girl, she insists — he was teaching her “not to ride on his coattails.”

headline: The Stealth Drivers of the Record Bull Market
abstract: Stocks go up when the economy and earnings do well, but there were other reasons for the current upswing.
lead_paragraph: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

headline: Laura Benanti to Join ‘My Fair Lady’ on Broadway
abstract: The Tony-winning actress will portray Eliza Doolittle in the hit musical revival.
lead_paragraph: Henry Higgins will have to grow accustomed to a new face: the Tony-winning actress Laura Benanti is joining the cast of “My Fair Lady” as Eliza Doolittle.

headline: Living History on the Lower East Side
abstract: A look at life before modern amenities, at the Tenement Museum.
lead_paragraph: Can you believe next week is the last unofficial week of summer? Which of these adventures have you loved most? Send us your best stories and photos from our itineraries this season at summer@nytimes.com.

headline: How to Ask for a Raise
abstract: Think beyond salary. Act when your boss feels ugly.
lead_paragraph: ‘‘Don’t,” says Margaret Ann Neale, a professor at Stanford University’s Graduate School of Business. “Women especially are penalized when they ask for more money.” Instead, make a proposal to your boss that illustrates multiple ways in which your skills help solve the organization’s problems. Your increased compensation will be in there, just not as a single-issue zero-sum request.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on the Ethics of Chess-Strategy Books
abstract: Is reading them a form of plagiarism?
lead_paragraph: Angel writes: My college roommate, Reid, studies chess strategy. I want to play against him, not someone else’s intellectual property. He does this a lot. When we first met, he would make esoteric, absurd jokes that I only later learned were from your book “The Areas of My Expertise.”

headline: Hidden Wounds of Yemen’s War
abstract: The war in Yemen has reduced the country’s people to destitution, forcing many to beg for survival.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — On a recent evening, Ali al-Hajori, a man in his 60s, was begging on 70th Square in the western part of Sana, the capital of Yemen. Mr. Hajori, whose lips were parched, would stop by each car pulling over at a public park and raise his right hand in an appeal for help. As the sun set over the war-torn country, Mr. Hajori walked back to a rented room, where he lived with his family, who have been starving.

headline: ‘Suspiria’ Trailer: If You Thought Ballet Was Scary in ‘Black Swan’ ...
abstract: The remake, directed by Luca Guadagnino, stars Dakota Johnson and Tilda Swinton, who some think is playing dual roles despite what the filmmakers have said.
lead_paragraph: After releasing a teaser that was long on grotesque atmosphere but short on plot details, Amazon Studios has put out a follow-up trailer for its forthcoming shocker “Suspiria” that lays out the story more fully. Like the director Dario Argento’s 1977 Italian horror film of the same name, the remake follows an American ballet student (Dakota Johnson) who enrolls in a German dance school, only to discover it houses murderous secrets.

headline: Manafort Jury Holdout Blocked Guilty Verdicts on 10 of 18 Charges, Juror Says
abstract: “We laid it out in front of her again and again,” a juror, Paula Duncan, told Fox News. “She still said she had reasonable doubt.”
lead_paragraph: Paul Manafort, President Trump’s former campaign chairman, would have been convicted on all 18 charges of financial fraud but for one holdout juror, who forced a mistrial on 10 counts, another member of the jury said on Wednesday.

headline: Reality Winner, Former N.S.A. Translator, Gets More Than 5 Years in Leak of Russian Hacking Report
abstract: Reality Winner, who pleaded guilty, “knowingly and intentionally betrayed the trust of her colleagues and her country,” the prosecutor said.
lead_paragraph: Reality Winner, the former Air Force linguist and intelligence contractor who pleaded guilty in June to leaking a top-secret government report on Russian hacking, was sentenced on Thursday to five years and three months in federal prison.

headline: Betsy DeVos Eyes Federal Education Grants to Put Guns in Schools
abstract: The Education Department is considering allowing states to tap a fund for educational overhaul and improvement to buy guns for educators, a use not approved by Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Congress created its academic support fund three years ago, lawmakers had in mind a pot of money that would increase student access to art and music, mental health and technology programs at the nation’s most impoverished schools.

headline: How College Basketball’s Rule Changes Could Backfire
abstract: By allowing players to hire agents, the N.C.A.A. may have hastened amateurism’s demise.
lead_paragraph: College basketball is in crisis. Last year, a federal indictment brought to light the ways in which big-name programs, agents and apparel companies worked together to give top players special treatment, including bribing them. In a response to the scandal, the N.C.A.A. convened a panel to propose reforms, and this month it announced a series of rule changes around college players and the N.B.A. draft.

headline: 13 Great Movies Expiring From Netflix in September
abstract: Every month, as various licenses expire, streaming services lose movies and TV series from their catalogs.
lead_paragraph: Watching is The New York Times’s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.

headline: When Fear of Strangers Is Fatal
abstract: Stoking parental fear about predators inspires vengeance.
lead_paragraph: This summer in India, two dozen innocent people died at the hands of mobs convinced that they were meting out justice to kidnappers. One was a software engineer beaten to death after giving chocolates to children outside a school. One was a 65-year-old woman who got lost on a trip to a temple with her family and stopped to ask for directions. All five family members were stripped naked and beaten with fists, sticks and iron rods. One was hospitalized in a coma. A woman named Rukmani died in the street.

headline: Argentine Police Officer Promoted After Breast-Feeding Neglected Baby
abstract: After a colleague posted a photo of officer Celeste Ayala breast-feeding a neglected baby at a hospital, a small act of kindness turned into national news.
lead_paragraph: A policewoman in Argentina has been promoted after a photo of her breast-feeding a neglected baby at a hospital while in uniform went viral.

headline: Hawaii Braces for a Rare Encounter With a Hurricane
abstract: The storm is threatening to be the first hurricane to make landfall in Hawaii since 1992, but officials are warning of life-threatening impacts even if it skirts the islands.
lead_paragraph: For Friday’s latest updates, read our Hurricane Lane live briefing here.

headline: I Dated My Friend’s Ex. Will He Keep Hating Me Forever?
abstract: Maybe, but you could try giving him some space and apologizing.
lead_paragraph: A close friend, 32, dated a woman for eight months, then broke up with her. Three months later, I began dating her after hanging out with her in groups. I told my friend my intentions. (The woman and I dated briefly, but it didn’t work out.) I knew my friend wouldn’t like it, but he’s furious and our relationship now seems irreconcilable. “I forgive you,” he said. “But I don’t want your friendship.” I’ve tried reasoning and apologizing until I’ve run out of things to say. Is there anything I can do to salvage our friendship? What am I not seeing?

headline: The Week in Good News: Dementia Treatment, a Young Fly-Casting Champion, Two Lost Goats
abstract: Sometimes it seems as if we’re living under a constant barrage of heavy news. But it isn’t all bad out there.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes it seems as if we’re living under a constant barrage of heavy news. But it isn’t all bad out there. This feature is meant to send you into the weekend with a smile, or at least a lighter heart. Want to get The Week in Good News by email? Sign up here.

headline: E-Cigarettes May Raise Risk for Heart Attack
abstract: Compared with people who never used e-cigarettes, daily users almost doubled their risk for heart attack.
lead_paragraph: E-cigarettes may not be as harmless as many people think. A new study suggests they significantly increase the risk for heart attack.

headline: 7 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Two very different works of fiction lead off this week’s list of recommended books. Olga Tokarczuk’s “Flights,” winner of this year’s International Man Booker Prize, feels untethered from time and space, blending fiction and fact, moving across different historical periods. Delia Owens’s debut murder mystery “Where the Crawdads Sing,” on the other hand, is deeply rooted in its specific world: the North Carolina marshlands. The rest of the list is nonfiction: a history of Citigroup and its predecessors; a manifesto arguing for literary excellence; an eyewitness account of upheavals in Egypt; a lament for the toll taken by climate change; and a memoir about being married to a monk.

headline: Top C.E.O.s Denounce Trump Immigration Policy as Threat to U.S. Economy
abstract: Timothy D. Cook of Apple, Ginni Rometty of IBM and dozens of other C.E.O.s said new guidelines and practices were hindering skilled foreign workers and harmful to economic growth.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of American business leaders are challenging the Trump administration over changes to immigration policy that they say threaten the livelihoods of thousands of their skilled foreign workers, and the nation’s economic growth and competitiveness as well.

headline: Are You the Next Voice of New York Today?
abstract: New York Today is hiring a voice for our indispensable early-morning newsletter.
lead_paragraph: New York Today is hiring a voice for our indispensable early-morning newsletter.

headline: From Obama to Fox News: The Term ‘Polish Death Camps’ Persists, and Poland Objects
abstract: Poland has often warned against the use of the misleading term for Nazi-run camps, and this year it passed a law banning the phrase.
lead_paragraph: The Polish government criticized a Fox News program this week after a headline on screen referred to “Polish death camps,” a misleading term that has a history of setting off diplomatic incidents and as of this year is illegal to use in Poland.

headline: Just 21 People Are Known to Have This Rare Genetic Condition. Can You Help Us Find More?
abstract: The patient, now 6, began suffering brief spells of slowing and drooping around the time she turned 1.
lead_paragraph: The patient, now 6, began suffering brief spells of slowing and drooping around the time she turned 1.

headline: Mary Pratt, Realist Painter of Household Scenes, Dies at 83
abstract: Ms. Pratt, defying early advice that only her husband could become a painter, became a popular artist in Canada and something of feminist champion.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago, Mary Pratt was mopping the floor of her family’s isolated cottage in rural Newfoundland when she was taken by the sight of the sunlight on an unmade bed and its red blanket.

headline: Briton Arrested in Iran in 2016 Is Given 3-Day Furlough to See Family
abstract: The imprisonment of Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, a British woman of Iranian descent accused of sedition, has been a major issue between Britain and Iran.
lead_paragraph: A British woman of Iranian descent incarcerated in Iran on sedition charges since 2016 was granted a three-day furlough on Thursday to see her young daughter and other relatives, a break in a bitter dispute between Britain and Iran.

headline: The Knicks Make It to the Finals — in an Alternate Reality
abstract: The N.B.A. 2K League is the first official esports league operated by a U.S. professional sports league.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Friday night, the Knicks and the Wizards jogged out of the locker rooms in a red brick warehouse in Long Island City and tossed white towels into the outstretched arms of cheering fans.

headline: Special Envoys Were Once Disdained Under Trump. Now They’re Popping Up All Over.
abstract: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo announced that he would appoint a special envoy to North Korea, the third such announcement he has made in a week as he moves to fill depleted diplomatic ranks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo announced Thursday that he was appointing a special envoy to handle negotiations with North Korea. Just days earlier, he introduced special envoys for Iran and Syria, equally knotty problems. Another for Afghanistan is said to be in the offing.

headline: There’s Plenty to Read About the ‘Trial of the Century’
abstract: Two new books explore the drama surrounding the murderous love triangle between Evelyn Nesbit, Harry K. Thaw and Stanford White.
lead_paragraph: The epigraph of Mary Cummings’s book about the trial of the century — the early 20th, at least — pretty much sets the tone for the tawdry, misogynistic and, even in the 21st century, painfully familiar narrative that follows in the latest recaps of Stanford White’s murder, one by her and another by Simon Baatz.

headline: Marilu Henner, the Former ‘Taxi’ Star, Doesn’t Need a Grocery List
abstract: The 66-year-old actress, who stars in the Broadway musical “Gettin’ the Band Back Together,” remembers everything.
lead_paragraph: Marilu Henner had her last bite of cheese 39 years and one day ago.

headline: Alice Dunnigan, First Black Woman to Cover White House, Will Get Statue at Newseum
abstract: The daughter of a Kentucky sharecropper, Ms. Dunnigan endured poverty, segregation and sexism as she fought to fulfill her dream of becoming a journalist.
lead_paragraph: The daughter of a Kentucky sharecropper, Alice Allison Dunnigan endured poverty, segregation and sexism as she fought to fulfill her dream of becoming a journalist.

headline: Trump Put a Low Cost on Carbon Emissions. Here’s Why It Matters.
abstract: How much economic damage will global warming cause? It’s a tough calculation, and the answer, to a big extent, determines how easily the government can roll back environmental rules.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — How much economic damage will global warming cause? That’s one of the key questions embedded in the Trump administration’s recent proposals to weaken Obama-era regulations on greenhouse gas emissions from both vehicles and power plants.

headline: Details of the Ohio State Report on Urban Meyer
abstract: Meyer was suspended by the university for 3 games after an investigation found fault with the way he handled the case of Zach Smith, an assistant coach who was accused of domestic violence.
lead_paragraph: Urban Meyer, the highly successful head coach of the Ohio State football team, has been suspended without pay for three games after a university investigation found fault with the way he handled the case of Zach Smith, an assistant coach who was accused of domestic violence.

headline: The Camaraderie of the Long-Distance Relay Runner
abstract: Relays give those who haven’t participated in a team sport since high school or college a way to be part of a team again.
lead_paragraph: For long-distance runners tired of banging out mile after lonely mile by themselves, there is an alternative: the relay race. And while the big-name relays have traditionally been overnight — and costly — events, shorter relays are adding more affordable and realistic options, whether they’re stand-alone events or additions to an established marathon.

headline: Should These Tests Get a Failing Grade?
abstract: High scores on standardized tests are crucial for students seeking admission to elite schools. But faulty questions may be skewing the scores.
lead_paragraph: I haven’t had to take a standardized test in decades. Before I took the SAT, when I was a senior in high school, I had no coaching or test preparation. As far as I know, none was then offered in the small Midwestern city where I grew up. Still, I did well enough to gain admission to DePauw University, and later Harvard Law School, and I doubt I’d be where I am today were it not for my test scores.

headline: Review: ‘Pula!’ Dancing for Rain on Broadway
abstract: The story in this song-and-dance show from Botswana turns on drought but the experience is one of abundance.
lead_paragraph: One of the first things you learn in “Pula!, Botswana on Broadway,” the large-spirited song-and-dance show performed by the I Love Botswana Ensemble, is that the non-English word in the title means “rain” and that rain is all-important to this semiarid African nation. The story that follows turns on drought. But the experience is one of abundance.

headline: An Artist Warns of a Robot-Ruled Future. Or Is It Our Present? Let’s Discuss.
abstract: At the Guggenheim, an art critic and The Times’s former Shanghai bureau chief discuss a brilliant new artwork that dissects China’s economic development.
lead_paragraph: No young artist has a sharper view of the future than Cao Fei. Her dreamlike visions of China’s full-tilt economic development, and the social dislocation and environmental abasement that have come with it, were the most beguiling and unnerving parts of her acclaimed midcareer retrospective at MoMA PS1 in 2016.

headline: David Pecker, Chief of National Enquirer’s Publisher, Is Said to Get Immunity in Trump Inquiry
abstract: Mr. Pecker is close to President Trump and Michael D. Cohen, his former lawyer, and had been integral to a campaign effort to help protect Mr. Trump from embarrassing stories about women.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors reached an immunity deal with the tabloid executive David J. Pecker, a key witness in their monthslong investigation into payments during the 2016 campaign to two women who said they had affairs with Donald J. Trump, according to two people familiar with the investigation.

headline: An Avant-Garde Theater Artist Gets Her Due
abstract: María Irene Fornés is being celebrated at MoMA and the Public Theater. Her colleagues and students reflect on her enduring legacy.
lead_paragraph: María Irene Fornés never had a play that opened on Broadway. Few of her 40 full-length works are regularly presented on major professional stages. Yet as anonymous as she is in the wider culture, she is revered by many in the theater world.

headline: I Stood Up in Mass and Confronted My Priest. You Should, Too.
abstract: Catholics should not keep on filling the pews every Sunday. It is wrong to support the church.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Last Sunday, I did something that no properly raised Catholic ever does. I stood up in the middle of Mass and called out the priest.

headline: Elon Musk Wants to Take Tesla Private. Can He Make the Math Work?
abstract: A buyout of the electric-car maker would be complicated and costly.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk says he wants to take Tesla private. The electric car company’s chief executive announced that he was considering as much with an impulsive tweet on Aug. 7, and expanded on his thinking in a letter to employees, a blog post and an interview with The New York Times.

headline: Review: ‘The Innocents’ on Netflix Is a Stylish, Slender Teen Romance
abstract: This new series about a 16-year-old with a strange power is on the brooding side of the mutant-teenager spectrum.
lead_paragraph: From among the transformational metaphors for teenage alienation — turning into a vampire, turning into a human spider — “The Innocents,” a handsome new Netflix series, goes with the plain vanilla variety. Its heroine, a 16-year-old British girl named June, is a basic shape-shifter, who takes on other people’s forms when she’s frightened: a girl she’s dancing with, a nurse, a burly Norwegian who’s trying to kidnap her.

headline: We Spy Two BlacKkKlansmen — and One is Omarosa
abstract: Both Ron Stallworth and Omarosa Manigault Newman tell us about the white institutions they infiltrated.
lead_paragraph: This week, we realize we have two black klansmen on our hands — one on the big screen in the form of Spike Lee’s new film “BlacKkKlansman,” and one on the small screen in the form of America’s most notorious reality show villain turned ex-White House employee, Omarosa Manigault Newman. Both the film and person showcase black people infiltrating hostile white institutions and coming out the other side to tell us about it. We question, however, if the message they’re bringing us was worth the journey.

headline: Weakening Rules on Coal Plant Emissions
abstract: Readers are concerned about the effects on Americans’ health and global warming, and point out that poor minority communities will be among the most affected.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Beware the Tick
abstract: A reader offers advice for keeping companion animals safe.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: De Blasio Is Stalled on School Integration, but Brooklyn Parents Have a Plan
abstract: The plan for District 15 — which includes Park Slope, Sunset Park and Red Hook — would scrap the screened admissions process for middle school students and replace it with a lottery.
lead_paragraph: As New York City reckons with the fact that its schools are among the most segregated in the nation, a swath of Brooklyn synonymous with fiercely progressive politics is about to test how effective a local integration effort can be.

headline: Army Recommends Silver Star for Captain Criticized in Deadly Niger Ambush
abstract: The appeal to recognize Capt. Michael Perozeni’s acts of valor in the Oct. 4 firefight contrasts with earlier findings that he filed misleading plans for the mission.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Green Beret team leader who was singled out in a Pentagon investigation for blame after a deadly ambush in Niger last October has now been recommended for one of the military’s highest valor awards, officials said.

headline: Purveyors of Juice-Box Style, Nicotine-Filled E-Liquids Quit Selling the Products
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration had targeted 17 makers and sellers of items loaded with nicotine in packaging that could appeal to children.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Makers of e-cigarette and vaping liquids like One Mad Hit Juice Box, V’Nilla Cookies & Milk, Unicorn Cakes and other products with packaging that could appeal to children have stopped selling them, according to the Food and Drug Administration.

headline: The Failure of Republicans to Speak Out
abstract: Readers discuss the president’s praise for Paul Manafort and criticize Republicans for not standing up to Mr. Trump.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: It’s the Summer of Challenges
abstract: Challenges get shared. Challenges get fans. Challenges make hits.
lead_paragraph: We’ve seen challenges before. The Ice Bucket Challenge, in which people had ice water dumped on them and sometimes raised money for ALS research, and the Mannequin Challenge, in which groups of people remained still in videos. But in the summer of 2018, challenges have proliferated rapidly and have been a dominant format on social media.

headline: The Bitter Regrets of a Useless Chinese Daughter
abstract: I used to spurn what I saw as an excess of pragmatism in my culture. After my mother had a stroke, I understood.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t until a whole week later that I found out my mother had had a stroke.

headline: End Stock Buybacks, Save the Economy
abstract: Big companies have squandered $4 trillion since 2007 buying their own stock. It’s time to rein them in.
lead_paragraph: Since the 1980s, corporate boards in the United States have embraced as dogma the position that companies should be run primarily for the benefit of their shareholders. The stranglehold of this doctrine of “shareholder-value maximization” over corporate decision making has been a leading cause of inequitable incomes, unstable employment, and sagging productivity.

headline: Woman Sues Mario Batali, Saying He Groped Her in Boston Bar
abstract: A Massachusetts woman says the celebrity chef offered to take a selfie with her, then kissed and grabbed her.
lead_paragraph: A Massachusetts woman who says the celebrity chef Mario Batali sexually assaulted her at a Boston bar in April 2017 filed a lawsuit against him on Wednesday, seeking damages for the infliction of emotional distress following sexual assault.

headline: Italy to Frick Collection: Give Our Painting Back
abstract: The Italian government had issued an export license for the portrait last year, but now argues that it had not realized the subject was a Borghese prince.
lead_paragraph: The Frick Collection doesn’t make acquisitions lightly, so when the museum announced in December 2017 that it had bought a painting, its first purchase of one since 1991, the art world took special note of the new addition to the museum’s collection, a full-length portrait of Prince Camillo Borghese by the French painter François Gérard.

headline: Google Deletes 39 YouTube Channels Linked to Iranian Influence Operation
abstract: The accounts were linked to the state broadcaster, the company said. The news followed similar moves by Facebook and Twitter.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Two days after Facebook revealed far-reaching Iranian and Russian disinformation campaigns on its social network, Google said Thursday that it had removed 39 YouTube channels linked to the Iranian state broadcaster.

headline: This Conspiracy Theory Should Worry Trump
abstract: When two or more people join together to break the law, as Michael Cohen says he and the president did, the penalties can be harsh.
lead_paragraph: President Trump needs a new defense. He started out with the claim that he didn’t know anything about payments that his former lawyer Michael Cohen arranged or made to the former Playboy model Karen McDougal and the pornographic film actress Stormy Daniels. Mr. Cohen’s tape destroyed that assertion, at least as it applied to Ms. McDougal.

headline: One Tesla Investor Wants It to Stay Public
abstract: Elon Musk has insisted that taking the company private would allow it to achieve its potential. A letter from ARK Invest on Thursday took issue with his argument.
lead_paragraph: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

headline: Review: In ‘Support the Girls,’ Sisterhood Is Funny, Essential and Sweet
abstract: A perfectly cast Regina Hall stars in this stealth charmer about women working in a Texas sports bar, the latest from the director Andrew Bujalski.
lead_paragraph: Lisa, the general manager of a Texas sports bar called Double Whammies, spends a lot of time putting out fires. The would-be thief she discovers at the start of her shift is just the beginning of her epically challenging yet ordinary day in Andrew Bujalski’s stealth charmer “Support the Girls.” There are also rats, a meanspirited boss, a larcenous employee and of course the customers, who guzzle and chow down while ogling the skimpily dressed waitresses or the blaring TVs. Welcome to America!

headline: New York’s Yeshiva Students Deserve Better
abstract: Elected officials should require Orthodox Jewish schools to meet legal standards.
lead_paragraph: In 2015, concerned parents, teachers and former students filed a complaint to New York City’s Department of Education charging that 39 ultra-Orthodox Jewish schools in the city failed to give children a basic education, violating state law that requires instruction to be “substantially equivalent” to that in public schools.

headline: The Passion, and Sometimes Profit, of Vintage Racing
abstract: Amateur racers get the joy of rounding a track in a car built for speed, and can still end up with a prize investment.
lead_paragraph: In the best sporting tradition, Douglas Cushnie doesn’t like to talk about how much his vintage Bugatti — a 1927 Type 35C Grand Prix — might be worth.

headline: What Is Being Lost in Our Era of Discontent?
abstract: Australia is part of a larger trend, with leaders elected to act on our behalf encouraging or being threatened by venal instincts. Tell us the impact you see in your life.
lead_paragraph: The Australia Letter is a weekly newsletter reflecting the experience (and quirks) of our Australia bureau chief. Sign up to get it by email. Here’s where to find all our Australia and New Zealand coverage.

headline: María Isabel Chorobik de Mariani, Crusading Argentine Grandmother, Dies at 94
abstract: Ms. Mariani’s long search for her abducted granddaughter drew attention to the crimes of Argentina’s military junta in the 1970s. She never found the girl.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — María Isabel Chorobik de Mariani, who stood up to Argentina’s military junta during the 1970s in the search for abducted children as a founder of the Grandmothers of the Plaza de Mayo, died on Monday in La Plata, near Buenos Aires. She was 94, having never found the granddaughter she lost

headline: Malcolm Turnbull, Trade War, Amazon Tribe: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: After Worst Kerala Floods in a Century, India Rejects Foreign Aid
abstract: The United Arab Emirates offered $100 million to help the recovery, but the Indian government turned it down.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — After devastating floods killed more than 400 people and engulfed entire towns in a southern state in India, the United Arab Emirates offered $100 million to help the recovery.

headline: Treasury Issues Crackdown on State and Local Tax Workarounds
abstract: A proposed rule aims to foil states that sought to counteract provisions of the new federal law. But taxpayers elsewhere may also be affected.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Treasury Department moved on Thursday to block states from circumventing new federal limits on state and local tax deductions.

headline: Russian Trolls Used Vaccine Debate to Sow Discord, Study Finds
abstract: Twitter accounts that were used to meddle in the 2016 presidential election also sent both pro- and anti-vaccine messages and insulted parents.
lead_paragraph: “Don’t get #vaccines. Illuminati are behind it.”

abstract: Previews, openings and some last-chance picks.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages and a few last-chance picks of shows that are about to close. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.

abstract: Our guide to film series and special screenings.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to film series and special screenings happening this weekend and in the week ahead. All our movie reviews are at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.

abstract: Our guide to the city’s best classical music and opera happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to the city’s best classical music and opera happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

abstract: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for children and teenagers happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for children and teenagers happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

abstract: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
