abstract: Duncan Hunter was a war hero and promising politician, but now his life is falling apart amid a corruption scandal that jeopardizes the Republican Party’s grip on a key district.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — In Alpine, Calif., a suburban Southern California enclave, Duncan Hunter was a good neighbor. He’d help people do yard work, or move heavy furniture. He drove the same dented-up truck for years. At parties, he’d have a beer, two tops, and he might go off and sneak a cigarette so his wife wouldn’t see. He rarely talked about his job as a congressman.

headline: The Nuclear Power Plant of the Future May Be Floating Near Russia
abstract: Offshore reactors could be cheaper, safer and more flexible, proponents say, making them a useful weapon against climate change. Critics are incredulous.
lead_paragraph: MURMANSK, Russia — Along the shore of Kola Bay in the far northwest of Russia lie bases for the country’s nuclear submarines and icebreakers. Low, rocky hills descend to an industrial waterfront of docks, cranes and railway tracks. Out on the bay, submarines have for decades stalked the azure waters, traveling between their port and the ocean depths.

headline: John McCain, Pope Francis, Myanmar: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Historians Seek Proof of Tennis’s Oldest Tales
abstract: What order which people started playing tennis in the 1870s has been a point of contention for those who think they have a claim to having been first.
lead_paragraph: Asked if his new book will upset people, Richard A. Hillway answered immediately in the affirmative.

headline: Actors and Writers on Neil Simon: ‘When He Laughed, You Knew You’d Hit His Truth’
abstract: TV showrunners and comedy stars on what the prolific playwright left behind.
lead_paragraph: Neil Simon, the playwright behind hits like “Barefoot in the Park” and “The Odd Couple,” died on Sunday. Mr. Simon wrote for television and movies, but his work on Broadway came to define his legacy. He was remarkably prolific, racking up over 9,000 performances of his work between 1965 to 1980.

headline: Report on VW Progress After Emissions Scandal, and Consumer Spending Data
abstract: Businesses have a last chance to give feedback on a proposal for additional tariffs on Chinese goods, and bankers in Germany discuss the threat to their business posed by technological change.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what to expect in the week ahead:

headline: Echoes of Gunshots and ‘Goodfellas’ on a Quiet Bronx Street
abstract: A botched ambush seems a throwback to days when organized crime had power in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: The shots popped at 6:30 on the sunny morning of July 11, at the corner of a quiet street near the water in the Bronx. Just off Tierney Place in Throgs Neck, Salvatore Zottola, 41, was ambushed by a gunman, who sped off while Mr. Zottola, full of gunshot wounds, rolled on the pavement.

headline: Arizona Governor Faces a Tough Choice: A Senator Made From McCain’s Mold or Trump’s
abstract: The vacant Senate seat of the late John McCain has exposed the rift between his followers and the party’s Trumpian base.
lead_paragraph: Senator John McCain’s death this weekend laid bare the long-simmering Republican tensions over who will be appointed to fill his Arizona seat, pitting the pragmatic wing of the party that Mr. McCain represented against the ascendant, hard-line forces loyal to President Trump — and hostile to the late senator.

headline: Review: A Sprawling ‘Days to Come’ Has Everything Except Central Figures
abstract: The Mint Theater Company’s revival of Lillian Hellman’s 1936 play is a mishmash of acting styles, tonally uneven and frustratingly unfocused.
lead_paragraph: Lillian Hellman’s “Days to Come” begins with domestic conspiracy in an expensively appointed living room — one servant firmly coaxing another to hand over her wages because, she says, “The boys need it.” In the middle of the Great Depression, the local men are striking against the factory that is the engine of their Ohio town, and the dispute shows no sign of being resolved. In fact, it’s about to amp up.

headline: Neil Simon Drew Big Laughs, Then Came a Cultural Shift
abstract: Though he remains the greatest American comic playwright, Mr. Simon was standing over a fault line in the culture that eventually pulled him down.
lead_paragraph: In my high school’s production of “The Odd Couple,” I played Roy, one of slobby Oscar Madison’s poker buddies.

headline: In Name Only
abstract: Susan Gelfand notices something cool about certain entertainers.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — When I took this job, I was promised there would be no math. And yet here we are, adding things together. Well, not things, but people.

headline: Artificial Intelligence Is Now a Pentagon Priority. Will Silicon Valley Help?
abstract: The Defense Department, believing that A.I. research should be a national priority, has called on the White House to “inspire a whole of country effort.”
lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — In a May memo to President Trump, Defense Secretary Jim Mattis implored him to create a national strategy for artificial intelligence.

headline: Live-Stream Captures Shooting at Gaming Event in Jacksonville
abstract: Multiple fatalities were reported at a mass shooting on Sunday in Jacksonville, Fla., at a live gaming event.
lead_paragraph: Multiple fatalities were reported at a mass shooting on Sunday in Jacksonville, Fla., at a live gaming event.

headline: John McCain’s Parting Message: Our Greatness Is in Peril
abstract: Today’s Republican Party is the biggest threat to the country that McCain served and loved. He offered an alternative.
lead_paragraph: John McCain was no moderate. He won Barry Goldwater’s Arizona seat in 1986 and was, for the most part, a fitting heir to Goldwater. McCain supported a smaller federal government, a hawkish foreign policy and the typical Republican positions on abortion, guns and other issues.

headline: Emboldened by Parkland, Newtown Students Find Their Voice
abstract: Students who were in fourth grade at Sandy Hook during the 2012 massacre are starting 10th grade. Many are becoming more vocal about mass shootings.
lead_paragraph: NEWTOWN, Conn. — Last year, Natalie Barden heard an announcement about a meeting of the Junior Newtown Action Alliance, a club for high school students working to reduce gun violence.

headline: Tech Industry Pursues a Federal Privacy Law, on Its Own Terms
abstract: With California setting a benchmark for restrictions, companies are lobbying to supersede it with proposals that would give them wide leeway on how they handled personal data.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Technology companies have taken plenty of hits on privacy this year. In May, Europe began enforcing a sweeping new law that lets people request their online data and restricts how businesses obtain and handle the information.

headline: Prison Strike Organizers Aim to Improve Conditions and Pay
abstract: Prisoners are protesting a growing number of deaths in custody and demanding an end to forced or underpaid and unpaid labor.
lead_paragraph: The inmates at North Carolina’s Hyde Correctional Institution hung three banners from the prison fence last week as supporters gathered outside. One sign asked for better food; another requested parole; the third said, “In solidarity.”

headline: 8 Dead, Including 6 Children, in Chicago Fire, Officials Say
abstract: So far this year, 39 people have died in residential fires, a city official said. In 2017, such fires killed 27 people.
lead_paragraph: Eight people, including six children, died after a fire broke out at an apartment in Chicago early on Sunday, officials said.

headline: Surprisingly, a Disastrous Loss for the Mets Was Surprising
abstract: After the team’s first-half collapse, some recent improvement might actually have legs if the Mets can stay healthy and keep on trying.
lead_paragraph: Mickey Callaway threw batting practice Sunday morning to the Staten Island Little League team. It made for a charming tableau: 12-year-olds just back from Williamsport, Pa., taking their hacks against the manager of the Mets at a sun-splashed big league ballpark. The Mets had visited the boys last Sunday at the Little League World Series.

headline: In Brazil, ‘Queer Museum’ Is Censored, Debated, Then Celebrated
abstract: A controversial exhibition was shut down after protests by religious groups, inciting a national argument about art. After a record-setting fund-raising drive, the show reopened to large crowds.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Had it gone as planned, an exhibition that opened last year in Brazil — which included a drawing of smiling children with the words “transvestite” and “gay child” stenciled across them — would likely have been a mere blip in the country’s lively art scene.

headline: Looking for Equality in Tennis? Check the Stat Sheet
abstract: Women’s tennis regularly comes under attack for attracting smaller crowds, generating less revenue and playing shorter matches. But analytics tell a different story.
lead_paragraph: As the debate about equal pay for men and women in tennis invariably bubbles to the surface at the United States Open, the last Grand Slam event of the year, consider the metrics, not the money.

headline: North Korea to Expel Japanese Tourist Accused of Crime
abstract: North Korea says it has decided to “leniently condone” the man and expel him “on the principle of humanitarianism.”
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea has decided to expel a Japanese man accused of committing a crime while visiting the isolated country on a tourist visa, the country’s state media reported.

headline: Opera of Demons
abstract: Trump has created a series of odd bedfellows.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has warped reality.

headline: As a Nation Mourns McCain, Trump Is Conspicuously Absent
abstract: Senator John McCain’s death seemed to be a metaphor for the demise of civility and unity in the Trump era.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As leaders of both political parties and foreign dignitaries publicly mourned John McCain on Sunday, President Trump conspicuously avoided a national moment of tribute to a senator whose death seemed to be its own metaphor for the demise of civility and unity in the Trump era.

headline: For Bryson DeChambeau, a Northern Trust Win That’s Not Like Him
abstract: DeChambeau, who is usually scratching and clawing and tinkering at tournaments, cruised to a comfortable victory in the first FedEx Cup event.
lead_paragraph: PARAMUS, N.J. — Bryson DeChambeau does not play golf casually. He fumes and frets and flips through geometric notes in a little book that bears his initials, B.A.D. He carries heavy bags under his eyes, the look of a frenzied scientist buried in a laboratory.

headline: Quotation of the Day: John McCain, a Last Lion of the Senate
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 27, 2018.
lead_paragraph: “The lions are gone. The lions of the Senate are gone. It is very sad.”

headline: The DeVos School for the Promotion of Student Debt
abstract: The education secretary is working hard to protect the scandal-ridden for-profit education industry from accountability.
lead_paragraph: Say this for Betsy DeVos: The secretary of education has shown an impressive commitment to rescuing her friends in the for-profit college business from pesky measures to rein in their predatory behavior. As pet projects go, it lacks the sulfurous originality of her emerging idea to let states use federal dollars to put guns in schools. But it is a scandal nonetheless. Given the choice between protecting low-income students — and, by extension, American taxpayers — and facilitating the buck-raking of a scandal-ridden industry, Ms. DeVos aggressively pursues Option B.

headline: Brands Try to Convince New Generations Products Aren’t Just for Their Parents
abstract: Companies like Planters and SunnyD are reintroducing products to younger consumers. Some critics are skeptical, but others say it’s the only way for brands to stay relevant.
lead_paragraph: In June, Planters’ iconic Mr. Peanut popped up on social media to peddle a canister of Cheez Balls.

headline: No Corrections: August 27, 2018
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, August 27, 2018.
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, August 27, 2018.

headline: Patricia Clarkson’s Role on ‘Sharp Objects’ Cut Deep
abstract: Over eight episodes, Ms. Clarkson’s character is revealed to be much more than just a domineering matriarch.
lead_paragraph: This interview includes spoilers for “Sharp Objects.”

headline: In Russia, a Top University Lacks Just One Thing: Students
abstract: The European University at St. Petersburg lost its teaching license after attacks from conservative nationalists who resent its Western orientation.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — At this time of year, the halls of the European University at St. Petersburg, a private liberal arts college in the heart of Russia’s second-largest city, would normally be filling with students returning from summer break.

headline: ‘Sharp Objects’ Finale Recap: Good Apple, Bad Tree
abstract: The HBO mini-series concluded Sunday night by reminding us, yet again, that there is something rotten at the core of the Crellin clan.
lead_paragraph: “It’s the family, Camille,” Detective Richard Willis insisted in last week’s episode, just after arresting John Keene for the murder of his little sister, Natalie. “It’s always the [expletive] family.” And he was right; he just had the wrong family in mind. The Keenes’ only crime was to move their gentle son and unladylike daughter to a town where the penalty for diverging from gender norms is death.

headline: ‘Insecure’ Season 3, Episode 3: The Bad Decision Index
abstract: This episode is called “Backwards-Like” for a reason.
lead_paragraph: The title of this week’s episode (“Backwards-Like”) couldn’t be more apt: Issa took some big steps in the wrong direction and so did Molly (though in this Dro-less episode, Molly’s issues are all work-related). But were their missteps enough to knock Daniel from his current reign as Worst Decision Maker in Season 3 thus far? Let’s break it down.

headline: Pope Francis, John McCain, Copenhagen: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Yanks Closer to Red Sox but Still Seeking First-Place Form
abstract: The Yankees’ A.L. East deficit is down to six games, but the team is more concerned about being resourceful and getting injured players back.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — For a moment, it seemed as though Giancarlo Stanton’s chiseled physique was not quite the product of rigorous exercise, drinking his milk and eating all his vegetables.

headline: Scott Morrison Is a New Kind of Australian Prime Minister: An Evangelical Christian
abstract: Sworn in last week, the new leader has talked openly and often about his evangelical Christian faith — a rarity in Australian politics.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — At a regular Sunday morning service, before the praise songs and a sermon on resilience, a pastor at one of Sydney’s largest Pentecostal churches mentioned a congregant who was usually among those worshiping there.

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Mother!’ and ‘POV: Nowhere to Hide’
abstract: The divisive psychological thriller “Mother!” arrives on Hulu. And the gripping documentary “Nowhere to Hide” is on “POV.”
lead_paragraph: The divisive psychological thriller “Mother!” arrives on Hulu. And the gripping documentary “Nowhere to Hide” is on “Point of View.”

headline: What to Do When You’re Bad at Money
abstract: Personal finance management is a concrete, learnable skill. Here’s where to start.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Smarter Living newsletter. The editor, Tim Herrera, emails readers with tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: In Arizona Primary, Joe Arpaio Is Making His Last Stand
abstract: Joe Arpaio is in last place in the Senate primary, a sign of how Arizona is changing. Democrats hope to break their long dry spell in the state.
lead_paragraph: FOUNTAIN HILLS, Ariz. — Joe Arpaio grimaced as he called himself “stupid” for being pranked by Sacha Baron Cohen. He thundered against the polls showing him in last place among Republicans in Tuesday’s Senate primary in Arizona. The sheriff of yore in this part of the West even reserved some harsh words for Fox News.

headline: ‘Sick of Losing,’ Democrats Race to the End of a Wild Florida Primary for Governor
abstract: An unusually tight and unpredictable contest in the nation’s largest swing state reflects the contours of the national Democratic Party.
lead_paragraph: HOLLYWOOD, Fla. — She made her way past a man in a coconut-shell bikini top and a burly guy in a parrot-head hat, and then the candidate trying to become Florida’s first female governor began swaying to an escapist island tune being played onstage in her honor. Just days before a stubbornly close primary election, the show stood a chance of helping win over an undecided Democratic voter or two.

headline: John McCain ‘Suffered Fools Poorly,’ and Arizonans Admired Him For It
abstract: Mourners gathered along the roadways in Phoenix to pay respects to a man who had become an institution in Arizona.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — As the motorcade carrying the body of Senator John S. McCain made its way into Phoenix this weekend, Arizonans lined up on the side of roads, some with hands over their hearts, others saluting, as if somberly acknowledging that a political era was coming to an end.

headline: Did Juul Lure Teenagers and Get ‘Customers for Life’?
abstract: The e-cigarette company says it never sought teenage users, but the F.D.A. is investigating whether Juul intentionally marketed its devices to youth.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The leaders of a small start-up, PAX Labs, gathered at a board meeting in early 2015 to review the marketing strategy for its sleek new electronic cigarette, called Juul. They watched video clips of hip young people, posed flirtatiously holding Juuls. And they talked about the name of the gadget, meant to suggest an object of beauty and to catch on as a verb — as in “to Juul.”

headline: Sloane Stephens and the Art of Defending
abstract: Seven different women have won the last seven Grand Slam titles. They are discovering that a return trip to the champion’s podium is strewn with obstacles.
lead_paragraph: When Sloane Stephens won the United States Open last year, she delighted tennis fans worldwide with her joyful celebration, which included sitting beside Madison Keys, her vanquished opponent and friend, to chat and share a laugh.

headline: ‘Laura, I’ve Thought of You Many Times Since That Night’
abstract: The aftermath of a pedestrian accident. A love for Mr. Softee. And more reader tales from New York City.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: The Quiet Heroism of Arthur Ashe
abstract: John G. Zimmerman's photos of Arthur Ashe, the first black man to win a singles title at the United States Open, represented the athlete as he lived: a complex and self-possessed man in the midst of a life-altering event.
lead_paragraph: John G. Zimmerman’s modest photograph depicts a 25-year-old man surrounded by commuters on the platform of a Manhattan subway station in September 1968. He is simply dressed in a short-sleeved shirt and khaki trousers. Pen in one hand, folded newspaper in the other, he is working on a crossword puzzle.

headline: ‘Son of Immigrants, Black and Gay’: A D.J. Breaks Barriers in France
abstract: Pierre Hache, who performs as Kiddy Smile, is taking the energy and inclusive spirit of Paris ball culture to the masses — and even to the presidential palace.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It was on a June afternoon, in the courtyard of his favorite Paris hotel, when Pierre Hache got the call saying that he would perform for the president. At first he thought it was a prank; the Élysée, the presidential palace, usually welcomes visiting dignitaries. But President Emmanuel Macron was hosting an event to honor France’s electronic musicians, and Mr. Hache, a D.J. and dancer who performs as Kiddy Smile, had been booked to spin records.

headline: Myanmar Generals Should Face Genocide Charges Over Rohingya, U.N. Says
abstract: A United Nations panel says that Myanmar’s top general, Min Aung Hlaing, should be among those tried for a “plan for destruction” of Rohingya Muslims.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Myanmar’s army commander and other top generals should face trial in an international court for genocide against Rohingya Muslims and for crimes against humanity targeting other ethnic minorities, United Nations experts said on Monday after a yearlong investigation.

headline: ‘What’s Going On in This Graph?’ Is Now Weekly. STEM Teachers Explain Why It’s a Powerful Activity.
abstract: Each week we select an engaging Times graph and pair it with a simple protocol — asking students what they notice, what they wonder, and what they think is going on in the graph.
lead_paragraph: Updated, Feb. 26, 2019

headline: The Heartbreakers at Chain Restaurants
abstract: McDonald’s is far from the worst offender. The Cheesecake Factory’s Breakfast Burrito has more than a day’s worth of calories, two days’ worth of sodium and more than three of saturated fat.
lead_paragraph: Who is to blame for fattening up Americans and killing their hearts? McDonald’s, it seems, is not even in the running. In fact, when you compare the fare under the Golden Arches with many of the dishes served at chain restaurants around the country, a Big Mac with large fries and soda begins to sound like health food.

headline: Out From Under the Family Name
abstract: Away from the uptown empire, a son of Eli Zabar will open his own restaurant on the Lower East Side.
lead_paragraph: Working in a family business can be both a privilege and a burden. If you are a young person with a last name that looms, it is perhaps natural to want to create something of your own.

headline: Astrology Is Fake but It’s Probably Fine
abstract: From astrology memes to Instagram crystals, mysticism is taking over the internet. Is it all irrational nonsense — or is it a necessary corrective to the data-driven, hyper-logical, crypto-libertarian values that rule the internet?
lead_paragraph: From astrology memes to Instagram crystals, mysticism is taking over the internet. Is it all irrational nonsense — or is it a necessary corrective to the data-driven, hyper-logical, crypto-libertarian values that rule the internet?

headline: Books That Take Children Back to School
abstract: Reading can help kids understand the story of their own lives in school.
lead_paragraph: Lots of parents — and lots of teachers — use books that feature the first day back at school to help with the summer-to-school transition. You might, for example, read picture books aloud to small children at home in the days before school and smile together as you encounter a cast of characters dealing with a variety of back-to-school issues. You might find Kevin Henkes’s worried mouse Wemberley meeting an even more worried classmate, or Jane Yolen and Mark Teague’s rambunctious young dinosaurs learning classroom comportment or Rosemary Wells’s childlike bunny Emily moving through her first hundred days of school. Teachers can then pick up the story by reading these books in the classroom and helping children understand the story of their own lives in school.

headline: The Dark Side of the Male Fitness Internet
abstract: One of the internet’s most popular fitness personalities is a dead bodybuilder named Zyzz. Is he the key to unlocking the link between toxic masculinity, objectification, and fringe politics?
lead_paragraph: One of the internet’s most popular fitness personalities is a dead bodybuilder named Zyzz. Is he the key to unlocking the link between toxic masculinity, objectification, and fringe politics?

headline: Mekelburg’s Opens an Outpost in Williamsburg, Brooklyn
abstract: The Clinton Hill grocery, bar and restaurant is setting up a new, larger space across from Domino Park.
lead_paragraph: Mekelburg’s, a grocery, bar and restaurant that opened in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, three years ago, is growing. In a larger space in Williamsburg, shelves will still be crammed with crackers and tinned seafood, and counters will dispense fine meats and cheeses. But the bar is double the size of the original. The new location, across from Domino Park, will be equipped with a gas-fueled kitchen, to enable it to turn out what Alicia Mekelburg calls “bigger food” like whole porchetta. They are also installing an espresso bar, with a window overlooking the street.

headline: Astrology Is Fake but It’s Probably Fine
abstract: From astrology memes to Instagram crystals, mysticism is taking over the internet. Is it all irrational nonsense — or is it a necessary corrective to the data-driven, hyper-logical, crypto-libertarian values that rule the internet? Episode 4 of our video series.
lead_paragraph: As a woman on the internet, my feeds are frequently stirred by the actions of digital mystics  — astrologers, tarot readers, sage smudgers, crystal outfitters and generally witchy women.

headline: Batidos for Bed-Stuy
abstract: Pilar Cuban Bakery will serve those tropical fruit shakes, along with croquettes and empanadas.
lead_paragraph: Cuban bakeries in Miami offer pastries, breads, sandwiches and those wonderful pre-smoothie-era confections, tropical fruit batidos. Ricardo Barreras, a restaurateur who is from Miami, opened his Pilar Cuban Eatery in Brooklyn nine years ago. Soon his Pilar Cuban Bakery next door will be ready to sell savory and sweet specialties, including croquettes and empanadas, Cuban tamales filled with pork, Cuban bread, café con leche and batidos.

headline: The Danes Arrive With Danish
abstract: A Copenhagen bakery brings its seeded rye breads and breakfast pastries to Union Square.
lead_paragraph: Ole & Steen, a bakery and cafe based in Copenhagen, with branches in England, is setting up shop near Union Square, the first in its planned American expansion. It will be turning out an inventory of rye and wheat breads, including rustic ovals riddled with seeds, crusty sourdough beauties, and heavy, brick-shaped loaves of traditional moist, dark bread. Breakfast pastries that New Yorkers might refer to as “Danish” — some cinnamon-scented with cream fillings, others with marzipan tucked inside — will also be sold. The baking is done on site and in Long Island City, Queens. An all-day menu features the open-faced sandwiches for which Denmark is known.

headline: How Unboxing Videos Soothe Our Consumerist Brains
abstract: On the internet, we can vicariously consume more stuff than we could ever actually buy, touch, or even see in our lifetimes. Are these videos eliminating a desire, or creating one?
lead_paragraph: On the internet, we can vicariously consume more stuff than we could ever actually buy, touch, or even see in our lifetimes. Are these videos eliminating a desire, or creating one?

headline: What We Know About Trump’s $130,000 Payment to Stormy Daniels
abstract: The guilty plea by Michael Cohen, President Trump’s ex-lawyer, brought to light new revelations about the payoff — and the efforts to conceal it.
lead_paragraph: In the landslide of news last week about guilty pleas, immunity deals and criminal convictions, you no doubt heard something astonishing: President Trump’s ex-lawyer said in open court that Mr. Trump directed him to pay a pornographic film star quite a bit of money not to tell the world that they had sex.

headline: Why Arthur Ashe Is the Spiritual Father of Colin Kaepernick
abstract: Touré reviews Raymond Arsenault’s major new biography, “Arthur Ashe: A Life,” which tells the story of a remarkable athlete and activist.
lead_paragraph: ARTHUR ASHE A Life By Raymond Arsenault Illustrated. 767 pp. Simon & Schuster. $37.50.

headline: The Dark Side of the Male Fitness Internet
abstract: One of the internet’s most popular fitness personalities is a dead bodybuilder named Zyzz. Is he the key to unlocking the links between toxic masculinity, objectification and fringe politics? Episode 5 of our video series.
lead_paragraph: The internet has ushered in an era of hyper-visual culture, and the shift is so seismic that it’s starting to affect a group of people who have previously escaped the harsh body spotlight: heterosexual men.

headline: A City Market Moves Across the Street
abstract: Two dozen longtime vendors in the Essex Street Market are relocated to a spacious new address.
lead_paragraph: The pending relocation of the Essex Street Market — a city-run market space, one of several first established by Mayor Fiorello H. LaGuardia in the 1940s as an alternative to street vendors — is happening this fall. It will be one part of a huge new indoor market building being built across Delancey Street. All but one of the market’s 25 vendors are moving in the first wave, including Pain d’Avignon, Nordic Preserves, Osaka Grub, Puebla Mexican Food, New Star Fish market, Shopsin’s General Store and Saxelby Cheesemongers, a shop selling craft American cheeses and owned by Anne Saxelby. She said that like most of the other establishments, her space would be expanding (more than doubling to 300 square feet) in the new market, which will be on two floors and occupy 37,000 square feet. In February, 14 new vendors — including Samesa for Middle Eastern food, Chinatown Ice Cream Factory and  Essex Shambles, the butcher shop — will move in. In addition, dozens of market stalls are  coming in 2019 to another part of the three-block development, a privately run space called Market Line.

headline: Hill Country Opens a Food Park
abstract: Hill Country Barbecue Market is transformed into a wonderland of food stalls in its Downtown Brooklyn location.
lead_paragraph: The 10,000-square-foot space occupied by Hill Country Barbecue Market in Brooklyn has been reconfigured as a collection of food stations. A breakfast stall will serve coffee and new Hill Country items like doughnuts and breakfast tacos. Other stalls will sell Texas barbecue, fried chicken and pizza. Nickie’s, the company’s first Tex-Mex outlet, will have burgers and tacos. And on the second floor will be a reincarnation of Hank’s Saloon, a venerable dive bar in Boerum Hill that’s set to close at the end of the year. Hank’s at Hill Country will have snacks and craft beers on tap. The owners of Hank’s are working with Hill Country to achieve the right vibe. All these goings-on will be in the hands of the chef Steven Ferdinand.

headline: From Ride Share to Rickshaw: Wedding-Shopping Adventures in India
abstract: Champagne and cake? Try chai and samosas: A bride-to-be returns to India to shop for her wedding in a bumpy, smog-filled trip, in-laws in tow.
lead_paragraph: On a Tuesday in December, from the dark corridors of the Delhi Metro, we climbed the staircase of the Chawri Bazar station single file, me last, since I had no idea where we were going. We emerged on the fringes of a traffic circle, into a thick, hazy smog that clung to our skin and throat and nostrils, and formed a film that for the next three weeks, would never really go away.

headline: Paul Pogba and the Power of Perception
abstract: Pogba left Manchester United at the end of last season as a midfielder of lavish talent but mercurial effect. He returned as a World Cup winner. But did anything really change?
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — José Mourinho did not have to wait long to be proved right.

headline: How Unboxing Videos Soothe Our Consumerist Brains
abstract: On the internet, we can vicariously consume more stuff than we could ever actually buy, touch or even see in our lifetimes. Are these videos eliminating a desire, or creating one? Episode 6 of our video series.
lead_paragraph: As an American, I’m a big fan of stuff. Products, merchandise, wares — I love it all. I enjoy acquiring stuff, keeping that stuff until it degrades in worth, and then replacing it with more stuff.

headline: One Architect’s Study in Color
abstract: Guillermo Santomà‘s dining room and kitchen are Pepto-Bismol pink — not so much covered in it as made of it — and it only begins there.
lead_paragraph: Guillermo Santomà‘s dining room and kitchen are Pepto-Bismol pink — not so much covered in it as made of it — and it only begins there.

headline: In Barcelona, a House That Was Remade by Taking It Apart
abstract: For a home with an unassuming facade, the architect Guillermo Santomà has ignored spatial logic in favor of color, light and cultivated chaos.
lead_paragraph: FROM THE OUTSIDE, Casa Horta is an inconspicuous, seemingly one-story house in northern Barcelona with a forgotten-looking facade that’s more decorative than those of its neighbors. Built in an ornate early 20th-century Catalan vernacular, it’s one of three boxlike homes on a narrow street near the edge of a steep hill. Surrounding it are more recently constructed low-rise apartments, as if the area had been rebuilt in the wake of a bomb. There’s a bucolic park. The atmosphere would seem suburban except that, outside the house, the street is lightly charred: Someone set the garbage bins on fire the night before.

headline: John McCain, Myanmar, Jacksonville: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: What John McCain Taught Us About Torture
abstract: “This is a moral debate. It is about who we are.”
lead_paragraph: It was that other P.O.W.-turned senator, the unfathomably brave Jeremiah Denton, who first signaled to United States military intelligence — via blinking out “T-O-R-T-U-R-E” in Morse code during a propaganda video — that our prisoners of war in North Vietnam were being treated in gross violation of the Geneva Convention. But it was John McCain who brought that mistreatment viscerally into American living rooms, through a harrowing hospital-bed interview broadcast by CBS News in the fall of 1967.

headline: Representation Is More Than Skin Color
abstract: Is it enough to look like the artist if you do not recognize yourself in the art?
lead_paragraph: I remember the first time I fell in love with poetry.

headline: Volkswagen’s Effort to Stop Scandals Needs More Work, Report Says
abstract: The automaker, which was humbled after falsifying emissions data, still has work to do to protect potential whistle-blowers, according to its U.S. monitor.
lead_paragraph: WOLFSBURG, Germany — Nearly three years after Volkswagen admitted to a vast emissions cheating scheme, the company has only just begun to take steps necessary to prevent future scandals.

headline: The Paradoxes of John McCain
abstract: “The Daily” looks at the senator’s complex legacy through his half-century of public life.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: New York Today: Remembering McCain
abstract: Monday: New Yorkers remember Senator John McCain, and the City of Immigrants project.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this sunny Monday.

headline: The West Bank Model Is a Failure
abstract: And Israel’s new nation-state law will import those failures into Israel itself.
lead_paragraph: In the seven decades of its independence, Israel has developed a unique model of statehood. This model can be understood in various ways, and these have evolved over the years, but any description of it always comes back to two terms: Jewish and democratic.

headline: Ally of South Korean Leader Conspired to Rig Online Opinion, Inquiry Finds
abstract: A special counsel found that a key ally of President Moon of South Korea conspired in an illegal attempt to influence public opinion ahead of Mr. Moon’s election.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — A close political ally of President Moon Jae-in of South Korea conspired with a team of online bloggers to illegally influence public opinion ahead of Mr. Moon’s election last year, a special counsel said Monday.

headline: A Surprisingly Simple Way to Help Level the Playing Field of College Admissions
abstract: White, Asian-American and affluent students commonly take the SAT more than once, but disadvantaged students are less likely to, and it’s holding them back.
lead_paragraph: New research contains a message for high school students, especially low-income ones, who want to go to college: Take the SAT early and often.

headline: Airstrike Near Tajikistan Border Kills Taliban, Afghans Say
abstract: Officials said Tajikistan’s Air Force carried out the strike, but the accounts seemed to conflict with what is known about its capabilities.
lead_paragraph: MAZAR-I-SHARIF, Afghanistan — An airstrike killed six Taliban insurgents along the border of Tajikistan and Afghanistan, an area where cross-border attacks are rare, Afghan officials said on Monday.

headline: U.S. Open Highlights: Wins for Williams Sisters; Big Loss for No. 1 Halep
abstract: Stay here for live results and analysis from the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows.
lead_paragraph: • The 2018 U.S. Open began with a shock on Monday, with the loss of top-ranked Simona Halep in one of the first matches of the day.

headline: California Today: ‘Secret Science’ in the Salinas Valley?
abstract: Monday: How a study on the effect of pesticides illustrates President Trump’s conflict with the E.P.A., remembering John McCain, and a taco truck opens on a freeway.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Five Films That Go Inside The New York Times
abstract: A slew of new productions about The Times (or inspired by Times reporting) are on the way; for now, enjoy these classics.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.

headline: Tommy Robredo Is Out of the Tennis Wilderness and Back in the U.S. Open
abstract: A 36-year-old once ranked in the top 10 who is now 214th earned a spot in the Open’s main draw for the first time in three years.
lead_paragraph: The wrap-around sunglasses that Tommy Robredo wears during matches can’t hide his soul.

headline: Trump Reaches Revised Trade Deal With Mexico, Threatening to Leave Out Canada
abstract: The preliminary agreement is a major step for President Trump, who has threatened to scrap Nafta. But Canada’s role is just one of many issues that remain unresolved.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Monday that the United States and Mexico had reached an accord to revise key portions of the North American Free Trade Agreement and would finalize it within days, suggesting he was ready to jettison Canada from the trilateral trade pact if the country did not get on board quickly.

headline: Women Struggling to Get Pregnant Turn to Fertility Apps
abstract: Wearable apps can help women determine their most fertile days each month. Despite numerous successes, not all doctors are convinced they actually work.
lead_paragraph: When Nicole and Christopher Roberts of North Stonington, Conn., decided to start a family in 2016, Nicole quickly became pregnant, but then miscarried three months later.

headline: In a New Book of Sketches, Françoise Gilot Clears Her Mind of the Past
abstract: Picasso’s former lover and muse has a philosophy formed by nine decades of living. And forgetting.
lead_paragraph: The 96-year-old French painter and author Françoise Gilot — famously known as the former lover and muse to Pablo Picasso, and the mother of two of his children, Claude and Paloma — has a book of sketches out this week that she completed during her travels to India, Senegal and Venice between 1974 and 1981.

headline: Deal Reached to Reactivate Speed Cameras at New York City Schools
abstract: An agreement has been reached to allow speed cameras around New York City schools to resume operation, without the need for state legislation.
lead_paragraph: State and city officials have brokered a deal to reactivate speed cameras around New York City schools before students return in September, in a maneuver intended to bypass the State Legislature.

headline: U.S. Commander Urges More Transparency in Yemen Strike on School Bus
abstract: The top United States air commander in the Middle East frustrated with the Saudi-led air campaign in Yemen after an airstrike killed more than 40 children.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The top American air commander in the Middle East is urging the Saudi-led coalition of Arab nations to be more forthcoming about an investigation into an airstrike in northern Yemen earlier this month that struck a school bus, killing more than 40 children.

headline: Trump Relents Under Pressure, Offering ‘Respect’ to McCain
abstract: The president broke a period of silence by issuing a proclamation to fly the flag of the United States at half-staff until the day of John McCain’s interment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the Senate chamber on Monday, John McCain’s desk was draped in black and topped with a vase of white roses. The majority leader, Senator Mitch McConnell, rose to praise Mr. McCain as a colleague and hero who “spotlighted many of our highest values.” Outside, an impromptu memorial took shape as the flags over Capitol Hill flew at half-staff.

headline: What to Cook Right Now
abstract: Make Alison Roman’s littleneck clams, or indulge in Melissa Clark’s ratatouille pie, or David Tanis’s spicy minced shrimp with rice noodles.
lead_paragraph: Good morning! It’s the right time for clams, but then, it’s always the right time for clams, isn’t it?

headline: How to Tame Health Care Spending? Look for One-Percent Solutions
abstract: Maybe the answer isn’t something big, a group of economists is suggesting, but rather many small tweaks, such as reining in long-term care hospitals.
lead_paragraph: The health care system in the United States costs nearly double that of its peer countries, without much better outcomes. Many scholars and policymakers have looked at this state of affairs and dreamed big. Maybe there’s some broad fix — high deductibles, improvements in end-of-life care, a single-payer system — that can make United States health care less expensive.

headline: Your Personal Training Questions, Answered
abstract: Joe Holder is a performance specialist, health consultant and founder of the Ocho System. He worked with our editors to answer your questions about getting in better shape.
lead_paragraph: Joe Holder is a performance specialist, health consultant and founder of the Ocho System. He worked with our editors to answer your questions about getting in better shape.

headline: What the Heck Is That?
abstract: A look at one of last week’s crossword puzzle entries that stumped our solvers.
lead_paragraph: The entry ERL stumped many of our solvers this week, and while it has appeared in The New York Times Crossword only 53 times, it can pop up on any day of the week, so it pays to know the word that is most often clued as a Schubert lied, or song.

headline: Capturing a Genocide on Their Cellphones
abstract: The Rohingya refugees of Myanmar have enough raw footage to make a case at the International Criminal Court.
lead_paragraph: The Rohingya refugees of Myanmar have enough raw footage to make a case at the International Criminal Court.

headline: Capturing Their Genocide on Their Cellphones
abstract: The Rohingya refugees of Myanmar have enough raw footage to make a case at the International Criminal Court.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, the United Nations released an explosive report saying top military officials in Myanmar should face trial in an international court for genocide against Rohingya Muslims.

headline: Hospitality, Senegal’s Way, at Teranga in Harlem
abstract: The chef Pierre Thiam plans to serve the foods and drinks of West Africa at a new restaurant in the Africa Center.
lead_paragraph: For years, the chef Pierre Thiam has been planning to open a restaurant and call it Teranga. Translated from Wolof, a language spoken in Senegal, teranga means hospitality — though as Mr. Thiam explained it, the meaning is more significant, and more complex, than any English translation will allow.

headline: Hairy Baby? Better Get a C-section. Gingivitis? C-section. Scoliosis? C-section.
abstract: The challenges of trying to give birth naturally in surgery-happy Brazil.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — It takes determination to have a normal childbirth in Brazil, and I’m not talking about just getting through labor.

headline: Frustration With Racism Is Coming to the Ballot Box
abstract: A new poll shows people of color feel disrespected and fed up — and they stand to influence many of the most competitive House races.
lead_paragraph: A new poll on voters’ attitudes in the nation’s most competitive House races showed that when it comes to perceptions of racism, there are two Americas — one in which people of  color are distressed by President Trump’s rhetoric and policies and another in which white Americans are far less convinced that there’s a problem.

headline: How to Celebrate a Complicated Win for Women
abstract: Can we honor those who helped achieve women’s suffrage, while recognizing the complexity — and occasional ugliness — of their movement?
lead_paragraph: There’s a historical haze confounding plans to observe the coming 100th anniversary of the ratification of the 19th Amendment in 1920.

headline: Why Am I Paying for My Neighbor’s Roof Garden?
abstract: Co-op shareholders have to pay for common elements like water, but what happens when one of them is using it to irrigate a private oasis?
lead_paragraph: Q: A shareholder in my Upper East Side co-op has a roof garden and waters it with the co-op’s water. That means that the building’s shareholders are paying for the water for her personal garden. Shouldn’t this shareholder pay more of the co-op’s water bill for the building, and if so, any suggestions on how that could be calculated?

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $800,000
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: What the Press Can Do Better
abstract: Readers responded to a Times editorial joining hundreds of other publications affirming the value of a free press.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 15, The Times Editorial Board joined hundreds of local and regional publications affirming the value of a free press. Readers responded to the editorial, “A Free Press Needs You,” with their thoughts on the role and, sometimes, overreach of the media. A selection of those comments, edited for length and clarity, is below.

headline: Hong Kong Professor Faces Murder Trial in ‘Yoga Ball Killing’
abstract: Dr. Khaw Kim-sun, an anesthesiologist, is accused of using an exercise ball filled with carbon monoxide to kill his wife and daughter.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A yoga ball filled with carbon monoxide. An affair between a professor and his student. A dead wife and daughter.

headline: A ‘Queer Eye’ Makeover for a Vintage Diner
abstract: Antoni Porowski, the food guy on the hit TV series, is planning his first restaurant, the fast-casual Village Den.
lead_paragraph: The first thing Antoni Porowski — the food and wine expert on “Queer Eye,” this year’s hit reboot of the makeover TV show — wants everyone to know about his new West Village restaurant is that it will not center on avocado.

headline: Five Essential ‘Dear Sugars’ Episodes
abstract: As our final season draws to a close, we’ve compiled a list of our most memorable episodes from the last year.
lead_paragraph: We’re not big on greatest hits collections here at Dear Sugars — aside from Cheryl’s forthcoming album of ’70s yacht rock covers, tentatively titled “Cheryl Strayed Under the Influence: The Pina Colada Years.”

headline: London Flavors Head West
abstract: New projects in Williamsburg, Brooklyn and Columbus Circle, bring British chefs and restaurateurs to New York.
lead_paragraph: In theater and music, the English come to New York in droves. In food, not so much. But this season London is on our doorstep with Sunday roasts, afternoon tea and lemon posset.

headline: A New Trick to Keep Barnacles From Sticking to Ships
abstract: By experimenting with tiny textures, scientists may have found a technique that could save the shipping industry billions of dollars each year.
lead_paragraph: Barnacles may have a small footprint, but their effect on global shipping is large.

headline: A Catholic Civil War?
abstract: Traditionalists want strict adherence to church doctrine. Liberals want the doctrine changed.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis must resign. That conclusion is unavoidable if allegations contained in a letter written by Archbishop Carlo Maria Viganò are true. Archbishop Viganò, the Vatican’s ambassador to the United States from 2011 to 2016, says that Pope Francis knew Cardinal Theodore McCarrick had abused seminarians, but nonetheless lifted penalties imposed on Cardinal McCarrick by Pope Benedict XVI.

headline: ‘I Tried to Think Like a Corrupt Party Hack’
abstract: The Queens Democratic Party machine seemed to be nominating candidates without their consent. I needed to find them. But how?
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.

headline: Bruce Ohr Fought Russian Organized Crime. Now He’s a Target of Trump.
abstract: Mr. Ohr, a longtime Justice Department official, was targeted in attacks by the president and his allies for links to the Russia investigation. He could lose his security clearance.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When a lawyer for one of Russia’s most powerful reputed crime bosses arrived at F.B.I. headquarters one day around 2006, he wanted to cut a deal. The Russian, Semion Y. Mogilevich, had been indicted three years earlier by the department on charges of defrauding a company outside Philadelphia out of $150 million and could not travel for fear of arrest.

headline: New Reasons (Cookies, Pizza) to Go to Greenpoint
abstract: This fall’s openings serve up more of the comfort foods that exemplify the area’s ‘small-town charm.’
lead_paragraph: It was only a matter of time before Greenpoint became a magnet for restaurants.

headline: A Trump Endorsement Can Decide a Race. Here’s How to Get One.
abstract: The president’s grip on G.O.P. primary voters is as strong as it has been since he seized the party’s nomination a little over two years ago.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Before she agreed to run for the Senate in Arizona this year, Representative Martha McSally reached an agreement with White House officials: President Trump would remain on the sidelines and not endorse one of her more conservative competitors.

headline: Extinct Cave Bear DNA Lives On in Brown Bears
abstract: Modern brown bears are carrying a bit of genetic material passed down from the cave bear, in a study that suggests extinction does not always vanquish a species’ genes.
lead_paragraph: About 25,000 years ago in Western Europe, the last cave bear drew its final breath and the species went extinct.

headline: A Finer Flagship Store for Morgenstern’s
abstract: The ice cream shop is moving to a spot on LaGuardia Place, giving it room to grow.
lead_paragraph: Nick Morgenstern needs more space. After all, his traditional and inventive ice cream inventory consists of 88 flavors, and it’s growing. So he will open a new flagship in a space that’s segmented three ways. The front will have a fairly conventional dipping shop with seating for six and outdoor tables. A kitchen with a sundae-bar counter, seating 10, anchors the space. Next to it will be a retail area with freezers full of pints and ice cream cakes.

headline: Review: ‘Sehnsucht’ Navigates the Inexact Science of Nostalgia
abstract: This dementedly daffy piece of fun, from the theater company TV, will give you a warm glow in the fleeting moment it’s here for a brief run.
lead_paragraph: Basket and Ink, loincloth-clad women of the Stone Age, are sitting around the cave feeling wistful for a simpler time — before clothing, community and social taboos came along and ruined everything.

headline: 3-D Printed Gun Plans Must Stay Off Internet for Now, Judge Rules
abstract: A federal judge, in approving a preliminary injunction sought by states, cited the potential harm caused “if the existing restrictions are withdrawn.”
lead_paragraph: Cody Wilson, the self-described crypto-anarchist who has tried for years to post blueprints for 3-D printed guns online, will have to keep waiting, a federal judge ruled on Monday.

headline: JJ Johnson’s Journeys Bring Him Home
abstract: At FieldTrip, the former Cecil chef nods to his travels and one of his grandmother’s specialties.
lead_paragraph: Rice was one of the chef Joseph Johnson’s first loves and first heartbreaks.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ and ‘True Detective’: Get a Glimpse of the New Seasons
abstract: Buried within a teaser reel is a pretty significant moment for two beloved “Thrones” characters.
lead_paragraph: On the same night HBO aired its shocking finale for “Sharp Objects,” the network also on Sunday released teasers for its coming lineup of highly anticipated new programming. One is a full trailer for Season 3 of the anthology series “True Detective,” which stars Mahershala Ali and Stephen Dorff as detectives investigating a crime involving two missing children in the Arkansas Ozarks. The preview is ominous and enticing, with the kind of stark photography and haunting soundtrack we have come to expect of the series, created by Nic Pizzolatto.

headline: Ariana Grande Returns to No. 1 With ‘Sweetener’
abstract: The album is the singer’s third to reach the top of the Billboard 200, bumping Travis Scott to No. 2.
lead_paragraph: Ariana Grande reached No. 1 on the Billboard chart for a third time this week, while Aretha Franklin continued to draw listeners in the week after her death, taking the Queen of Soul to her highest position on the chart in 50 years.

headline: ‘Who Is America?’ Ends With O.J. Simpson. But Where Was Sarah Palin?
abstract: One of the most highly anticipated segments of Sacha Baron Cohen’s Showtime series — an interview with Sarah Palin — never aired. It’s unclear why.
lead_paragraph: The final episode of Sacha Baron Cohen’s Showtime series — “Who Is America?” — aired on Sunday night and it was as notable for what didn’t air as it was for what did. Where was the highly anticipated interview featuring the former Republican vice-presidential nominee Sarah Palin?

headline: 17,500 Dutchmen Gave Their DNA in a Murder Inquiry. After 20 Years, an Arrest.
abstract: A practice known as familial DNA profiling, in which investigators take samples from potential relatives of a suspect, has led to the resolution of two major Dutch cold murder cases.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — For 20 years, the Dutch police investigated the rape and murder of an 11-year-old schoolboy, and the Dutch news media chronicled the case’s many twists and turns.

headline: Gary Shteyngart Is Back, on the Road and Still a Master of Dislocation
abstract: In his new novel, “Lake Success,” the author tells the story of a hedge-fund guy who loses everything in order to find himself.
lead_paragraph: On a certain level, the plump new Gary Shteyngart novel, “Lake Success,” doesn’t work at all. It’s a road trip story about a Manhattan hedge-fund guy named Barry Cohen who chucks it all — wife, kid, $2.4 billion in assets, cellphone, credit cards, wedding ring —– and hits the American highway like Sal Paradise or Humbert Humbert or Thelma and Louise or V.S. Naipaul in “A Turn in the South.” He doesn’t ride through mansions of glory in suicide machines. He has only a few $20 bills left in his pocket. He’s a bum manqué. He takes flatulent Greyhound buses — “the Hound,” in his lingo. He sits up front, to lessen the reeking sensory overload. He’s going to find himself and lose himself and find himself again. He putt-putts across America, his heart tucked up into the overhead bin, from where it is frequently retrieved.

headline: The Upper West Side Gets Some Dining Upgrades
abstract: The neighborhood’s fall openings may help shake its reputation as a dining dead zone.
lead_paragraph: For all of its attractions, the Upper West Side has stubbornly remained a desert for destination restaurants. Except for brunch at Barney Greengrass and the options around Lincoln Center, there’s been little to tempt those who don’t live nearby.

headline: A Hotelier Who Knows How to Make Chefs Feel at Home
abstract: Ian Schrager, who has a long roster of big-name cooks, will add John Fraser to the list at his new Times Square hotel.
lead_paragraph: There are few phrases in the dining lexicon less inviting than “hotel restaurant,” a term that has traditionally called up images of serviceable food in corporate settings.

headline: New York Is Just a Bowl of Chinese Noodles
abstract: Some fall arrivals will bolster the city’s rich array of slurp-worthy restaurants.
lead_paragraph: The Bowery already has a restaurant called Great NY Noodletown. But these days, that name could describe the entire city, which suddenly seems awash in noodle menus.

headline: Student Loan Watchdog Quits, Saying Trump Administration Is Harming Students
abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau’s top student loan official accused its leadership of favoring “powerful financial companies” over consumers.
lead_paragraph: A top federal official in charge of handling complaints about student loans stepped down on Monday, blasting the Trump administration for protecting predatory lenders at the expense of borrowers.

headline: China Has Withheld Samples of a Dangerous Flu Virus
abstract: Despite an international agreement, U.S. health authorities still have not received H7N9 avian flu specimens from their Chinese counterparts.
lead_paragraph: For over a year, the Chinese government has withheld lab samples of a rapidly evolving influenza virus from the United States — specimens needed to develop vaccines and treatments, according to federal health officials.

headline: Donna Shalala Isn’t Done Yet
abstract: Impeachment. Guaranteed income. A conversation with the former Clinton administration official, who hopes to win a seat in Congress.
lead_paragraph: At a time when Democrats are having a splintering, soul-searching debate about the wisdom of replacing longtime leaders like Nancy Pelosi with a new generation, Donna Shalala’s campaign for an open House seat in the Miami area is as much about the Democratic Party’s future as it is about its past.

headline: The Kinship of Anxious, Exhausted New Moms
abstract: Having friends to advise and commiserate is invaluable in the early months of motherhood, two readers agree.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Death in the Age of Narcissism
abstract: But enough about John McCain. Here’s some more about me.
lead_paragraph: Just before and after John McCain’s death on Saturday, I read many tweets, Facebook posts and essays that beautifully captured his importance.

headline: Baffled by the Chilling ‘Sharp Objects’ Finale? Here’s What to Read
abstract: Things got ugly at the end of this gothic HBO mystery series. They were also maybe a bit confusing. The world’s TV writers have thoughts.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday night, after eight episodes of eerie, languid Southern Gothic storytelling, the HBO murder mystery “Sharp Objects” reached its ugly conclusion. But then it reached a different ugly conclusion. Finally, two quick scenes embedded in the credits added further wrinkles to the tale.

headline: No, the Church Does Not Love Ireland
abstract: But the Irish people have learned to love one another.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — On Sunday, while the faithful gathered for mass with Pope Francis in Dublin’s Phoenix Park, a large group gathered in the city’s Garden of Remembrance at an event called Stand for Truth. The railings had been hung with dozens of tiny pairs of baby shoes.

headline: The Designers Striving for Radical Inclusivity
abstract: Charles Jeffrey, Rio Uribe and Shayne Oliver are among those redefining queer aesthetics on the runways.
lead_paragraph: How do you define a queer aesthetic in fashion? Originally, queer simply meant “strange” or “atypical,” and plenty of fashionable clothes can be described as that. And yet, over the past few years, we’ve seen the emergence of a band of 20- and early 30-something designers expressly looking to explore the hinterland that lies beyond the boundaries of both hetero- and homonormative conventions. Among the pioneers are Charles Jeffrey, who calls his line Loverboy, after the monthly L.G.B.T.Q.I.A. club night he hosts in East London; the duo Eden Loweth and Tom Barratt, who design as Art School; Rio Uribe of Gypsy Sport; and Shayne Oliver, formerly of Hood by Air.

headline: Aleksei Navalny, Kremlin Critic, Is Jailed Ahead of Russian Pension Protests
abstract: The latest short jail term for the opposition leader comes before expected demonstrations against an unpopular plan to raise the retirement age in Russia.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia’s highest-profile opposition leader, Aleksei A. Navalny, was sentenced to 30 days in jail on Monday for a protest that happened seven months ago — a move that he maintained was intended to prevent him from organizing nationwide protests against plans to raise the retirement age in Russia.

headline: What Is Identity?
abstract: Francis Fukuyama’s “Identity” and Kwame Anthony Appiah’s “The Lies That Bind” examine the role of personal identity in our modern age.
lead_paragraph: IDENTITY The Demand for Dignity and the Politics of Resentment By Francis Fukuyama 218 pp. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $26.

headline: Does Our Cultural Obsession With Safety Spell the Downfall of Democracy?
abstract: Two new books — “The Splintering of the American Mind,” by William Egginton, and “The Coddling of the American Mind,” by Greg Lukianoff and Jonathan Haidt — warn of the threat to the country’s political and social well-being by a fractured generation convinced of its fragility.
lead_paragraph: THE SPLINTERING OF THE AMERICAN MIND Identity Politics, Inequality, and Community on Today’s College Campuses By William Egginton 263 pp. Bloomsbury. $28.

headline: Kushner Companies and Michael Cohen Accused of Falsifying Building Permits to Push Out Tenants
abstract: New York City’s Department of Buildings cited Kushner Companies, saying the company underreported the number of rent-regulated tenants. Tenant activists claim a group led by Mr. Cohen did the same thing.
lead_paragraph: Charles Kushner, the developer whose son Jared Kushner is a senior adviser to President Trump, and Michael Cohen, the president’s former personal lawyer, face scrutiny in New York for claims that they falsified construction permits in an attempt to remove rent-regulated tenants from buildings scattered across the city.

headline: How a Plant Ages
abstract: The genetic mechanisms that seem to influence human life span may also be at work in plants.
lead_paragraph: Q. I have read that animals die of old age because telomeres, the protective caps at the ends of chromosomes, shorten, allowing harmful mutations to accumulate. Does the same mechanism apply to the life span of plants?

headline: Thank You, Neil Simon
abstract: A reader recalls how his plays made her unhappy childhood a bit cheerier.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The City Council Has New Muscle. And It’s Starting to Flex It.
abstract: A new unit has opened an investigation into the garbage industry and is threatening to subpoena Nycha’s emails with City Hall.
lead_paragraph: A new City Council investigative unit has opened a wide-ranging inquiry into the city agency that regulates the private carting industry — the second instance in four months where the Council’s investigators have challenged a mayoral agency under Bill de Blasio.

headline: Shopping for Multi-Armed Chandeliers
abstract: A multi-armed light fixture can add drama to a dining room — or anyplace in need of illumination and a conversation piece.
lead_paragraph: Some chandeliers illuminate a cluster of crystals or dangle a collection of pendants, but there is another style that is becoming increasingly popular in contemporary interiors: the slender, multi-armed chandelier that stretches out and distributes light across a larger area.

headline: Queeneth Ndaba, Champion of South African Jazz, Dies at 81
abstract: She managed Johannesburg’s most influential home of art and culture during the darkest days of apartheid and invested heavily in the music she staged there.
lead_paragraph: Queeneth Ndaba, a South African jazz advocate who managed Johannesburg’s most influential home of art and culture during the darkest days of apartheid, died on Aug. 15 at a hospital in Boksburg. She was 81.

headline: Read Senator John McCain’s Farewell Statement
abstract: His former campaign manager, Rick Davis, read a farewell statement on behalf of Mr. McCain, who passed away at the age of 81.
lead_paragraph: Senator John McCain’s former campaign manager, Rick Davis, read a farewell statement on Monday in Phoenix on behalf of Mr. McCain, the Arizona lawmaker and war hero, who died on Saturday at the age of 81.

headline: What You Might Not Know About E-Sports, Soon to Be a $1 Billion Industry
abstract: A fatal shooting in Florida on Sunday thrust e-sports, a young and growing industry, into the national spotlight.
lead_paragraph: A gunman opened fire on Sunday at a video game tournament in Florida, killing two people, wounding numerous others and killing himself.

headline: Getting Off the Fence About Jeremy Corbyn’s Anti-Semitism
abstract: I won’t vote Labour again until he’s gone.
lead_paragraph: Is Jeremy Corbyn an anti-Semite?

headline: Republicans Are Complicit in This Mess
abstract: Readers agree with Peter Wehner’s call for his fellow Republicans to stand up to the president.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Myanmar, John McCain, Pope Francis: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Meet Josh Shapiro, the Man Behind the Bombshell Investigation of Clergy Sexual Abuse
abstract: As attorney general of Pennsylvania, Mr. Shapiro rooted out sexual abuse in the Catholic Church, prompting international calls for reform. Now, he talks about the anti-Semitism he faced, how the report shaped his own spirituality, and the possibility of a federal investigation.
lead_paragraph: Josh Shapiro had no idea about the secret grand jury investigation that was waiting on his desk when he was sworn in as attorney general of Pennsylvania last year.

headline: Pope Francis, the Accusations and the Back Story
abstract: Here are questions and answers about allegations that Francis helped cover up a cardinal’s misconduct and about the deeper church disputes behind them.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For people who are not immersed in the doctrines and politics of the Roman Catholic Church, the uproar over new accusations against Pope Francis can be hard to parse — a mix of the sexual abuse scandals that have rocked the church, and bitter factional infighting over its direction.

headline: North Korean State Media Denounce U.S. as Diplomacy Stalls
abstract: Belligerent articles alleged “extremely provocative and dangerous” American military moves after the United States canceled a trip by Secretary of State Mike Pompeo.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — North Korean state media criticized the United States over the weekend for “extremely provocative and dangerous military moves” in Pacific waters and warned that the diplomacy forged between the two countries’ leaders during their Singapore summit meeting in June could be in jeopardy.

headline: How Much Alcohol Is Safe to Drink? None, Say These Researchers
abstract: A large study of drinking habits in 195 countries contradicts widely shared advice on healthy drinking.
lead_paragraph: Just one alcoholic drink a day slightly increases an individual’s risk for health problems, according to a large new study.

headline: Elon Musk and Tesla Resolved One Issue. Now for the Rest.
abstract: After deciding not to try to remove its shares from the market, the electric carmaker must focus on some stubborn challenges while facing new ones.
lead_paragraph: So Tesla is no longer seeking to go private. Now what?

headline: Could Trump’s Missing Signature Force Him to Testify?
abstract: President Trump never signed the non-disclosure deal with Stephanie Clifford. With that omission, her lawyer has asked a judge to allow him to question Mr. Trump under oath.
lead_paragraph: In the history of presidential scandals, it is often hidden things that end up proving decisive. Think, for example, of Monica Lewinsky’s stained blue dress or of Richard M. Nixon’s secret Oval Office tapes.

headline: Fight Drug Abuse, Don’t Subsidize It
abstract: Americans struggling with addiction need treatment and reduced access to deadly drugs. They do not need a taxpayer-sponsored haven to shoot up.
lead_paragraph: Almost 64,000 Americans died of drug overdoses in 2016, a shocking 54 percent increase since 2012. Dangerous opioids such as heroin and fentanyl contributed to two-thirds of the deaths. This killer knows no geographic, socioeconomic or age limits. It strikes city dwellers and Midwestern farmers, Hollywood celebrities and homeless veterans, grandparents and teenagers.

headline: In Defending Trump, Is Giuliani a Shrewd Tactician or ‘Untethered’?
abstract: Rudolph Giuliani, President Trump’s lawyer, offered the first detailed look at his strategy for representing the president, in blunt and divisively political terms.
lead_paragraph: The man identified these days as President Trump’s lawyer seems vaguely familiar. It’s in the way he feigns genuine laughter. How he clasps his hands. How he widens his eyes, as if he’s just been handed a birthday cake with a firecracker for a candle.

headline: In a Shift in Driverless Strategy, Uber Deepens Its Partnership With Toyota
abstract: Toyota is investing $500 million in Uber and the ride-hailing company plans to provide its autonomous technology to the Japanese carmaker, a person briefed on the matter said.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Since Uber started a self-driving car program in 2015, it has insisted on developing its own driverless technology and operating its own fleet of autonomous vehicles.

headline: In Police Stations, Help for Crime Victims Is Closer to Home
abstract: Professionally trained advocates in each of the city’s police stations help crime victims access services and regain a sense of safety.
lead_paragraph: One day in July, a detective approached Jeri Bacchus inside an East New York police station. The officer was investigating an assault in which a woman in her 60s was pushed to the ground and beaten after she refused to give the attacker money she had withdrawn from an A.T.M., Ms. Bacchus recalled.

headline: San Antonio Spurs Guard Manu Ginobili Retiring After 16 Seasons
abstract: Ginobili, 41, was a two-time All-Star, Sixth Man of the Year Award winner and core member of four Spurs championships teams.
lead_paragraph: The highly entertaining Argentine guard Manu Ginobili of the San Antonio Spurs announced his retirement Monday, continuing the exodus of pillars from one of the most successful franchises in N.B.A. history.

headline: New Restaurants to Fill In New York’s Gaps
abstract: This fall’s openings offer fresh choices in busy neighborhoods that need them, and in cuisines that can always use a bigger spotlight.
lead_paragraph: Around New York City you’ll find thickets of restaurants — so-called restaurant rows, or neighborhoods so saturated with food choices that they seem zoned for dining. Elsewhere, even in highly trafficked places, the options can be sparse, neither satisfying to the locals nor attractive to visitors.

headline: Keep Your Gut Healthy and Your Skin May Follow
abstract: A wave of designer probiotic pills and powders — stylishly packaged, with names like Glow and Inner Beauty — is based on the idea that perfect skin may be linked to your tummy.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, Danielle Fleming, a real estate agent in Hoboken, N.J., started suffering persistent acne around her jawline. She had “ugly, weird pimples,” she said. After switching detergents, hair spray and anything else she could think of, she went to a dermatologist to ask about a prescription for Accutane or maybe a laser treatment. What she left with was a diet.

headline: E-Sports World Is Rocked as Gunman ‘Clearly Targeted Other Gamers’
abstract: A gunman who fatally shot two young men at a video gaming tournament in Florida appears to have targeted his fellow gamers, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — The off-season had just ended. The competitors, the finest players of a football video game, had gathered on the riverfront in Jacksonville for two days of animated battle. The weekend’s tournament was their first sanctioned chance to show which game-winning moves of the “Madden” franchise they had unlocked.

headline: Trump Falsely Calls Preliminary Pact Between U.S. and Mexico ‘Maybe the Largest Trade Deal Ever’
abstract: “I cannot imagine any metric in which an agreement between the U.S. and Mexico can be the largest,” a trade expert said.
lead_paragraph: — President Trump, in a phone call with President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico on Monday

headline: Breast-Feeding Mothers Should Avoid Marijuana, Pediatricians Say
abstract: A new study showed that chemical traces of marijuana can be detected in breast milk up to six days after use, highlighting the need for research into the effect of pot on babies.
lead_paragraph: Marijuana is more widely available than ever, but what does it do to babies?

headline: Nafta, John McCain, Pope Francis: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Future of Men’s Gymnastics Is Not Well-Balanced
abstract: Women’s gymnastics, even while weathering horrific scandals, has prospered and drawn crowds. The audience to watch men continues to shrink. Why?
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — It’s an endeavor in which chiseled bodies hurl through the air at full speed, muscles pushed to their biomechanical extremes as NBC’s cameras pan the action. One event involves hanging from rings more than eight feet above the ground while using extreme body strength to spin like a top. Another event has men darting powerfully into the air in a series of triple twists, punished should their might take them beyond the borders of the competition field.

headline: Why It Can Happen Here
abstract: We’re very close to becoming another Poland or Hungary.
lead_paragraph: Soon after the fall of the Berlin Wall, a friend of mine — an expert on international relations — made a joke: “Now that Eastern Europe is free from the alien ideology of Communism, it can return to its true historical path — fascism.” Even at the time, his quip had a real edge.

headline: F.C.C. Investigation Clears Chairman in Sinclair Inquiry
abstract: The agency’s inspector general had been looking for months into whether Ajit Pai’s decisions were intended to benefit Sinclair as it sought to merge with Tribune Media.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The internal investigator for the Federal Communications Commission has found that the agency’s chairman, Ajit Pai, did not give preferential treatment to Sinclair Broadcast Group in the company’s effort to merge with Tribune Media.

headline: Maduro’s Wild Ride
abstract: Chaos in Venezuela.
lead_paragraph: Chaos in Venezuela.

headline: The Trump Tax Cuts Were Supposed to Depress Housing Prices. They Haven’t.
abstract: So far, economists see only faint effects of the new tax law in housing prices. The predicted carnage hasn’t materialized.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It wasn’t supposed to take long for the Trump tax cuts to hobble housing prices, particularly in the high-tax, high-cost metro areas where the new law was poised to rip federal incentives to buy new homes.

headline: Giants Make Odell Beckham Jr. the N.F.L.’s Highest-Paid Receiver
abstract: The team expects the 25-year-old Beckham to be the future face of the franchise, and they showed it by giving him $65 million in guaranteed money.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants have made their top playmaker, Odell Beckham Jr., the highest-paid wide receiver in the N.F.L.

headline: No. 1 Simona Halep Exits the U.S. Open in the First Round
abstract: Halep offered no excuses beyond her own demons as she became the first top-seeded woman to lose in the first round of a U.S. Open.
lead_paragraph: It only seemed as if Simona Halep made history Monday in a New York minute. Actually, it took all of 76 minutes for her to become the first No. 1 women’s seed in the history of the United States Open to lose in the first round, falling by 6-2, 6-4 to Kaia Kanepi.

headline: Claims of Staff Sex Parties: New Troubles for Public Housing
abstract: The entire 40-member staff of a Bronx housing project was reassigned after residents complained that workers were drinking and having sex on the job.
lead_paragraph: The litany of problems facing public housing residents in New York City — mold, lead paint, faulty boilers and leaky roofs — just got longer: claims of staff sex parties.

headline: George Walker, Barrier-Breaking Composer, Is Dead at 96
abstract: He was the first black composer to be awarded a Pulitzer Prize. Earlier, as a pianist, he had felt deprived of concert opportunities because of his race.
lead_paragraph: George Walker, a composer who broke barriers during a long and distinguished career, including, in 1996, becoming the first black composer to win the Pulitzer Prize for music, died on Thursday in Montclair, N.J. He was 96.

headline: North Carolina Is Ordered to Redraw Its Gerrymandered Congressional Map. Again.
abstract: What happens next is unclear, but the case will likely be appealed to the Supreme Court, which has never ruled a partisan gerrymander to be unconstitutional.
lead_paragraph: A panel of three federal judges again declared North Carolina’s congressional district map to be unconstitutional, ruling on Monday that it was gerrymandered to unfairly favor Republican candidates.

headline: Daniel Murphy Reconnects With Mets and Tries to Move Past Comments on Gay Players
abstract: The second baseman is off to a fast start in Chicago, where he once was public enemy No. 1.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The last time second baseman Daniel Murphy was around so many Mets in Chicago he was one — trying to beat the Cubs.

headline: An Unlikely Courtside View of an Unlikely Qualifier
abstract: I never fulfilled my dream of leading Israel’s Davis Cup team, but getting close to Israel’s top players provided a unique experience at the U.S. Open qualifiers.
