McCain to the rotunda, where constituents began saying farewell to the war veteran who became a towering political figure in this part of the West.

headline: New Trailer: Ryan Gosling in ‘First Man’
abstract: The actor teams up with the director Damien Chazelle again for this Neil Armstrong biopic.
lead_paragraph: In a signature scene from the Oscar-winning director Damien Chazelle’s 2016 musical “La La Land,” the song-and-dance man Ryan Gosling suddenly lifts off into the sky. The duo will shoot for the stars once again with “First Man,” a biopic of the astronaut Neil Armstrong that opens the Venice Film Festival.

headline: Golden Statue of Erdogan Is Removed in German City
abstract: The 13-foot statue of the Turkish president put up at an art festival was hauled away in the city of Wiesbaden amid fears that it was a security concern.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey has the ability to provoke in art as well as in life.

headline: Why Are Black People Still Punished for Their Hair?
abstract: Only black people are shamed when they choose to wear hairstyles consistent with their natural hair texture.
lead_paragraph: It was the fall of my first year of law school, in 2005, and I was headed to my first interview for a legal internship. I wore my only interview outfit, a conservative navy skirt suit and a cream blouse. A classmate complimented me on the look. Then she added, “But you’ll never look really professional with your hair in dreadlocks.”

headline: Algae Bloom in Lake Superior Raises Worries on Climate Change and Tourism
abstract: Scientists cannot say for sure what causes algae blooms, but their appearance is associated with runoff, heavy rain and warming temperatures.
lead_paragraph: In 19 years of piloting his boat around Lake Superior, Jody Estain had never observed the water change as it has this summer. The lake has been unusually balmy and cloudy, with thick mats of algae blanketing the shoreline.

headline: Rain Dove Says Asia Argento Texts Were Sent to the Police
abstract: The gender-nonconforming model says Argento is not being truthful about a sexual-assault case.
lead_paragraph: Rain Dove Dubilewski, the gender-nonconforming model whose texts with the Italian actress Asia Argento have emerged as evidence in a potential criminal case against Ms. Argento, said Wednesday that they — Rain Dove — turned the messages over to the Los Angeles police because they believed that Ms. Argento was not being truthful. (Rain Dove prefers nongendered pronouns.)

headline: The Fourth Season of ‘Mr. Robot’ Will Be Its Last
abstract: Sam Esmail’s puzzling drama will air its final season in 2019.
lead_paragraph: “Mr. Robot,” Sam Esmail’s puzzling drama series centering on themes of corruption, surveillance and anarchy, will conclude after its coming fourth season, USA Network announced on Wednesday. The thriller, which ended its third season in December, stars Rami Malek as Elliot Alderson, a cybersecurity engineer who gets caught up in a revolution led by internet activists and hackers called “fsociety.”

headline: From F.B.I. to Fashion Design
abstract: Dan Snyder left a career in intelligence to create Corridor, an urban sportswear label that he sees as America’s answer to A.P.C.
lead_paragraph: Age: 33

headline: Customers Died. Will That Be a Wake-Up Call for China’s Tech Scene?
abstract: The rape and killing of two women using a ride-hailing service owned by Didi Chuxing should be a shock to an industry that has long prized growth over users.
lead_paragraph: Huang Jieli, who ran a Chinese ride-sharing business called Hitch, was invited to a wedding in March. One of her drivers was getting married to a woman who had once been his passenger. Thanks, the invitation said, for getting them hitched.

headline: Review: In ‘1969: The Second Man’ Buzz Aldrin Is an Unhappy Runner-Up
abstract: The creators of this folk-rock musical about the second man on the moon want us to sympathize with his emotional wound.
lead_paragraph: Quick, name the three astronauts from Apollo 11, the NASA flight that first put human beings on the moon.

headline: One Dead, 17 Sickened From Salmonella Linked to Kosher Chicken
abstract: Eight people were hospitalized and cases were reported in New York, Pennsylvania, Maryland and Virginia, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said.
lead_paragraph: A person in New York has died and 17 people from four states were sickened from a salmonella outbreak linked to chicken from the largest kosher poultry producer in the United States, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said Wednesday.

headline: DeSantis Warns Florida Not to ‘Monkey This Up,’ and Many Hear a Racist Dog Whistle
abstract: The Republican nominee for governor in Florida drew condemnation from Democrats for a comment about his opponent, Andrew Gillum.
lead_paragraph: Representative Ron DeSantis, the Republican nominee for governor in Florida, drew accusations of using a racist dog whistle on Wednesday after saying in a television interview that voters should not “monkey this up” by electing his opponent, Andrew Gillum, who would be the state’s first black governor.

headline: The National Portrait Gallery Lost Visitors, Though Not as Many as Feared
abstract: Reporting from a company that counts visitors suggested there was a drop of more than 40 percent at the London museum. It was more like 10 percent.
lead_paragraph: Art institutions in Britain have faced declining attendance in recent years, and museum officials met last year to discuss the issue. But when a steep drop-off in visitors to the National Portrait Gallery in London was included in its report to Parliament in July, people were alarmed: It was a decrease of more than 40 percent.

headline: Unreleased Jazz Treasures Are Arriving: Here’s a Guide
abstract: From “The Savory Collection 1935-1940” to lost Coltrane music from 1963, records from jazz’s halcyon midcentury are being released this year.
lead_paragraph: There’s never a shortage of old jazz albums being repackaged, or previously unknown recordings finding the light of day. But this year, a particularly impressive trickle of unreleased music from jazz’s halcyon midcentury has emerged for the first time. We already took a look at notable reissues. Here’s a guide to the historic recordings that have arrived so far.

headline: What Does It Mean to Be an Artist and a Mother?
abstract: A new retrospective reveals the extent of Ree Morton’s brief career, and the agonizing decision women of her era had to make between their children and their work.
lead_paragraph: IN THE FALL of 1976, the artist Ree Morton, then 40 years old, drafted an application for a Guggenheim Fellowship. She opened the submission with a condensed autobiography. “My career probably began at the age of 3, when I took up watching ant hills and protecting lady bugs,” she wrote. “This caused a long interruption in my artistic progress, because my family read it as an interest in science and directed me to nursing.” Here there is a paragraph break, and on one copy of the document, a faint wrinkle. Morton continued, “As soon as I realized the mistake, I started studying art, but it was already 1965, and I had a naval officer husband, three children and a house in a middle-class neighborhood in Norfolk, Virginia.” She summarized her life story, with a winking ironic detachment, as a “feminist classic” and then went on to list some of her accomplishments: “I got a B.F.A. and an M.F.A. I learned to use power tools and to know the difference between needing help and just thinking I did. I got a teaching job in Philadelphia. I moved to a loft in N.Y.C. I learned to take myself seriously. I learned not to take myself THAT seriously. I did some good work, got some shows and some reviews. Not bad, for a girl.”

headline: Trump’s Ludicrous Attack on Big Tech
abstract: The idea that Google and Twitter are rigging their platforms against him is patently false.
lead_paragraph: Here’s the truest conundrum of the social media age: Those who complain loudest about being silenced never ever shut up.

headline: Ron DeSantis, the Republican Trump Wants to Be Florida’s Governor
abstract: Mr. DeSantis, who represents Florida’s Sixth District in Congress, is a loyal Trump supporter, a regular on Fox News and a Navy veteran.
lead_paragraph: The Florida governor’s race is shaping up to be a ferocious showdown after Tuesday night’s primary victories by Representative Ron DeSantis, the Republican endorsed by President Trump, and Mayor Andrew Gillum of Tallahassee, a progressive Democrat endorsed by Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont.

headline: Coming of Age — and Becoming a Writer — in an America Obsessed With ‘Dead Girls’
abstract: “Dead Girls,” by Alice Bolin, and “Against Memoir,” by Michelle Tea, reflect on American culture’s often violent fixation on female bodies.
lead_paragraph: DEAD GIRLS Essays on Surviving an American Obsession By Alice Bolin 273 pp. William Morrow/HarperCollins Publishers. Paper, $15.99.

headline: Ruth Wilson Is a Riddle, and You Like Her That Way
abstract: The award-winning actress talks about the elusive qualities that have made her a magnet to filmmakers and fans.
lead_paragraph: When she was 8, Ruth Wilson liked re-enacting movie scenes with her two rambunctious brothers. One of her favorites, she recalled the other day, was the ending of “Platoon,” in which Willem Dafoe, peppered by bullets, collapses in slow motion on a verdant field.

headline: You Want Me to Cook at Home? Go Fly a Kite!
abstract: For some, preparing a meal is time well spent. For others, it’s a total waste.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Thwarting Efforts to Combat Climate Change
abstract: Readers discuss a plan to ease regulations for coal plants and how global warming is bad for business.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: NASA’s New Horizons Spacecraft Takes First Picture of Distant Rock It Will Visit
abstract: The mission’s scientists were pleasantly surprised that the camera aboard the robotic probe could see the Kuiper belt object, known as 2014 MU69, so soon and from so far.
lead_paragraph: NASA’s New Horizons spacecraft still has 100 million miles to go, but it has taken its first snapshot of the space rock that will be its date for New Year’s Day 2019.

headline: A Church in Crisis, Within and Without
abstract: Readers react to an archbishop’s challenge to Francis’ papacy and the clergy abuse scandal.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: U.N. Sounds Alarm on Repression in Nicaragua
abstract: Extrajudicial killings, rape, torture and disappearances have created a climate of fear, leading thousands to flee the country, investigators say.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The Nicaraguan authorities and paramilitary groups working with them have killed, tortured, raped and forcibly disappeared anti-government protesters, creating a climate of fear that is driving thousands of people to flee the country, the United Nations said Wednesday.

headline: S’mores and Wedding Cake Around the Campfire
abstract: Wedding campsites offer space to accommodate a long guest list overnight as well as plenty of activities to occupy their time.
lead_paragraph: Alyssa Marie Long and Collin Long both enjoy the outdoors and camping, so when it was time to pick a site for their wedding in May 2017, it came as no surprise that they would chose a campsite.

headline: Is Your Child Asking to Play Tackle Football This Year? We Want to Hear From You
abstract: Participation in youth football continues to drop, and studies continue to link the sport to brain injury. How much do you let these statistics affect your children’s participation?
lead_paragraph: The Friday night lights are on: High school (and junior high school) football season began this month in many areas of the country.

headline: Venezuelan Refugees Are Miserable. Let’s Help Them Out.
abstract: President Nicolás Maduro has plunged his country’s population into despair.
lead_paragraph: On a recent August morning at a church-run food pantry in Cúcuta, Colombia, a Venezuelan refugee named Carolina described her predicament in an exhausted, shellshocked tone.

headline: Plans for U.F.O.-Like Home in Norway Are Rejected
abstract: “A House to Die In,” by Bjarne Melgaard and Snohetta, has been scuttled by Oslo authorities after debate over its impact on a nearby studio of Edvard Munch.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Controversial plans by the Norwegian artist Bjarne Melgaard and the renowned architecture firm Snohetta to build a U.F.O-like home in the suburbs of Oslo have been rejected by the local authorities.

headline: After Urban Meyer Suspension, Some at Ohio State See a Culture of Sports Above All
abstract: The football coach’s suspension for his handling of a domestic abuse case, following a sexual abuse case implicating a former wrestling team doctor, has raised difficult questions on campus.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — On any given Saturday, the nearly 105,000-seat home stadium of the Ohio State football team shakes and sways as the team, more often than not, roars to victory in a weekly manifestation of the university’s grip on the psyche of the state.

headline: You Took Lousy iPhone Photos. Here’s How to Make Them Beautiful.
abstract: Not every shot on your smartphone will be Instagram worthy, but you can often salvage middling snaps with just a few taps. Here are six easy steps.
lead_paragraph: We spend a lot of time trying to tame our technology or wean ourselves from its ills. But tech at its best can help us create new things and express ourselves.

headline: Teaching Critical Thinking in English Class With Short Documentary Films
abstract: A Florida teacher explains how he uses our weekly Film Club feature to teach analysis and promote students’ awareness of the larger world.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to a new year of Great Ideas From Readers, a long-running feature that highlights the work of teachers, parents, students, librarians, coaches and anyone else who teaches (or learns) with The New York Times. If you have an idea, tell us about it here, or write to LNFeedback@nytimes.com. You can also browse our full collection to see what others have done.

headline: Big Environmental Rollbacks Are Pending. Here’s How You Can Weigh In.
abstract: In this week's climate newsletter: An abridged guide to public hearings and some podcast recommendations.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: China, North Korea, Nafta: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Writer Named in Hotchkiss School Sex Abuse Report Resigns College Post
abstract: Ron Carlson resigned from the University of California Irvine after an accusation surfaced that he had fondled a student while teaching at Hotchkiss, a high school, in the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: Ron Carlson, a writer and director of the postgraduate fiction program at University of California Irvine, has resigned his position after a report prepared for a Connecticut boarding school, where he taught in the 1970s, cited him as someone who had been accused of sexual misconduct by a former student there, according to The Los Angeles Times.

headline: James Villas, Sharp-Tongued Food Critic, Dies at 80
abstract: His cookbooks and magazine articles championed Southern fare, and he eschewed the contrived and trendy mix of ingredients in gastronomic innovation.
lead_paragraph: James Villas, an author of numerous cookbooks and magazine articles who staunchly defended his homegrown Southern cooking and waged an uncivil war against voguish gustatory gimmickry, died on Aug. 17 at his home in East Hampton, N.Y. He was 80.

headline: New U.S. Sexual Misconduct Rules Bolster Rights of Accused and Protect Colleges
abstract: Education Secretary Betsy DeVos is preparing to propose new sexual misconduct rules that cement the rights of the accused and reduce liability for institutions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Education Secretary Betsy DeVos is preparing new policies on campus sexual misconduct that would bolster the rights of students accused of assault, harassment or rape, reduce liability for institutions of higher education and encourage schools to provide more support for victims.

headline: The Long, Monstrous Reign of the Red Delicious Apple Is Ending
abstract: After more than 50 years as America’s most-grown apple, the fruit is expected to be unseated this year as consumers seek crisper, sweeter alternatives.
lead_paragraph: After more than a half-century as America’s most-grown apple, the Red Delicious is on track to be ousted this year by a sweet, juicy, young upstart: the Gala.

headline: Lindsay Kemp, Dancer Who Taught David Bowie, Is Dead at 80
abstract: Another student, Kate Bush, said Mr. Kemp was “astonishingly inspirational.” But his boundary-pushing work often divided critics.
lead_paragraph: Lindsay Kemp, a boundary-pushing British dancer, choreographer and mime who taught David Bowie and Kate Bush how to move, died on Friday at his home in Livorno, Italy. He was 80.

headline: Happy 20th Anniversary, Harry Potter
abstract: A publishing saga, captured in Potter ephemera — letters, sketches, mementos and more — that has been transfigured into treasure.
lead_paragraph: Before there was a movie franchise, and a collection of theme parks, and a Broadway play (two actually); before you could spot wand-wielding children sporting long black robes and know just what they were up to; there was Joanne Rowling’s manuscript, famously rumored to have been partly written on disposable napkins, about an orphaned boy who did not know he was a wizard. It was rejected by several British publishers, and then accepted by one, Bloomsbury, which published it as “Harry Potter and the Philosopher’s Stone,” with Rowling’s name defeminized into “J.K.” A year later — on Sept. 1, 1998 — it arrived in American bookstores as “Harry Potter and the Sorcerer’s Stone,” with a new cover designed by Mary GrandPré. There was another publisher, Scholastic, tasked with introducing the book and the wizarding world to American children, and soon enough, across the country there were young readers, and more than a few older ones, clamoring for more.

headline: Tap That: 5 Items That Are Sure to Go Viral
abstract: What the cool girls will be wearing on your feed this fall.
lead_paragraph: Time was, if you wanted to see what people were wearing, you had to go out and actually see people. Endless inspiration awaited the alert people watcher, particularly in a city like New York, where passers-by seem to dress with your personal entertainment in mind.

headline: South Africa Is at a ‘Critical Juncture’
abstract: David Mabuza, the deputy president, rebuts reports of corruption.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: After Trump, the Deluge?
abstract: The president, who has condoned violence at his rallies, says Democrats will “violently” overturn all he has done if they prevail in the midterms.
lead_paragraph: Once again, there was text and subtext, and as often with this president, both were disturbing.

headline: Cynthia Nixon, Danielle Brooks and Uma Thurman Read From Modern Love
abstract: In a special episode, the Modern Love podcast reprises readings about the secrets we keep.
lead_paragraph: This week the Modern Love podcast pulls together three readings into an hourlong episode, perfect for a car ride back from the beach.

headline: ‘Castle Rock’ Season 1, Episode 8: Dangerous and Foolhardy
abstract: Say this about the Kid: He has a real knack for popping up wherever things get bonkers.
lead_paragraph: Last week’s episode of “Castle Rock” was widely and rightly hailed as one of the best TV episodes of 2018, although the intense focus on Ruth Deaver did leave the show with a bit of a problem. With this season now hastening to a close, we’re not much closer than we were a few weeks ago to filling in this story’s big blanks. Who is “the Kid?” What happened to Henry Deaver 27 years ago? What’s with this hum that only certain people in town can hear?

headline: Louis C.K. and Men Who Think Justice Takes as Long as They Want It To
abstract: A comedian who admitted to sexual misconduct seems to think it’s time for his comeback.
lead_paragraph: The #MeToo movement has existed for more than a decade, since the activist Tarana Burke coined the phrase, and it was popularized in 2017, as men such as Harvey Weinstein, Mario Batali, Matt Lauer, Kevin Spacey, Louis C.K. and Charlie Rose were called to account for reported instances of sexual harassment, assault and, in some cases, rape. For the past several months the court of public opinion has litigated the misdeeds of these men. Some have lost their jobs. Harvey Weinstein is facing criminal charges. They have fallen from grace, but they have had mighty soft landings.

headline: New Sentences: From Mitski’s ‘Two Slow Dancers’
abstract: There are great sentences on paper and great sentences in songs, but the categories don’t often overlap.
lead_paragraph: — From Mitski’s “Two Slow Dancers,” the final song on the new album “Be the Cowboy” (Dead Oceans, Aug. 17, 2018).

headline: Overlooked No More: Ruby Payne-Scott, Who Explored Space With Radio Waves
abstract: Payne-Scott helped establish the field of radio astronomy by using radio waves to detect solar bursts, but she was forced to resign after she got married.
lead_paragraph: Since 1851, obituaries in The New York Times have been dominated by white men. With Overlooked, we’re adding the stories of remarkable people whose deaths went unreported in The Times.

headline: New York City, Geocachers’ Paradise
abstract: Thanks to social media and GPS in every smartphone, geocaching has left the fringe and is having a resurgence in the five boroughs.
lead_paragraph: Jeremy Jacobowitz and John Mitchell were on the hunt for treasure in Central Park. Mr. Jacobowitz consulted the coordinates on his phone as a misty rain fell. He and Mr. Mitchell were geocaching, and if past experience was any guide, they would most surely find something. In nine years as a geocacher, Mr. Jacobowitz has discovered more than 8,200 caches, as the treasures are known, ranking him very near the top of the heap among New York City players. Mr. Mitchell counts his haul at around 3,600.

headline: A Serial Cat Killer Is on the Loose in Washington State
abstract: A 10-person task force has been set up to try to catch the person responsible for mutilating and killing at least 12 cats in and near Olympia, Wash., since February.
lead_paragraph: All across part of Washington State, cats are turning up dead.

headline: Clint Dempsey Retires Atop the American Record Books
abstract: Dempsey announced his retirement on Wednesday, ending a 15-year career that included stints in the United States and in Europe.
lead_paragraph: The combative and prolific United States national team striker Clint Dempsey, who played and scored in three straight World Cups, is retiring from soccer.

headline: John McCain, Nafta, Harry Potter: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: A Mets Prospect Redefines the Meaning of a Lost Season
abstract: Dominic Smith dutifully dropped more than 30 pounds. But his major league numbers are even worse than the year before and his status on the team is diminished.
lead_paragraph: Dominic Smith needed to lose weight.

headline: 18 Water Main Breaks Flood Hoboken, Pitting Mayor Against Water Company
abstract: The city, in a lawsuit, blamed a construction project in nearby Jersey City. The water company pointed to an aging infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: HOBOKEN, N.J. — This city has been plagued by flooding for decades. A simple heavy rain used to fill low-lying streets with water, forcing drivers to move their cars to higher ground and residents to leave rubber boots next to their welcome mats outside most doors.

headline: Bloomberg Moves New Forum for Elites From China Amid Fallout of Trade War
abstract: Organizers are moving the event to Singapore after a Chinese partner for the conference, planned by Michael R. Bloomberg, requested that it be postponed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Fallout from the trade war between the United States and China has prompted Michael R. Bloomberg, the billionaire media executive and former mayor of New York City, to relocate what was planned as a conference of global business and political leaders in Beijing to rival Davos, the elite annual conclave in Switzerland.

headline: ‘Can You Stop Interrupting?’ ‘Can You Stop Lying?’ Cuomo and Nixon Clash in Debate.
abstract: The candidates for governor in New York fought over standing up to President Trump, marijuana, health care policy and corruption in Albany.
lead_paragraph: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y. — After months of shadowboxing from afar, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Cynthia Nixon clashed up close in a heated debate on Wednesday that featured sharp attacks, flashes of frustration and two competing visions for the Democratic Party and New York.

headline: $400,000 Poured In for a Homeless Man, and Now He Wants It
abstract: He gave a stranded couple his last $20. They used his story to raise $400,000 through GoFundMe. He claims he never saw any money. Now he has a lawyer.
lead_paragraph: When a homeless man in Philadelphia gave a stranded couple his last $20 so they could buy gas, they were so inspired that they started an online fund-raiser to help him.

headline: A Day Watching ‘Japan’s Wildest Game’
abstract: Botaoshi, or “topple the pole,” is violent enough that many Japanese high schools have dropped it. But at Kaisei Gakuen, a 90-year-old tradition lives on.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.

headline: E.P.A. to Reconsider Obama-Era Curbs on Mercury Emissions by Power Plants
abstract: It is the latest effort by the Trump administration to revisit or weaken environmental rules. Mercury has been tied to brain damage and other ailments.
lead_paragraph: Want climate news in your inbox? Sign up for our Climate Fwd: newsletter.

headline: Ted Achilles, Who Gave Afghan Girls Access to Education, Died at 82
abstract: Mr. Achilles and Shabana Basij-Rasikh founded the School of Leadership Afghanistan, a boarding school in Kabul that provides a safe education for Afghan girls.
lead_paragraph: Ted Achilles, a retired businessman who helped found an innovative boarding school for girls in Kabul, a potentially dangerous undertaking in a country still rife with Taliban militants violently opposed to teaching girls, died on Aug. 21 at a hospice in Portland, Ore. He was 82.

headline: Want to Be the Governor’s No. 2? Debate Offers Opposing Views of Job
abstract: Should the No. 2 be the governor’s partner, as Lt. Gov. Kathy Hochul suggests? Or someone who will challenge him, as Jumaane Williams says he will do?
lead_paragraph: As undercards go, it would be hard to go further under than this one.

headline: The Commander of Fear
abstract: Trump’s magical mixture is to make being afraid feel like fun.
lead_paragraph: During the presidential campaign, in the spring of 2016, the Republican front-runner Donald Trump sat down for an interview with Bob Woodward and Robert Costa of The Washington Post. They quoted President Barack Obama on global power and foreign affairs saying that “real power means you can get what you want without having to exert violence.” They then asked Trump if he agreed.

headline: Egypt’s Soccer Star Aims for a New Goal: Humbling His Own Bosses
abstract: Egypt’s soccer superstar Mohamed Salah unleashed a fierce assault on the country’s sporting establishment — an unusual act in a country where dissent is dangerous.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — When Mohamed Salah is on the offensive, you better watch out.

headline: Quotation of the Day: ‘Overtourism’ and the Role of Technology
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, August 30, 2018.
lead_paragraph: “Seventy-five years ago, tourism was about experience seeking. Now it’s about using photography and social media to build a personal brand.”

headline: Gillum Win Continues Breakthrough Year for Black Candidates
abstract: Andrew Gillum’s primary victory in Florida is the latest in a series of high-profile triumphs for black Democratic candidates running for governor, joining Stacey Abrams in Georgia and Ben Jealous in Maryland.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Gillum’s primary victory in Florida is the latest in a series of high-profile triumphs for black Democratic candidates running for governor, joining Stacey Abrams in Georgia and Ben Jealous in Maryland.

headline: Democratic Embrace of Diverse Candidates Collides With Barbed Politics of Trump Era
abstract: Andrew Gillum’s victory in the Democratic gubernatorial primary in Florida comes at a time when racial and ethnic issues are becoming more volatile and explicit in politics.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Democratic nominees for governor include three African-Americans, two of them in the old Confederacy, a prospect that not long ago would have been unthinkable. Record numbers of women are competing in congressional races. Elsewhere, Muslims, gays, lesbians and transgender people will be on the ballot for high-profile offices.

headline: Trump Accuses China of Undermining Diplomacy With North Korea
abstract: The president tried to make China the scapegoat for his administration’s stalled negotiations with Pyongyang. Beijing accused him of “magical logic.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Wednesday tried to make China the scapegoat for his stalled diplomacy with North Korea, accusing it of undermining the American-led pressure campaign against Pyongyang because of an escalating trade dispute with the United States.

headline: Sloane Stephens Beats the Heat and a Mysterious Opponent
abstract: Nobody was immune from the conditions at the Open on Wednesday, with temperatures again hovering in the mid-90s. Stephens won; Andy Murray didn’t.
lead_paragraph: Sloane Stephens had her share of challenges on Wednesday in her second-round match at the United States Open. She labored with her serve. She fussed with a blister on her right palm. She coped with the oppressive heat. (Perhaps you’ve heard about the heat? It was hot again.)

headline: Capturing How John McCain Was Honored Across the Country
abstract: New York Times photographers documented the ceremonies.
lead_paragraph: From Arizona to Washington, John McCain was honored in a series of memorial services this week. Mr. McCain’s family, colleagues in Congress and the public paid tribute to the Navy veteran, presidential candidate and longtime senator.

headline: Trump’s Swamp Things
abstract: Did anybody mention clearing the air?
lead_paragraph: I cannot think of a better time to talk about draining the swamp.

headline: Trump Claims ‘We Did a Fantastic Job in Puerto Rico’
abstract: President Trump asserted that Puerto Rico’s power utility was “dead” and that electricity was “gone” even before Hurricane Maria hit the island in September 2017. The utility was in disrepair but still operational, and the island was not in the dark.
lead_paragraph: — President Trump, in remarks on Wednesday at the White House

headline: A Generation Overshadowed by Federer and Nadal Heads for the Exit
abstract: Julien Benneteau, David Ferrer, Gilles Müller and Mikhail Youzhny all plan to retire soon. And despite plenty of success, their Grand Slam trophy cases will probably stay empty.
lead_paragraph: In 2001, Mikhail Youzhny walked forward onto the Australian Open court for his first Grand Slam match, just as he would for the next 17 years at the top tennis tournaments around the world. But in his final Grand Slam match on Tuesday, Youzhny walked backward off Court 6 at the United States Open.

headline: The Culture Calendar
abstract: Add an event to your calendar, email it to a friend or subscribe here to receive our monthly updates.
lead_paragraph: Add an event to your calendar, email it to a friend or subscribe here to receive our monthly updates.

headline: Andrew Gillum Pulled Off the Upset of a Lifetime. Now Comes the Hard Part.
abstract: After the surprise victory of Mr. Gillum, a progressive, 39-year-old black man, in the Democratic primary for Florida governor, he must now find a way to raise enough money for a grueling general election.
lead_paragraph: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — Andrew Gillum waged a quixotic Democratic primary campaign for Florida governor, defeating wealthy rivals who outspent him, dismissing moderate naysayers who questioned him and believing until the end that an unorthodox strategy of excitement generated mostly by word of mouth would propel him to victory.

headline: Corrections: August 30, 2018
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Thursday, August 30, 2018.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: For Foreigners Imprisoned by Iran, an Uncertain Plight
abstract: There was a flicker of hope when Iran briefly released Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, a Briton, from a prison. Now she and other foreigners held there can only wait.
lead_paragraph: When a British-Iranian charity worker was abruptly released from a Tehran prison last week on a three-day leave and allowed to see her daughter, joy erupted among supporters in Britain, where her case has received extraordinary attention.

headline: Fact Check on Cuomo-Nixon Debate: Who Stretched the Truth?
abstract: Cynthia Nixon and Gov. Andrew Cuomo made accusations about President Trump, the M.T.A. and corruption.
lead_paragraph: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y. — The lone debate in the Democratic primary pitting Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo against his challenger, Cynthia Nixon, featured its fair share of brickbats and bon mots. Here’s a quick look at some of the candidates’ statements, and when they may have stretched the truth.

headline: Let There Be Light, in Church
abstract: Priests and other clergy members should have to report cases of suspected child sexual abuse, however they hear about them.
lead_paragraph: The Roman Catholic clergy sex abuse crisis blankets the globe in darkness. We are at a tipping point — or at least we ought to be.

headline: You Need a Raise. How Do You Start the Conversation?
abstract: Ask after a “win.” Know what you want. And have a backup plan.
lead_paragraph: It’s Personal Finance 101: If you want to be good with money, you have to learn how to save it. But there are only so many slices of avocado toast you can refuse. At some point, being good with money requires something a bit more difficult: earning more of it.

headline: How McCain Got the Last Word Against Trump
abstract: For years, the president had used Twitter and his bully pulpit to mock and condemn the senator from Arizona. In death, John McCain found a way to have the last word.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Not long after Senator John McCain learned last summer that he had terminal brain cancer, he began convening meetings every Friday in his Capitol Hill office with a group of trusted aides. The subject was his funeral.

headline: Popular Browser Extension
abstract: Grant Thackray is trying to influence us.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — This is probably as good a time as any to tell you that I used to work in advertising. It was the mid-1980s, an unstable time for ad agencies, so when I say I worked in advertising, what I really mean is that I spent roughly six months at each of the major agencies hiding from my manager, until someone above us would lose a big account and we’d all have to go job hunting again.

headline: In the Heart of Gentrifying Brooklyn, Nixon Finds Her Audience
abstract: The crowd at the debate watch party had no patience for Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s recitation of investments in transportation, given the area’s subway woes.
lead_paragraph: There was some applause when Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo offered that he had tried marijuana in college, and even some laughter when he wryly noted that the public would have a better sense of Cynthia Nixon’s personal worth if she released more tax returns.

headline: Trump Attacks CNN After Source Raises Doubts About Report on Russia Meeting
abstract: The president says the network was “caught in a major lie” and refused to admit the mistake. CNN stands by its story.
lead_paragraph: President Trump attacked CNN on Wednesday, writing on Twitter that the network had been “caught in a major lie” in connection to an article it published in July about claims made by the president’s former personal lawyer, Michael D. Cohen.

headline: U.S. Open Changes Course on Women Changing Shirts
abstract: U.S.T.A. officials have nimbly been patching emerging cracks in its proud foundation of gender equality during the first week of its marquee tournament.
lead_paragraph: The United States Open completed a massive renovation project around the grounds in time for its 50th anniversary this year.

headline: ‘Beach With No Water’ Draws Sneers in Rome. But It Has Fans, Too.
abstract: A riverfront beach has been criticized as too little, too late for this summer, but for those who cannot get to the seaside, it’s a welcome option.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The riverfront beach was supposed to be a summertime gift from the beleaguered mayor of Rome, Virginia Raggi, to her citizens. Called “Tiberis,” an ancient name for Rome’s main waterway, the municipal beach had been promoted as Rome’s answer to Seine-side installations in Paris.

headline: Cuomo 2020 Presidential Run: Citing God and Death, He Rules It Out
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo vowed to finish a full third term if re-elected in November, saying that the only caveat was if “God strikes me dead.”
lead_paragraph: In his firmest denial of presidential ambitions yet, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Wednesday that, if re-elected this year, he would finish a full third term as New York’s governor — or die trying.

headline: Another Major Venus-Serena Showdown. In the Third Round.
abstract: Venus and Serena Williams will face each other on Friday at the U.S. Open for the 30th time in their professional careers. But the matchup comes early in the tournament.
lead_paragraph: For the 30th time since they became professional tennis players, Venus Williams and her younger sister Serena Williams will face one another this week in a clash of two of the best to ever play the game.

headline: Australia Plans to Deny Chelsea Manning an Entry Visa, Citing ‘Criminal Record’
abstract: The Australian government said Ms. Manning, who was convicted of sharing classified American military documents, failed a character test.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The Australian government said on Wednesday that it would not grant a visa to Chelsea Manning, a former American soldier sentenced to prison for sharing classified government documents, because she failed a character test required for entry.

headline: Scared to Be a Parent?
abstract: Fear not — there are books and consultants to help you figure out if you even want a child.
lead_paragraph: For most of her 30s, Katie Wilson was pretty certain she did not want children. But at 36, there was a looming sense that her fertility window was closing and a wave of anxiety set in about her and her husband’s once-firm decision to remain child free.

headline: Maureen Dowd, in Australia, Explains Trump’s ‘Ego Arithmetic’
abstract: Our opinion columnist is in Australia, sharing her blistering take on politics and the media in America.
lead_paragraph: The Australia Letter is a weekly newsletter reflecting the experience (and quirks) of our Australia bureau chief. Sign up to get it by email. Here’s where to find all our Australia and New Zealand coverage.

headline: Ryan LaMarre’s Stunning Outburst Humbles the Yankees
abstract: LaMarre, a White Sox journeyman outfielder, drove in all four of his team’s runs to give the lowly White Sox a series win over the Yankees.
lead_paragraph: Over his 18-season major league career, C.C. Sabathia had posted the equivalent of a pretty good season statistics line against the Chicago White Sox: a 19-6 record and 3.73 E.R.A., with 227 strikeouts over 234 innings in 36 career starts.

headline: Lost in the Storm
abstract: Houston thought it was prepared for a major hurricane like Harvey. But as the flooding overwhelmed the city’s emergency systems, families like the Daileys found out too late that they were on their own.
lead_paragraph: Houston thought it was prepared for a major hurricane like Harvey. But as the flooding overwhelmed the city’s emergency systems, families like the Daileys found out too late that they were on their own.

headline: For Sale: 55-Foot-Tall Lobster. Owners in a Pinch. Can You Help?
abstract: A giant lobster named Larry is at the center of a small town’s identity. What happens if he leaves? And what does a dispute about its future say about the culture of Australia’s “Big Things”?
lead_paragraph: KINGSTON SOUTH EAST, Australia — On a grassy patch of land beside the Princes Highway, Casey Sharpe sighed as he looked up at his most prized and problematic possession: a 55-foot-tall spiny lobster.

headline: Russia, Scallops, Aston Martin: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘Take Two’ and ‘The Great Food Truck Race’
abstract: Watch two new episodes of “Take Two” and the season finale of “The Great Food Truck Race.”
lead_paragraph: Watch two new episodes of “Take Two” and the season finale of “The Great Food Truck Race.”

headline: Review: In ‘The Little Stranger,’ a Haunted House and a Fading Way of Life
abstract: Domhnall Gleeson stars as a doctor who gets mixed up with an aristocratic family in Britain in this adaptation of Sarah Waters’s Gothic novel.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds Hall is the name of a grand pile of brick in Warwickshire, England, and if you’re moderately familiar with movies and television — “Downton Abbey,” “Crimson Peak,” the “Ghostbusters” reboot — you have no doubt seen hundreds like it. Its sprawling grounds and cavernous rooms evoke ancient aristocratic privilege, but by the late 1940s, when “The Little Stranger” takes place, that grandeur has begun to fade.

headline: Forgotten Images of the Vietnam War Made for the Americans Who Fought In It
abstract: These uncovered photos explore previously buried scenes of the Vietnam War, as well as the outsize role of a publication led by two tenacious women.
lead_paragraph: For more than four decades, Art Greenspon kept his recollections of photographing the Vietnam War for Overseas Weekly tucked away deep in his memory, as inaccessible as the images themselves. Then, in 2014, a treasure trove of 35 mm negatives emerged from the gloom of a Scandinavian cellar, vividly reminding Mr. Greenspon of his time working for the scrappy little alternative tabloid.

headline: Maya Rudolph and Fred Armisen Play It (Relatively) Straight
abstract: The “Saturday Night Live” veterans trade Beyoncé and Prince impersonations for a normcore couple in Southern California in their new series “Forever.”
lead_paragraph: MALIBU, Calif. — During their lengthy runs on “Saturday Night Live,” Maya Rudolph and Fred Armisen created some of the sketch comedy show’s most outrageous characters.

headline: Poem: Rain at Three
abstract: Selected by Rita Dove.
lead_paragraph: A sudden summer storm, cushions and laundry caught out in the rain — the scene feels familiar, although these details stem from Tishani Doshi’s memories of monsoon season in India, under “the fan-whir sea-heave/of our muscled Tamil Nadu nights.” Nature’s brusque disruption has broken the trance of routine, and for a moment the hinge between childhood and adulthood swings wide. Even as they bend to the task of reclaiming what the tempest has scattered, a trace of that wild ache lingers — a glimpse into what it means to be inconsolably, joyously human. Selected by Rita Dove

headline: The First Time I Got High
abstract: It was in Colorado — surprise, surprise — where you can look at the stars and the trees won’t judge you for being 27.
lead_paragraph: I’m not exciting. I’m sleepy by 10 p.m. and resent any plans that keep me out of my apartment, far from my pajamas; I’m not a huge fan of flying, so I tend to not go on too many trips; and spicy foods aren’t for me.

headline: National Enquirer Had Decades of Trump Dirt. He Wanted to Buy It All.
abstract: Donald Trump and his lawyer, Michael Cohen, devised a plan to buy all the stories on Mr. Trump that the National Enquirer and its parent company had collected, according to Mr. Trump’s associates.
lead_paragraph: Federal investigators have provided ample evidence that President Trump was involved in deals to pay two women to keep them from speaking publicly before the 2016 election about affairs that they said they had with him.

headline: Precious as Silver, Vanilla Brings Cash and Crime to Madagascar
abstract: With prices reaching hundreds of dollars a pound, Madagascar’s vanilla-growing region is in the midst of an economic boom. The windfall, however, has come at a steep cost.
lead_paragraph: With prices reaching hundreds of dollars a pound, Madagascar’s vanilla-growing region is in the midst of an economic boom. The windfall, however, has come at a steep cost.

headline: How to Get the Most Out of a Theme Park Trip
abstract: When to go, and how to save on everything from admission to food. (And are passes that let you bypass lines worth it?)

headline: At McCain’s Memorial, Tears, Laughs and Allusions to the Man Not Invited
abstract: The emotional ceremony lacked President Trump’s presence, though speakers could not help but reference the ways in which his and Mr. McCain’s leadership styles contrasted.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Senator John McCain was remembered Thursday at a memorial service that evoked the one-time prisoner of war’s unbreakable will, the Arizona senator’s devotion to his adopted state and the maverick Republican’s willingness to break with his party to defend what he believed were his country’s founding principles.

headline: Surplus in Those Shiny Towers
abstract: At the high end of the market, the rate of sales has slowed significantly in the past year.
lead_paragraph: The pace of home sales over the past year shows there is a glut at the high end of the market in New York City and surrounding areas. Properties with the highest prices — those in the top 10 percent — are taking longer to sell.

headline: The Flea Circus of Times Square
abstract: Yes, it really was a thing. And yes, those fleas seemed to be trained. And very athletic.
lead_paragraph: Q. I remember seeing an old building in Times Square with a window saying “Flea Circus.” Do you have any information on this place?

headline: Secret Doorways, Gargoyles and Wood-Carved Angels: Cleaning Out the Cathedral Basement
abstract: The crypt of St. John the Divine is getting renovated. And yes, it’s a little spooky down there among the organ pipes and the tombs of the bishops.
lead_paragraph: When he first arrived at the gothic-style Cathedral of St. John the Divine last year as interim dean, the Rt. Rev. Clifton Daniel III asked to see the basement. Maybe his dark curiosity came from his Southern Gothic background (he hails from North Carolina).

headline: A Broken Relationship and Accusations of Emotional Abuse: The Case of Keith Ellison
abstract: Allegations against the high-profile progressive leader represent a potentially new chapter of the #MeToo movement.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — When Keith Ellison became the first Muslim elected to Congress in 2006, it made him an instant national star: a charismatic young black leader who was now a symbol of the Democratic Party’s commitment to diversity and equal rights.

headline: Norm Macdonald, Still in Search of the Perfect Joke
abstract: He has won a cult following by playing the wise fool, but his comedic ambitions are much greater than that. If he could only hold down a job.
lead_paragraph: Midway through his third orange Fanta, in the course of explaining why he doesn’t talk to strangers anymore, Norm Macdonald told the story of one of his stalkers. We were at the Panini Kabob Grill, an aggressively normal eatery in a planned community of shops and condos not far from his home on the Westside of Los Angeles. It was April, sunny but mild. The night before, Macdonald taped an episode of his new Netflix talk show, and he still had makeup in the crevices around his nostrils when he arrived for brunch. We were sitting with Lori Jo Hoekstra — Macdonald’s producing partner for the last 20 years — and a representative from Netflix. The tables were heavily lacquered, the menus were laminated and there were a few discreetly placed TVs. It was the kind of place where Macdonald was both unlikely to be noticed and virtually guaranteed to be the most famous person there.

headline: By the Book: Ben Macintyre
abstract: The author, most recently, of ‘The Spy and the Traitor’ is moved by ‘discretion and modesty’ in literature: ‘As a very British sort of Briton, I have an affection for the stiff upper lip, the emotion unvoiced, the desire undeclared.’
lead_paragraph: The author, most recently, of “The Spy and the Traitor” is moved by “discretion and modesty” in literature: “As a very British sort of Briton, I have an affection for the stiff upper lip, the emotion unvoiced, the desire undeclared.”

headline: Has This Neighborhood in Seoul Figured Out the Secret to Slow Living?
abstract: In Korea, one housing development offers new versions of tiled-roof residences, and with them, a less frenetic lifestyle.
lead_paragraph: FOUR YEARS AGO, Lee Byoungcheol was riding the subway to his job at a corporate I.T. firm when he saw an advertisement for a housing development in the foothills of the towering Bukhan Mountain in northern Seoul. Eunpyeong Hanok Village was selling locals hanok, the traditional Korean tile-roofed residences that have, after hundreds of years, increasingly been destroyed and replaced by towering steel structures; indeed, not since the 1930s have hanok been constructed in significant numbers.

headline: 30 Years After Her Acclaimed Debut, a Zimbabwean Novelist Returns to Her Heroine in a Sequel
abstract: In “This Mournable Body,” Tsitsi Dangarembga revisits the indomitable protagonist of “Nervous Conditions,” her prize-winning first novel, and finds her still struggling but unbowed.
lead_paragraph: THIS MOURNABLE BODY By Tsitsi Dangarembga 284 pp. Graywolf Press. Paper, $16.

headline: Parasitic Vines That Feed on Parasitic Wasps That Feed on Trees
abstract: It’s parasites all the way down.
lead_paragraph: Parasites have a leisurely lifestyle — set up camp at someone else’s place, live off their food, profit (evolutionarily speaking). But new research shows that sometimes the parasite gets a taste of its own medicine, and from an unexpected source.

headline: Cuomo-Nixon Debate: Six Takeaways
abstract: Did Cynthia Nixon come across as a credible candidate for governor? Yes. Did Gov. Andrew Cuomo stumble irreparably? No.
lead_paragraph: He didn’t snap. She didn’t whiff.

headline: Detroit Schools Turn Off Drinking Water, Citing Elevated Lead and Copper
abstract: Faucets and water fountains will be switched off when students return to public schools next week, but the district will provide water bottles.
lead_paragraph: When public school students in Detroit return to their classrooms next week for the first day of the school year, the water fountains will be dry.

headline: Rent That Was Too Good to Last
abstract: A new landlord drives up the rent, so a Manhattanite decides to move to a place that doubles her rent, but also nearly doubles her space.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Shaker would have been happy to remain indefinitely in her little fourth-floor walk-up in the East Village. Given the location, her friends were incredulous when they learned how low her rent was — $1,475 a month.

headline: 36 Hours in the Dolomites
abstract: This monumental mountain range in northeastern Italy is an idyllic playground for both outdoor adventurers and those seeking a taste of the region’s cultural heritage.
lead_paragraph: A travel tip for the Dolomites: You don’t want to be the driver, negotiating steep hairpin turns and bands of Italian cyclists pedaling through dangerously narrow mountain passes. You want to be the passenger, the one hanging her head out the window, mouth agape, transfixed on the mountain peaks and gloriously green valleys. This monumental mountain range in northeastern Italy is one of the world’s most beautiful playgrounds for outdoor adventurers, from winter skiers to summer hikers, bikers, mountain climbers and more. But equally fascinating is its cultural heritage.

headline: At Transfer Time in Lithuania, Prospects and Profits Collide
abstract: Contract disputes at a tiny Baltic club have shined a light on the wilder side of soccer’s player-trading market.
lead_paragraph: KAUNAS, Lithuania — The letter was short and to the point: A.S. Monaco, the elite soccer club on the French Riviera, wanted Ibrahima Sory Soumah to travel from his home in Guinea to France for a 10-day trial.

headline: Laughs From ‘Othello,’ and a Swoon From ‘Little Shop of Horrors’
abstract: In two outdoor productions, Mark Rylance draws humor from a pitiless Shakespeare villain, and Maria Aberg locates a heart in a musical of delightful kitsch.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Some productions of “Othello” chill the blood or, at the very least, make you ponder afresh the human capacity for psychic abrasion. But probably not until the current production at Shakespeare’s Globe has this eternally bitter tragedy delivered so many laughs.

headline: John McCain, New York, U.S. Open: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: An Unexpected Upset in Florida
abstract: After a surprise outcome in the primary, the Florida governor’s race is shaping up to be a litmus test for 2020.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: New York Today: Cuomo vs. Nixon One-Liners
abstract: Thursday: Notes from Nixon vs. Cuomo, and Broadway Week
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this clammy Thursday.

headline: What Guantánamo Says About Kavanaugh
abstract: As an appeals court judge, he signed on to decisions that deprived detainees of the chance to contest their detentions.
lead_paragraph: For a long time, I made it a point to write about Guantánamo at least once a year. There was usually some new development to hang a column on. But the real reason was that, having chronicled the riveting legal saga sparked by the George W. Bush administration’s decision to create a legal black hole at the U.S. Navy base there in which to imprison hundreds of men captured in Pakistan and Afghanistan in the aftermath of 9/11, I felt an obligation to show that I was still watching, even if most people no longer were.

headline: Trump, Erdogan and the New Global Order
abstract: The Trump administration must not choose drastic and destabilizing steps to put further pressure on Turkey or strong-arm allies into playing along with its decisions.
lead_paragraph: The current crisis between Ankara and Washington over the fate of the imprisoned American pastor Andrew Brunson is the culmination of a long-simmering dispute over the fundamental nature of the relationship between the United States and Turkey. Both sides want the relationship to continue but have irreconcilable expectations about whose terms it should continue on.

headline: Who’s Afraid of a White Minority?
abstract: The battle over how to project the future population of the United States has profound political implications.
lead_paragraph: The question of whether America will become a majority-minority nation — and when that might happen — is intensely disputed, of enormous political import and extraordinarily complex.

headline: A Labor Day Thank You for the Arts
abstract: This holiday weekend we tip our hats to those performers and others who work days, nights and weekends to enrich your cultural experiences.
lead_paragraph: It’s the time of year when we start to shake off that summer lull. As you reflect on your cultural adventures over the past few months, consider the people who made it all possible. We have a lot of people to thank, and we’re introducing you to several of them. Some of the following excerpts from conversations have been edited. NICOLE HERRINGTON

headline: Lawsuit Accuses the Italian Fashion House Etro of Discrimination
abstract: A former employee says she was fired for taking a stand against the race, gender and age bias of company practices.
lead_paragraph: A former employee of the Italian fashion house Etro, a family-owned brand known for its lush textiles and boho deluxe aesthetic, filed a lawsuit against the company and its leadership this week that says they have discriminated against employees on the basis of race, gender and age for more than two decades.

headline: Review: University Spoils a Cinephile in ‘A Paris Education’
abstract: A student befriends artists and fellow film lovers in this drama from Jean Paul Civeyrac.
lead_paragraph: Étienne Tinan (Andranic Manet) is a would-be film director in search of his own direction. This country boy’s quest for inspiration leads him to a modern university program in Paris. Étienne, who possesses the poky intelligence of a long-lashed farm cow, slights the taste of all who encourage him, whether they are his collaborators, girlfriends or professors. The only opinions that Étienne trusts are those of his classmate, Mathias (Corentin Fila), a snobby cinephile with a distaste for whiny French films.

headline: Review: In ‘Pick of the Litter,’ Good Dogs Compete to Be the Best
abstract: This unexpectedly suspenseful documentary follows the training of guide dogs for the blind.
lead_paragraph: On one hand, “Pick of the Litter” is a genuinely informative documentary on the rigors of training guide dogs for the blind, which need to be taught not only to obey commands, but also when to disobey (if, for instance, they’re ordered to march into traffic). It’s startling, even inspiring, to see how many humans it takes to condition a fully successful dog. Every single canine on screen deserves plenty of head-pats and naps in the shade.

headline: Review: In ‘Kin,’ a Futuristic Weapon and Family Troubles
abstract: This science-fiction film is fantasy wish fulfillment of a laser-blasting sort.
lead_paragraph: Frustrated teenage boys are apt to dream up elaborate fantasies about gaining all the power they don’t have. The dream factory that is cinema has now enabled the sibling filmmakers Jonathan and Josh Baker to bring one such fancy to the screen. In “Kin,” Eli (Myles Truitt), the 14-year-old adopted son of the hard-working Man of Integrity Hal (Dennis Quaid, seemingly angling to play Harrison Ford’s younger brother in a future film), finds an unusual weapon in an abandoned warehouse.

headline: Review: In ‘Reprisal,’ With Bruce Willis as Your Neighbor, You Too Can Fight Crime
abstract: This vigilante thriller is the kind of movie that, once, would have gone straight to video.
lead_paragraph: You used to be able to describe a movie as “the kind of thing that would have gone straight to video,” and people would have understood you. “Video on demand” doesn’t have the same ring. Nevertheless, “Reprisal” would have once filled out a lonely shelf at a Blockbuster, the ideal home for its sedate performances and visually hectic action.

headline: Review: In ‘Prototype,’ Multiple Screens Tell an Apocalyptic Story
abstract: A handmade film of uncompromising vision, “Prototype” is not your major studio’s 3-D movie.
lead_paragraph: In the Pere Ubu song “Street Waves” (from its 1978 album “The Modern Dance”), the future-minded singer looks for “a picture of what it’ll be like.” He turns his TV dial to a static-filled UHF station, and voilà: “I see electricity jump and spark.” In “Prototype,” an avant-garde science fiction film by Blake Williams, you can see something very much along those lines — in 3-D, no less.

headline: Review: ‘Active Measures’ Looks at Links Between Trump and Russia
abstract: Directed by Jack Bryan, this documentary digs through reams of documents and interviews more than two dozen people, including Hillary Clinton and John McCain.
lead_paragraph: Eager to make you uncomfortable, “Active Measures” piles on the ire as it outlines Russian efforts to manipulate world events, particularly the 2016 American presidential election.

headline: Can Bike Polo Go Legit?
abstract: The game, created by bored bike messengers when they were on breaks, is now, sort of, going mainstream. You can even buy bike polo mallets on Amazon.
lead_paragraph: They call it “the pit.” On a shady asphalt lot between Chrystie and Forsyth Streets on the Lower East Side, a young man in glasses and a faded tank top walked around with a leaf blower, sending twigs, grit and debris into its far corners.

headline: Review: Teenagers Tackle Environmental Enemies in ‘Inventing Tomorrow’
abstract: A documentary follows young scientists as they try to create solutions to environmental threats.
lead_paragraph: I’ve seen more than a few documentaries in recent years addressing vital environmental issues, chief among them climate change, and they all have one thing in common: they’re terrifying. Not just for what they show of the damage that humankind has done and is doing to its only home, but also for the limited options (if any) that these films present to counter that damage. Last year’s “The Age of Consequences” in particular was real doomsday nightmare fuel.

headline: New Zealand Town May Ban Cats to Protect Other Species
abstract: The idyllic coastal town of Omaui, full of rare bird species, is considering a sunset clause for felines.
lead_paragraph: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — Omaui, an idyllic coastal town on the South Island of New Zealand that overflows with rare bird species, is home to just 35 people and seven or eight much-loved cats.

headline: It’s ‘Hamilton’ and Prince Harry, Together Onstage
abstract: The Duke of Sussex sang a line from the hit musical at the end of a charity performance in London on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Does Prince Harry have the voice to be in the cast of “Hamilton?”

headline: Specter of Trump’s Car Tariffs Forces Allies to Give Ground in Talks
abstract: But their offers may not satisfy a president who has shown a willingness to embrace trade tensions to extract more from American trading partners.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — President Trump’s threat to impose tariffs on imported cars is working, sending foreign leaders from Mexico to Japan racing to the negotiating table to make deals. But their offers may not satisfy a president who has shown a willingness to embrace trade tensions in an effort to extract more from American trading partners.

headline: Can Andrew Gillum Win in Florida?
abstract: Democrats are trying to win over red and purple America with inspiration.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.

headline: California Today: The Costs of Making Buildings Safer
abstract: Thursday: The effects of a 1973 law that are still being felt, new policies on campus sexual misconduct, and a special escort to kindergarten.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: On the Market in New York and Connecticut
abstract: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom in Rye, N.Y., and a three-bedroom in Bridgeport, Conn.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom in Rye, N.Y., and a three-bedroom in Bridgeport, Conn.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
abstract: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom in Rye, N.Y., and a three-bedroom in Bridgeport, Conn.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: On the Market in Manhattan and Brooklyn
abstract: This week’s properties and in Yorkville, the West Village, and Brooklyn Heights.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties and in Yorkville, the West Village, and Brooklyn Heights.

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
abstract: This week’s properties are in Yorkville, the West Village, and Brooklyn Heights.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: Climate Museum Sends Distress Signals to Stimulate Discussion
abstract: Promoting the climate change conversation in a bold way throughout the five boroughs.
lead_paragraph: New signs that resemble the digital highway messages that typically flash bad news about road construction, traffic delays, flood warnings and missing children will be dotting New York City by Labor Day.

headline: Paul Taylor Dies at 88; Brought Poetry and Lyricism to Modern Dance
abstract: Mr. Taylor’s poignant and exuberant works entered the repertory of numerous dance companies. His own company has been one of the world’s superlative troupes.
lead_paragraph: Paul Taylor, who brought a lyrical musicality, capacity for joy and wide poetic imagination to modern dance over six decades as one of its greatest choreographers, died on Wednesday in a Manhattan hospital. He was 88.

headline: Review: In ‘Let the Corpses Tan,’ Bullets Fly. People Die. But a Story? No.
abstract: The directors, Hélène Cattet and Bruno Forzani, are more concerned with their own style than with telling a tale.
lead_paragraph: In “Let the Corpses Tan,” a man squints, a woman tinkles and time passes very, very slowly as guns fire and the sun glares. A formalist experiment that soon devolves into a mannerist indulgence, the movie almost incidentally involves a gang of snarly, sweaty men loafing about in a studiously rundown Mediterranean compound. There, amid dilapidated structures and half-buried bodies, a woman, Luce (Elina Lowensohn), strides around in boots and little else, occasionally pausing to emit one of those huge, raucous laughs that’s meant to suggest madness or mystery.

headline: Jason Pierce Struggled to Make a New Spiritualized Album. And He May Do It Again.
abstract: “And Nothing Hurt,” the first Spiritualized album in six years, is the result of the 53-year-old musician’s “obsessive” process of assembling sounds.
lead_paragraph: “Stupid.” That’s the word the English rocker Jason Pierce keeps coming back to when he describes how he made the latest album by Spiritualized, “And Nothing Hurt,” due Sept. 7. It has been six years between albums for Spiritualized, the band Mr. Pierce started in 1990, and as he worked on the new record, he often said it would be his last one.

headline: Influence of Big-Money Donors Declined in 2017 Mayoral Election
abstract: Nearly 75 percent of donors to last year’s mayoral race in New York City gave $175 or less, a much higher share than in the 2013 election.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s emphasis on small donors in last year’s mayoral race helped fuel a resurgence of donations of $175 or less to candidates participating in New York City’s matching funds program, according to a new report by the Campaign Finance Board.

headline: Justice Dept. Backs Suit Accusing Harvard of Discriminating Against Asian-American Applicants
abstract: The agency has filed a so-called statement of interest in their case, saying that Harvard “has failed to show that it does not unlawfully discriminate.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department lent its support on Thursday to students who are suing Harvard University over affirmative action policies that they claim discriminate against Asian-American applicants, in a case that could have far-reaching consequences in college admissions.

headline: On the Trail of a Lover Boy in the Age of Enlightenment
abstract: Seducer, scammer, courtier, spy: Giacomo Casanova hovers like a governing spirit over the art of the 18th century in a sumptuous new show.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — His parents were actors, his grandfather made shoes; he did not seem born for great things. Giacomo Casanova, though, had assets that outshone the lack of money and title: boldness, wit, a gift for languages, and charm enough to slide into a seat at a cardinal’s dinner table or a countess’s bed. In his native Venice, in glittering Paris, and then across the continent, he reinvented himself as he went, playing the roles of author, courtier, entrepreneur, spy. The actors’ son trod the boards of a different stage, one that stretched from London to Constantinople.

headline: Things to Do in New York This Weekend: Sharks in Brooklyn? You Better Believe It.
abstract: It’s time to meet your marine neighbors at the New York Aquarium, and have some good, old-fashioned fun at the Bronx Brewery.
lead_paragraph: Like summer, our pop-up newsletter is sadly coming to a close. Thank you for joining us on these adventures, and we hope you learned a few new things about our city — we sure did.

headline: Pause in Military Drills, Ordered by Trump, Leaves South Koreans Uneasy
abstract: President Trump’s complaints about the cost of the exercises, and of the American military presence itself, have some Koreans fearing for their security.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — For six decades, joint exercises held by the militaries of South Korea and the United States have been the most visible and celebrated display of the alliance. Each year, their Marines storm South Korean beaches together, their tanks spew orange-red flames and their warplanes run mock bombing raids on imaginary North Korean nuclear targets.

headline: Argentina’s Peso Tumbles as Turbulence in Emerging Markets Spreads
abstract: Argentina’s central bank raised interest rates, trying to halt a plunge in the value of the peso. The turmoil led to a sell-off in other emerging-market currencies.
lead_paragraph: Investors for weeks have been anxious that problems in developing economies could lead to broader trouble in financial markets. Turmoil in Turkey has been the most frequent cause for concern.

headline: New Plan for City Streetcar: Shorter, Pricier and Not Coming Soon
abstract: Officials say a plan for a trolley along the Brooklyn-Queens waterfront is still alive, but cannot be built without $1 billion in federal funding.
lead_paragraph: The good news for fans of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s Brooklyn-to-Queens streetcar project is that, speculation to the contrary, the city says it is still alive.

headline: Serving Time Should Not Mean ‘Prison Slavery’
abstract: A national strike by prisoners is the latest iteration of demands for freedom from forced labor.
lead_paragraph: Since Aug. 21, prisoners across the United States have been on one of the largest prison strikes the nation has seen in years. They have several demands, but at the top is the end of the forced labor the state coerces out of them. Up to 800,000 prisoners a day are put out for work without their choice, usually for extremely paltry compensation that in Louisiana is as low as 4 cents per hour.

headline: Will Trump Pardon Manafort?
abstract: By speculating about it, the president and his surrogates have already acted improperly.
lead_paragraph: Since Paul Manafort was convicted last week, the president and his associates have encouraged speculation about it. Rudy Giuliani, President Trump’s personal lawyer, claims that he has agreed not to pardon anyone related to the investigation by Robert Mueller, the special counsel, until it is completed. Mr. Giuliani explained that he and the president were concerned that a pardon at this stage could be viewed as obstruction of justice. Yet other reporting suggests that Mr. Trump remains eager to move forward on a pardon and is even considering cutting the White House counsel, Don McGahn (who is opposed to it), out of the process.

headline: The Week in Good News: Paris Beekeepers, Peter Dutton, Night Owls
abstract: Sometimes it seems as if we’re living under a constant barrage of heavy news. But it isn’t all bad out there.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes it seems as if we’re living under a constant barrage of heavy news. But it isn’t all bad out there. This feature is meant to send you into the weekend with a smile, or at least a lighter heart. Want to get The Week in Good News by email? Sign up here.

headline: Campbell Soup Prepares a Return to Its (Canned) Roots
abstract: The company said it planned to sell off its fresh food and overseas businesses, and left open the option of selling the entirety of the company as well.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 150 years ago, the Campbell Soup Company was founded as a seller of canned soups and vegetables. But over the past decade, as consumers demanded fresher food options, it has tried to oblige.

headline: New York City Is Briefly Labeled ‘Jewtropolis’ on Snapchat and Other Apps
abstract: The label was linked to a third-party company called Mapbox. The company’s chief executive said the map had been vandalized, calling it the “ugliest kind” of error.
lead_paragraph: Users of a variety of popular apps and services, including Snapchat, awoke Thursday morning to find that New York City had been relabeled “Jewtropolis” on maps displayed in the apps.

headline: Who’d Be on Your Spaceship? A School Exercise Backfires in Ohio
abstract: Children were asked to decide life or death for a group that included a gay athlete, an Asian orphan and a racist police officer.
lead_paragraph: An Ohio school superintendent has apologized for a class exercise that asked middle school students to choose from a list of racially, ethnically and religiously diverse candidates to save or leave behind if Earth were “doomed for destruction.”

headline: Insults Fly at Cuomo-Nixon Debate
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Cynthia Nixon faced off in their only scheduled debate before the Democratic Primary for governor in New York.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Cynthia Nixon faced off in their only scheduled debate before the Democratic Primary for governor in New York.

headline: ‘Ozark’: What to Remember Before Watching Season 2
abstract: A lot of people wanted to control, arrest or kill the Byrde family in Season 1 — so many you may have lost track. Here’s a refresher.
lead_paragraph: From about halfway through the first episode of “Ozark,” the financial planner Marty Byrde (Jason Bateman) and his family have tiptoed the razor’s edge, surviving certain death through guile, ingenuity and plain old luck. After learning that his partner embezzled $8 million in Mexican cartel money, Marty first slips the noose by successfully pitching the cartel on Lake of the Ozarks as a new haven for their money-laundering needs. From there, the Byrdes are given just a few days to liquidate $8 million in assets, leave Chicago and set up shop in Missouri — where, under threat of execution, they have three months to launder all that cash.

headline: U.S. Open 2018 Results: Wozniacki’s Loss Gives Women’s Tournament a Jolt
abstract: Wozniacki was upset by Lesia Tsurenko after Roger Federer and Novak Djokovic reached the third round. Here’s what happened Thursday at the U.S. Open.
lead_paragraph: • Caroline Wozniacki, the No. 2 seed in the women’s draw, exited the tournament in the second round with a 6-4, 6-2 loss to Lesia Tsurenko.

headline: ‘Activists in Shackles’: Indians Denounce Arrests as Crackdown on Dissent
abstract: Five people have been arrested on charges including having ties to communist rebels, planning assassinations of government officials and inciting a riot.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Vernon Gonsalves, a rights activist, was preparing for his morning bath when the police banged on his front door. Officers rummaged through his home in Mumbai for nearly eight hours, confiscating books, his laptop, a hard drive and pen drives — and then arrested him.

headline: Every Generation Gets the Beach Villain It Deserves
abstract: Aggressive, shameless, obsessive and optimistic, the tech billionaire Vinod Khosla is willing to litigate the California coast for the rest of his life.
lead_paragraph: It sounds simple. For nearly a decade, the venture capitalist Vinod Khosla has been fighting in court to keep the public off a piece of beach that abuts his property on the Pacific coast. What could be more familiar than another case of rich Californian versus the oceangoing citizenry?

headline: From Rooftops to Algae Pools: Orlando’s Vision for Carbon-Free Energy
abstract: On its own and in league with other cities, Orlando is working to curb climate change, starting with the electricity it generates.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — This city has long been a leading tourist destination. Now, it is vying for another distinction: to be a pioneer in weaning itself from carbon-based energy.

headline: How Have Recent Abuse Allegations Affected Your Faith?
abstract: Catholics have again been forced to confront allegations of abuse in the church. We want to know how Catholics in New York City have dealt with these recent revelations.
lead_paragraph: Catholics have again been forced to confront allegations of abuse in the church. We want to know how Catholics in New York City have dealt with these recent revelations.

headline: England Proposes Ban on Selling Energy Drinks to Children
abstract: As part of a campaign to reduce childhood obesity, products like Monster Energy and Red Bull would face age restrictions akin to those on beer.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In England, 16-year-olds can down a pint in a pub, if having a meal in adult company. But under a new government proposal, it would be illegal for them to buy an energy drink like Red Bull at the corner store.

headline: J.A. Happ Turns Into the Yankees’ Unlikely Ace
abstract: Acquired at midseason, Happ has become the Yankees’ most trustworthy starter, and should probably start their biggest game of the year.
lead_paragraph: Long before he became their summer savior, J.A. Happ was a footnote in Yankees history. In Game 6 of the 2009 World Series, as a reliever for the Philadelphia Phillies, Happ allowed a two-run double to Hideki Matsui in the fifth inning. The hit gave Matsui six runs batted in for the night, matching a World Series record. The Yankees clinched the title a few innings later.

headline: Someone Just Made a Racist Remark. What Do You Do?
abstract: We want to learn more about how people who have heard a racist remark address it.
lead_paragraph: You heard a racist comment from a friend, a relative, a co-worker, a stranger: What did you do? Did you speak up? Were you stunned into silence?

headline: Review: This ‘Destination Wedding’ Does No One Any Favors
abstract: Keanu Reeves and Winona Ryder play damaged misanthropes in this grating romantic comedy.
lead_paragraph: All right, then, let’s rip off the Band-Aid: “Destination Wedding” is torture. And not just because this would-be romantic comedy is grating, cheap-looking and a mighty drag: it also turns two seasoned, likable actors into characters you’ll want to throttle long before the credits roll.

headline: Let’s Talk About What Happened at the Wedding
abstract: A reader wants her brother to patch things up with their parents after they were treated badly on his big day.
