lead_paragraph: My brother and I have always been close. When I met his future wife, who is engaging and kind, we got along immediately. But at their wedding, she and her family treated my parents disrespectfully: They weren’t seated at the main table, allowed to make toasts or acknowledged in any way. Her parents also refused to attend a reception hosted by mine. I still get along with my brother and my sister-in-law, but I’m deeply angry at him for allowing our parents to be humiliated. This has created a rift: My parents are bitter, and my brother either doesn’t notice or care. How can I solve this?

headline: How Burning Man Has Evolved Over Three Decades
abstract: Every year thousands make the pilgrimage to the Nevada desert to dance, do drugs and make colossal art.
lead_paragraph: A dust storm overwhelmed the road to Burning Man this week. Clouds of billowing white dust obscured the caravan of cars snaking through the barren Nevada desert, according to recent news reports. Travelers parked in ditches and covered their faces with kerchiefs until the squall passed.

headline: What if Emailing During Your Commute Counted as Work?
abstract: A study of 5,000 commuters who traveled to work in London asked whether their time on the train functioned as part of their working day.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Should commuting hours count as part of the workday?

headline: A Fertility Doctor Used His Sperm on Unwitting Women. Their Children Want Answers.
abstract: Donald Cline, an Indiana doctor, may have fathered more than three dozen children. Decades later, they are finding one another through DNA testing sites.
lead_paragraph: To couples at the end of their ropes who wanted children but could not conceive them for medical reasons, Dr. Donald Cline was a savior of sorts, offering to match the women with sperm from anonymous men resembling their partners.

headline: Dry American Rieslings Never Tasted So Sweet
abstract: Consumers may be thrilled by the rieslings produced in America, but still unpleasantly surprised because of imprecise labeling of sweetness.
lead_paragraph: With riesling, the line between dry and not-dry can be awfully fine.

headline: 3 Morgons to Drink Right Now
abstract: Next in Wine School, Morgons from Beaujolais.
lead_paragraph: Of the many exciting developments in American wine, one of the most interesting for me is the arrival of good gamays, primarily in Oregon and California.

headline: F.B.I. Arrests California Man After Threats to Kill Boston Globe Employees
abstract: According to the F.B.I., the California man made a series of menacing phone calls to The Boston Globe, calling the newspaper an “enemy of the people.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. said on Thursday that it charged a California man who threatened to kill employees of The Boston Globe after calling them the “enemy of the people” in a series of menacing phone calls.

headline: New Trailer: ‘The Front Runner,’ With Hugh Jackman
abstract: Hugh Jackman plays the U.S. senator Gary Hart in period political drama from Jason Reitman.
lead_paragraph: A politician is accused of infidelity, and the activities of the tabloid media become an integral part of the story. The new trailer for the forthcoming drama “The Front Runner” depicts events from 30 years ago, but its themes could be ripped from today’s headlines.

headline: A Building With Kosher Flourishes
abstract: To appeal to observant Jews, an Upper West Side development hired a “kosher consultant” to help create features that would meet their needs.
lead_paragraph: Some luxury buildings have hired feng shui experts to help arrange harmonious spaces. Others recruit fitness experts to craft gym amenities. But a new Upper West Side co-op development called in a “kosher consultant” to advise it on how to ensure that the project would be attuned to the needs of observant Jews.

headline: Fine Cuisine in a (Mostly) Empty Dining Room
abstract: Shik, in Melbourne’s Central Business District, turns out challenging Korean cuisine. But the crowds aren’t coming.
lead_paragraph: Shik, in Melbourne’s Central Business District, turns out challenging Korean cuisine. But the crowds aren’t coming.

headline: Review: Shik in Melbourne, Australia
abstract: The challenging, ingredient-driven cooking is in danger of not finding the audience it deserves.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Peter Jo has made some bold choices in opening his first restaurant.  Shik, in Melbourne’s Central Business District, is not an easy place to find. Neither is it an easy place to define. Mr. Jo’s cooking represents such a significant leap forward for Korean food in Australia that it’s in danger of missing its audience entirely.

headline: Ohio State Trustee Resigns, Saying Urban Meyer Punishment Was Too Soft
abstract: The trustee, Jeffrey Wadsworth, said he was the “lone voice” in pushing for harsher punishment of Mr. Meyer, the university’s football coach.
lead_paragraph: An Ohio State trustee has resigned, saying the punishment of the football coach Urban Meyer, a three-game suspension, should have been “more profound” after a report concluded he had mishandled domestic violence accusations against an assistant coach and had tolerated the assistant’s misbehavior for years.

headline: Postal Service Improperly Divulged Spanberger’s Sensitive National Security File, and Asks for It Back
abstract: The Postal Service blamed “human error” for the release of a Democratic House candidate’s security clearance application, requesting that a Republican super PAC return it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Postal Service said on Thursday that it “deeply regrets our mistake in inappropriately releasing” the official personnel file of Abigail Spanberger, a former C.I.A. operative now running as a Democratic candidate for Congress, and requested that a Republican-aligned super PAC return the documents.

headline: Comedy Clubs Are Ready for Louis C.K.’s Return. Is Everybody Else?
abstract: If he wants to return to doing stand-up in clubs, he probably will be given the go-ahead, according to insiders and producers on the comedy scene.
lead_paragraph: When Louis C.K. stepped onstage unannounced Sunday night at the Comedy Cellar, just nine months after admitting to sexual misconduct, he set off a furious debate over whether his comeback was too soon or tone deaf. But in the club scene, where he forged his reputation as a master stand-up, insiders are acknowledging an awkward truth: He has a sizable base of support among owners and bookers of several renowned performance spaces who would be happy to have him back. In addition, some comedians are defending him as well.

headline: With Tampons and Concrete, Vandals Hit Paris Urinals Seen as Sexist
abstract: The city says the “eco-toilets” help solve a hygiene problem. Critics say they are an emblem of sexism.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — To some, the new street urinals in Paris are a mere eyesore, to say nothing of the men using them. To others, they are no less than an emblem of sexism, still more evidence that men’s needs are put above women’s.

headline: Building Perfection From Scratch
abstract: The chef Kelly Cho has cooked curry for decades and her mother cooked for decades before her: She won’t open her restaurant until the flavor is right.
lead_paragraph: The chef Kelly Cho has cooked curry for decades and her mother cooked for decades before her: She won’t open her restaurant until the flavor is right.

headline: At Suki, Patience Seasons the Curry
abstract: Kelly Cho, the chef, won’t open her six-seat East Village restaurant until she’s convinced that the dish’s flavor is right.
lead_paragraph: Kelly Cho, the chef of Suki, a six-seat Japanese curry shop in the East Village, eats nothing for an hour before she tastes her curry, just clearing her palate with a sip of green tea. She won’t open the restaurant until she’s convinced that the flavor is right, even though it’s a dish that she’s cooked for decades and that her mother cooked for decades before her.

headline: George Bush Is Lying in State. Here’s What That Means.
abstract: The former president joined a short list of American figures to lie in state at the United States Capitol.
lead_paragraph: Updated: Dec. 4

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: High fashion, high society and high altitudes are all in the spotlight this week, thanks to two histories (“The Husband Hunters,” by Anne de Courcy, and “Fly Girls,” by Keith O’Brien) and a posthumous memoir from the legendary Times photographer Bill Cunningham, who died in 2016 at the age of 87. For those who prefer their reading matter a little more grounded, we also offer an account of America’s recent military activities, a novelist’s memoir of life as an extreme latchkey kid, and a couple of takes on winners and losers in the current economy. In fiction, you’ll find a debut story collection from Neel Patel and a political allegory from the great Albanian novelist Ismail Kadare.

headline: Paul Taylor, a Master of Light and Darkness
abstract: His pristine, plotless masterpiece “Aureole” never abandons its sense of serenity. But Mr. Taylor was committed to showing the ugly side of existence too.
lead_paragraph: When Paul Taylor began working on “Aureole,” a pristine and plotless work set to Handel, his dance company was performing in Paris. Their days were free, and that afforded him a rare opportunity to choreograph on a stage instead of in a studio — to take in the bigger picture.

headline: N.C.A.A. Drops Michigan State Inquiry Over Nassar
abstract: After starting its investigation in January, the N.C.A.A. ended it, though trouble for M.S.U. continues.
lead_paragraph: The N.C.A.A. has dropped an investigation of Michigan State’s role in the Lawrence G. Nassar scandal, in which the former university doctor is alleged to have sexually abused hundreds of girls, including prominent gymnasts like Simone Biles as well as Michigan State athletes, saying that the university does not appear to have violated association bylaws.

headline: Are Video Games Olympic Material? Some Boosters Say Yes
abstract: Competitive video gaming is an exhibition sport at the Asian Games and there’s a push to include it in the Olympics. But some are concerned about the violence.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — As fighting raged across the battlefield in a video game called Arena of Valor, the announcers could barely contain their enthusiasm.

headline: Worth the Ride: 5 Surprising Exhibition Spaces in Upstate New York
abstract: A glass house, a drawing made of bent wood and a sculpture about the slave trade that uses piano keys: These are among the intriguing works awaiting north of New York City.
lead_paragraph: If the long holiday weekend tempts you to head out of the city, you won’t have to venture far to find terrific art. Whether taking you deep into the woods, or simply away from the familiar ways and means of painting and sculpting, a range of shows waits for you in upstate New York this Labor Day weekend.

headline: You Don’t Drive a Minivan? You Should. Here’s Why.
abstract: Ready for a satisfying relationship with your car? Skip high-maintenance coupes and sport utility vehicles that demand you open your wallet all the time.
lead_paragraph: We often shun the ones that can help our lives the most. Maybe out of pride. Perhaps ignorance. Many of us are looking for good solid family material, yet reject prospects that are committed and generous.

headline: Time to Change Our Drug Policies
abstract: Decriminalizing drug use raises understandable fears, but these fears are not supported by evidence, readers say.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Is Trump Invincible? Well, He Thinks So
abstract: The president believes that he can act without consequences, and the G.O.P. rationalizes even his most egregious acts, readers say.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Night Owl’s Story
abstract: Life isn’t easy for people who can’t get to sleep at night, a reader writes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Louis C.K. Slithers Back, Whether We’re Ready or Not
abstract: When a celebrity offends, the act refracts across the culture. Now, we are grasping to figure out what punishment could address that public wound.
lead_paragraph: He’s baaa-aaack. Louis C.K., the comic who in November admitted to having masturbated in front of female colleagues, climbed back onstage and tested out new material at the Comedy Cellar on Sunday night. “Comeback” is not the right word for what is being floated here. A comeback implies a hero’s journey — an adventure, a transformation, a triumphant return. This feels more like a malignancy. We try to cut men like him out of public life, but nine months later, we get a call with the bad news.

headline: The Endless Afghan War(s)
abstract: A former Defense Department official sees “a chilling picture.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Need a Quick Read for Labor Day Weekend?
abstract: Here are three short novels to enjoy before summer is over.
lead_paragraph: Summer doesn’t officially end for a few weeks, but for most of us, the transition to fall starts after Labor Day weekend; that’s when summer hours end, companies purge their stores of hot weather collections and many scramble to take their final beach trips. If you’re in the latter category, here are three quick reads for you to bring along.

headline: $40,000 Insect and Lizard Theft Was an Inside Job, Police Say
abstract: Desert hairy scorpions and warty glowspot roaches were among the estimated 7,000 creatures stolen last week from the Philadelphia Insectarium and Butterfly Pavilion.
lead_paragraph: The desert hairy scorpions and domino cockroaches had vanished. The shelves at the Philadelphia Insectarium and Butterfly Pavilion were empty, and there was little movement in the glass cases. Electric-blue staff uniforms hung from knives that had been stabbed into a wall.

headline: Mom and Dad Were Spies: Two New Novels Unravel Complicated Legacies, One Secret Mission at a Time
abstract: In both Lea Carpenter’s “Red, White, Blue” and Dan Fesperman’s “Safe Houses,” a daughter learns more about the death of a parent who worked for the C.I.A.
lead_paragraph: SAFE HOUSES By Dan Fesperman 405 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $26.95.

headline: The Religion of Whiteness Becomes a Suicide Cult
abstract: A wounded and swaggering identity geopolitics puts the world in grave danger.
lead_paragraph: “White men,” an obscure Australian academic named Charles Henry Pearson predicted in his 1893 book “National Life and Character: A Forecast,” would be “elbowed and hustled, and perhaps even thrust aside” by people they had long regarded as their inferiors — “black and yellow races.” China, in particular, would be a major threat. Pearson, prone to terrors of racial extinction while living in a settler colony in an Asian neighborhood, thought it was imperative to defend “the last part of the world, in which the higher races can live and increase freely, for the higher civilization.”

headline: Picture Books Tell Children the Harsh Stories of Migrants and Refugees
abstract: The dark, dangerous realities are not glossed over, but they’re presented with a gentle touch by these storytellers and artists.
lead_paragraph: Whether they are nostalgic reveries of those who came long ago to this nation of immigrants, or the brutal nightmares of worldwide millions fleeing war, violence and persecution today, memories of migration matter. Telling these stories seems more important than ever — even, and some might say especially, to children. A wave of picture books has arrived to help with this difficult task.

headline: Review: Meet the New Jack Ryan, Same as the Old Jack Ryan
abstract: Amazon Prime’s reboot of the Tom Clancy spy hero is still a Boy Scout and he’s still determined to save the world the American way.
lead_paragraph: Played by four men in five movies across 24 years, Jack Ryan has been more of a curriculum vitae than a character. Boy Scout, Marine, history professor, C.I.A. analyst, reluctant action hero — he can be taken out of the drawer any time and handed to the next actor in line.

headline: Supreme Court Stays Out of Case on Gay Rights and Foster Care
abstract: The justices refused to intercede in a dispute between Philadelphia and a Catholic foster care agency that does not work with same-sex couples.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court refused on Thursday to intercede in a dispute between Philadelphia and a Catholic foster care agency that does not work with same-sex couples.

headline: Our Coronary Complacency
abstract: Deaths from heart attacks are dropping, but the number of people whose hearts cannot pump enough blood for a healthy, comfortable existence is on the rise.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — When Ally Babineaux was 22, before she had the first of two heart transplants but after she had nearly died from a ruthless virus that attacked her heart, a woman accosted her in a parking lot. As sick as Ally was on that day in 2010, she was, still, a classic Texas beauty, with long blond hair, flashing blue eyes and just a hint of the trim, muscular body years of ballet had given her. She was fresh from a monthslong hospital stay — her recovery never assured — and was trying to do some quick shopping before the last of her energy drained away.

headline: Why Did a Naval Mine Show Up Off the Coast of Washington?
abstract: John Ismay, a New York Times reporter who served as an explosive ordnance disposal officer, explains how the Navy detonated a loose mine that was found floating in Washington’s Puget Sound.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, local boaters near the Brownsville Marina off the coast of Washington spotted something straight out of a World War II movie: a naval mine with four horns floating by, untethered. Matt Appleton, who manages the Brownsville port, was listening to a maritime radio in his office around 12:30 p.m. when he heard people talking about a mine in the water.

headline: Modi’s Cash Crackdown Failed, Indian Bank Data Shows
abstract: The prime minister’s surprise decision in 2016 to scrap old paper currency did not deter criminals, who found ways to exchange the bills.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Almost two years ago, Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India threw the country into turmoil when he decided, by surprise and practically overnight, to effectively invalidate the old paper currency.

headline: We R-E-S-P-E-C-T Aretha Franklin
abstract: We pay our respects to the late, great Aretha Franklin.
lead_paragraph: This week we pay our respects to the late, great Aretha Franklin. A legendary singer, writer, arranger, pianist, performer and more, Ms. Franklin channeled both the difficult and beautiful aspects of American culture to make the songs that have scored our lives. From her breakout hit “Respect,” to her performance of “Dr. Feelgood” at Fillmore West in San Francisco, to her rendition of “My Country, ’Tis of Thee” at former President Barack Obama’s first inauguration, she left a legacy of virtuosity and swagger that will live on — both online and off.

headline: Who Is Rain Dove?
abstract: The gender-nonconforming model has been in the news after having turned texts sent by Asia Argento over to the police.
lead_paragraph: Rain Dove, a model who is dating Rose McGowan, has been in the news after turning over texts with the Italian actress Asia Argento to the police. The texts may be used as evidence in a potential criminal case against Ms. Argento, who arranged to pay $380,000 to “help” Jimmy Bennett, a former child actor who said she sexually assaulted him when he was 17.

headline: Hacker of Nude Photos of Jennifer Lawrence Gets 8 Months in Prison
abstract: The man, George Garofano, gained access to about 240 iCloud accounts, including ones belonging to celebrities like Ms. Lawrence and Kate Upton.
lead_paragraph: A Connecticut man was sentenced on Wednesday to eight months in prison for his part in a hacking scandal in which nude photographs of the actress Jennifer Lawrence and other celebrities were made public on the internet, according to the man’s lawyer.

headline: Trump Seeks to Block Pay Raises for Federal Workers
abstract: The president, who has moved to curb government unions, said the pay increase wasn’t affordable. But Congress can still pass legislation granting the raises.
lead_paragraph: After being rebuffed in an attempt to peel back the union protections of federal workers, President Trump took aim elsewhere on Thursday: at their paychecks.

headline: How Abortion Rights Will Die a Death by 1,000 Cuts
abstract: Brett Kavanaugh's confirmation to the Supreme Court would mean the demise of not just abortion rights but also a century of progressive reforms.
lead_paragraph: Judge Brett Kavanaugh’s voluminous record, his opinion of the Supreme Court’s landmark abortion ruling, Roe v. Wade, and his views on legal precedent have deservedly been scrutinized in the lead-up to his confirmation hearings next week. But the Supreme Court’s 1992 decision in Planned Parenthood v. Casey, more than Roe, holds the key to understanding the stakes of Judge Kavanaugh’s potential confirmation.

headline: This Surrealist Is Having a Moment, 66 Years After Her Last New York Show
abstract: Karma gallery celebrates the strange, lonely paintings of the Chicago artist Gertrude Abercrombie with an exhibition and a comprehensive catalog.
lead_paragraph: With nearly 70 paintings and a four-and-a-half-pound book, the exhibition “Gertrude Abercrombie” reintroduces New York to the lonely, poignant art of an overlooked American Surrealist painter from the Midwest. Abercrombie (1909-77) — whose work has not had a solo show here since 1952 — was also a jazz devotee, Chicago bohemian and saloniste, and her return represents a herculean effort. Karma, the gallery (and publisher) where the show is on view, often outdoes itself, and has done so again, this time with assistance from the writer and independent curator Dan Nadel.

headline: In ‘The Piranhas,’ the Chronicler of Italy’s Mobsters Tries His Hand at Fiction. For a Change?
abstract: In hiding for 12 years, Roberto Saviano is starting to realize that he’s not so different from the people he writes about. He’s not afraid to die, he wants to live, but he wants vengeance.
lead_paragraph: NAPLES — Roberto Saviano is only 38, but for nearly a dozen years it has been like this: He is guarded around the clock, moving from house to house and sleeping in the police station when he returns to Naples, because it’s the only safe place for him to stay overnight in his home city.

headline: End of Summer Escape, in Poetry and Pictures
abstract: Female photographers were given poems written by women, to be inspired by and to interpret. Here’s what they wrought.
lead_paragraph: Gender Letter helps you keep up with the world, and the women shaping it. Tell me what you think at dearmaya@nytimes.com.

headline: John McCain, China, Narendra Modi: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Arizona Supreme Court Blocks a Ballot Measure, and Schools Miss Out on $690 Million
abstract: The proposal would have raised money for education by raising taxes on the wealthy.
lead_paragraph: In a major blow to the national protest movement against classroom budget cuts and stagnant teachers’ salaries, the Arizona Supreme Court blocked a ballot initiative Wednesday that would have increased taxes on the wealthy to help raise money for schools.

headline: Soulpepper Looks to Britain for New Executive Director
abstract: After two leaders resigned in the wake of sexual misconduct allegations, the prominent Canadian theater company will put Emma Stenning in charge
lead_paragraph: A prominent Canadian theater company that lost its top two leaders in a sexual harassment scandal announced on Thursday that it had hired a British theater executive to help it move forward.

headline: Man Who Wrongfully Spent 17 Years in Prison in ‘Doppelgänger Case’ Seeks $1.1 Million
abstract: Richard A. Jones sought release after another prisoner who closely resembled him threw his conviction for aggravated robbery into doubt.
lead_paragraph: Nearly two decades ago, Richard A. Jones was convicted of aggravated robbery after being picked out of a lineup by witnesses who said he stole a cellphone in a Walmart parking lot in Kansas.

headline: Government Can Stop Paying to House Puerto Rico Hurricane Victims, Judge Rules
abstract: After months of temporary reprieves, the judge says temporary housing vouchers for victims of Hurricane Maria staying in hotels can be ended on Sept. 13.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Almost a year after Hurricane Maria devastated Puerto Rico, more than 1,000 families who lost their homes remain in hotel rooms paid for by the government. Thursday, a judge’s ruling gave them two more weeks before that assistance runs out, though he conceded they “may well be rendered homeless.”

headline: Gérard Depardieu Under Investigation After Rape Accusation
abstract: Mr. Depardieu, a towering figure in French cinema who is also a Hollywood star, denied the charges through his lawyer.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Prosecutors here are investigating rape allegations against the French film star Gérard Depardieu, the Paris authorities said on Thursday.

headline: Colin Kaepernick’s Collusion Case Against the N.F.L. Will Advance
abstract: An arbitrator determined that the quarterback’s lawyers had unearthed sufficient evidence of collusion by N.F.L. owners to keep the free-agent quarterback off the field.
lead_paragraph: In a major blow to the N.F.L., Colin Kaepernick achieved a preliminary but important win in his case accusing the league of colluding to keep him off the field because of the player protests during the national anthem that he instigated.

headline: Little Decline in Number of Children in Public Housing With High Lead Levels, Report Says
abstract: The number of children in public housing that tested positive for elevated lead levels remained steady over the last few years, even as it declined across the city.
lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, New York City made steady progress in reducing the number of children living in public housing who have tested positive for lead, but that trend ended about the same time that the city’s housing authority stopped inspecting its apartments for lead-paint hazards.

headline: 8 Plays and Musicals to Go to in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Previews, openings and some last-chance picks.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages and a few last-chance picks of shows that are about to close. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.

headline: 2 Classical Music Concerts to See in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to the city’s best classical music and opera happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to the city’s best classical music and opera happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

headline: 7 Things to Do With Your Kids in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for children and teenagers happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for children and teenagers happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

headline: 30 Art Exhibitions to View in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to new art shows and some that will be closing soon.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to new art shows and some that will be closing soon.

headline: 3 Dance Performances to See in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to dance performances happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to dance performances happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

headline: 6 Comedy Shows to Catch in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

headline: 4 Film Series to Catch in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to film series and special screenings.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to film series and special screenings happening this weekend and in the week ahead. All our movie reviews are at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.

headline: 14 Pop, Rock and Jazz Concerts to Check Out in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

headline: Cynthia Nixon Relives a One-Night Debate vs. Andrew Cuomo
abstract: Ms. Nixon moved busily between television interviews the morning after her sole debate with Mr. Cuomo. The governor chose not to rehash it.
lead_paragraph: The first and only debate between Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Cynthia Nixon had barely ended, when both campaigns declared a resounding victory. “Commanding performance,” the governor’s team declared. “The reviews are in: Cynthia won,” Ms. Nixon’s handlers said.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix Canada in September
abstract: Every month, Netflix Canada adds a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are the titles we think are most interesting for September.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Watching, The New York Times’s TV and movie recommendation site.

headline: Picking 13 New Voices From 20,000 Applicants
abstract: We posted a job opening for new contributors to The Edit, our newsletter for college students and recent grads. It took months to narrow down the field.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.

headline: Summer Movie Scorecard: Some Crazy Rich Hits and Shocking Misses
abstract: The return of the rom-com and the ho-hum performance of blockbuster franchises hold lessons for Hollywood. Will the industry listen?
lead_paragraph: The summer movie season started on an appropriately unsettling note as Marvel killed off half its superheroes, and though the apocalypse of “Avengers: Infinity War” will no doubt be reversed in the next installment, the lesson was clear: The summer-movie stakes are higher than ever, and no one — neither superhero nor major studio — is safe. Disney, the mammoth entity that owns Marvel as well as other moneymakers like Pixar and Lucasfilm, sealed a deal this summer to acquire most of 21st Century Fox, and you can expect jobs and projects from that venerable studio to disappear as though Josh Brolin’s “Infinity War” villain Thanos had snapped his fingers once more.

headline: Russ Heath, Whose Comics Caught Lichtenstein’s Eye, Dies at 91
abstract: In a long and prolific career, Mr. Heath drew countless comic books. He was known for his viscerally illustrated combat stories.
lead_paragraph: Russ Heath, a prolific comic book artist who was known for viscerally illustrated combat stories — and for either inspiring or being outright copied by the Pop artist Roy Lichtenstein, depending on whom you ask — died on Aug. 23 in Long Beach, Calif. He was 91.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Got some time for the tube this Labor Day weekend? Our critic Margaret Lyons has three great ideas for what to watch.
lead_paragraph: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every Friday for new suggestions on what to watch.

headline: Algae May Be Small — But Its Impact Could Be Big
abstract: Algae are tiny, but potentially mighty. They grow in saltwater and can produce bio-oil that one day could fuel our transportation needs. See how ExxonMobil is researching this renewable fuel.
lead_paragraph: Algae are tiny, but potentially mighty. They grow in saltwater and can produce bio-oil that one day could fuel our transportation needs. See how ExxonMobil is researching this renewable fuel.

headline: Judge Rules Against Alex Jones and Infowars in Sandy Hook Lawsuit
abstract: Mr. Jones sought to have the defamation case dismissed on free speech grounds.
lead_paragraph: A Texas judge denied the motion by the conspiracy theorist Alex Jones to dismiss a defamation lawsuit brought against him and his Infowars operation by the parents of a Sandy Hook shooting victim, in a ruling released on Thursday.

headline: The Giants Try to Pass Chemistry
abstract: After a 3-13 season that included a poisonous locker room, the Giants are trying to bond. Anyone want to join the team photography club?
lead_paragraph: On a rare day off during training camp recently, three Giants linebackers made their way to Lower Manhattan. They wanted to take advantage of the downtime. They each brought a camera.

headline: From Farm Waste to Fuel Tank
abstract: Scientists at ExxonMobil are working to transform plant waste into biofuel. What they create could one day be used to power jets, trucks and trains, all while producing fewer emissions.
lead_paragraph: Scientists at ExxonMobil are working to transform plant waste into biofuel. What they create could one day be used to power jets, trucks and trains, all while producing fewer emissions.

headline: John McCain, Colin Kaepernick, U.S. Open: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Ruth Finley, Who Put Fashion Shows on a Schedule, Dies at 98
abstract: Ms. Finley plotted out a checkerboard of cat-walking for generations of designers jockeying for time slots in the New York show season.
lead_paragraph: Ruth Finley, who brought order to the fashion world for nearly 70 years by publishing a biweekly calendar that mapped out the schedules of designers’ shows in New York City and helped them avoid conflicts with rivals, died on Saturday in Manhattan. She was 98.

headline: The Y.A. Surge at Netflix Is On, With Two Good Comedies
abstract: “To All the Boys I’ve Loved Before” and “Sierra Burgess Is a Loser” keep the teenage rom-com alive. And they trumpet John Hughes’s influence.
lead_paragraph: A specter is haunting Netflix: the specter of John Hughes.

headline: The Bugs Are Coming, and They’ll Want More of Our Food
abstract: Climate change is expected to make insect pests hungrier, which could encourage farmers to use more pesticides.
lead_paragraph: Ever since humans learned to wrest food from soil, creatures like the corn earworm, the grain weevil and the bean fly have dined on our agricultural bounty. Worldwide, insect pests consume up to 20 percent of the plants that humans grow for food, and that amount will increase as global warming makes bugs hungrier, according to a study published Thursday in the journal Science.

headline: The Sculptor Turning Treasure Hunts Into Art
abstract: As he prepares for a new solo exhibition, the Mexican-American artist Eduardo Sarabia recounts how a multigenerational family quest has shaped his work and identity.
lead_paragraph: Many artists claim that their work is multidisciplinary. But Eduardo Sarabia’s varied practice includes painting, sculpture, mezcal making and even treasure hunting. “There’s a lot of fantasy and imagination involved in my work,” he says, seated in his studio on the first floor of a 1950s industrial building in the Zapopan district of Guadalajara, Mexico. He shows me the handcrafted, blue-and-white Talavera-style ceramic tiles he’s produced for a coming solo exhibition in Antwerp, Belgium. In place of the typical Talavera motifs of flora and fauna, one piece is adorned with crossed swords and floating pills, the other reads “Mas Oro” (“More Gold”). “Everything comes from a real place,” he says. “That’s why I love what I do. I get to share these stories — my stories.”

headline: Venus and Serena, Back for Yet Another Encore
abstract: Serena Williams called it “remarkable” that she was facing her sister Venus for the 30th time. Venus would rather play her sister than talk about it.
lead_paragraph: It remains both a blessing and a curse that Venus and Serena Williams grew up in the same household with the same Technicolor tennis dreams.

headline: In His 5th Year as Mayor, de Blasio Finally Acts on Horse-Carriage Pledge
abstract: City Hall plans to bar horse carriages from waiting for passengers on Central Park South. They will be moved inside Central Park.
lead_paragraph: On his 1,703rd day in office, Mayor Bill de Blasio directed his administration to move the Central Park location where horse carriages wait for passengers to five boarding areas within the park.

headline: For Whom the Economy Grows
abstract: G.D.P. is only part of the story, and we need to know the rest.
lead_paragraph: “What’s in a name?” asked Shakespeare. But hey, I’m an economist, so let me ask a somewhat different question: What’s in a number?

headline: Justice in Myanmar?
abstract: A recent United Nations report condemned crimes against humanity by Myanmar’s military.
lead_paragraph: A recent United Nations report condemned crimes against humanity by Myanmar’s military.

headline: San Francisco Grants 2 Scooter Permits (but Not to the Early Disrupters)
abstract: The city’s regulators have a message for freewheeling scooter start-ups: Those that “ask forgiveness, not permission,” will not be forgiven.
lead_paragraph: Regulators in San Francisco have a message for freewheeling scooter start-ups: Those that “ask forgiveness, not permission,” will not be forgiven.

headline: Canadian Court Halts Expansion of Trans Mountain Oil Pipeline
abstract: The ruling, a blow to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s plans to increase the flow of oil from Alberta to the Pacific Coast, said the government failed to adequately consult with Indigenous people along the route.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — A Canadian court on Thursday froze plans to expand an oil pipeline that the government is about to purchase, ruling that the government’s National Energy Board had not adequately consulted with Indigenous people along the pipeline’s route or assessed the project’s potential effects on the waters off British Columbia.

headline: The Continuing Tragedy of the Separated Children
abstract: Just because mass separations have been halted doesn’t mean that the crisis is over.
lead_paragraph: “I didn’t like the sight or the feeling of families being separated,” President Trump said on June 20, when he signed an executive order halting his administration’s depraved practice of separating migrant children from parents seeking asylum at the nation’s southern border. “This will solve that problem.”

headline: Trump Whines That Google Isn’t a Safe Space
abstract: The right is pressuring tech to be more MAGA-friendly.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, in the course of his morning rage-tweeting, Donald Trump denounced Google for having news results “RIGGED” against him, “so that almost all stories & news is BAD.” It was part of an escalating right-wing assault on various technology platforms, including Twitter, Facebook and YouTube, which conservatives are accusing, in timeworn fashion, of liberal bias.

headline: Here’s the Conversation We Really Need to Have About Bias at Google
abstract: President Trump’s charges that Google shows anti-conservative search bias is wrong. But Google may well be biased against minorities and others who lack real-world power.
lead_paragraph: Let’s get this out of the way first: There is no basis for the charge that President Trump leveled against Google this week — that the search engine, for political reasons, favored anti-Trump news outlets in its results. None.

headline: Nick Kyrgios Was Struggling. The Chair Umpire Stepped Down and Stepped In.
abstract: After a visit and some encouraging words from Mohamed Lahyani, Kyrgios rallied to defeat Pierre-Hugues Herbert in the second round of the U.S. Open.
lead_paragraph: Nick Kyrgios did not seem to be trying very hard Thursday afternoon in his second-round match at the United States Open. He was barely lunging for serves from his opponent, Pierre-Hugues Herbert. He moped around the court between games with a towel clenched between his teeth. He looked as if he would have preferred being anywhere other than Court 17.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Tears, Laughter and Allusions to a Man Who Wasn’t Invited
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, August 31, 2018.
lead_paragraph: “He’d part company with you if you lacked the basic values of decency, respect, knowing that this project is bigger than yourself.”

headline: ‘An Attack on Students’ Rights’: Reactions to Betsy DeVos’s New Rules on Sexual Assault
abstract: Students, alumni and advocates shared their thoughts on the rules, which give more rights to students accused of rape, assault or harassment.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — College students across the country are heading back to school as the debate intensifies over how to deal with accusations of sexual harassment and assault in and around campus. After repeatedly criticizing Obama-era regulations, Education Secretary Betsy DeVos is preparing an overhaul of federal policies dealing with sexual misconduct in colleges.

headline: Corrections: August 31, 2018
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Friday, August 31, 2018.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Ronan Farrow’s Ex-Producer Says NBC Impeded Weinstein Reporting
abstract: Rich McHugh said an order to pull the plug on an investigation of Harvey Weinstein had come from “the very highest levels of NBC.”
lead_paragraph: In October, when Ronan Farrow published his first article in The New Yorker on the alleged transgressions of Harvey Weinstein, people in the media and entertainment industries wondered how NBC had missed the story. After all, Mr. Farrow had spent months gathering material on the mogul when he was with NBC News.

headline: 2 Airline Sexual Assault Cases Draw Charges and a Call for Help
abstract: Prosecutors said they needed “the flying public’s help” to root out sexual assaults and misconduct on airplanes, a problem that is gaining public notice.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Federal prosecutors here announced on Thursday that they had charged two men with sexual assault aboard airplanes, violations that have become an increasingly recognized problem for passengers, the airline industry and flight crews, who are often the first to receive reports of assaults in the air.

headline: Rumba, the Dance of Love
abstract: Ernesto Palma and Nikolai Shpakov show how competitive ballroom dance is enhanced, not diminished, by same-sex partnering.
lead_paragraph: #SpeakingInDance is a weekly visual exploration of dance on Instagram. Watch the video from our most recent post below, and follow us at @nytimes.

headline: Works With Kids
abstract: Peter Wentz orders up an interesting themeless puzzle.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — You had me at STAY AT HOME DAD, Peter Wentz. That in itself is a marquee answer — and a New York Times Crossword debut — but I also applaud you for debuting the author TA-NEHISI COATES, who wrote the National Book Award-winning “Between the World and Me.”

headline: President Trump Skirts Mention of John McCain at Rally and on Twitter
abstract: Conspicuously absent from the president’s active media day was any acknowledgment that a nation was remembering Senator John McCain.
lead_paragraph: EVANSVILLE, Ind. — As Senator John McCain’s coffin was being loaded onto a military plane bound for Washington on Thursday afternoon, cameras from major American TV networks beamed the coverage around the world, allowing a rapt public to witness the next leg of his four-day funeral.

headline: How Germany’s Far Right Stole a Rallying Cry for Democracy
abstract: Violent demonstrations against refugees have featured a chant that translates to English as “we are the people.”
lead_paragraph: Violent demonstrations against refugees have featured a chant that translates to English as “we are the people.”

headline: Chemnitz Protests Show New Strength of Germany’s Far Right
abstract: A rampage in the eastern city now stands as a high-water mark in the outpouring of anti-immigrant hatred that has swelled in Germany.
lead_paragraph: CHEMNITZ, Germany — Waving German flags, with some flashing Nazi salutes, the angry mob made its way through the streets, chasing after dark-skinned bystanders as police officers, vastly outnumbered, were too afraid to intervene.

headline: How Much Hotter Is Your Hometown Than When You Were Born?
abstract: See how days at or above 90 degrees Fahrenheit have changed in your lifetime and how much hotter it could get.
lead_paragraph: See how days at or above 90 degrees Fahrenheit have changed in your lifetime and how much hotter it could get.

headline: Yankees, With Strongest Home Run Muscles, Are Outdone by a Weakling
abstract: The Tigers, last in the majors in homers, hit five, including two by Victor Martinez, to offset Giancarlo Stanton’s 300th career blast.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees lead the major leagues in home runs. With six players having at least 20 homers, and 218 over all, no other team is even close. The runners-up, the Los Angeles Dodgers, were more than 30 home runs behind.

headline: Caroline Wozniacki Becomes Latest Giant to Fall at Armstrong
abstract: With the No. 2 seed joining No. 1 Simona Halep as early losers at the U.S. Open’s newest stadium, Sloane Stephens is the top remaining seed on the women’s side.
lead_paragraph: Like the old No. 2 Court at Wimbledon, the new Louis Armstrong Stadium is proving to be the end point for many Grand Slam champions in its first year at the U.S. Open.

headline: Germany, Vanilla Beans, Riz Ahmed: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Honey, I Swept the Floor!
abstract: Why do so many husbands feel the need to boast about completing simple household chores? With mine, it’s all about branding.
lead_paragraph: Closing the Whirlpool’s door with an exaggerated swagger, Christopher rolled down his oxford sleeves and said, “Just unloaded the dishwasher!”

headline: Yankees Acquire Andrew McCutchen From Giants
abstract: The team traded two prospects to the Giants, the middle infielder Abiatal Avelino and the right-handed pitcher Juan De Paula.
lead_paragraph: Needing an outfielder to strengthen a lineup depleted by injuries, the Yankees announced on Friday that they had acquired right fielder Andrew McCutchen in a deal with the San Francisco Giants.

headline: U.S. to End Funding to U.N. Agency That Helps Palestinian Refugees
abstract: President Trump’s son-in-law Jared Kushner and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo made the decision to cut all aid for Palestinian refugees at a meeting in early August.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States government has decided to stop all funding it gives to a United Nations agency that provides assistance to millions of Palestinian refugees, ending a decades-long policy of supporting it, according to a former senior United States aid official.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Ozark’ and ‘Jack Ryan’
abstract: Stream “Tom Clancy’s Jack Ryan” on Amazon and a new season of “Ozark” on Netflix.
lead_paragraph: Stream “Tom Clancy’s Jack Ryan” on Amazon and a new season of “Ozark” on Netflix.

headline: Why You Should Tell Your Co-Workers How Much Money You Make
abstract: It’s unlawful for private sector employers to prohibit employees from discussing wages and compensation. Take advantage of that protection.
lead_paragraph: It’s unlawful for private sector employers to prohibit employees from discussing wages and compensation. Take advantage of that protection.

headline: Serena vs. Venus: 15 Chapters of Grand Slam Drama for the Williams Sisters
abstract: Their third-round U.S. Open match on Friday will be the Williams sisters’ 16th meeting at a Grand Slam event. Serena has won 10 of those matches.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, Venus and Serena Williams will meet for the 30th time in their professional tennis careers. Serena has won 17 of those matches, but Venus won the last one, in March in the third round of the BNP Paribas Open in Indian Wells, Calif., Serena’s first tournament after her maternity leave.

headline: Hacking a Prince, an Emir and a Journalist to Impress a Client
abstract: The NSO Group, a spyware maker, targeted the phones of powerful figures to show off its product, emails show. It’s now accused of illegal spying in lawsuits.
lead_paragraph: The rulers of the United Arab Emirates had been using Israeli spyware for more than a year, secretly turning the smartphones of dissidents at home or rivals abroad into surveillance devices.

headline: Australia’s Catholic Leaders Reject Call to Report Sex Abuse Heard in Confessions
abstract: Catholic officials in Australia said the proposal would violate a sacred rite, infringe on religious freedom and do little to protect children from predatory priests.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Catholic leaders in Australia on Friday rejected a government push to force priests to report accusations of child sexual abuse heard during confession, saying it would violate a sacred rite, infringe on religious freedom and ultimately do little to protect children.

headline: China’s State Media: Trump Tweets Come From an ‘Alternative Universe’
abstract: In recent days, China’s English-language state media outlets have grown more strident in their mockery of the president and his policies.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — To the long list of reproachful replies to President Trump’s social media commentary, add an editorial from a Chinese state media outlet, which called his recent tweets on China “messages from some alternative universe.”

headline: Coca-Cola Bets on Coffee With $5.1 Billion Deal for Costa
abstract: Buying the British coffee chain, which has over 3,800 stores worldwide, is meant to give Coke a way to branch out from sugary sodas.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As consumers shy away more and more from sugary soft drinks, Coca-Cola is betting on a new way to cater to them: Serve them coffee.

headline: Tenderly Photographing the End of Her Father’s Life
abstract: When Safi Alia Shabaik found out her father had Parkinson’s disease, she moved back home to help care for him, documenting the last months of his life as he developed dementia.
lead_paragraph: With a Ph.D. from Berkeley, and a long career as an engineering professor at U.C.L.A., Aly H. Shabaik might be called a genius.

headline: He Knows His Way Around a Half-Butt (That’s Snooker Talk)
abstract: The playwright Richard Bean brings world-class professional snooker onstage in “The Nap,” produced by the Manhattan Theater Club.
lead_paragraph: SHEFFIELD, England — “Surely this isn’t the first time you’ve seen topiary snooker players?” asked the playwright Richard Bean with mock incredulity. Two figures, artfully shaped out of robust greenery, leaned, as if poised to pot a ball, on either side of the entrance to the Crucible Theater here.

headline: Too Many Chinese Children Need Glasses. Beijing Blames Video Games.
abstract: China’s Tencent and other video game companies saw their shares tumble as the government puts additional pressure on the industry.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — It started this week with a call to action from China’s leader, Xi Jinping. Too many of the country’s children need glasses, he said, and the government was going to do something about it.

headline: News Quiz: Test Your Knowledge of the Week’s Headlines
abstract: Did you stay up to date this week?
lead_paragraph: Did you stay up to date this week?

headline: Eminem Addresses Trump Rap in Surprise Album ‘Kamikaze’
abstract: The rapper uses the opening track to address the aftermath of his freestyle rap last year aimed at President Trump and his supporters.
lead_paragraph: With no advance fanfare, Eminem released a surprise album late Thursday, using the opening track to address the aftermath of last year’s freestyle rap aimed at President Trump and his supporters.

headline: She Gambled on Her Claim to Link Russians and Trump. She Is Losing.
abstract: Facing trial in Thailand, the Belarusian escort Anastasia Vashukevich has begun backtracking on her claim to have evidence of election interference.
lead_paragraph: PATTAYA, Thailand — Caught in a Thai police raid on her group’s seduction seminar, a Belarusian escort grabbed the world’s attention in February when she claimed to have audio recordings that might show a link between Russian officials and the election of President Trump, betting that it could turn into a get out of jail free card.

headline: At These New European Hotels, a Night’s Stay Supports Worthy Causes
abstract: A number of new hotels and other destinations are eager to help socially minded travelers put their money where their principles are. Here are a few of them.
lead_paragraph: Several European properties have taken a fresh approach to socially responsible travel by integrating pressing issues — from immigration and old age to domestic violence — into their daily operations. Travelers can contribute to worthy causes while getting a good night’s sleep.

headline: When Is a Baby Fully Protected by Vaccines?
abstract: Vaccines don’t confer 100 percent immunity, but when all children are immunized, it creates what is called herd immunity, which makes everyone safer, especially babies.
lead_paragraph: Q. I’m pro-vaccine and having a baby in a few months. My sister refused to vaccinate her two children, ages 1 and 5. How long will I need to keep them away from my baby in order to protect him or her from preventable diseases?

headline: Why This Doctor Is Choosing to Stay in Syria
abstract: President Bashar al-Assad’s forces have targeted medical workers and attacked hospitals throughout the country’s civil war. But Dr. Mohammed al-Bardan is defying the regime.
lead_paragraph: To his family and the lives of the patients he’s saved, Dr. Mohammed al-Bardan is a hero. To the government of President Bashar al-Assad, he’s an enemy of Syria.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Silence After the Hit-and-Run
abstract: Five years ago, several shocking fatalities pushed the police department to expand its crash investigation squad. Apart from renaming the unit, little has changed.
lead_paragraph: The sun had just risen when Bernadette Karna, dressed in her American Airlines uniform, set out on her commute: a taxi from her Upper East Side apartment in Manhattan to 41st Street and Lexington Avenue, then a shuttle to John F. Kennedy International Airport.

headline: A Mother’s Fragmented Identity
abstract: My partial selves — writer, runner, mother — have become like islands I travel between and my life is the ocean around them, unknowable.
lead_paragraph: Every once in a while, I take a trip and leave my 3-year-old daughter behind. I drop her off at my parents’ farm in southeastern Ohio, where I load the fridge with blueberries, kiss her, and say goodbye. On the return drive to Pittsburgh, I feel bittersweet and fragile. My life has a missing piece.

headline: Home Alone, With a Spy Cam
abstract: Smart devices make it possible for parents to keep close tabs on their latchkey children, but is it really a good idea?
lead_paragraph: My son is off the leash. When he starts middle school next week, he will have the house to himself after school on the days when I’m not working from home.

headline: It’s Cute, but This Cat Probably Wasn’t Feeding Its Toy Kittens
abstract: Feline behaviorists offered explanations for a viral tweet that captured a cat’s tendency to bring stuffed toys to its food bowl.
lead_paragraph: In the United States, there are more than 74 million pet cats. We love these spastic weirdos. So when Maureen Johnson, an author of best-selling young adult novels, tweeted about her parents’ cat’s strange behavior during a visit home early this week — it went viral.

headline: How Modern Medicine Has Changed the Supreme Court
abstract: Longer lives, longer terms and tougher nomination fights, as well as a premium on youth.
lead_paragraph: Two related health trends mean that each Supreme Court nomination now has the potential to shape the nation’s highest court for far longer than in the past.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘Unbelievable,’ ‘Improvement’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.

headline: He’s a Doctor. To Syria’s Regime, He’s an Enemy.
abstract: Since the beginning of Syria’s civil war, the Assad government has targeted and killed hundreds of medical workers. Many have fled. This is the story of one doctor, Mohammed al-Bardan, who chose to stay.
lead_paragraph: Since the beginning of Syria’s civil war, the Assad government has targeted and killed hundreds of medical workers. Many have fled. This is the story of one doctor, Mohammed al-Bardan, who chose to stay.

headline: College Football’s Biggest Rivalries
abstract: The college football rivalry — that strange mix of tradition, history, and competition — continues to evolve, but these are some of the big ones.
lead_paragraph: The Michigan-Notre Dame rivalry is plenty eminent. But at 42 games, it is nowhere near college football’s most contested; in recent years, it has not been among the most nationally decisive, either. Here are other notable competitions. (Numbers from Sports Reference.)

headline: He Wrote a Memoir About Infiltrating the Ku Klux Klan. Then Spike Lee Turned It Into a Film.
abstract: Ron Stallworth joined the Klan as a black detective working undercover in 1978. Now his memoir, “Black Klansman,” is a best seller — and an acclaimed film.
lead_paragraph: In 1978, Ron Stallworth was a 25-year-old officer on the Colorado Springs police force — the first black detective in the city’s history — when he rang David Duke, then the grand wizard of the Ku Klux Klan. That call, part of a successful, if highly improbable, seven-month undercover operation Stallworth conducted into the Klan’s local chapter, has been memorialized on film by John David Washington, who plays Stallworth in this summer’s much lauded adaptation by Spike Lee of Stallworth’s memoir, “Black Klansman” (retitled for the movie as “BlacKkKlansman”). But Stallworth’s own performance — as a black-hating white guy eager to defend the Aryan race — required some quick-witted improvisation of his own. “Undercover work is nothing more than acting,” Stallworth says. “The only difference is you don’t have a Spike Lee to say ‘Cut! Move on to the next scene.’ And there’s no danger that the person you’re talking to is going to pull a gun on you and threaten to kill you. That happened to me on more than one occasion.”

headline: How to Protect Your Cellphone (and Your Data) When You Travel
abstract: Our smartphones are indispensable, especially when we’re away from home. Here’s how to protect your device, and all of the information stored on it.
lead_paragraph: Many travelers consider their cellphones essential when they’re on the road and rely on it for taking pictures and texting to using it to find their way around.

headline: Why the Artist Mari Andrew Loves Solo Travel
abstract: Her popular Instagram drawings are personal observations on a wide variety of subjects. Her trips provide inspiration.
lead_paragraph: After going through what she called the “triple-axel tragedy” of losing her father, surviving a painful breakup and facing health issues three years ago, Mari Andrew began drawing.

headline: ‘In the Garden of the Fugitives’: A Literary Tale of Love and Obsession
abstract: In Ceridwen Dovey’s new novel, a wealthy benefactor and his much younger protégée resume contact after a 17-year break.
lead_paragraph: IN THE GARDEN OF THE FUGITIVES By Ceridwen Dovey 305 pp. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $27.

headline: Poetry’s Hanging Judge Tries On a Detective Hat
abstract: In “Dickinson’s Nerves, Frost’s Woods,” the usually scathing critic William Logan unearths the historical context behind some beloved poems.
lead_paragraph: DICKINSON’S NERVES, FROST’S WOODS Poetry in the Shadow of the Past By William Logan 396 pp. Columbia University Press. $35.

headline: ‘The Garden Party’ Is a Tale of Mismatched Families, a Wedding and Lots of Wine
abstract: When the Barlows — eccentric academics — and the lawyerly Cohens meet at their children’s rehearsal dinner in Grace Dane Mazur’s novel, polite chatter soon skids off the rails.
lead_paragraph: THE GARDEN PARTY By Grace Dane Mazur 212 pp. Random House. $27.

headline: Trump Approach on Nafta Relieves Automakers’ Worst Fears
abstract: Car and parts makers should be able to adapt to changes negotiated with Mexico without undue expense or disruption, analysts say.
lead_paragraph: As the Trump administration sought trade concessions from Mexico in recent weeks, automakers and their suppliers feared that manufacturing costs could increase by billions of dollars. Now, they are breathing a sigh of relief.

headline: Are Ben Marcus’s Dark and Disturbing New Stories the Literary Answer to ‘Black Mirror’?
abstract: “Notes From the Fog” features the author’s trademark humor and a vision of society both devastatingly bleak and seemingly plausible.
lead_paragraph: NOTES FROM THE FOG By Ben Marcus 266 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $26.95.

headline: Lot-Line Window? Keep Your Fingers Crossed
abstract: If someone decides to build on an empty lot or low-rise building next door, you’ll have to brick up that window and say goodbye to your view.
lead_paragraph: When Jason Biggs and Jenny Mollen bought their TriBeCa loft in 2013, they weren’t concerned that the living room windows were on the side of the building that bordered the adjoining property. In fact, they were perfectly positioned to offer views of the Hudson River over the parking lot next door.

headline: Michigan and Notre Dame Bolster a Sport Built on Rivalries
abstract: College football is all about its rivalries, those traditional matchups that endure and now more than ever determine championships.
lead_paragraph: Notre Dame should never have become Notre Dame. The small Catholic university in Indiana roamed the country playing an eclectic group of opponents and recruiting from the archipelago of Catholic high schools dotting the nation. But these idiosyncratic features, along with several national titles, actually made the Fighting Irish, in the postwar years, the most popular (and polarizing) college football team in America.

headline: How Burak Cakmak, Dean of Fashion at Parsons, Spends His Sundays
abstract: The Turkish-born school administrator starts his day off with espresso-induced exercise, followed by a ritual feast and a visit to a museum.
lead_paragraph: As the dean of fashion for Parsons School of Design, Burak Cakmak both oversees the school’s student body and various partnerships with designers and organizations around the world. Mr. Cakmak recently traveled to Kenya and Ethiopia to facilitate a collaboration between the United Nations and Parsons students commissioned to design absorbant underwear for women of menstruation age in refugee camps. Born and raised in Ankara, Turkey, Mr. Cakmak, 43, lives alone in the Financial District.

headline: A Parade of Francophiles, With Peter Mayle in the Lead
abstract: Four new books — from Peter Mayle, Eric Hazan, Mark Greenside and the team of Stéphane Hénaut and Jeni Mitchell — explore the riches of Gallic culture.
lead_paragraph: A WALK THROUGH PARIS By Eric Hazan Translated by David Fernbach 192 pp. Verso. $22.95.

headline: Beto O’Rourke Dreams of One Texas. Ted Cruz Sees Another Clearly.
abstract: For years, a blue Texas has seemed both impossible and inevitable. Have the political winds there finally shifted enough for an unapologetic liberal to win a Senate seat?
lead_paragraph: LONGVIEW, Tex. — Beto O’Rourke was racing left again, insisting he knew what he was doing.

headline: Cambodian Court Sentences Australian Filmmaker to 6 Years for Espionage
abstract: Prosecutors never said what country James Ricketson, an outspoken critic of Cambodian human rights abuses, was supposed to have spied for.
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — An Australian filmmaker who has been outspoken about human rights abuses in Cambodia, and who was arrested while filming an opposition political rally, was sentenced on Friday to six years in prison for espionage.

headline: Nafta, John McCain, Coca-Cola: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: When We Almost Stopped Climate Change
abstract: The U.S. had an opportunity to solve the climate crisis in the 1980s. What went wrong?
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Son, Placed for Adoption, Leads Birth Parents to Altar 36 Years Later
abstract: “The day that I got the call that Martin wanted to reach out to us was the best day of my life. And it’s just gotten better every day after that.”
lead_paragraph: Martin Schmidt knew from a young age he was adopted, but he didn’t seek out his biological parents until he was about to have children of his own. His adoptive parents, William and Cynthia Schmidt, gave him the paperwork he needed for meeting his biological parents when he turned 18, but “didn’t push it,” Mr. Schmidt said. “They absolutely loved me like I was biologically born. I have a great family.”

headline: New York Today: A Maple Syrup Boom
abstract: Friday: An uptick in maple syrup production in New York, and a question for Catholics.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this fair Friday.

headline: Twisting for Solos, the Violist Is a Quartet’s Odd Player Out
abstract: Chamber music conventions dictate that on the rare occasion that a viola gets the melody, it’s facing the wrong way.
lead_paragraph: There’s not much to look at when a string quartet is playing. Other than the movements that draw sound from the instruments, the scene is relatively static.

headline: We Are Not a ‘Cabal,’ Just Critics of Trump
abstract: Never before have a few guys with podcasts, academic postings and Twitter accounts constituted such a powerful evil empire.
lead_paragraph: During the preparation for his second 2012 debate with Mitt Romney, I had to walk President Barack Obama through the conspiracy theories about the Benghazi attacks so he’d be ready for them: that he issued a “stand-down” order, for instance, to deny military assistance, or that we’d watched the attacks unfold in the White House via a drone feed. He didn’t believe me at first — unlike the current occupant of the Oval Office, he rarely watched cable news. “I’m serious,” I said. “It’s all over Fox.” Obama shook his head: “That’s some real tin-hat stuff.”

headline: The Catholic Church Is Sick With Sex
abstract: Outside of condemning adulterous behavior, Christ never said anything about whom you could love.
lead_paragraph: One pope was a father of 10 through multiple mistresses, a man who purchased the papacy with mule-loads of silver. It is said that Alexander VI, the most debauched of the Borgia pontiffs, elected in 1492, even had an affair with one of his daughters.

headline: Summer Road-Tripping While Black
abstract: Creating family memories meant taking a risk. My dad got behind the wheel anyway.
lead_paragraph: I always knew that the lazy days of summer were coming to an end when my family piled into our 1979 black Cadillac Eldorado with red leather interior and began a two-day journey from Morristown, N.J., to Hilton Head Island, S.C.

headline: An All-but-Extinct Piano Plays Once More
abstract: The tangent piano, a rarity from the late-18th century, is the star of Alexei Lubimov’s recording of works by Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach.
lead_paragraph: When a recording of forgotten music on a forgotten instrument appears on the prestigious ECM label, chances are good that something ear-opening has been exhumed from the graveyard of history.

headline: In Classic Car Market, Exceptional Is the Rule
abstract: Automobiles have long been the poster child of “passion investments.” But most buyers these days are specialists, not speculators.
lead_paragraph: Are classic cars still a va-va-voom investment?

headline: ‘Support the Girls’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: The director Andrew Bujalski narrates a sequence from his film starring Regina Hall.
lead_paragraph: The director Andrew Bujalski narrates a sequence from his film starring Regina Hall.

headline: How to Manage in ‘Support the Girls’
abstract: The director Andrew Bujalski narrates a scene from his film featuring Regina Hall as the manager of a Hooters-style restaurant called Double Whammies.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series each Friday. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: Congress Pays Tribute to John McCain
abstract: Republicans and Democrats flocked to the Capitol to pay their respects, highlighting both Mr. McCain’s style of reaching across the political aisle and the brand of politics whose demise he lamented.
lead_paragraph: • Senator John McCain is lying in state in the Rotunda of the United States Capitol, the 31st person to receive that honor.

headline: Duterte Jokes About Rape, Again. Philippine Women Aren’t Laughing.
abstract: “As long as there are many beautiful women, there will be more rape cases,” the president said in a speech — “by way of a joke,” his spokesman explained.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — Women’s rights groups assailed President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines on Friday, after he made a crass joke suggesting that rape was inevitable as long as there were beautiful women.

headline: One Last Time, McCain Counterprograms Trump
abstract: The senator’s memorials laid out his vision of civic life, and said a lot, indirectly, about someone who was conspicuous by his absence.
lead_paragraph: Thursday morning, in images carried live on every major cable news network, the body of Senator John McCain arrived at the North Phoenix Baptist Church in a hearse with the word “Dignity” on the rear window. Inside, the Republican senator was remembered, by a man who ran on a ticket against him, for a friendship that transcended political difference.

headline: The Week in Arts: Season 2 of ‘The Deuce,’ 5-Minute Dances at Joe’s Pub
abstract: HBO’s rough-and-tumble series about the 1970s Times Square sex trade is back, and the Dance Now Festival returns to present 40 artists.
lead_paragraph: Sept. 9; hbo.com.

headline: Lego Wants to Completely Remake Its Toy Bricks (Without Anyone Noticing)
abstract: The Danish toymaker has relied on oil-based plastics for over 50 years. It wants to give them up by 2030. Finding alternatives is a vast project.
lead_paragraph: BILLUND, Denmark — At the heart of this town lies a building that is a veritable temple to the area’s most famous creation, the humble Lego brick. It is filled with complex creations, from a 50-foot tree to a collection of multicolored dinosaurs, all of them built with a product that has barely changed in more than 50 years.

headline: ‘Birtherism Is Now Federal Policy’
abstract: The Trump administration is denying basic rights to dark-skinned citizens.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.

headline: Notes From the Book Review Archives
abstract: In which we consult the Book Review’s past to shed light on the books of the present. This week: Emily Dickinson’s letters and poems.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s issue Robert P. Baird reviews William Logan’s “Dickinson’s Nerves, Frost’s Woods,” an analysis of some of English literature’s greatest poems. Here is an unsigned 1894 review of a posthumously published collection of Emily Dickinson’s letters and poems. Below is an excerpt.

headline: The Week in Tech: Claims of Censorship Come Through Loud and Clear
abstract: The president, social media users and even employees are accusing tech companies of political bias. How will the companies respond?
lead_paragraph: Each week, technology reporters and columnists from The New York Times review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.

headline: In the West Village, a Penthouse With a Pool for $43.5 Million
abstract: The sprawling apartment was bought by a part owner of the Philadelphia 76ers and New Jersey Devils; and in Brooklyn, Mary Louise Parker bought a Heights penthouse.
lead_paragraph: Michael Rubin, the billionaire sports merchandiser and part owner of the Philadelphia 76ers and New Jersey Devils, has picked up a sprawling new penthouse in Manhattan’s West Village.

headline: California Today: Why One Billionaire Insists on Closing Off the Beach
abstract: Friday: A coastal access case being considered by the Supreme Court, the Justice Department weighs in on affirmative action, and college football makes its return.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: The Deadly Toll of the Red Tide
abstract: In southwestern Florida, the harmful algal bloom has lasted about 10 months and continues to kill large amounts of marine life.
lead_paragraph: They come in staggering, looking depressed. Sometimes they have ulcers on their eyes or in their stomachs.

headline: In Myanmar, a Facebook Blackout Brings More Anger Than a Genocide Charge
abstract: Many citizens seemed more annoyed about the social media site’s barring of the country’s military leaders than about accusations of ethnic cleansing.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Myanmar made international headlines twice this week, with each instance provoking a drastically different response from the country’s citizens.

headline: Greeted as the First Great Millennial Author, and Wary of the Attention
abstract: Sally Rooney, a funny, cerebral Marxist from Dublin, wrote a novel about people like her. She didn’t expect it to be a smash hit.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — On the morning of Ireland’s abortion referendum this May, the novelist Sally Rooney was sitting on an airplane, scrolling through her Twitter feed and crying. They were tears of anxiety. It was the most important day in her life, politically speaking, a vote she had wanted to cast since she was 15, and as far as she knew the country was split right down the middle. Too much hung in the balance.

headline: The Last Company You Would Expect Is Reinventing Health Benefits
abstract: Frustrated with insurers, some large companies — including a certain cable behemoth — are shedding long-held practices and adopting a do-it-yourself approach.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to think of a company that seems less likely to transform health care.

headline: In This New Restaurant, a Room Just for Pasta
abstract: At Misi in Williamsburg, the chef Missy Robbins and her cooks prepare to serve 500 bowls of noodles a day.
lead_paragraph: EVERY MORNING, as the sun arrives, so do they: a handful of employees, taking their spots at two maple benches custom-made by John Boos & Co., the Illinois company revered for its cutting boards. They will stay for around 10 hours, producing whichever pasta the kitchen requests: corzetti, stamped like Roman coins; or cappelletti — little hats — stuffed with mascarpone and spinach. Near one of the 10-foot tables stands a steel extruder; when fitted with various brass dies, it creates the dried shapes (bucatini, rigatoni) that some restaurants purchase by the box. The front table is reserved for fresh pasta: agnolotti, gnocchi and others that involve hand turning. By the time the restaurant’s first guests arrive, dozens of noodles will be drying in the maple-framed racks on the wall, next to a refrigerator where the fresh ones rest.

headline: ‘Adventure Time’: Here Are the 10 Best Episodes
abstract: The silliest, saddest, warmest and most thoughtful episodes the series, which ends on Monday, had to offer.
lead_paragraph: Each episode of “Adventure Time” was only 11 minutes in length, but that bite-sized quality was one of the show’s strongest selling points: “Adventure Time” could be almost anything, if only for a few minutes.

headline: Danny DeVito on the Joys of Getting Down and Dirty
abstract: Mr. DeVito riffs on the impolitic pleasures of “It’s Always Sunny in Philadelphia,” Jersey love and how he’d like you to celebrate his special day.
lead_paragraph: “It’s Always Sunny in Philadelphia” has never been for the faint of heart, the delicate of constitution or the politically correct. And despite the caution wrought by #MeToo and Time’s Up, it’s not about to start showing anything close to restraint.

headline: Flipping for Dance in the Catskills
abstract: With ever-rising real-estate costs in New York City, dance is strengthening its presence in the Hudson Valley and Catskills. Next up: The Lumberyard.
lead_paragraph: ROUNDTOP, N.Y. — Perched on 175 acres at the end of a rising road in the Catskill Mountains, surrounded by protected forest and deep vistas, the Petronio Residency Center here is an isolated retreat. It’s also luxurious, with a house chef and an air-conditioned studio. The veteran choreographer Stephen Petronio opened it this summer as a research and development site for fellow dancemakers. Subsidized and well-fed, they can try things out, free from the anxieties of renting work space by the hour. They can dig deeper and explore.

headline: Five Weeknight Dishes
abstract: Plan out your menu for the week with soy-basted chicken thighs, lemony pasta with zucchini, and, of course, burgers.
lead_paragraph: Good day. I’m Emily, here for you on our last Friday together in this space. Sam will resume writing to you on Fridays, in time for all the roast chickens and squash soups and plum tortes that beckon soon after Labor Day.

headline: U.S. Open 2018 Results: Serena Is ‘Untouchable’ in Beating Venus
abstract: In the 30th professional match between the sisters, Serena defeated Venus in the third round. Rafael Nadal, Juan Martin del Potro and Sloane Stephens also won Friday.
lead_paragraph: • Serena Williams beat her sister Venus in their 30th professional match to reach the fourth round of the U.S. Open.

headline: The Man Who Gives Form to the Sprawling Salzburg Festival
abstract: Markus Hinterhäuser, who took over the festival last summer, is already making his mark with daring stagings and a focus on late-20th-century music.
lead_paragraph: SALZBURG, Austria — Speaking to reporters about the Salzburg Festival’s new production of Monteverdi’s “L’Incoronazione di Poppea,” one of its stars, the mezzo-soprano Kate Lindsey, described the “incredible freedom” this prestigious festival provided the staging. Young dancers, Ms. Lindsey said, were “the heart of the show.”

headline: White House Gives Canada More Time to Rework Nafta
abstract: The administration informed Congress on Friday that it intends to sign a trade agreement with Mexico and, if it is willing, with Canada.
