lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration eased off its threat to exclude Canada from the North American Free Trade Agreement, extending talks that were set to end on Friday while warning that the Canadians must be “willing” to accept the United States’ terms.

headline: Remembering a Diva: The Week in Classical Music
abstract: Excellent productions of “Rigoletto” and “Evita” were among the highlights.
lead_paragraph: [Read all of our classical coverage here.]

headline: A Plum Tart That Keeps Its Charms Hidden
abstract: Buttery shortbread dough surrounds a surprise filling of simmered plums with honey and cinnamon in this French-inspired treat.
lead_paragraph: Most fruit tarts flaunt their bright fillings.

headline: Yes, There’s Hope for Health Care Reform
abstract: A bipartisan consensus is focused on reducing the system’s chronic waste and inefficiency.
lead_paragraph: The political divide over the insurance provisions of the Affordable Care Act looks to be unbridgeable for now, but out of public view, Republicans and Democrats are quietly forging a consensus on an even more consequential aspect of medical care: improving its value for all Americans by increasing its quality and lowering its cost.

headline: Rafa When I’m Up, Kyrgios When I’m Down
abstract: On the tennis court I fluctuate between emotional states with such thoughtless speed that I must be an amalgam of various demons.
lead_paragraph: There are moments when I believe, with some evidence, that I am a 35-year-old adult in full command of my emotions. Then there are the moments I play tennis.

headline: Manresa, Bay Area Restaurant Damaged in Fire, Will Reopen
abstract: David Kinch’s acclaimed kitchen has been closed since mid-July, after its second fire in four years.
lead_paragraph: The highly regarded Bay Area restaurant Manresa will reopen for business on Sept. 19, two months after a fire started outside the building and blazed through the kitchen.

headline: Do Public School Students Have Constitutional Rights?
abstract: The Supreme Court used to answer with a resounding yes. In recent decades, regrettably, it has changed its mind.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, as many students around the country start the school year, the eyes of the nation will turn to the Senate Judiciary Committee as it begins hearings on Judge Brett Kavanaugh’s nomination to our highest court. The convergence of these two events presents an opportunity to stress the crucial intersection of two distinctively American institutions: the public schools and the Supreme Court.

headline: Aretha Franklin’s Funeral: Stars, Dignitaries and Fans Honor the Queen of Soul
abstract: Thousands packed a Detroit church to pay respects to a musical giant whose legacy was evident in several hours of tributes in song.
lead_paragraph: • People packed a Detroit church on Friday to pay respects to Aretha Franklin, the musical giant whose legacy was evident in several hours of tributes in song and speeches.

headline: Letting Vegetables Speak for Themselves
abstract: The markets are bursting now with fresh produce: This lightly dressed salad allows its flavors to shine through.
lead_paragraph: Because my summer dining habits rely heavily on fresh vegetables, I’m jealous of anyone with a garden. To step outside in the evening and pick a head of lettuce or pluck a few sprigs of basil is my idea of heaven.

headline: Lobbyist Sam Patten Pleads Guilty to Steering Foreign Funds to Trump Inaugural
abstract: The lobbyist, Sam Patten, worked for a pro-Russia Ukrainian political party, the same one that employed Paul Manafort.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An American lobbyist on Friday admitted brokering access to President Trump’s inauguration for a pro-Russian Ukrainian oligarch in a scheme that highlighted the rush by foreign interests to influence the new administration.

headline: Theresa May Dances Her Way Through an African Visit
abstract: The British prime minister’s wooden moves drew ridicule when she joined in with two performances on a trip chasing trade deals.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — She danced, Britain cringed, and then she danced again.

headline: From 0 to 10 Million: Vaping Takes Off in the U.S.
abstract: Since 2004, millions of American have started using e-cigarettes. More than half also smoke traditional cigarettes.
lead_paragraph: Some experts have suggested that e-cigarettes can help wean people off regular cigarettes; others believe that they reinforce the smoking habit and increase the user’s exposure to nicotine.

headline: Lisa Marie Velasquez Answered a Friend’s Call for Help and Paid With Her Life
abstract: Ms. Velasquez tried to stop a domestic assault on her battered friend. The abuser turned on her with a hammer, then cut up her body with a machete, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: It started with a call for help.

headline: Rum Enthusiasts Have a New Obsession: Fresh-Cut Sugar Cane
abstract: Two rums, distilled from sugar cane juice rather than molasses, have intrigued bartenders and popped up on cocktail menus.
lead_paragraph: Among aficionados of craft spirits, the obsessive quest for the “authentic,” “pure” and “rustic” intensifies with each passing year. Not too long ago, rhum agricole from Martinique or Guadeloupe — a rum distilled from the juice of fresh-cut sugar cane, following strict rules enforced by an “appellation d’origine contrôlée” in France — might have satisfied those nebulous ideals.

headline: People, Places and Things to Know: Perfect Robes, a Hotel That Sells Thom Browne and More
abstract: T’s cultural compendium of what’s new.
lead_paragraph: Looking at art can be tiring business, and resting spots in museums tend to be rare, crowded and generally uninviting. But at last year’s Whitney Biennial, where visitors of course knew not to touch the art, they came to an awkward consensus regarding the work of Jessi Reaves: They sat on it. In their defense, the New York artist makes sculptures with reassuring references to everyday chairs, tables and lamps — though rather than broadcast their functionality, her pieces challenge us to question the very concept of furniture. One of the pieces on view, “Basket Chair With Brown Pillow,” resembles a head-on collision between the 19th-century German cabinetmaker Michael Thonet’s classic bentwood Chair No. 14 and the sort of metal butterfly one finds in college dorms. “I didn’t anticipate the sheer number of people and the damage they could do,” says Reaves. “But you can’t create a nuanced instruction for interaction — it can’t be, Sit gently. It’s either all on or all off.”

headline: Guy Pearce Knows How to Riff
abstract: The actor, who stars in “The Innocents,” lusts after some pricey electric guitars.
lead_paragraph: How does the Australian actor and musician Guy Pearce know when a guitar is right for him? “You play it and it’s just like butter in your hands,” he said.

headline: It’s Tempting to Take Social Security at 62. You Should Wait.
abstract: Most Americans start the retirement payments as soon as they are eligible, and many need to. If you can afford a delay, that will pay off.
lead_paragraph: Perry Volpone was determined to follow the herd. All his friends started collecting Social Security benefits the moment they retired, and he saw no reason to do anything different. Yet Dana Anspach, Mr. Volpone’s newly hired financial adviser, argued against it. She urged the former retail executive, then 65, to put off applying for Social Security for five more years. Why? Because delaying it would increase his monthly benefit.

headline: Julia Garner Is the Tough but Tender Heart of ‘Ozark’
abstract: With the return of the Netflix series, the actress talks about her spitfire role opposite Jason Bateman and her earlier roles as the “go-to cult girl.”
lead_paragraph: There aren’t many actors who can break your heart or break your nose with equal aplomb, but that’s the block Julia Garner has claimed in her still burgeoning career.

headline: A Debate Over ‘Rational Suicide’
abstract: Americans are increasingly determined to exercise control over their deaths, and some believe suicide ought to be considered a reasonable option.
lead_paragraph: On a March morning in 1989, Robert Shoots was found dead in his garage in Weir, Kan. He had run a tube from the tailpipe of his beloved old Chrysler to the front seat, where he sat with a bottle of Wild Turkey. He was 80.

headline: 13 Faces That Tell the Story of 2018
abstract: They’re remarkable first-timers, spurred by Donald Trump to help Democrats retake the House.
lead_paragraph: They’re remarkable first-timers, spurred by Donald Trump to help Democrats retake the House.

headline: In This Comeback, K’s Keep a Low Profile
abstract: Carlos Rodon of the White Sox has become a stronger pitcher after shoulder surgery, even though he is striking out fewer batters.
lead_paragraph: In his first three major league seasons, Carlos Rodon of the Chicago White Sox was right in line with modern trends. Rodon had a losing record and an earned run average near 4.00, but he averaged more than a strikeout per inning, like so many others in the age of power pitching.

headline: Colin Kaepernick Is Not Going Away
abstract: Despite a ruling from the arbitrator allowing the case to continue, the N.F.L. is not inclined to settle. Neither is Kaepernick.
lead_paragraph: Proving that a team or a league colluded to keep a player off the field has been difficult over the years.

headline: When You Love Chocolate, This Isn’t Like Work
abstract: Brad Kintzer oversees chocolate making for Tcho Chocolates, a small player in California doing bean-to-bar production within a huge industry.
lead_paragraph: Brad Kintzer, 41, is the chief chocolate maker for Tcho Chocolate, in Berkeley, Calif.

headline: Juuls and Teenagers: What’s Your Experience?
abstract: We want to hear from teenagers and their parents about the popularity and the perils of using e-cigarettes such as those manufactured by Juul.
lead_paragraph: The e-cigarette brand Juul is wildly popular with teenagers, though the company says its focus is on getting adult smokers to use its devices to quit. Now Juul’s sales campaigns are at the center of an investigation by the F.D.A. into whether it intentionally targeted teenagers.

headline: Six Years, Four Sore Feet, 2,650 Miles
abstract: My daughter and I finished hiking one of “our” properties: the Pacific Crest Trail.
lead_paragraph: Six years ago my daughter and I set off on a hike.

headline: E.U. Will Let Countries Decide Whether to Use Daylight Saving
abstract: Some countries have lobbied to end the requirement that all 28 member states spring forward and fall back each year.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European countries that have observed daylight saving time for generations may soon put an end to it, European Union officials signaled on Friday, saying that they would drop a rule that member countries must abide by the “spring forward, fall back” ritual.

headline: Review: Death, Betrayal and Greed in a Gripping ‘Henry VI’
abstract: The National Asian American Theater Company puts on a fast-paced and unusually lucid staging of the bloody history play.
lead_paragraph: Halftime was ticking down at a marathon performance of Shakespeare’s “Henry VI” when the guys in front of me returned to their seats and I fell a little in love with them. Riffling through plot points and names of characters they vaguely remembered were coming up (“Who’s Edmund? Or am I thinking of ‘King Lear’?”), they were like soap opera fans preparing to dive back into an engrossing serial.

headline: Trump’s Charity Calls Attorney General’s Suit a Political Attack
abstract: New court papers ask for the suit to be dismissed, citing the former attorney general’s “record of antipathy” against President Trump.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for President Trump’s charitable foundation pushed back aggressively against the New York State attorney general’s office in court papers on Thursday, calling a lawsuit against the charity a political attack motivated by the former attorney general’s “record of antipathy” against Mr. Trump.

headline: Lawrence Rubin, Art Dealer and Supporter of Frank Stella, Dies at 85
abstract: Mr. Rubin helped restore the fortunes of the Knoedler Gallery, the troubled New York dealer, well before it was engulfed by a more recent scandal.
lead_paragraph: Lawrence Rubin, an art dealer who oversaw galleries in Paris and New York and presented the first European solo show of Frank Stella, with whom he had a long association, died on Aug. 16 in Zurich, where he had a home. He was 85.

headline: Taking the College Tour by Private Jet
abstract: New luxury services offer to whisk families on a private jet outfitted with college regalia and staffed with a personal college admissions counselor.
lead_paragraph: High school students heading back to class this fall have more on their minds than finding homeroom. Many juniors, sophomores and even freshmen are already turning their attention toward picking a college.

headline: What Does It Mean to Be German? We Want to Hear From You
abstract: With anti-immigration protests and raids roiling a city in Germany this week, we want to hear what German citizens and immigrants think about the country’s national identity.
lead_paragraph: The protests and raids this week in Chemnitz were the latest boiling point of the anti-immigration sentiment that has simmered in Germany since 2015, when Chancellor Angela Merkel opened the borders and more than one million asylum seekers entered.

headline: Giving Government Workers the Shaft
abstract: It’s long-term G.O.P. policy, but Trump picked an odd moment to chisel the people who keep us safe
lead_paragraph: You sometimes hear the claim that Republicans hate public spending. In practice, however, their hatred is selective. They tend to be OK with spending that flows into the pockets of private-sector friends, whether it’s mercenaries or for-profit colleges. No, what they really hate are two kinds of spending: outlays that help Americans afford life’s essentials, like food and health care, and paying wages to government employees.

headline: John McCain Is Honored at U.S. Capitol
abstract: Senator John McCain was brought to the Rotunda to lie in state. Leaders from both parties paid tribute to the celebrated lawmaker.
lead_paragraph: Senator John McCain was brought to the Rotunda to lie in state. Leaders from both parties paid tribute to the celebrated lawmaker.

headline: Got Milk? Or Was That Really a Plant Beverage?
abstract: A remark by the F.D.A.’s chief about almonds and lactation has set off a seemingly existential debate about what milk is.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — No one can even agree on milk anymore.

headline: Live Jazz: Three August Standouts, From Gilad Hekselman to Rebolú
abstract: Top performances this month also include intriguing piano work by Ran Blake at Kitano.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to “The Month in Live Jazz,” a column highlighting three standout performances from the past month on stages across New York City.

headline: New Medicare Cards Are Being Issued. Here’s What You Need to Know.
abstract: The updated cards are safer, but criminals are finding new ways of scamming people.
lead_paragraph: As people across the country receive new, safer Medicare cards in the mail, advocates are warning about fraudulent callers who try to dupe people into paying money or divulging personal information.

headline: Listen to ‘Dear Sugars’: The Long Goodbye
abstract: A final dose of sugar for the lost, lonely, and heartsick.
lead_paragraph: A final dose of sugar for the lost, lonely, and heartsick.

headline: What if the Economy and Markets Are Even Better Than They Look?
abstract: The strength of the economy and the stock market might seem too good to be true. But you may want to hedge your bets.
lead_paragraph: You won’t lose much money if you’re prepared for the worst.

headline: In Quake-Prone California, Alarm at Scant Insurance Coverage
abstract: Experts warn that California property, both commercial and residential, is vastly underinsured. “What are we going to do when no one has insurance and everyone has damage?”
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The ravages of wildfires in California have kept Dave Jones, the state’s insurance commissioner, very busy over the past year. But that’s not what keeps him up at night.

headline: Martin Shubik, Economist and Game Theory Pioneer, Dies at 92
abstract: In the mid-1960s, he predicted that there would be “computing machines” in homes and schools. In the 1970s, he conducted a serious study of pastrami.
lead_paragraph: Martin Shubik, an economist whose prescient visions of a computerized world and pioneering applications of game theory to everyday life enlivened what has been described as the dismal science, died on Aug. 22 at his home in Branford, Conn. He was 92.

headline: Trump’s Ignoring Norms Does Matter
abstract: To suggest otherwise, as an Op-Ed writer did, is “ludicrous,” a reader says.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What Trump Didn’t Say
abstract: The president notably left out the second part of John Adams’s blessing, inscribed in the White House State Dining Room.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Even at Her Funeral Celebrations, Aretha Franklin Was the Height of Glamour
abstract: Inside the posthumous styling of the Queen of Soul
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, her outfit consisted of a lacy crimson gown, towering scarlet Christian Louboutin heels, and cherry-red lipstick and nail polish. On Wednesday, she had been changed into a pale, shimmering blue frock, again with matching heels. On Thursday, she wore a rose gold custom-knit suit by St. John’s, again paired with Christian Louboutins.

headline: Shining a Light on Black and Brown Representation in Film
abstract: “Ori Inu: In Search of Self” has emphasized rich visuals to capture a range of skin tones, one of several screen projects to focus on lighting of people of color.
lead_paragraph: “But mama told me my God was black.” That’s what Natalia says standing beside the altar at her baptism in the independent film “Ori Inu: In Search of Self.”

headline: Democracy in Poland, Alive and Well
abstract: Poland’s ambassador objects to a column by Paul Krugman that argued “democracy as we normally understand it is already dead” there.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How Rising Inequality Has Widened the Justice Gap
abstract: When low-income families face difficult legal disputes, most cannot afford a lawyer. A small change in tax policy could solve this problem, an economist says.
lead_paragraph: Rising inequality has harmed low-income families not only by depriving them of a fair share of society’s income growth, but also in a more specific way: It has stacked the legal system even more heavily against them.

headline: Democrats Battle Over a New Jersey Jail’s Contract With ICE
abstract: Some officials want Hudson County to cancel its multimillion- dollar deal with the federal government to detain undocumented immigrants at its correction facility
lead_paragraph: KEARNY, N.J. — A hastily renewed contract between the federal government and Hudson County to house detained immigrants in the Hudson County jail here has become a hotly debated issue among elected officials and activists that has stretched beyond this working-class community.

headline: The Democrats’ Bad Move on Superdelegates
abstract: The Democratic Party may regret weakening the power of its party elders, readers say.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Serena Williams. New Mom. Elite Athlete. Extraordinary and Ordinary All at Once.
abstract: Williams’s success has the sports world buzzing about new mothers and great performances. It has happened before, and it will happen again.
lead_paragraph: During the 2017 United States Open, Serena Williams, holder of 23 Grand Slam titles, was fighting for her life. She had just given birth to Alexis Olympia Ohanian Jr. by cesarean section and faced life-threatening complications from a pulmonary embolism and blood clotting.

headline: The Playlist: Eminem’s Surprise ‘Venom,’ and 10 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by LSD, Big Red Machine, Laura Jane Grace & the Devouring Mothers and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: The Hot College Gig: Online Brand Promoter
abstract: American companies are turning to students to push products on their personal social media accounts.
lead_paragraph: Noah Lamfers, a senior at the University of Northern Iowa, had never tried a 5-Hour Energy drink. But he still signed up to promote the brand online, getting paid to post images of himself and bottles of the product on his personal Facebook, Instagram and Snapchat accounts. He tagged each one with #5houruintern.

headline: The Uses and Misuses of Identity
abstract: “Very often, the identity labels we use tell you much less than you might think,” Kwame Anthony Appiah says.
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

headline: Poisonous Plants
abstract: Chemicals in some nightshade plants are potentially lethal and should be avoided for herbal uses — unless they’re involved in a fictional murder plot.
lead_paragraph: Q. I read about something called Datura in an old mystery novel. Mixed with honey, it was used as a hypnotic drug to keep a kidnap victim in control. What is it, and how does it work?

headline: Straining to Keep Faith With America
abstract: John McCain knew that we are better than Trump.
lead_paragraph: Among the events of John McCain’s five-and-a-half years of imprisonment and torture in North Vietnam, probably the most heroic, and surely the most celebrated, was his refusal to accept an early release from his captors.

headline: John McCain Lies in State in the Capitol: ‘We Lost a Good One’
abstract: Senator John McCain lay in state in the Capitol’s Rotunda, hailed as a principled war hero as citizens wondered whether an era of comity died with him.
lead_paragraph: Senator John McCain lay in state on Friday in the Capitol whose halls he prowled for decades, hailed as a war hero, a principled lawmaker, and a restless fighter for his beliefs — and honored with a ceremony reserved for the country’s most revered figures.

headline: Bobby Lynn Maslen, Who Found Young Readers’ Wavelength, Dies at 87
abstract: Ms. Maslen created Bob Books, simple stories simply illustrated, and thereby helped teach countless youngsters to read.
lead_paragraph: If you’re a teacher, sometimes the best classroom materials are the ones you improvise yourself.

headline: Dr. Elizabeth Connell, Authority on Contraception, Is Dead at 92
abstract: An activist as well as a scientist, Dr. Connell helped open a clinic in East Harlem and promoted women’s health around the world.
lead_paragraph: From the stage of the Phil Donahue show in front of a live audience, Dr. Elizabeth B. Connell, a tiny middle-aged mother of six, opened her purse and began pitching condoms in wrappers with smiley faces into the audience.

headline: Ukrainian Separatist Leader Is Killed in Restaurant Bombing
abstract: Aleksandr Zakharchenko, the leader of the Donetsk People’s Republic, died in a bomb attack on Friday evening in eastern Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The leader of the Donetsk People’s Republic, a Russian-backed separatist enclave in eastern Ukraine, was killed on Friday when a bomb exploded at a restaurant where he was having dinner, an attack that threatened to set off an escalation of the Ukraine war.

headline: How to Get a Raise, Even When the Boss Won’t Negotiate
abstract: Management keeps giving you great performance reviews — and the runaround when it comes to salary discussions. Here’s how to cope when the other side just won’t engage.
lead_paragraph: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: A Path to the Runway, Paved With Hardship
abstract: Life in a homeless shelter taught Aaron Philip how to navigate obstacles. Soon she may be navigating fashion's biggest runways.
lead_paragraph: For a long time, being online was where Aaron Philip felt most confident.

headline: India Pushes Back Against Tech ‘Colonization’ by Internet Giants
abstract: With Facebook, Google and Amazon dominating India’s internet, lawmakers have declared their intention to impose tough new rules on the tech industry.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — In India, American companies dominate the internet. Facebook’s WhatsApp is the most popular app on phones. Virtually every smartphone runs on Google’s Android system. YouTube is the favorite video platform and Amazon is the No. 2 online retailer.

headline: A Rare Moment of Unity, in Celebration of John McCain
abstract: At Mr. McCain’s last visit to the Capitol, colleagues embraced the spirit of public service.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — John McCain on Friday made his final visit to the Capitol he ruled as a commanding presence for more than three decades to be grieved and celebrated by colleagues past and present. He would have loved it.

headline: Urban Meyer Says Damning Report Largely Exonerates Him
abstract: The Ohio State coach went back to Twitter to defend himself in his handling of a former assistant accused of domestic violence.
lead_paragraph: ,The embattled Ohio State coach Urban Meyer defended himself Friday, trying to contrast a university investigation into his handling of a former assistant who had been accused of domestic violence with other accusations he attributed to “the media.”

headline: Open Thread: Fashion Week Is Coming
abstract: Get ready! Also, some thoughts on sneakers for work and life, not sports.
lead_paragraph: Hello and happy end of summer.

headline: Federal Judge in Texas Delivers Unexpected Victory for DACA Program
abstract: The decision regarding the Obama-era program was a temporary win for activists who are waging a legal fight against the Trump Administration to save it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge in Texas declined on Friday to halt an Obama-era program that protects young undocumented immigrants from deportation, handing a temporary victory to activists who are waging a legal fight against the Trump administration to save it.

headline: Family of Jordan Edwards Says 15 Years Is Not Enough for Officer Who Murdered Him
abstract: Jordan’s stepmother realized immediately that the sentence was as long as his life: 15 years. “That’s not enough because Jordan can’t see life again,” she said.
lead_paragraph: Fifteen is a significant number for Jordan Edwards’s family. It’s how many years he lived before a police officer opened fire with a high-powered rifle as Jordan and four other teenagers drove away from a house party in the Dallas suburb of Balch Springs in April 2017.

headline: A Little Fall of Rain Makes a Big Difference in Sloane Stephens’s Win
abstract: A break to close the Ashe Stadium roof allowed the third-seeded Stephens to regroup on her way to a 6-3, 6-4 win over Victoria Azarenka.
lead_paragraph: Sloane Stephens, the defending women’s champion, and Victoria Azarenka were grinding it out from the baseline in their third-round match at the United States Open when mother nature intervened on Friday.

headline: Iraq’s Forgotten Casualties: Children Orphaned in Battle With ISIS
abstract: Tens of thousands of children lost their parents under Islamic State rule or the battle against it. Iraq has few resources to care for them.
lead_paragraph: MOSUL, Iraq — When he was 8 years old, Muhammad says, he watched as fighters from the Islamic State dragged his father from their house in Mosul and shot him dead on the street.

headline: Ellie Mannette, Father of the Modern Steel Drum, Dies at 90
abstract: A Trinidadian musician and drum maker, he was captivated by steel-pan bands as a child. He sought to elevate the craft and share it with the world.
lead_paragraph: Ellie Mannette, a Trinidadian musician known in the United States as the father of the modern steel drum, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Morgantown, W.Va. He was 90.

headline: The Last Thing Mom Asked
abstract: I am not a doctor. I am not very brave. But I want to do what she wants.
lead_paragraph: I am about to kill my mother.

headline: Once Bipartisan, an Election Security Bill Collapses in Rancor
abstract: Lawmakers were once on track to approve a bipartisan election security bill. Its ugly collapse sends a message: “There isn’t a sense of urgency or priority.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The purpose of the bill seemed unassailable: to ensure that state officials could protect their elections against the kind of hacking or interference that has clouded the 2016 campaign.

headline: Memorable Moments From Aretha Franklin’s Funeral
abstract: Jennifer Hudson sang a stirring “Amazing Grace,” Bill Clinton called himself a “groupie” and Stevie Wonder gave a speech about love.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of people packed a Detroit church on Friday to pay respects to Aretha Franklin, the musical giant whose legacy was evident in several hours of tributes in song. Here are some memorable moments.

headline: Toxic Dust Still Threatens Housing Authority Residents, U.S. Says
abstract: The government criticized the city’s housing authority for failing to fulfill a promise to safeguard residents from toxic materials during lead-paint removals.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s housing authority promised in June as part of a landmark legal settlement to correct years of maintenance failures, mismanagement and cover-ups that federal authorities said had exposed 400,000 public housing residents to lead paint and other health hazards.

headline: The Village Voice, a New York Icon, Closes
abstract: The media mogul Peter Barbey, who envisioned a prosperous future for the paper when he bought it in 2015, has shut it down a year after ending its print edition.
lead_paragraph: When Peter D. Barbey bought The Village Voice in 2015, he vowed to invest in the storied alternative weekly, saying it would “survive and prosper.” But last August he shuttered the print edition, and on Friday he closed the operation altogether.

headline: Aretha Franklin, Nafta, U.S. Open: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Trump Administration’s Move to Cut Aid to Palestinian Refugees Is Denounced
abstract: The drastic aid cut, urged by President Trump’s son-in-law Jared Kushner and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, changes another pillar of U.S. policy in Israel.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration’s decision to end American funding to a United Nations agency that provides assistance to millions of Palestinian refugees was denounced broadly on Friday by international officials, former United States diplomats and Palestinians who were reeling from the elimination of a decades-long policy of support.

headline: A Vengeful and Shortsighted Act
abstract: The Trump administration, currying favor with hard-liners in Israel, eliminates funding for the United Nations agency that aids Palestinian refugees.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration has offered various explanations for cutting aid to the Palestinians and stopping all contributions to the United Nations agency that supports five million Palestinian refugees: They need to learn to help themselves. Other Arabs should pay. Most of them are not really refugees and should stop claiming a right to return to what is now Israel. This will push them to the negotiating table. They’re not grateful enough.

headline: In-N-Out’s Political Donation Attracts Boycott Calls, but Will It Matter?
abstract: A $25,000 donation to the Republicans prompted calls for a boycott, but even liberal Californians may find it hard to give up on the cult burger chain. And the company says it helps both parties.
lead_paragraph: In-N-Out Burger recently gave a $25,000 donation to the Republican Party, prompting calls to boycott the chain.

headline: Krishna Reddy, Master Printmaker and Indian Modernist, Dies at 93
abstract: Mr. Reddy, who apprenticed with the sculptor Henry Moore, was an expert in intaglio printing who applied sculptural techniques to paper.
lead_paragraph: Krishna Reddy, a master printmaker, sculptor and teacher who played an important role in the shaping of Modernist art in India, died on Aug. 22 at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.

headline: The U.N.’s Palestinian Refugee Agency: What It Does and Why It Matters
abstract: The Trump administration’s decision to stop funding the agency, which provides services to more than five million Palestinians, carries enormous implications.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations agency that assists Palestinians who are classified as refugees has received more than $6 billion in American funding since its creation nearly seven decades ago, making the United States the agency’s single most important donor.

headline: Tiger Woods and Serena Williams Are Friends With a Comeback Connection
abstract: After shooting one over par in the opening round of the Dell Technologies Championship, Woods said he planned to watch Williams play her sister Venus in the U.S. Open on Friday night.
lead_paragraph: NORTON, Mass. — Tiger Woods planned to start the Labor Day weekend like millions of other people: parked in front of a screen Friday night watching the United States Open tennis match between Serena Williams and her older sister, Venus.

headline: The Prison Escape That Riveted the Nation: 5 Things We Learned From an Inquiry Into How It Happened
abstract: Sex, contraband and sleepy guards are among the problems cited in a report on New York State prisons, where the tailor shops are a particular concern.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — The elaborate 2015 escape of two convicted murderers from an upstate prison riveted the nation and led to all manner of introspection from embarrassed New York State officials.

headline: Trump to Skip Meetings in Asia as He Keeps a Distance With Allies
abstract: In his decision not to attend summit meetings in Asia this fall, the president will miss an opportunity to calm frazzled relationships in the region. And China could step in, analysts said.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — As President Trump hardened his stance on trade with Canada, one of the nation’s closest allies, the White House said Friday that Mr. Trump would not be traveling to Asia for a round of economic and security meetings with allies this fall.

headline: Ivan Lendl Defeated the Father. He Now Helps Guide the Son.
abstract: The eight-time Grand Slam singles titlist is one of the coaches for fourth-seeded Alexander Zverev Jr., as is Alexander Zverev Sr.
lead_paragraph: Ivan Lendl and Alexander Zverev Sr. have known each other for decades. Born six weeks apart in 1960 — Zverev in the Soviet Union and Lendl in Czechoslovakia — they played once as junior tennis players, in the semifinals of the European under-18 championships in Maribor, Yugoslavia. According to Zverev Sr., Lendl won, 6-3, 6-3.

headline: University of North Carolina Chancellor Explores New Spot for ‘Silent Sam’
abstract: The toppling of the statue of a Confederate soldier sparked a tense debate on campus and in the state capital about where the monument should go next.
lead_paragraph: After a spate of heated demonstrations over the “Silent Sam” statue at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, the school’s chancellor suggested on Friday that she wanted to move the Confederate monument to another part of campus.
